review_text: TIFF 2024 #41: Centrepiece (World Premiere)Gripping, distressing - among many things that can be said to describe the experience of a woman who could just as easily lose everything she ever knew with as much as a single unplanned pregnancy. But perhaps the added stress to watching Sunshine is only exacerbated by the environment in which our title character is inhabiting, where the conservative religious and social norms of the Philippines are infringing on her own rights as a human being too.Really liked this one a whole lot.
So was that girl a personified version of her fetus or was she literally just stalking her?

World Premiere at TIFF 2024! Maris is magnetic. She makes the movie. I also wanna commend Jennica Garcia! I was deeply moved by her. The storytelling I wanna say is quiteâ€¦unexpected. It added to the layers of the movie and I just know this will totally ruffle feathers when it finally gets shown in the Philippines. Even on the Q&A Director Antoinette Jadaone mentioned she wanted to spark the conversation on this, to which I hope people donâ€™t take for granted. Also, the cameos! I live for them.
TIFF 2024 - World Premiere. I really enjoyed this oneâ€”happy to see more creative and bold films being made in the Philippines. ğŸ¤ Protect our women. â¤ï¸

TIFF film #2 (World Premiere) I had no idea what I was getting myself into, but damn, what a pleasant surprise. I felt so hard for the lead character, with an solid performance from Maris Racal. She carried the movie, alone, brilliantly. It really show how decisions made by men (that doesn't have a lot of screen time in this movie) can impact the lives of women and girls. This movie really opened up conversations after the screening (for my friends and I) and I hope it will do the same after it open in the Philippines. I'm glad I saw that movie and I learned a lot, still processing things.

TIFF film #4 â€“ a simple, straightforward piece about women's sexual and reproductive health and rights in the Philippines, and a portrait into the country's politics, faith, societal pressures and expectations, and gender roles. the film is carried both by its message and by Maris Racal's great performance (there is also very few supporting characters â€“ honorable mention to Sunshine's ate). i enjoyed the cinematography and the boldness in the telling of this story. looking forward to the conversations + reception of this film, especially within the Filipinx diaspora.

TIFF Film #14: Well received in Toronto but I expect this to be divisive in PH and will spark conversations. Probably the film by which the audiences are too eager to attend the Q&A (as handfuls only left after the credits of the world premiere screening). A very important film which is very timely to be told and the Jojo Rabbit inspired reference gives lighter touch to the dark subject. The Piolo Pascual cameo is noteworthy and unsettling (I Am aloof to any forms of pastors lol).

i watched the world premiere for this film for tiff 2024. maris racalâ€™s performance in this film is ABSOLUTELY amazing. she embodies the character so well and its a lot of pressure to carry being that her screen time is 90% of the film.the pacing of the film was pretty good in the 2nd half. I found the first part to be repetitive and didnt contribute to the characters development nor the storyline.overall, since the directors main intention is to spark a conversation, i will be looking forward to the reception of this movie once it is released to a wider audience. the subject matter is a very sensitive topic especially in the ph. different religious, political, and cultural perspectives regarding abortion are depicted in the movie and i have no doubt that it will receive strong criticism but perhaps thats only the start.

A Filipino drama that feels gritty and grounded, offering an interesting glimpse at life in the Philippines from a perspective that I hadnâ€™t really seen before. Maybe a touch heavy-handed in places, but still a pretty nuanced and even-keeled exploration of its tough subject matter.Full Review

a very important film with such a precise and well thought out look into the real conditions of young filipina women in PH.honestly what i rlly loved about the movie, besides the themes and messages it portrays, is its efficient uses of every single scene in the movie. there's no unnecessary scene in this movie that doesn't forward the character's arc, the pace of the movie and it's messages. everyone's performances are top notch and every beat hits very hard emotionally. nd it rlly is such a realistic portrayal of what folks go through in the philippines when it comes to reproduction rights. i love how this movie covers every part of this issue without it feeling hamfisted and blatant, such as not only the stigmatization, but also the economic conditions of every day filipinos (u can argue the kids might be that, but honestly it was a good narrative tool in what otherwise be on insight we might not be able to obtain). i sincerely hope this movie gets distributed widely nd ESPECIALLY in the philippines.great way to end tiff 2024!!!

Sunshine is on the verge of joining the national gymnastics team and going to the Olympics, when she loses focus, careens off balance, and falters. Dreams nearly in her grasp shift to distant phantoms as she realizes she is pregnant. Shaken, fearful, desperate, and determined not to lose her rightful place on the national team, Sunshine searches the underground of the city for abortifacients. Abortion and even divorce are illegal in the Philippines, so Sunshine has few options and few people she can trust. Just then a mysterious young girl appears in the darkness and crowded streets with knowledge of Sunshineâ€™s heart that surprises her and touches her deeply.â€œI wanted to be brave for these girls,â€ said Maris Racal (Sunshine) â€œwho have no one else to turn to.â€ Racal is intrinsically believable in her role. In the conservative religious culture of the Philippines and with the lack of access to reproductive support, many girls are in crisis. The issue is relatable and timely not just in the Philippines, but in many other countries including, unfortunately, our own.At this world premiere screening at the Toronto International Film Festival, director Antoinette Jadaone said she got the idea for an imaginary friend from the film Jojo Rabbit. As part of her film research Jadaone interviewed girls who had abortions. She hopes the film sparks conversations and change, that it is part of the solution for the country, and helps girls in such situations make their own decisions.

This is a film of two parts. This film is part compelling drama, with a strong lead performance from the young actor and a powerful examination of the treatment of women in the Phillipines. This film is also part surrealist, but in a way that I feel undermines the strengths of the film. There is a young girl who appears at various points throughout the film; her identity is left to interpretation. However I feel that this apparition weakens every scene she's in. You'll have this powerful understated drama and then this wise-cracking girl appears to swear at you. It is clear that they couldn't even make her fit throughout the film because she disappears for at least half an hour in the middle. The filmmaker said this was the original core concept of the film and I understand that, but I feel that the film moved beyond the need for this character. I will say that I found the final interaction between the girl and our protagonist quite touching. Maybe if the girl was more understated it could have worked better. I do want to mention that it was really lovely to be in the TIFF audience for this one; the Filipino community was so passionate about this film and it was the longest and most involved Q&A I'd ever seen. It's really inspiring to see how beloved it was.

Switching between goofy magic realism, teenage coming-of-age clichÃ©s and a gritty look at the reality of trying to get an abortion in the Philippines â€” which is prohibited in the constitution itself â€” Sunshine is a heartfelt story with an angry edge. Maris Racal stars as the wonderfully-named Sunshine Francisco, an aspiring gymnast whose potential tryouts at the Olympics are derailed by an unexpected pregnancy. With no officials to turn to, she is forced to search the black market, where she is followed by a strange young girl (Annika Co) who appears to be a figment of her imagination (itâ€™s obvious when no one else interacts!). While the film certainly draws awareness to this issue of womenâ€™s rights in the Philippines, Jadaoneâ€™s cornier tendencies overwhelm the message.Part of our Berlinale Generation coverage

Tiff Catchup cause I'm racing to log 2024 movies watched #5This and Queer are not just the best movies I saw at TIFF, but both are experiences that have stuck with me throughout the last year. Just like how Queer paved an honest way of portraying gay men, Sunshine isn't like an abortion movie I've seen before. I'm always excited to watch a Filipino movie that breaks out into a critically praised festival run. As a Filipino who grew up in a family that owned a lot of Filipino movies, I was never a fan to be quite real with you. Filipino movies ranged from Hallmark style romances, repetitive action movies and cheesy low budget horror (although Shake, Rattle and Roll did slap). But every once in a blue moon there comes an ambitious director who tells an honest Filipino story that is both intimate in its narrative and expansive in its political themes. Sunshine doesn't hold your hand the way mainstream Filipino cinema does. It takes you on this journey of this ambitious woman who has to make the toughest choice of her life in order to determine her future. Surreal manifestations of her consciousness is brought out by imaginary characters in a way I never saw in abortion centred stories. Its so powerful. Want to watch this again with my parents. I met the director at Tiff too! :D the only person I met at the festival. While everyone else I knew wanted to get into the big films I patiently waited with my friend to see this hidden gem.
A film that "delivers" and unfortunately does not much else with a rich world it hints at almost constantly.

In the Philippines, Catholicism is the predominant religion comprising around 80% of the population. Because of the churchâ€™s influence, the countryâ€™s policy is restrictive and conservative, especially regarding family planning. Considering the social context, Jadaoneâ€™s attempt to address the topic of abortion is certainly admirable, but the simplistic and tear-jerking way it is done leaves much to be desired.asianmoviepulse.com/2025/02/film-review-sunshine-2024-by-antoinette-jadaone/

Very moving. Very emotional. Sunshine's story is probably one of many young women in the Philippines and it is important that every single one counts. The film shows more than clearly the difficulties and impossibilities that are placed in the way of young women (or far too often children) and that sometimes there is no way out when everyone really is against you. The film shows that you can be strong on your own, but that your environment is also so essential. A really important film!

What sets â€˜Sunshineâ€™ apart is how writer-director Antoinette Jadaone roots the film in the Philippinesâ€™ conservative culture, shaped by Catholicism and its influence on public policies. While some moments may feel a bit heavy-handed, Jadaone delivers an earnest take on the tension between religious values and societal realities, while occasionally poking fun at certain hypocrisies. Another unique aspect of â€˜Sunshineâ€™ is how it weaves in magic realism. This creative approach, which is like a mix of Taika Waititiâ€™s â€˜Jojo Rabbitâ€™ and Celine Sciammaâ€™s â€˜Petite Mamanâ€™, might not be for everyone; nevertheless, it enriches the discourse and keeps the narrative from feeling simplistic. The script never shines for true brilliance or originality but tackles its central theme with genuine nuance and sincerity, confronting both the emotional and physical horror of an unwanted pregnancy AND the delicate hopes of a new life about to flourish. This honesty gives even the clumsiest and most ham-fisted parts of Sunshine, which are not rare (found myself rolling my eyes whenever the "imaginary children" showed up and the film tried to make it comically clear that you understood what they represented), a nice emotional weight.

La nostra si dovrÃ  districare tra cattive conoscenze, pensieri disturbanti e una cittÃ  che viene fotografata in modo stupendo seppur per brevi tratti. L'intreccio scorre bene senza retorica stantia, con dialoghi convinventi e un'ottima interpretrazione di Maris Racal. Nel complesso sicuramente un film riuscito.

A beautifully devastating film about female reproductive rights and self-agency in the Philippines, Sunshine follows a young gymnast who discovered she is pregnant right before the Olympics qualifiers. It explores what being a woman is like in a society that does not see you as a human being with your own thoughts and aspirations. Although my stint as a trampolinist did not lead me to the success that she has achieved, I felt personally acquainted to the title character and her experience and struggle really resonated with me.

I was at an exclusive screening for this film, and there was a girl dressed in all-pink, and I thought to myself "Why is she dressed like Glinda from Wicked?"... I later learned this was Xyriel Manabat.

Early in this coming-of-age sports drama from Antoinette Jadaone, we see Maris Racal as the titular character, twisting and turning her body gracefully like a professional who's been doing this routine all her life. Right there and then, I told myself silently that this is going to be the best and most unforgettable performance of her career. In the film, she plays Sunshine, a dedicated young gymnast preparing for her teamâ€™s upcoming tryouts for the Olympics. But days before their tryouts, she discovers that she is pregnant. Now she must embark on a desperate and risky journey to fight for her dream.Penned and directed by Antoinette Jadaone, this is definitely one of her strongest works and one that truly stands out amongst all the films in her sprawling filmography, thanks to its solid script paired with equally confident direction. Her works, which are reminiscent of the late Marilou Diaz-Abaya, albeit with a more modern flair, are always centered around fully fleshed-out female characters who, while at times flawed, go through a transformative journey (case in point: directing That Thing Called Tadhana, Beauty in a Bottle (2014), Never Not Love You (2018), Alone/Together (2019), and Fan Girl (2020)). And this latest one is no different. Here, we follow a young woman faced with the burden of her unplanned pregnancy in a country like the Philippines, where abortion is illegal under all circumstances and has no exceptions, even in cases of rape, incest, or when the woman's life is at risk.It's honestly a pretty daunting task to write a story like this given its themes, let alone actually make one and release it in a highly conservative, mostly Catholic country like the Philippines. Yet Jadaone successfully completed the film without sacrificing her vision. The film manages to bravely portray the burden brought by unwanted pregnancies to women while men get a free pass in this patriarchal society designed by and controlled by men. It also paints how religious people can't help but keep shoving their beliefs on others instead of minding their own business. Most importantly, the film discusses the importance of a proper health care system in a third-world country like ours, which is run by capitalism and corrupt government officials. Instead of providing safe and accessible procedures like safe abortion for women, we have a country forcing them to find unsafe means on their own, endangering their lives in the process.Performance-wise, the film is packed with numerous talents, so not a single shot in the film is put to waste. Both Meryll Soriano as Sunshine's coach, Eden, and Xyriel Manabat as her best friend, Thea, are effective. Elijah Canlas nails the gaslighting asshole of a boyfriend, Miggy, while Jennica Garcia is simply brilliant as Sunshine's sister, Geleen. Other noteworthy turns include Rhed Bustamante, Juan Miguel Garcia, Angeli Bayani, and Piolo Pascual in a cameo role as Miggy's father. A young Annika Co also shines with her role as the young girl constantly nagging Sunshine.But the film will definitely not work if not for the career-best portrayal from its lead, Maris Racal, who delivers a tour-de-force performance as Sunshine herself. One can really feel and see the dedication she had for such a demanding role, physically and emotionally. Her performance really pulls you into the film and won't let go until the emotionally charged third act, making it one of the best local female performances I've seen this year so far.The film also boasts some great visuals thanks to Pao Orendain's slick camerawork and incredible music courtesy of Rico Blancoâ€”a first for the singer-songwriter.Overall, this latest film from Antoinette Jadaone is one rollercoaster of emotions that is buoyed by a daring and electrifying performance from Maris Racal. It's a poignant, gripping and thought-provoking journey of a woman coming to terms with her own inner conflicts. It's already halfway through the year, but this is already the best Filipino film of 2025 in my opinion.Trust me, you will not be prepared for how powerful this film is.

This is the best Filipino film I've seen so far. It follows a gymnast whose dreams are challenged by an unexpected pregnancy. Because the Philippines are incredibly Catholic, abortion is illegal and hard to execute. Will she give in to the pressure of keeping the child, will she seek medically unadvised procedures, or will she get help from others who understand her situation?The film explores the pressures that religion and misogyny place on young women - pressures that unfortunately appear to still be widespread in today's world.

Watched as a representative of UP Cinema. It's a brave take on one of the most controversial issues in Philippine society ever. Maris Racal is soooo good. Direk Tonet is on Fan Girl mode: things get quite tense and harrowing.

Claustrophobic, not just in how the frame is composed in several scenes, but in how it shows the extent in which the malignant structure of self-righteous patriarchal conservatism has done palpable harm to women and children everywhere. The film uses its central plotline to weave a rich tapestry of people and places that paint a picture of how this corrupted structure affects the titular protagonist, as well as the people around her. The tone possesses a gradually ratcheting anger at the oppressive status quo, going for the throats of its targets with at times bleak satire, or crushing nightmarish realities. This indignation, however, is ultimately fueled out of immense compassion. The film never really downs itself in hopelessness as it actively claws for hope, and never loses sight of Sunshine's agency through it all. Maris Racal's humane, scrappy performance is the total anchor of this film, carrying the heaviness with determination impressively.Although the breadth of the screenplay's scope is the film's biggest strength, there is some messiness in terms of scene-by-scene progression, and the more metaphorical/allegorical stuff doesn't fully coalesce with the film's more tangible arcs. Still, its willingness to take an approach both upfront and delicate to its central topic proves to be a burning, driving core towards a cathartic final endpoint. Meaningful, impassionate stuff.

I am averse to making comparisons to Brocka, but here we are. You see it in this film's Manila, a hysterically cruel city that somehow maintains its kindness in its edges. Here we are, at the claws of light, a sliver of sunshine cutting through the darkness. Sunshine makes a lot of bad decisions, but that's all she has. This is a nation of bad decisions, especially when it comes to the plight of young women. And she has to weave through these apathetic streets to find the kindness that exists in spite of the cruelty.The film uses a device that I found tenuous at points, though I do think it works out in the end. It's just that the film is so good at depicting the casual reality of these characters and the city that surrounds them that I found the break from it a little distracting. The film is transcendent when it just shows us what this city is: a place where a churchyard is where you go to find abortion drugs, a city where a motel is hesitant to give you a room if you're alone, a place where a person charged with caring for you might also take it as an opportunity to shame you for your choices.At the heart of this is Maris Racal, who delivers what might be the performance of a lifetime. A lot is asked of the young actress, who is made to mask the rage of generations of women and put on the facade of someone who is pretending that all this will pass without incident. It is sadness and worry, but also the prevailing need to show the world that everything is okay. She gets ample support from the rest of the cast, with Jennica Garcia in particular embodying the spirit of this film in its most crucial moments.There were several moments watching Sunshine where I find myself saying, "yes." Yes, because I was agreeing with what the movie was saying. Yes, because it was showing me a Manila that felt right. Yes, because Racal was really nailing something. Yes, because the music just swelled at just the right moment. There will be much talk about what the movie says, what it argues in the face of a society that often feels immovable. But here we are. Here it is. All I can say is yes.

â€œMahirap maging babae, mas lalo na babae sa Pilipinas.â€No matter how matriarchal, modern, or progressive we claim to be, women here are still shackled by outdated norms, patriarchal laws, and the belief that their bodies and their choices are not truly their own.Sunshine confronts these hard truths with unflinching honesty. The quiet desperation of having limited options. The shame bred by religious and societal expectations. The resilience women are forced to summon simply to survive.Maris Racal delivers a tour-de-force performance. Iâ€™ve loved her since Marupok AF, but here, she transcends. She carries the film with depth and vulnerability, her portrayal of Sunshine equal parts fragile and fierce.Sheâ€™s matched beautifully by Jennica Garcia, whose turn as her older sister is quietly powerful. In her hands, sisterhood becomes a form of motherhood, a reminder that parenting can come from places we least expect.Sunshine hopes to be a catalyst for reproductive rights, choice, and change. And at its core, itâ€™s a love letter to every Filipina who has ever had to fight for her rights and a light in the dark.Go see it.

Cinemaster FJ Calvario says:In 2022, the government of Cuba had undertaken a bold move. It ratified a revision of its Family Code which redefined the â€œfamilyâ€. It was no longer defined by only biological ties but also by relationships based on love and mutual support. This revised code is a radical piece of legislation, expanding the rights of women and children and recognizing same-sex marriages and adoption. It is a watershed moment for a country once colonized by Catholic Spain whose religious policies defined what was and wasn't allowed in society. In another corner of the world, the government of the Philippines continues to enforce the same religious norms set by Spain. Unlike Cuba, the Philippines has a long road ahead of itself in dismantling colonial legacy. A road perhaps may be paved by radical films such as Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s Sunshine. A pioneer of the dialogue-driven hugot films of the 2010s, Jadaone is best known for her screenplays that blended comedy and romance. However, beginning with 2020â€™s haunting thriller Fan Girl which tackled male idolatry in the Duterte era, she seems to be on a sociopolitical streak in her directorial efforts. Her latest drama Sunshine now examines a womanâ€™s decision to abort her pregnancy in a country where it is illegal and heavily stigmatized by the influential Catholic Church. At the heart of the film is the eponymous protagonist Sunshine (played by Maris Racal), a gymnast who dreams to compete for the Olympics. We first see Sunshine practice her routine in a stunningly directed scene showcasing well-paced editing and choreography. The pulsating electronic score by Rico Blanco is the cherry on top. He embodies his inner Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross who coincidentally scored another sports film released the same year as this one. Her characterâ€™s Olympic ambitions remind me of the great women athletes in our country who have been making waves for their international achievements. I see in her the Olympic gold-winning weightlifter Hidlyn Diaz and the Wimbledon-competing tennis player Alexa Eala. But this dream of Olympic glory and national pride may not be realized if Sunshine decides to continue her pregnancy. We spend much of the film following her as she navigates through her personal relationships with her family and friends, her boyfriend, her gymnastics coach, and a mysterious girl who questions her decision to abort. Itâ€™s quite a cast really. Maris Racal makes the film as Sunshine; she plays her with steadfast determination. Bubbling behind Racal's eyes is great fear and tragedy. Xyriel Manabat does a lot with silent glances as Sunshineâ€™s best friend Thea who begins to distance herself from her pregnant friend. Elijah Canlas epitomizes the upper class douchebag as Miggy the boyfriend, frequently speaking in straight English and hilariously offloading responsibility to his girlfriend. Annika Co as the mysterious nagging girl manages to be cute, annoying, and threatening in the same scene (although her characterâ€™s inclusion in the film is questionable and counter-intuitive, well intentioned as it is).Jadaoneâ€™s dense screenplay is riveting in its timeliness, empathy and boldness. The struggle of Sunshine in choosing between her career and an unwanted pregnancy recalls last yearâ€™s controversy around another athlete the Olympic gold winner Carlos Yulo who feuded with his mother over the latterâ€™s misappropriation of his hard earned money. The discourse around the Yulo issue saw the clashing of cultures, the divide between conservatives (who viewed the athlete as an ungrateful son) and progressives (who championed Carlosâ€™s autonomy). I expect the same discourse around Sunshineâ€™s decision in choosing herself to unfold in Facebook comments sections once the film gets widely released in the country. It takes a cold heart not to be moved by Sunshineâ€™s struggle for bodily autonomy. Jadaone situates her protagonist in the working class environs of Manila. It is a landscape defined by neglect and economic difficulties. Sunshineâ€™s mother and father are nowhere to be seen, leaving only Sunshine and her siblings to fend for themselves. Sunshine meets a young girl who is also in need of money for her own abortion, having been raped by her own family member. Miggy refuses to share the burden of Sunshineâ€™s pregnancy and keeps his distance. Beyond her words, Jadaoneâ€™s images (courtesy of cinematographer Pao Orendain) strikingly capture urban oppression. There is a great shot of Sunshine praying behind the grills of a church, visualizing the struggle between Catholic faith and personal freedom. Thereâ€™s another great shot where a lone Sunshine is again framed behind a window of a motel beside a train line, highlighting how isolating her struggle can be. Who would want to give birth to a child into a world of constant struggle amidst economic hardship and social stigma? The screenplay brilliantly reimagines what a family and society could be. In the place of a mother and a father, Sunshine has two mother figures: her sister Geleen (played by Jennica Garcia) and her coach Eden (played by Meryll Soriano). Where other films would fixate on the familial tension between a parent and a child, this film is refreshingly optimistic in envisioning a family that supports and respects each other in their decisions, even with a decision as controversial as abortion. Sunshineâ€™s supportive, orphaned family challenges the dominant Filipino imagination of the family (a father, a mother, and children). There is a wryly funny dialogue exchange in a Catholic hospital scene between Geleen and a conservative doctor where the former defends Sunshine by pointing out the doctorâ€™s religious hypocrisy. Jadaoneâ€™s screenplay beautifully emphasizes the solidarity between women. Beyond interactions within her family, we see Sunshine helped by a kind doctor (played by Angeli Bayani) and, in turn, she helps a young pregnant girl (played by Rhed Bustamante). Even in an unjust male-dominated world, the film shows hope in the kindness among women. I have read reviews comparing this film to works of Lino Brocka and Marilou Diaz-Abaya. Perhaps, they are not far off. What Jadaone achieves in this film is the start of an honest conversation about womenâ€™s bodily autonomy in our society, much like what Brocka and Abaya have done in their social dramas during the Second Golden Age of Philippine Cinema. Time will tell how impactful Sunshine will be on legislation regarding abortion and other aspects of womenâ€™s rights. The Philippines, society and state, has a long way ahead to embrace progressive ideas, unlike for our fellow ex-Spanish colony Cuba. I suspect this film will trigger backlash among conservative audiences. God, imagine the online discourse and private message chains from concerned parents. But I do hope that close minded people would be moved by a film as empathetic as Sunshine.Watch Sunshine exclusively in SM Cinemas starting July 23

Very backlogged review but hey, to have a star such as Maris (who is great in this film) lead in a controversial topic in this day and age is a breath of fresh air. Antoinette Jadaone steps out of her comfort zone yet again to bring out one of her bolder works. I am happy that something like this is out there, don't get me wrong, but there is something so off and odd about representing their struggles with hallucinatory unborn children. Feels almost counterproductive. In the talkback, direk says that she was inspired by Jojo Rabbit with this style of narrative and I wish she went deeper in explaining her reasoning. Edit: I strongly urge everyone to read my friend Macâ€™s review on this here. Perfectly captures the qualms with the film.Watched the premiere in SM Aura.Thanks for the opportunity UP Cinema!

Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s Sunshine is a powerful, intimate portrait of a young gymnast who discovers sheâ€™s pregnant just days before her Olympic tryouts. Rather than using the pregnancy as a dramatic twist, the film treats it as a deeply human momentâ€”one that forces Sunshine to confront her identity, future, and agency as a young woman. Jadaoneâ€™s direction is sensitive and grounded, allowing the story to unfold with quiet urgency and emotional truth.The film bravely highlights the invisible struggles women face when ambition and reality collide. Through layered characters and subtle symbolism, Sunshine reveals how choicesâ€”especially for womenâ€”are rarely simple, often shaped by expectations and silent pressures.Maris Racal delivers a standout performance, capturing Sunshineâ€™s vulnerability and strength with nuance. The final scene is restrained yet powerful, offering a deeply satisfying end. Sunshine is a brave, necessary film that speaks volumes about the difficult choices women must make in a world that rarely makes space for them.

What do you mean Sunshine walked from Quiapo Church to Siena College? Iâ€™d recognize that street corner anywhere. As in Fan Girl, the best thing about Jadaoneâ€™s filmmaking here is how she leverages unreality to create an immersive, tactile, and real subjective experience. The film is not just set in Manila, but Sunshineâ€™s Manila, at times hypocritically prim and tragically seedy, both just different modes of alienation borne from the conservative milieu that devalues and abandons the marginalized among us, here particularly young women. Itâ€™s a potent text not because it presents clear answersâ€”although its allegiance to its protagonist is never uncertainâ€”but because it paints the sort of full and rich portrait of a womanâ€™s life that the society it portrays cannot seem to imagine for the women in it. Very good.

Sunshine is a powerful, empathetic, and important film that bravely confronts a topic still considered taboo in the Philippines. As someone born and raised in the country, I found it both courageous and deeply resonant. Itâ€™s not just what the film is trying to say, but how it says it and, that stands out. They did it with care, nuance, and emotional clarity rarely seen in local cinema.Premiering internationally was also a smart and strategic move. It speaks to how difficult it still is to have open conversations around abortion back home. The truth is, stories that challenge long-held cultural or moral beliefs often need recognition from abroad before theyâ€™re embraced locally, a reflection of our lingering colonial mindset and deeply rooted conservatism.I truly hope Sunshine finds its audience in the Philippines. It deserves to, it needs to. Until we confront the systems that silence stories like these. Film this bold will remain the exception, not the norm. And for that alone, I commend Jadaone. We need films like Sunshineâ€”not just to provoke, but to create space for real change.

Gets na gets ko na. During the film's duration, I felt like I was drowning. I was drowning with Sunshine in the chaos of Manila's unsafe milieu. As she traverse the limited and unfair choices, the feeling of helplessness associated with the ticking time bomb inside her is tactile. I felt restrained from the very beginning until the penultimate scene because every obstacle she goes through, she can't show weakness; she has to show up with a brave face because of the programmed noise in her head; which was generated by the years of social norms put upon every woman's shoulder.One of the most profound and sensitive moments I found deeply moving was when Sunshine said, "Hindi po ako buntis, coach", yet her eyes was swelling with tears. She can't believe that this is the only truth she is forced to deal with, that everything she has worked for will end in a whim, and that the choice wasn't even deliberately made by her; mirroring the many women in the Philippines who undergo teenage pregnancy, who also don't have a safe choice for their bodies, and for their dreams. As I sit and bask in her story in the cinema, my tears kept falling even in the most simplistic emotions. Maybe that's what happens when you feel like you've already lost the battle even if you haven't started to face it it yet. Maybe that's how it feels to be in the losing end of the decisions made by the very society that should be protecting you. Maybe this is how it is to step in the shoes of every woman in the Philippines, and at the very least, it's only a feeling I can imagine.Honestly hought this film wouldn't make a willful statement. But it takes a stand, and at the core of it is Maris Racal; supported by a riveting ensemble just as honest as her. Direk Antoinette Jadaone weaved the story with compassion through the lens of real stories of real women. She made a deliberate choice to conceive this film, and this time, it was made by her.

A major triumph for Philippine cinema. Antoinette Jadaone just gets it. You have those who preach God, yet fail in exhibiting compassion. You have those who canâ€™t help but conform to societal norms.The movie understands how taboo abortion is in the Philippines, and I really liked how Manila, in its realest self, was portrayed. The sound mixing also elevates the film to greater heights.Maris Racal is a revelation. Jennica Garcia also stands out. I really liked how most of the women here were very compassionate to each other. When faced with men who canâ€™t act like men, you can really only rely on women tbh. Jadaone gets it.The film portrays a very pressing matter with such careful handling, I am convinced itâ€™s going to succeed in starting a conversation that must be had. Very, very important movie. Congratulations to everyone involved!

a young gymnast, days away from national team tryouts, finds out she's pregnant - a truth that threatens everything she's trained for. in search of a way to undo it, she crosses paths with a strange girl who mirrors her fears, thoughts, and silence. what follows is a quiet unraveling of control, shame, and choice.maris racal is exceptional. every look, every movement feels lived-in. you can tell how much she trained - not just physically, but emotionally - to bring sunshine to life. itâ€™s a performance that doesn't ask for attention but demands it anyway. jennica garcia also delivers a quiet but aching presence that stays with you.the film isnâ€™t without its flaws. some parts felt rushed, others too drawn out. and the mysterious girl character, while symbolic, didnâ€™t fully land. but still, this is jadaoneâ€™s boldest and most important film. raw, intimate, and unafraid to touch topics weâ€™ve long kept in the dark.akala ko sapat na ang pagiging pro-women ko but this film reminded me how far we still have to go. i'll never fully know the weight women carry - lalo na sa bansa nating punong-puno ng limitasyon. and thatâ€™s the power of this film. it doesnâ€™t lecture, it just quietly shows you the truth.mahirap maging babae. mas lalo sa pilipinas. and this film makes that heartbreakingly clear.

Philippines is still a conservative country and, honestly, I'm shocked that this got a wide release thanks to SM Cinemas. I don't know how hard it must've been to make this release work given how abortion is still illegal in this country and the stigma surrounding it. Such an empathetic film that's filled with so much heart despite how other people make it seem like an immoral decision. As Direk Tonet said in the Q and A screening I went to, as a writer, she sides with her characters whether people think the decisions that her character makes is right or wrong. In other words, she doesn't give a fuck what other people thinks about abortion. As for Maris, damn, what a performance. She's known to be more expressive and she admits as well that the hardest thing for her is leveling that down that she has to unlearn even the small nuances that she does. Such a vulnerable performance. Give her the recognition she deserves.We have been behind as a country when it comes to talking about reproductive health and women's rights but I hope given how widely this film is being seen right now that it sparks the necessary conversation not only in our society but also in our government that at the very least, decriminalize abortion.Side note: what a complete 180 when I saw this after watching Fantastic Four

Sa Pilipinas, ang mga tulad ni Sunshine ay pinipilit habulin ang liwanag kahit paulit-ulit silang nilulunod sa dilim.Alam naman nating lahat: illegal ang aborsyon sa bansang ito. Pero kailanman, hindi ito makakapigil sa aborsyon. Ang nagagawa lang nito ay itulak ang mga babae sa delikado, hindi ligtas, at hindi kontroladong paraan. At ipinakita sa atin ng pelikulang ito kung gaano ka-mapanganib iyon. Mula sa pagbebenta ng pamparegla sa mga black market hanggang sa mga hilot na hindi naman ginagawa ng propesyonalâ€”lahat â€˜yan ay repleksyon ng desperasyong hindi nila ginusto, kundi bunga ng sistemang patuloy silang pinapabayaan.Pero hindi lang aborsyon ang laman ng pelikulang ito. Binuksan nito ang mas malawak na usapinâ€”bulok na healthcare system, paniniwalang relihiyoso na ginagamit panlaban sa kababaihan, incest, rape, teenage pregnancy, pressure bilang atleta, takot sa kahihiyan, at moralidad na tila laging nakasandal sa pananakit ng babae. Pinakita ng pelikula ang buong paligid ni Sunshineâ€”pamilya, paaralan, simbahan, coach, kaibigan, doktorâ€”at kung paano sila naging bahagi ng problema o ng solusyon.At sobrang tamang-tama lang na sa Maynila ito kinunan. Sa Morayta, Recto, at Quiapoâ€”mga lugar na malapit sa University Belt, kung saan maraming estudyante ang nakakaranas ng hindi planadong pagbubuntis. Mga lugar rin ito na kilala sa underground na kalakaranâ€”mula sa pekeng dokumento hanggang sa black market na pampalaglag. Realidad ito ng maraming kabataan, at pinili ng pelikula na hindi ito pagtakpan.Wala itong pa-plot twist. Walang engrandeng eksena. Pero ramdam mo ang bigat. At naipaabot niya ang mensahe nang malinaw sa masa, sa bawat Pilipinong kailangang mamulat. Hindi para mangumbinsi, kundi para magpasimula ng pag-uusap. Pag-uusap na maaaring maging tulay tungo sa legalisasyonâ€”o kahit dekriminalisasyonâ€”ng aborsyon sa bansa natin.Sobrang husay ni Maris Racal. Para siyang talagang gymnast. Lahat ng galaw may kahulugan. Lahat ng tahimik na sandali, may sigaw. Kudos sa choreographersâ€”dahil bawat routine, may sariling kwento.Si Sunshine ay isa lang. Pero napakarami pang katulad niya. Iba-iba man ang dahilan, iisa ang dapat malinaw: ang desisyon ay dapat laging nasa babae. Sa katawan nila. Sa buhay nila.Hindi kailangan ng pelikula ng sagot. Pero may lakas ito para magtanong. At sa isang bansang takot harapin ang tanong, sapat na iyon para tawaging rebolusyonaryo.Sana ang Sunshine na ito, maging sinag ng panibagong simula. #LegalizeAbortion

essay ka saken mamaya sunshine pero for now MAHAL KO TONG PELIKULA NA TOedit: eto na ako. woke up too early today and thoughtâ€¦bat di ko simulan ang araw! to talk about sunshine! first of all, maris? hands down. gets mo bat sya nasabihan na haggard nung nakakita sa kanya habang nagshoshoot. ganto ang mukha ng bawat batang babaeng naghahanap ng tulong sa mga sulok-sulok ng quiapo, hilutan, at twitter. wala eh, saan ba pwede humingi ng tulong ang isang babae kung isang buong relihiyon, gobyerno, at bansa ang humuhusga sayo? ganda ng cinematography, kuhang kuha yung pakiramdam ng manila; yung sulasok, yung ingay, yung mga dasal, pati na rin yung desperasyon. para sa mga nakakaangat-angat at hindi naranasang maglakad sa kahabaan ng quiapo habang nasa harap ang bag (dahil baka manakaw), mga hindi napadpad sa lugar dahil may kakayahang magpa-hospital, madaling husgahan ang mga nagtitinda sa quiapo o mga kustomer dito. pero di niyo alam ang pag-asang bitbit ng mga ale at langis at gamot at booklet na may instructions kung paano magpalaglag para sa mga taong kagaya ni sunshine. mga taong pinagkaitan ng karapatan sa katawan at accessible healthcare. mga kababaihan. mga kagaya namin.maaaring nakakadisorient yung existence ni annika dito, pero sobrang importante na andito siya. mahirap pag-usapan ang aborsyon sa pilipinas dahil sa predominantly catholic country tayo. mabigat ang pagkakaangkla ng mga batas natin, maging ang moralidad at paniniwala natin bilang indibidwal, sa mga turo ng simbahan. kaya kahit ako, bilang babae at pro-choice, nahihirapan pag-usapan ang aborsyon nang hindi nakakaramdam ng guilt (catholic guilt!). pakiramdam kasi ng mga tao, walang impact sa mga babae ang pagpapaabort. madalas din kasi sa mga video galing sa western countries, they can joke about it na cells lang yanâ€¦.kasi totoo naman. pero iba kasi pag lumaki ka sa bansang kagaya ng pilipinas na sobrang taas ng pagpapahalaga sa pamilya at diyos. mas iba yung bigat. iba yung konsensya. kaya nga dumaan muna si sunshine sa simbahan para humingi ng tawad (ARGH SOBRANG GANDA I LOVE IT) kasi ganon tayo lumaki dito. at oo cells lang, laman lang, pero laman mo. parang personification nito si annikaâ€¦sa madaling salita, sya yung anak that sunshine could have had, yung what if, paniguradong sasagi sa isip ni sunshine from time to time. Hindi ko gets kung bakit ang dami pa ring hindi nakaka-gets.Sunshine is a film about noiseâ€” ingay ng Maynila, ingay ng judgement ng iba, ingay ng kaguluhan, ingay ng mga maling desisyon. At sa gitna ng lahat ng ingay, ay isang babaeng may pangarapâ€” tumatakbo, lumalaban.I have so many to say about the political nature of this film but I think at its core, Sunshine is about understanding. Hindi natin kailangan baguhin ang paniniwala natin, kailangan lang natin matutong umintindi sa kalagayan at sitwasyon ng iba.If you donâ€™t believe in abortion, donâ€™t get one. Same goes with the idea of divorce and same sex unions. Why limit the choices of others? The screenplay works so well along with its perfect casting. Lahat bagay na bagay sa role lalo na si Maris as Sunshine. I also love the cinematography lalo na sa Quiapo scenes. I felt the chaos through that. We know our country is fucked up when women canâ€™t make choices for themselves. We know weâ€™re fucked up when weâ€™ donâ€™t have safe and accessible abortions. We know weâ€™re fucked up when we canâ€™t pass laws like the divorce bill and the sogie bill. So what do we do after this? Hindi sapat ang isang pelikula upang baguhin ang sistema. Hindi dapat ganitoâ€” pero madami pa tayong kailangan paliwanagan upang maka-gets. Kailangan ng kolektibong aksyon upang i-push ang progressive bills into legislation. Malayo pa tayo.

The best Filipino film Iâ€™ve seen so far this year.Raw, relevant, and worth talking about.Set in Manila: masikip, mainit, mabaho. The film captures it so well that you can almost smell and feel it. Beneath that heat and heaviness is a quiet story of sacrifice. It powerfully portrays the struggles of women in a deeply patriarchal society. Young women are expected to give way, to carry the weight, to make the harder choice. While men are often free to walk away, women are left at the crossroads, torn between duty and ambition, between what they want and what they are told they should become. Its honest portrayal of everyday hardship, mixed with strong feminist themes, feels like it is channeling both Lino Brocka and Marilou Diaz-Abaya.The film also reflects the quiet hypocrisy we see in everyday life. No one is truly exempt. People speak of values, yet live with contradictions. The film shows us these double standards in a way that makes you reflect.Maris Racal is so, so good as Sunshine. The rest of the cast is just as strong. Jennica Garcia, Meryll Soriano, Annika Co, Elijah Canlas, Rhed Bustamante and the rest of the casts are all remarkable. I also appreciate how even the crowd and background extras were credited at the end. It speaks volumes about how everyone involved was valued.And what a story it is. Raw, relevant, and worth talking about. Sunshine is not just the best Filipino film I have seen this year. It is one that dares to ask difficult questions and sit with uncomfortable truths. Brave and thought-provoking, it will likely spark conversation after the ending credits. Some of the choices in the film may feel morally difficult, and not everyone will agree with them. But the real question is, who are we to decide what is right for someone else? Are we even in their place to judge?More than anything, Sunshine reminds us to be kind. To live with empathy. To listen, to pause, and to try to understand before we judge.Just like these past few days, the rain has not stopped. For some, it is a blessing. For others, it feels like a never-ending trial. But in the middle of it all, we wait for the same thing: Sunshine.Sunshine that reminds us that after the storm, healing begins. And slowly, we rise. ğŸŒ¤ï¸

ChoicesSunshine makes mistakes and will make mistakes. People will question why she is pregnant at a very young age. And it was clearly hers and her boyfriendâ€™s choice to be unprotected. And when she decided to tell him she was pregnant, both of them had to make choices. But when legal options run out for Sunshine and the only choice she can make is to abort through illegal means, she puts her own life at risk. But it is also in making a choice that Sunshine finds herself.Godâ€™s Gift Sunshine leaves a jeepney with the words Godâ€™s Gift. She walks towards Quiapo church and asks for forgiveness, and outside the church there is a market selling religious things, but also potions that â€œinduce menstruationâ€. A medical professional preaches God at Sunshineâ€™s bedside after her â€œmedicineâ€ fails her. And it says a lot about the structures surrounding young women with unwanted pregnancies. Later on in the film, we see the impact of these structures on them. They are forced to make decisions that risk their lives.Full of GraceMaris Racal is perfect at portraying Sunshineâ€™s physicality and character. Her performance will make you believe sheâ€™s an Olympian who can take the spotlight and get everyoneâ€™s attention, a sister who learns how important it is to make her family proud, but most importantly, a dreamer who understands her young age is the right opportunity to change the world around her. I will never feel the exact same way as Sunshine experienced, but as a male audience, the film still allows me to put myself in Sunshineâ€™s hard and difficult situation. The film is able to open eyes, and hopefully the audience willingly opens their eyes to Sunshine.

"Naiintindihan mo ba 'ko?"Has the grit and guts of showing how women haven't had it easy when it comes to body agency in this patriarchal and faith-bound country. The part where the kid was used as a metaphor just seemed self-defeating to the movie for me. But as far as performances go, Maris sticks her landing here.

Itâ€™s so odd to see Jadaone out of her boxâ€”or perhaps returning to her old form. If Fan Girl leaned into the dark, Sunshine veers into the gritty. The clever use of environment makes Maris Racalâ€™s performance feel grounded and central, without overly commenting on political allegories like in Jadaoneâ€™s previous work. Orendainâ€™s shots donâ€™t try to elevate the storyâ€”they move hand-in-hand with it, gripping tightly to the isolation of being a young woman in the Philippines.I havenâ€™t seen any Filipino film tackle abortion quite like this. The nuance of setting it in a deeply religious country is compelling. It opens the conversation, but perhaps plays a little too safeâ€”maybe to appeal to a broader audience. I was hoping for a stronger push, but it chooses to be understated: a film beaming with quiet urgency and an accurate reflection of the current climate surrounding womenâ€™s reproductive rights.

This movie screams â€œyour body, your rules!â€ Grabe ang empowerment sa kababaihan sa pelikulang ito na mahusay na binigyang-buhay ni Maris Racal. Mapag-iisip ang mga manonood sa mga pagpapasya ng pangunahing tauhan, susuportahan ba o hindi? Sasang-ayunan ba o hindi? Tagos ang emosyong ipinakita ng mga karakter. Ang husay ni Maris, ang husay ni Jennica, ang husay ni Annika. Lahat ay epektibo sa kani-kanilang mga ginampanan. May mga bahagi sa pelikula na napatulo ang luha ko dahil sa lalim ng pagbigkas ng mga dayalogo.Habang tumatakbo ang kwento, mapagtatanto nating this country deserves better healthcare system especially for women, dapat ay may reproductive freedom din sila dahil sa mga kalagayang kagaya ng kay Sunshine, kabataang kababaihan ang talo at napeperwisyo.

Thereâ€™s a lot to unpack in Sunshine, but let me begin by saying this: Maris Racal owns this character. Thereâ€™s no other actress who could have pulled off Sunshine the way she did. She embodied every bit of the character so completely that Maris disappearsâ€”youâ€™re not watching Maris as Sunshine; youâ€™re watching Sunshine herself. Her performance is quietly powerful and emotionally charged, grounded in rawness and empathy.But this film isn't just carried by Maris alone. Alongside her are Annika Co, Jennica Garcia,and Rhed Bustamante, who play pivotal roles in deepening Sunshineâ€™s story. In many ways, their characters are Sunshineâ€”reflected through different lenses. Through themes of mental health and teen pregnancy, the film constructs a layered portrait of girlhood under pressure. It's raw, empathetic, bold, and unafraid. It doesnâ€™t flinch from the truth, nor does it romanticize the pain.What Sunshine does best is handle a very sensitive subject in our country with sincerity and urgency: the ongoing struggle for bodily autonomy. It quietly and firmly illustrates the emotional toll of being a young woman in a society that refuses to let her decide for herself. And worse, how these conversations remain taboo.Every silence in the film is so loud. The pauses, the stillness, the unspokenâ€”Sunshine knows that some of the loudest screams come from what isnâ€™t said. The film allows space for emotion to breathe, for truths to sink in, and for viewers to truly feel the weight these girls carry.The producers behind Sunshine had to fight to get this film seenâ€”not for profit, but because these are stories that matter. They pushed forward to open a much-needed conversation on bodily autonomy and reproductive rights. And itâ€™s 2025â€”yet these issues are still being dismissed, invalidated, or worse, treated like theyâ€™re myths. In truth, they are not up for debate. They are basic rights that every woman deserves.I only hope that in the years to come, we wonâ€™t need another Sunshine just to get people to listen.Panoorin ang Sunshine, hindi lang dahil gusto n'yo, kundi dahil kailangan. When I was in grade school, I wrote a feature editorial piece about abortion. I took the point-of-view of an unborn child narrating all his aspirations and would have been's in life had he had the chance to live, but I did not give voice to his mother, or at least I chose not to. 16 years later and here comes Sunshine.In the middle of this storming weather in the metro, Sunshine is haunting. It brings you to the darkest alleys of Manila where hope feels nowhere to be found, especially in a political climate where a woman is at a disadvantage, for the lack of a better term.Sunshine is disturbing in such a way that a woman, in this modern age, is still left with limited options, or the lack thereof, and has no autonomy in doing informed decisions on her own body amidst retribution of a patriarchal society.Sunshine is moving. It kicks. It punches. Five months after its Berlinale win, Sunshine comes home, and it needs traction. It is high time to make the conversation going until, for some divine intervention, it reaches the people that should be of utmost concerned about the plight of women.Sigh. Going back to the essay I wrote years ago, I guess I no longer need to rewrite nor revise that piece, kasi ngayon, mas gets ko na ang buong kwento.

2:30pm AWKP Screening @ SM North with Direk Tonet Jadaone & Maris Racal We live in a nation of choices & contradictions where women are the ones who are burdened with most of its unwanted consequences. Abortion? Illegal. Teenage pregnancy? Immoral. Contraceptives? Taboo. Elders look down on women who have pre-marital sex, unwanted pregnancy, and even an ounce of body autonomy.Beneath clouds of apathy & judgment, SUNSHINE reminds us to choose empathy & compassion.Nora Aunor was Bona. Hilda Koronel was Insiang. Today, Maris Racal is SUNSHINE.To bring up Lino Brocka is a heavy statement itself, but the Crystal Bear winning-SUNSHINE has also memorized Manila, and all its aches and decays. In her background are the familiar veins of Avenida & Quiapo. The heaviness of everyday life, religion and culture all add to her already buzzing headspace. She tries and must drown out the noise.With this award-worthy role, Maris might just have earned her place among the revered women in Philippine cinema who have embodied the honesty and rawness of the Filipina experienceâ€”in their respective era, each still under the same problematic patriarchal society.There's an all-timer hospital scene that stayed with me the most. As a medical student, what we're taught often align with Catholic teachings, even if our personal beliefs say otherwise. Our hope is that the next generation of health professionals will be provided with aligned legislation and protection that will help them become more compassionate, empathetic, and sensitive to women's autonomy over their bodies. These conversations should start not just in household discussions but in our social institutions as well.Elijah Canlas nails the recklessness of a young boy scared to man up. Xyriel Manabat's eyes speak for themselves. Jennica Garcia is simply luminous and embodies the 'Ate' in our lives. Her tough love exterior melts whenever Sunshine needs her genuine guidance. Meryll Soriano's presence is calming and reassuring. Piolo Pascual delivers friction and captures the high and mighty men in our society who assume to know all about everything and everyone, especially womenâ€™s needs. This is Direk Antoinette Jadaone's career-best work, yet. And at the heart of it all is Maris Racal, delivering a thrilling performance that will catapult her to superstardom.
Sometimes a raw no-frills straightforward piece is all you need to convey a powerful message.

How can you drown out the noise when even the silence starts to echo your doubts?Direk @tonetjadaoneâ€™s pragmatic approach to storytelling moves the soul.Although far from being perfect, the film delivered where it mattered most - clarity in messaging and a vision compelling enough to leave emotional resonance to spectators.

This film on female reproductive health boldly centers the female gaze, offering a fresh and unflinching take on the realities that many Filipinas face. It attempts to break the glass ceiling of deeply rooted Filipino norms and challenges the culture shaped by religion, stigma, and silence around topics like abortion, sex education, and womenâ€™s health.Direk Tonet Jadaone masterfully captures the struggles of the protagonist, whose aspirations are put on hold after she discovers sheâ€™s pregnant. The film follows her journey, portraying how a woman navigates the weight of societal expectations in a culture that often leaves little room for personal agency.Cinematically, itâ€™s far from your typical Filipino clichÃ©. The pacing is tight, the cinematography is visually compelling, and each scene is deliberate, drawing the viewer into the emotional and social turmoil the character endures. The film allows us to witness how Sunshine finds resilience amidst adversity, all while shedding light on the layers of deprivation and injustice a Filipina can experience in a patriarchal society.More than just a narrative, the film leaves an impact. It sparks important conversations about our broken systemsâ€”the stigma surrounding reproductive health, the taboo nature of sex education, the inaccessibility of contraceptives, and the criminalization of abortion. It confronts how society often reduces women to objects of pleasure or vessels of reproduction, without regard for their mental or physical well-being.Ultimately, this is a film about empowerment. Itâ€™s a powerful reminder that women can dream for themselves, stand their ground, and rise above a system designed to keep them down. Thought-provoking and timely, itâ€™s a testament to Direk Tonet Jadaoneâ€™s bold storytelling and her commitment to stories that matter.

This movie is arguably one of the best films of the year. It feels incredibly real because it reflects life in the Philippines, where women's rights are acknowledged but often support a male-dominated system and the patriarchy."Sunshine" tells the story of many women living in the Philippines. In this country, discussions about sex and sex education are frequently considered taboo. Many people talk about sex negatively, treating it as something sinful rather than educational. As a result, issues like teenage pregnancy are primarily viewed as public health problems. Furthermore, while there is a law aimed at protecting women from violence, it forces victims of sexual abuse to carry any resulting pregnancy to term, even in tragic circumstances such as r4p3.With abortion being illegal in the Philippines, many women find themselves in difficult situations. Those facing unplanned and unwanted pregnancies may have to consider unsafe options, which can threaten their lives.Women's rights must prioritize the well-being and choices of women, not men. The self-righteousness and views of certain religious groups should not dictate whether abortion is legalized. Women must have the power to make choices about their bodies."Sunshine" is a story of hope, second chances, and pursuing dreams. It hopes for a better society where women are not scrutinized for claiming rights over their bodies. This movie is a bold and significant step for film in the Philippines, as it represents the experiences of many women in the country. We must continue the conversation and let this film be a part of the movement advocating for better women's rights.Without a doubt, Maris Racal brought life to her character, Sunshine. Her outstanding performance solidifies her status as one of the best actresses of this generation.

â€œgets ko naâ€the physical representation of sunshine making peace, letting go of her guilt, and getting complete reassurance in her decision, all in the form of the child she once detested, but in the end, loved, was honestly beautiful. there is so much love and strength with the child in understanding sunshineâ€™s dreams and circumstances, and how society was truly set against them; two females who were young girls at the end of the day. in a way, it reminded me of the popular thought prompt, â€œif my mother didnâ€™t have me, what kind of life would she have had?â€ itâ€™s a bittersweet thought at first, but there is such genuine love and understanding in seeing your mother past her caregiving responsibilities and wanting to witness her thrive as an independent woman with goals and ambitions, even if it meant losing your existence. however, there is also so much love and strength with sunshine deciding what would be best for both her and for the child, even if it hurt. sunshine loved the child enough to recognize that she didnâ€™t deserve to be brought into such a cruel world, not when her own mother was still navigating through it, barely managing to survive the horrors she was dealt with. she knew she wasnâ€™t ready at all and she didnâ€™t want her child to bear the brunt of it, given what she herself has went through. there is love and strength in choosing yourself, recognizing your weaknesses, and acknowledging that both you and your child deserve the best version of yourself; one that has wholeheartedly lived her dreams and life despite societal expectations and harsh realities and one that is ready to help her child to do just the same.despite all odds, naintindihan nila yung isaâ€™t isa. and out of love, for both themselves and for each other, they both let go.

Sunshine is an aspiring Olympian. She is two weeks away from performing in the qualifying round. She has won numerous gold medals in local and Asian competitions, making her an ideal candidate for an Olympic gold. But everything changes when she discovers an unwanted pregnancy. In a male-dominated, conservative, church-leaning country, who can help Sunshine achieve her dreams?Jadaone's latest picture is a gritty coming-of-age sports drama that tackles a sensitive yet realistic portrayal of the struggles women face when the government and society turn their backs on them. It is a claustrophobic journey that dims the shine of its lead character even before she sees the end of the tunnel. The film offers a timely and relevant discussion on gender roles, sex education, the health care system, body autonomy, female rage, and empowerment.At its center is Maris Racal, who plays the titular character with grace, bareness, and nuance. She embodies the sunshine amidst a dirty, hypocritical, careless, and immovable society that becomes a character of its own. This is supported by the filmâ€™s striking eye for cinematic framing of the ragged city of Manila.I love how the film handles the core of its subject: should Sunshine get an abortion and continue chasing her dreams, or take the baby and live a life she is not prepared for? I love how the women characters come together to help each other against the oppressive weight of our patriarchal society.And when Sunshine finally makes a decision, I donâ€™t think the film wants you to agree or disagree with her. It wants you to ask why she had to be in this position in the first place. It wants us to notice the shoulder-to-shoulder crowding in public maternity wards. It wants us to see the hypocrisy of a society where black markets for abortion operate in the shadows of churches, and why a woman still cannot make a decision about her own body without judgment from everyone around her.Pero gets kita, Sunshine. Gets na gets.

Gets ko na.Hinding hindi ko malilimutan kung paanong pagkatapos ng lahat, hindi binitawan ni Sunshine ang pangarap niya. Kitang kita kung paanong ang gintong bola ng pag-asa sa loob niya ay patuloy na kuminang sa kabila ng kadiliman ng Maynila. Sa kabila ng lipunang hindi handa sa isang babaeng may paninindigan at pangarap sa sarili niya. Gets ko na.Ito ay sulat para sa akin. Hindi dahil isa rin akong gymnast na gustong maging Olympian. Ito ay sulat para sa akin at sa munting â€œihaâ€ na ang tanging kakampi lang sa kadiliman ng mundo ay ang tingkad ng pangarap niya. Gets na gets ko na. Gets na gets ko na kung bakit kahit hindi ako buntis, hindi ako gymnast, o kahit hindi ko pangarap maging olympian, ako si Sunshine. Dahil kahit anumang magyari, sigurado akong patuloy na mananaig at pipiliin kong yakapin ang pangarap at pagmamahal ng munting â€œihaâ€ sa akin.

Sunshine is a statement. Raw, delicate, and bold. It presents a social commentary on themes rarely explored yet deeply prevalent in the Philippine context. It dares to be radical. It dares to draw the line. When does the sun finally shine in a morally gray cloud of social disapproval?As linear and straightforward as the film appears, beneath it lies a complex character study â€” fearlessly told, thematically sharp, and emotionally unsettling. Antoinette Jadaone writes for women, and in a cinematic landscape like ours, we need more voices like hers. I was initially worried about where the story would go, but it was brave enough to take the harder path.This is Maris Racal's best performance yet â€” nuanced and quietly powerful. But it was Jennica Garcia who stole every scene she was in. She was the emotional anchor, the tearjerker. Some casting choices outside the leads, however, fell short. Certain scenes and narrative decisions could have landed harder with stronger performances or more fitting direction.That said, the editing needs work. The presence of a stunt double in certain scenes is obvious, breaking immersion. While the filmâ€™s visuals hauntingly capture a side of Manila we rarely see on screen, the sound design lacks polish. These flaws are noticeable but not deal-breaking.Still, this film succeeds in doing what few others do: it makes you ask what is ethical and what is not. It invites reflection. And when a film draws that line clearly for society to see, perhaps thatâ€™s when the sun truly begins to shine.

Sa bawat eksena ng pelikula ni Antoinette Jadaone, iisa ang tinig na umaalingawngaw â€” tinig ng babae. Hindi lang basta karakter ang mga babae, gaya ni Coach Eden mapa hanggang kay Doc Helena; silaâ€™y haligi, saksi, at sandigan. Maging ang mga ina sa maternal ward, tahimik man o may tinig, ay larawan ng kababaihang nagtutulungan, nagkakapit-bisig sa gitna ng unos.Sa mundong kinahon ng patriyarka, binubuksan ng pelikula ang mata natin sa lakas ng kababaihan â€” lakas na hindi lang para sa tahanan o pamayanan, kundi para sa paghubog ng mas makatarungan at pantay na lipunan. Sa mata ng kamera, dama ang panawagan: bigyang saysay ang katawan at karapatan ng kababaihan.Dahil sa mundong nararapat, walang Sunshine, walang Menggay, ang kailangang manahimik sa sakit. Walang babaeng kailangang dumaan sa dilim ng unsafe practices para lamang maramdaman ang kontrol sa sariling buhay. Obviously im not a woman so I will never fully understand the lived experience of a woman but just like sunshine, I am someone who made regrettable decisions in the past. Someone whoâ€™s also eager to make it right. At least for me. But sometimes itâ€™s hard to do the right thing when you have so many people telling you what to do, or when you donâ€™t have the resources to do so. Itâ€™s hard to drown out the noise in your head when everything around you is so loud. Sometimes you donâ€™t even need someone to tell you what to do at all, because you already know. Sometimes all you need is someone to be by your side. Something to make you feel like youre not alone. A text message from a friend. A hug from a sister. A pair of compassionate eyes of a stranger. Despite feeling alone in her whole ordeal, Sunshine was held together by the women she encounters. From the child, her sister, the cashier at the motel, the doctor at the hospital.I was lucky enough to have my own community lift me up at a time when I thought i was done for. Itâ€™s because of them that Iâ€™m still here, and that I still keep going. â€œMahalin mo si sunshine, kahit ano pa siya, kahit ano pang nagawa niyaâ€, said my friend. Indeed, we are all just people in need of community to get us through. In need of compassion. In need of empathy. Someone to say â€œkakampi mo ko ditoâ€. Sometimes having someone sit through it with you is enough. And yes, gets kita, Sunshine.

The film has a sense of urgency about it, presenting the drama with so much eagerness, firm convictions, and intense sentiments nearly to the point where it devolves into cheap propaganda for a cause with which I happen to agree ideologically. It was too on the nose and constantly going for shock value that it was draining to follow, brazenly provoking the audience to feel for a horrible social reality but instead of pointing it out with a nod and a commentary, it was trying so hard to make them feel bad about those situations. Not in a good way because it is one of those things that breeds frustration rather than empathy for the protagonist. At some point, Sunshine simply disappeared, becoming a vessel for the audience to put their shoes on since she is subjected to so much oppression, losing any semblance of agency as it is all about how messed up her social reality has become. It's the same problem I had with war films and other poverty porn, where it ignores developing the protagonist in favor of escalating the situations in front of her and throwing every miserable conflicts imaginable at her. To be fair, the protagonist as a vessel had an aspiration, a threatened dream that was about to be broken, and the idea of her interacting with all these women, smoothly transitioning from the one who needed help to the one who provided help, clearly distinguished the film from those with a typical point-of-view character. Those moments of empowerment and camaraderie with other women may have eased the tension and made it feel more hopeful than the premise implies, but it also falls into the trap of caricaturing other characters for the sake of cheap sensationalism. It also felt betraying that so many things transpired that the gymnastics was set aside for so long, and I would hope that it was more of an escape than a hardship because no joy was displayed during those routines except for the last act. I would say that the sport was not seamlessly wedded to the character, since it could have been any sport or dream, and the film would still be effective. The magical realism element is essentially what I detest about the film, because it could have lingered in the loneliness and allowed the audience to connect with the character through subtlety, but it had to be filled with hypothetical conversation that hits the audience on the head to explain the themes and demonstrate the unspoken dilemmas in the present predicament. It could be interpreted as a mean to communicate guilt, a process of forgiving oneself and empathizing with other women, or as humanizing the fetus inside the body, which I'm not sure how to feel about that ideologically. It's also tonally odd, which is a Philippine cinema branding at this point, but it's always convenient to use a child for humor, and it reduces the overall tone of what's happening to the main character. It was just too telegraphed at times, and I was hoping to let the sequences play out and use more silence because those are the scenes I enjoy when the protagonist is alone and burdened by her situation. The upward momentum of a film that begins bleakly will always impede any form of storytelling because it must outdo itself, building emotions that are overwhelming every ten minutes to the point of monotony. In fact, I can't recall the chronology of the film even though I saw it yesterday, but I do remember every segments and the emotions it was going for. It actually came to the point of absurdity in the third act, when one character emerged, followed by a terrible circumstances, followed by even more bleak information and an unsettling confrontation, which would undoubtedly disturb anyone. And then there was a cameo in which the small theater collectively whisper and giggle a bit as a result of being taken off guard, which again felt awkward because it always has to make a joke after every other miserably effective scene. Not letting the moments breathe for a while. It can even be tonally confusing at times, with scenes that is either attempting to be comical or unsettling as some of the dialogue was just satirical and they incorporate some triggering monologue ala Vincentiments, but they also made the film lighthearted, which I am not sure is a good thing. I suppose I want my abortion movies to be more thought-provoking and full of sociological nuances rather than funny and emotional, because it can be too loose for its sensitive subject matter, but it was heartfelt and that was good. I'm making it seem like I hate this film when than I don't because it was terrific and entertaining, but it's just that I'm not sure if those are the things I want to take away from this film. I have to say though that it had a very good filmmaking mechanics. I heard they tried to hide the camera in public scenes to make the setting appear more authentic, and I was expecting long takes because it was another Filipino film about a protagonist wandering around which they did not employ at all, but I kind of like what they did here, from the shot composition and coverages to the way they were edited together. The only criticism I had regarding the filmmaking was the noticeable stunt double in the gymnastic routines, as well as how the emotions in the close-ups did not match those in the wide shots whenever they intercut them together. I suspect no one grins when doing gymnastics since it is a serious performance by meticulous athletes rather than by an exuberant victorious person, as the film claims at the conclusion. It's just a little quibble, but I commend the filmmaking overall and even the rough cuts were fantastic. Definitely the best-directed Filipino film I've seen in quite some time, I can say that with confidence.

â€œStart strong, stay strong. You can do this.â€ But what happens when life throws you off balance? Sunshine is a powerful, no-frills story set in the gritty, chaotic streets of Manila. It follows a young gymnast whose future gets shaken when she finds out sheâ€™s pregnant. Antoinette Jadaone tells this story the way she does bestâ€”letting silence, glances, and small gestures speak louder than words. No drama for dramaâ€™s sake. Just raw, real moments. Maris Racal delivers a stunning performance.â€¦

This film tackles numerous points that need to be discussed. It provides a comprehensive overview of the different systemic issues that our country is not addressing, ranging from the double standards imposed on women to the societal barriers that make it difficult for women to meet these standards. It is an irony between what society wants for women and how society sets up women to fail to meet these standards.That's where the "bullsht-ery" comes in, as this film successfully sends it to its audience. I want to say a lot of things about this film, on how it provides a good argument, on how it provides a good piece of reality that is not glorified nor romanticized and on how it gave us something that will not just be left on the cinema, but to be talked about in the streets and on the media.I really understand the fear of the production of showing this in the Philippines, but I believe that strong and brave films like this are what we need, to not just start conversations but to challenge the views we have as individuals and as a collective. This is the kind of film that everyone needs to watch, as it will definitely afflict the comfortable and comfort the afflicted. No words, but pure awe of everything about this film. Definitely the best work of both director Antoinette Jadaone and actress Maris Racal. And it's weird for me to have a good rewatch feeling on these kinds of movies, but I believe I will be rewatching this film again (once the storm settles and subsides).Mabuhay ang pelikulang Pilipino!

Interviewer: Pabor po ba kayo sa aborsyon?Interviewee: Hindi. Labag 'yan sa batas ng Diyos. Kahit hindi mo ginusto, biyaya pa rin 'yan.Interviewer: Paano kung bunga ng panggagahasa, hindi handa, walang kakayahang magpalaki, o delikado sa buhay ng ina?Interviewee: Tanggapin na lang. Panindigan mo.Bakit nga ba ganito ang kultura natin sa Pilipinas? Tanggapin. Tiisin. Kimkimin at ituring na â€œblessingâ€ ang trauma at paghihirap.Bunga ba ito ng mapagkunwaring pagsabuhay ng relihiyon? Imbes na maging mabuting tao, nagiging mapanguhsga, sunod-sunuran sa mga itaas, at manhid sa damdamin ng iba. Ang tanging gusto ay makapunta sa langit at hindi maging sandalan ng kapwa niyang umiiyak sa hinagpis.Nakokontrol na nga ba tayo ng relihiyon at kultura kung saan ang mga lalaki ang palaging namumuno? Katulad ng conclave na puro lalaki ang bumoboto, nagtatalaga ng pinakamakapangyarihang lider ng simbahan. Samantala, ang babae'y itinutulak na maging ina: tungkulin daw niya ang isakripisyo ang kanyang pangarap, ang kanyang tinig.Hanggang kailan natin ituturing na banal ang pananahimik?Kung ang pananampalataya ay pinapatahimik ang naaapi sa ngalan ng â€œkalooban ng Diyos,â€ anong klaseng pananampalataya ito?Panahon na para tanungin, hindi lang ang ating mga prinsipyo, kundi ang mga sistemang kinukupkop nito. Kaya siguro, hanggang ngayon, narito pa rin tayo. Bansang walang pinagbago.Sex. Reproductive Health. Abortion. Teenage/Child Pregnancy. Mental Health. Iilan lang yan sa taboo topics na ayaw pag-usapan ng gobyerno at simbahan. Laging sinasabi na sumunod na lang sa â€œkung ano ang batas ng Diyos.â€ Pero hanggang kailan natin patatahimikin ang mga kwento ng kababaihan, kabataan, at mga taong naghihirap sa katahimikan? Hanggang kailan ikukubli ang realidad sa likod ng doktrina?Na may mga taong humihingi ng tulong: hindi ng dasal lang, kundi ng konkretong solusyon.Ang pananahimik ay hindi kabanalan.Ang pagtugon sa tunay na pangangailangan : iyan ang may malasakit.Panahon na para pag-usapan ang mga ayaw nilang pag-usapan.
