Powerful. Authentic. Bold.Ang ganda ng film. Ang gustong ipakita ng pelikula? Ang realidad ng mga kabataang babae na hindi madalas marinig. Ang galing ni Maris. Kahit na wala siyang binabanggit na mga linya, damang dama ko yung emotion. Ramdam ko yung sakit, guilty and takot ni Shine. Yung simpleng pagtitig, paghinga, and pagbitaw ng mga linya niya ay napakasolid. Hindi pang-arte lang. Totoo. Ito na yung pinakamahusay na role ni Maris. Yung kwento, well narrated. Kakaiba siya and kailangan talaga siyang pagusapan. Ineexpose ng film na ito yung real life issues tulad ng abortion, teenage pregnancy, and stigma. Hindi pinilit ang morality, pinakita ang reality and hinayan ako na makapagdecide kung anong mafefeel ko. Ang ganda ganda ng cinematography. Super totoong totoo bawat eksena. Yung color grading, grabe ang galing. Bawat kulay saktong sakto sa bawat eksena.Super galing ni Jennica. Bilang ate hindi niya pinagalitan si Shine. Kinampihan niya kasi alam niya yung nararamdaman ng kapatid niya. Ang galing din ni Elijah. Kuha niya gigil ko. Aside from Maris, ang galing ni Annika and yung isa pang bata. Speechless lang sa performance ni Annika. Si Annika ang manifestation ng konsensiya, guilt and innocence. Nasasabi niya ang lahat ng ayaw aminin ni Sunshine sa sarili niya.Grabe yung eksena sa motel. Ang powerful. Pero grabe ang ending. Walang dramatic confrontation, walang resolution, at walang solusyon sa mga problema ni Sunshine. Pero isang bagay lang ang ginawa niya, pinili niyang magpatuloy.
Naiintindihan mo ba ako? Gets ko na. Gets ko na.

Antoinette Jadaone has always been one of the few Filipino filmmakers I deeply admire, not just for her craft, but for the way she tells womenâ€™s stories with empathy and nuance. Her work has always felt personal, films like Alone/Together, Fan Girl and now Sunshine, might just be my favorite Filipino film released this year so far.I remember seeing the trailer last year and wondering if it would even get a proper release here. It tackles such a taboo topic, one that many in this country still refuse to even speak about. Thatâ€™s why I admire Jadaone so much. Sheâ€™s chosen to talk about what others wonâ€™t. In a predominantly Catholic nation where abortion is criminalized, even in cases of rape or incest, Sunshine feels like an act of courage.Iâ€™ve always been pro-choice. I grew up surrounded by the whole â€œabortion is murderâ€ narrative, from relatives, from my old Catholic school run by nuns. But even as a kid, it never sat right with me. I never saw it as a sin. And now that Iâ€™m studying to become a doctor, that belief matters even more to me, because women deserve healthcare that doesnâ€™t judge or shame them. Sunshine affected me on a personal level because of that. It reminded me why I want to do this.Itâ€™s not a perfect film. Some might find the pacing fast or feel like it didnâ€™t say enough. But to me, the point isnâ€™t perfection. What matters is that it exists. It dares. Itâ€™s a film that opens doors, uncomfortable ones, sure, but necessary. I really hope itâ€™s not the last of its kind.

Maris plays Sunshine with so much empathy that it permeates outside the screen, her win is our win, her disappointment is our disappointment. Through the streets of Manila to the corners of her room, we get to hold hands with her and be a confidant. I like how it positions the audience as part of this journey, not as the usual bystander. One sequence that stood out is the one from the inn to the hospital - Maris lets herself be consumed by Sunshine, almost as if the creeping is part of the routine itself. The messaging gets confusing in the middle but ultimately ends in a tender moment of acceptance and determination. Iâ€™m just happy films like this finally exist in our country.

Hindi ako nahihiya. Ayokong maging nanay Needless to say dahil expected na, pero ang galing ni Maris at Jennica. That leaning-on-shoulder scene nila sa taxi ang fave kong ganung moment in Asian cinema.Natuwa ako na nandito si Angeli Bayani, bilang isang compassionate na doctor.

gets ko na. gosh what a powerful one-liner to end and encapsulate the entire progression of the film. sobrang powerful that the child gets it; she understands and respects the reasons behind Sunshine's choices, even at the expense of her own life. sobrang powerful din ng scene before the last routine, with jennica and maris, na kahit anong desisyon ni Sunshine, mage-gets ng ate niya. at ganoon din yung goal ng pelikulaâ€”na ma-gets nating lahat why people resort to abortion,â€¦

for as many times as we sit and talk about unwanted pregnancies and abortion, there is a woman out there na katulad ni sunshine na dala-dala ang bigat ng desisyong siya lang ang pwedeng gumawa. conversations regarding this matter often talk about the cause and consequences, but never once did we talk about the process women have to endureâ€” the grief, the confusion, the isolation. it was never just in black and white. hindi lang siya basta nabuntis at mas lalong hindi lang siya basta nagdesisyon. this film showed everything in between. it was an honest attempt to potray the realities women go through, a reminder that we are free to dream and we are free to live life the way we choose to.

In a Q&A with writer-director Antoinette Jadaone that I was lucky to attend, she was asked how she braced for the potential backlash of this film from Filipino audiences given our mostly conservative background. Her answer resonated with me deeply: As a writer, Jadaone believes her primary duty is to stay loyal to her characters. If her character's arc demands visiting unnerving and controversial depths, she is not afraid to take the plunge - regardless of how viewers might perceive it. Her earlier work, Fan Girl (2020), already painted a similar picture, albeit a bit spottily.Jadaone takes her boldest steps yet in her latest work, Sunshine (2024), by tackling abortion, a highly contentious subject in the country, with both sensitivity and grit. This entry is unflinching in its commentary, taking us to the most harrowing places women can be in a nation where sexual abuse is prevalent, abortion is illegal, and healthcare fails the underprivileged . Sunshine, our protagonist, is a skilled gymnast, but even she can't leap over patriarchy, tumble past outdated laws, or cartwheel her way out of the conservative society and system. In one scene, Sunshine waits along a street choked with tricycles, behind the railing of a pharmacy counter - she is jailed in and by this wretched city, made a criminal for wanting to make a choice that should be her right. But this film's Manila is more than just Sunshine's prison. It's a breathing character, trailing her around from scene to scene. Always in the backdrop but never invisible. Never speaking but always loud. A passing MRT train rattles the windows of a shabby motel. A crammed jeepney bounces to the bass of a local rap song. Grimy streets teem with hustling vendors and weary residents. Sunshine makes her choices, but her choices are only as good as this bleak, brutal city allows . Maris Racal delivers a phenomenal performance, portraying our protagonist with nuance and raw intensity. She is backed by a stellar ensemble - Jennica Garcia, Annika Co, Xyriel Manabat, and Elijah Canlas - each breathing life into characters that are authentic and vital to the film's message. The sequences are daring, the story beats sometimes violent, but always necessary. The music elevates it all, with a standout Challengers-esque score underscoring the gymnastic scenes. This film is not without its faults though, with excessive cursing (seriously, again in a Project 8 work?), somewhat awkward acting, and some unpolished plot points, but these are forgivable given how effective the complete work is.Sunshine may very well be Direk Tonet's finest work yet - and rightly so. It stands as one of the most important Filipino films in the modern times.

first time watching a screening at a cinema with the star herself (ANG GANDA MO SA PERSONAL MARIS WTF)! such a great film with brilliant creative choices all throughout. so emotional and so so real. only a female director could masterfully tell this story!edit: after the second watch, i realized how empowering and important it was to portray this story using sports as a metaphor to her bodily autonomy. everybody loves her when she uses her body to look beautiful for the world, but when mishap occurs, she is shamed for it. yet, in the end, i noticed that the last thing she declares about her pregnancy is a statement that is so bold and firm: â€œAyoko maging nanay.â€ right in front of the men who tried to control her decisions. which maybe leaves the audience to think: â€œwhat happened after that?â€ but the point is that her decision, her body, and her passion, are all unshakably hers until the end. and we see that because after that scene with miggy and his dad, she practices her routine again. and then it was so perfect-had tears in my eyes the whole time. in that gymnasium, Sunshine â€œdrowns out the noise.â€ what remains is her unwavering bond with her body, both as a woman and as a gymnast.
Let women do what they want to do with their bodies!

i was deeply moved and inspired by sunshine. what a gem of philippine cinema. you know a film is good when it makes you want to create again. however, while undeniable in its prowess and relevance, its potency and impact dwindles in its struggle to pinpoint with conviction who its target audience is. it seems to want to pander to both liberal and conservative audiences, but this muddles its message. who is this film really for? who is it in dialogue with? i thought that the choice to portray the unborn fetus as a grown, conscious being was counterintuitive at first, but then i realized the film was only trying to meet its conservative audiences halfway in their beliefs. then i thought it was a stroke of genius: of course, the only way to convince someone to change their mind is by explaining it in the terms they understand, through their perspective of the world. but then it also alienates this very audience by demonizing them in the film. while it successfully empathizes with the horrors of being a woman in the philippines, there is a lack of nuance, a dichotomy of good vs. evil, that might be more harmful than helpful in the grander scheme of things.(there are also so many scenes where maris racalâ€™s quiet yet powerful performance should have been enough, but the beauty of the moment is ruined by the â€œchildâ€ voicing out sunshineâ€™s thoughts, spoon-feeding the audience.)only particularly critical because i think sunshine is an exciting step in the right direction for ph cinema. i loved it and i think everyone should still watch it in spite of its flaws.

As someone who is always online, I often encounter issues that are difficult to discuss, to the point where I sometimes become desensitized and think, 'ahh shit, eh ganyan talaga that's life.' I knew that the main topic of this movie is abortion, and after watching the movie as a woman and a Filipino, I was reminded na hindi kasi abortion 'lang', there are so many layers to it, may it be sexual education, healthcare, and the patriarchal society weâ€¦

The tone set by Sunshine over Jadaone's previous film, Fangirl, is way different. The urgency of survival is apparent and how it clashes with the film's thematic journey, like Paul Soriano's Thelma. Though Sunshine tends to get the feel of guerrilla direction, it is a combination of the director's experiences in mainstream and her indie roots. Meaning, we get to see well-lighted scenes and less usage of shake cam.Sunshine unpacks a lot of society's ills and inequalities. Patriarchy, discrimination in the medical field, inhumane laws, and glaring social class issues that don't benefit those without that much. In a country where religion reigns, or so they say, the film easily relays problems with well-made sequences and heartbreaking results. Jadaone knows the voices of her characters, and it tells a distinct topic with passion and wit, giving the audiences a rollercoaster of emotions.One thing that makes this film unique is the inclusion of a fantastic element. It somehow references, or a styling of, what they had in Death Note anime or Big Mouth to make it more accurate. And such symbolism as Sunshine's conscience made it relatively easier to tell the film's narrative. It was smartly added, and it didn't make the audience unintelligent.The technical are overwhelmingly great. The use of lighting in urban areas, especially those scenes shot at night, is worthy of a picturesque view of the marginalized reality. We rarely see such strong shots in film. The options to use close-ups for intensity of emotions and certain decisions to make the scenes with Mariz Racal's gymnastic performance were made with careful efficiency. And the sound editing was just on point. It is technically the protagonist's in-ear audio being shared with the viewers.Jadaone's casting is really one for the books. An appreciation to Mariz Racal's graceful bookend performance. The representation is exactly what we need to see from young adults, especially in the situation of what is happening to her character. The conflict-bearers really made the sequences memorable, and it made you think of the situations presented. These aren't farfetched ideas shown in the film. Most of them are realistically sound and Piolo Pascual's short stint really is just something for us to gasp about. And we also get to see Jennica Garcia and Elijah Canlas' supporting roles to complete the ensemble.Les we forget Annika Co's strong personality. I guess we have another star made by the director. And regarding Meryll Soriano being part of the film. It made me remember how she did a similar role back in 2010, as Lizette in the Mark Meily film, Donor.Sunshine displays what needs to be said in a society when abortion is considered a taboo topic. A possible eye-opener to the current status quo. .:smcityeastortigas>>

Sunshine Francisco played by Maris Racal, is a teenage gymnast dreaming of getting in the Olympics, got pregnant by accident, and must face the moral dilemma of choosing between her dreams and keeping the baby.Maris Racal carried the film to pitch perfection and rawness. She takes you in and makes you feel her struggles. Her facial nuances and physical vigor makes her the right choice to play the titular role, in what could be a role of a lifetime. Director Antoinette Jadaone's never been more sure and absolute of her vision here. The film stands as an audacious statement in a country full of naysayers when it comes to the sensitive and controversial subject matter: abortion. The ending really made me shed a tear, in response to understanding why women do what they do. Though the film is not without its flaws. I sometimes felt the script and characters could have been more seamlessly sewn, and not just coming out of nowhere, making it feel a bit unnatural. Nevertheless, this is an essential film that needs to be seen by a wide audience. It didn't provide the answers, but this is what a filmmaker does best: to start conversations, to challenge the status quo and make us reflect our own beliefs and morals.ps. support local films, local music, local products, and local boys. eme

Some people will never understand what it feels like to be a woman.Some will never understand what it feels like to be poor.Some will never understand what it feels like to have no choiceâ€”and to only be left with the harmful one.This film carries the burden of making you feel something about these topics and it does, effectively.It does not shy away from addressing these themes. Yet at the same time, the film never forces them down the audienceâ€™s throat. These issues are real. The depiction of Manila is painfully real. The horror of what Sunshine is going through feels immediate and heavy.Gorgeously shot. Gorgeously written. Gorgeously acted. This is Tonette at her bravest. Iâ€™m excited for what comes next.

naiintindihan mo ba ako? gets ko na. gets ko na.bawled my eyes out during the last scene when she was doing her routine. kuhang-kuha ako ni Maris. ramdam na ramdam mo ang bawat emosyon na pinapakita niya. this film is beautifully executed and cuts deep. it's the kind of story no oneâ€™s ready to talk about but we need to. it speaks for the silenced, for every woman forced to carry pain quietly.alsoâ€”ang realistic din ng pagkakuha ng relationship ni Maris with her coach. grabe ang flashbacks ko as a former gymnast sa mga â€œpa-drown the noiseâ€ moments ni coach, ramdam na ramdam.

This was honestly just a sad movie. Even though you should be at least happy for Racal's character at the end. She went through hell and back just for the sake of her dream. It was a poignant (POIGNANT?!) commentary on a person's instinct to pursue one's dream and how it can lead to decisions and sacrifices to avoid compromise or delay. The other commentary is definitely about teen pregnancy/sex education/family planning in the Philippines. Despite having dramatized scenes, the burden that tolls on the characters is easily felt. Direk Tonet's writing, cinematography, directing, and overall vision really had a strong impact with this movie. Grabe talaga, its one of those films na babalikan mo in the future. I was really hoping this movie wouldn't end in a tragedy the way so much media in the Philippines has portrayed abortion in the past. I was hoping Sunshine would live a good life and thankfully, Antoinette Jadaone did just that. Sunshine shows an important and timely message. That scene when Sunshine speaks up against her pathetic boyfriend Miggy and his pastor dad that she is not ready to be a mother means so much to me. To be able to say no, I choose when this will happen to me and it is not going to happen today. Jennica Garcia's character as Sunshine's older sister is also a powerful performance. The fact that Sunshine had women helping her in her struggles gave hope that in the midst of a very religious and conservative society in the Philippines, there are women who believe that we should have the freedom and power to choose what happens to our bodies.

Every time I visit Quiapo Church, Iâ€™m always amused by the chaos outside its gates. Right beside vendors selling rosaries, crucifixes, candles, and bottles of holy water, there are stalls hawking pamparegla and other herbal concoctions said to â€œregulateâ€ missed periods. The juxtaposition is striking. Sacred and taboo, salvation and cycle, side by side like itâ€™s the most natural thing in the world. Itâ€™s absurd, hilarious, and deeply Filipino. I always find myself thinking, someone should write a story, play, or movie out of this contradiction. With Sunshine, it finally feels like someone did. Fearlessly and with heart.Itâ€™s not exactly about Quiapo, but it carries the same beautiful mess of contradictions. Faith and survival, morality and body, dream and disappointment. It dares to talk about reproductive health care in the Philippines without flinching, but itâ€™s also about more than that. Itâ€™s about the right to choose. Not just over oneâ€™s body, but over oneâ€™s future. Itâ€™s about women tired of being told to wait, to settle, to stay silent. And finally daring to want more. What makes it powerful is its quiet grace. It doesnâ€™t preach. It listens. To the unspoken shame carried by women. To the whispers exchanged in tricycle/jeepney rides and neighborhood clinics. To the dreams that keep getting deferred by the weight of economy, expectation, and morality. Sunshine is a film that sees women. Not as symbols or martyrs, but as people.Technically, itâ€™s a marvel. The cinematography captures the real Manila. Not the sepia-toned or shadow-drenched â€œpoverty pornâ€ weâ€™re so used to. No extra lighting or artificial grime smeared on walls for the sake of grittiness. No â€œdesigning poverty.â€ The production design feels lived in, never overworked. Every detail feels honest. If I have only one criticism, it's that the magical realism elements could have been woven in more seamlessly. But even that doesnâ€™t take away from the filmâ€™s quiet power.Then thereâ€™s the acting. Maris Racal delivers the role of a lifetime. Raw, honest, and quietly devastating. Jennica Garcia, whenever sheâ€™s on screen, shines. Her presence is magnetic, and together, their chemistry feels lived-in and true.In every sense, Sunshine is a landmark film. It should be our Oscar submission for next year. And if thereâ€™s any justice, it should sweep every local award. Itâ€™s not just a movie. Itâ€™s a mirror. One weâ€™ve long needed in a country as patriarchal and hypocritical as ours. The kind of mirror thatâ€™s often hard for Filipinos to look into, but impossible to ignore.

Some films entertain you. Sunshine confronts you.When the credits rolled, no one moved. No one spoke. It was that rare kind of silence. Not awkward, but sacred. As if we had all just witnessed something painfully true and didnâ€™t quite know what to do with ourselves.Because Sunshine isnâ€™t just a movie. Itâ€™s a question. A confrontation. Directed with clarity and deep compassion by Direk Tonet Jadaone, Sunshine doesnâ€™t soften its message or try to make it more palatable.. Itâ€™s brave. Itâ€™s loud in its honesty. It doesnâ€™t ask for permission to be angry or tired or vulnerable. It simply is, and thatâ€™s why it hits the way it does. And yet, somehow, even with all its emotional weight, Direk Tonetâ€™s signature humor still finds its way through. There are momentsâ€”unexpected but perfectly timedâ€”when the entire cinema bursts into laughter. Itâ€™s sharp, itâ€™s honest, and it never feels out of place. Maybe Direk Tonet makes us laugh because she knows weâ€™ll cry eventually. Or maybe thatâ€™s just how we are as Filipinos, finding humor even in the heaviest moments, because sometimes, itâ€™s the only way we know how to carry the pain.What makes this film even more powerful is how it gives voice to things we often overlook. As someone who isnâ€™t a woman, I know I canâ€™t fully grasp the weight of that experience. But this film opened a window for me. A clear, honest glimpse into a reality I will never live, but need to see. Much of that power comes from the performances. Maris Racal, as Sunshine, delivers the most vulnerable and grounded work of her career. Her pain is quiet, but it radiates. You feel it in the way she holds her breath between words, in the weight behind her gaze. Jennica Garcia, as her sister, is just as affecting. Her stillness, her softness, the way she listens. She becomes a reflection of what the film asks of us: to pause, to witness, to respond with care. Thereâ€™s a moment near the end that stuck with me. Sunshine asks, â€œGets mo na ba ako?â€And while itâ€™s said to the person in the room, it felt like she was looking straight through the screen, asking us, the viewers. And like that person beside her, I hope we all have the courage to say: Yes. We see you. We understand.Please, Direk Tonet, keep making films like this (inutusan pa nga). Keep telling stories that hold space for women to be everythingâ€”loud and quiet, strong and hurting, tired and brave. Stories that make people feel seen.Gets kita, Sunshine.

what does it mean to want something just for yourself, when everyone else thinks they know better?sunshine is about what happens when a girl becomes a symbolâ€” of shame, of failure, of something to fix. itâ€™s about how the world will rally for gold medals but stay silent when a young woman says, iâ€™m not ready.this isnâ€™t just a film about abortion or teenage pregnancy. itâ€™s about the grief of losing the life you fought for before you ever got to live it.all throughout the film i kept thinking: would i have chosen differently if i were in her place?well, that's the point. the choice should be mine. even if it haunts me. even if no one else understands what that could mean.and sunshine, with all her fears and defiance, she reminds us: there is no right way to fight for your life.only your way.

Gets ko na. I am studying MA Women and Development. I always mention yan dahil di naman ako pinanganak na babae. Pero I feel feminine enough to be a woman. Sa tanan ng pagaaral ko ng kurso ko, andami ko na ring mga babaeng nakasalamuha. Yung feeling ko dito sa pelikulang to ay parang nakausap at nakaharap ko na si Sunshine. Sa mga babaeng nakausap ko, nakadaupang palad ko, natulungan ko, andun si Sunshine. Sa mga babaeng nagtuturo sa akin kung paano maging mas mabuting tao at mas mabuting babae o binabae, andun yung ate ni Sunshine, andun si Mary Grace, andun yung tricycle driver, andun yung hotel receptionist, nasa atin lang silang lahat. Sa buong sinehan sa Sta. Mesa, ako lang ata ang mugto ang mata na lumabas sa sinehan, di ko alam dahil siguro ramdam ko ang danas nila, dahil siguro yung mga nababasa ko sa klase ay totoo nga, at dahil siguro, yung pagkabigo ko sa bawat hakbang or lecture or recitation na naranasan ko sa loob ng dalawang taong pagbabagong hubog ko ay nagkaroon na ng isang imahe. Siguro yung iyak ko dahil sa tapang rin na sana meron ako, na sana meron tayong lahat, kasi yung laban natin, maraming maraming pagsubok pa na dadanasin, taong kukutya, at mga lalaking gagapi, pero sa kabilang dako, alam nating tayo tayo lang rin ang magkakakampi. Ako si Sunshine, tayo si Sunshine. Kaya naiintindihan ko na.

kung gagawan ng hirarkiya ang mga karapatan ng tao sa pilipinas, mula sa laging nabibigyang atensyon sa madalas naisasantabi, kasama sa laylayan ang kababaihanâ€”baka hindi lang sa pilipinas, malamang sa buong mundo.isa sa sentro ng pelikula ang reproductive health at aborsyon. isang maselang usapin sa isang bansang ilang siglo nang sadlak sa ideolohiya ng katolisismo, isang bagay na pilit pumipiit sa mga batas na dapat ay nagsisilbi sa lahat ng pilipino at hindi sa iilan lamang. sobrang pait makita ang depiksyon ng mga batang babaeng nais lamang kumawala sa tanikalang hindi naman sila lamang ang may gawa, ngunit sila lamang ang nagdurusa. nanliliit na sila sa lipunang mababa ang tingin sa mga batang ina, nanliliit pa sila sa sistemang iniwanan silang mag-isaâ€”sabi nga sa pelikula, krimen ang aborsyo.hugas-kamay pa ang doktor, na nangakong sumagip ng buhay nang matanggap ang kanyang lisensyaâ€”isang bagay na dinahilan para hindi tulungan ang nag-aagaw-buhay na si mary grace. naiintindihan ko na sistematiko ang pagkukulang, pero hindi ba may mali pa rin? hindi ko masisi ang doktorâ€”mahirap mawalan ng trabaho sa pilipinas. lalong hahaba ang listahan ng biktima ng kahirapan. pasalamat na lang sa mga doktor na tulad ni doktor helena. hindi ko maisantabi ang subtext na babae din siya. sino pa ba ang tutulong sa kapwa babae kundi babae rin? habang umaagos ang luha ko sa sinehan, pinagdarasal ko ang mga totoong taong nagbubuntis ngayon at nagnanais ng kalayaan. sana ligtas sila. sana makamit nila ang buhay na kanilang inaasam-asam.nasa puso ng istorya, para sa akin, ang pangarap. simula't sapul, sa pagbubukas ng kwento, pambungad na ang pangarap ni sunshine na maging isang olympian. ubos-lakas at buong tapang niyang linalakbay ang daan patungo dito. sa likod niya ang kaniyang pamilya, coach, at matalik na kaibigan. sa salaysay ng kwento, halos hindi mahalagang bahagi ng buhay niya ang ama ng kaniyang dinadalaâ€”nagkataon na lang na naging bahagi siya ng kwento. isang gabing pagkakamali na naiwasan sana kung mayroon matibay na reproductive health education sa bansa. isa sa mga pagkukulang ng mga institusyong nagsisilbi dapat sa nakararami, hindi ng mga bata. pero sa kanila pa rin ang sisiâ€”sabi nga ng tindera sa botika, kung anu-ano na ang ginagawa ng mga bata ngayon. kilala ba niya si sunshine? hindi. alam ba niya na atleta si sunshine? hindi. pero pambungad pa rin ang panghuhusga.isa pang bahagi ng opresyon ni sunshine ang pagiging bata. nabanggit ko kamakailan ang isa sa mga agam-agam ko na marahil ay hindi natin napapansin masyado, pero marahil ay nagagawa din natin paminsan. ang mga micro-aggression sa mga bataâ€”kesyo maingay sila, kesyo hindi pa nila alam ang ginagawa nila, kesyo bakit kayo nandito? pero huminto man lang ba tayo para isipin kung ano ang lagay nila? simula ng pandemya, lalong lumiit ang espasyong ginagalawan nila kung saan dapat silang makihalubilo at matuto kasama ang mga kaedad nila. saan ba sila dapat lumugar? nasaan ang pamilya nila? nasaan ang komunidad na dapat kumalinga sa kanila?sanga-sanga ang problemang pilit inilahad ng sunshine, pero hindi ko na palalayuin pa. pakiwari ko, alam naman ng lahat kung gaano kalalim ang mga isyu sa pilipinas. hindi lang natin alam paano magsisimulang solusyonan ito.ibabalik ko sa pangarap. lahat ng tao: minsan, hanggang ngayon, lagiâ€™t-lagi, ay may tangan-tangang pangarapâ€”maliit man o malaki. isa itong krus na boluntaryo nating binibitbit hanggang sa makamit natin ang patimpalak o kaya naman ay pansamantalang binibitawan para sa iba pang mga pangarap.puso ng pelikula si sunshine na nais maging olympian. nakakatuwang makita ang paninindigan niyang makamit ito anuman ang mangyari. kanya-kanya tayong may mga isinakripisyo para sa pangarap. nakakatuwang hindi niya isinakripisyo ang sarili para lamang sa iisipin ng ibaâ€”para sa ano ang 'tama' sa tingin ng tao at ng 'diyos'. naiintindihan ng 'diyos' niya kung bakit niya kinailangang gawin ang mga bagay na ginawa niya. mapagpatawad ito. nakapagpatawad na rin ang bata sa imahinasyon niya. naiintindihan niya na para maging olympian sila ni sunshine, dapat siyang magpaalam. isang malalim na pagmamahal ang pinakita ni sunshine sa pelikula, sa kabila ng lahatâ€”pagmamahal sa sarili, pagmamahal sa pangarap, at pagmamahal sa buhay, sa buhay na nais niyang buuin para sa kanya.sa loob ng isang oras at kalahati, napakalalim at napakagandang nailatag ng pelikula ang mga tunay na kwentong ito. napakagaling ng bawat aktor na nagbigay-buhay sa mga karakter na base sa mga totoong tao. kulang ang isang beses na panonood para makuha pati maliliit na detalye na sigurado ay mahalaga. kailangang panoorin. kailangang panoorin uli. kailangan natin ng mas marami pang gantong kwento sa pelikula. bigyang-boses muna sila hanggang marinig na din natin ang kanilang totoong mga tinig.

Ang ganda ng film na â€˜to. Ang ganda ng cinematographyâ€”ramdam mo kung gaano kagulo sa Metro Manila. Ang galing ni Maris. I think she solidified her place as one of, if not the best, Filipina actress in her age group right now (wag nyo lang panoorin ang Sosyal Climbers). Solid ng range niya sa pag-arte. May mga eksena ditong ramdam na randam mo talaga yung sakit na pinapasan nya (emotionally at physically).Gayunpaman, may mga detalye pa ring medyo di nag-klik para saâ€™kin. May mga creative choices sa plot na questionable depende sa kung saang spectrum ka sa abortion debate. If pro-abortion ka tulad ko, magigets mo â€˜to.Overall, a very timely film considering na sobrang conservative nga ng Pilipinas pagdating sa issue na â€˜to. Brings to light the unfair challenges women must face just to have autonomy over their own bodies.Feeling great. Andami kong napanood na Filipino films lately!

Sunshine (2024) would be a perfect double feature with Eliza Hittman's Never Rarely Sometimes Always (2020) as they both tackle similar topics but with a stark difference in privilege and access.where the latter becomes a story of sisterhood and compassion, as two girls cross state lines to get access to healthcare, Sunshine offers no such respite to our eponymous protagonist.in here, what Sunshine wants is not even a matter of choice, it is something that she is forced to bear. all alone as her confidants succumb to the stigma of her dilemma, Sunshine takes to the streets of Manila in search of a way to terminate her pregnancy.the plot moves along while the audience is served scenes of what i believe to be one of the better cinematic depictions of modern Manila. the first few minutes almost feel like an entirely different film (one i would have particularly liked more) until the plot takes a peculiar detour.in all of its realism and poignancy i found a particular element in its storytelling very out of place and oftentimes distracting. while the ending made me understand why those choices were made i just don't think a semblance of Magical Realism is the perfect vehicle for a message as heavy as this one.while i think the point that: "an entire generation of Filipino women being forced to reckon with their unborn children as if the choice of abortion is something that has to be explained, and in turn, be understood." is a step in the right direction for this nation's pro-choice discourse, the delivery just felt like it was bordering into Diary of an Unborn Child territory. with that being said, i still thoroughly enjoyed Sunshine and i would still highly recommend it. despite some of my grievances with the film, the unblemished ray of sunshine known as Maris Racal delivers a stellar performance in the titular role. perhaps even a mariesteller one. *wink* *wink*

Itâ€™s horrible for my cinephile ass out hereâ€¦This is the Happening of Filipino cinema, except itâ€™s less thrilling and more aligned with the traditional storytelling of Filipino drama.Perhaps my favorite element of this new project from Antoinette Jadaone is the contrast between morality and sin as personified by the hawker who sells abortion pills behind figures of saints beside Quiapo Church, which is arguably the most popular place of veneration among Catholic Filipinos throughout the country.Beyond that, Iâ€™m struggling to seek nuance and proper closure. What sets this work, aside from the palpable gentleness toward the female main character, apart from the many stories about abortion out there?Itâ€™s worth noting, however, that stories about women are told by women, just like what Jadaone manages to deliver here. Sunshine is going to be an eye-opener for a lot of people here in the Philippines. It doesn't just raise awareness, it confronts the daily injustices Filipino women face just for being women. This should kickstart long-overdue conversations about reproductive rights, no matter how uncomfortable they may be.Maris Racal gives a career-defining performance as Sunshine. She fully captures the vulnerability, resilience, and quiet strength of her character. She feels heartbreakingly real. The supporting cast also pulls its weight, with Jennica Garcia standing out in a big way.What I really appreciated is how the film frames everything through the lens of a deeply Catholic country. The Sto. NiÃ±o statues being sold next to illegal abortion pills and the Christmas lights in the maternity ward stick with you. They are not just background details, they feel like commentary. Birth and suffering are made sacred here, even when they come with pain, even when they are not wanted.Sometimes it feels like the film is about to lean into pro-life messaging, with "what if" hypotheticals and future-president guilt trips. But instead of reinforcing those ideas, it pulls them apart. I didn't expect it to handle such a taboo subject with this much care. Subtlety is completely thrown out the window at times, with some characters written like Facebook comment sections come to life. They are loud, caricature-like, and clearly meant to provoke. But the sad truth is that people like that exist.Without getting into spoilers, the film isnâ€™t trying to decide whatâ€™s right or wrong. Itâ€™s more interested in what it means to be understood.Heavy-handed? Sometimes. Necessary? Absolutely.So with that, we thank God for Sunshine.

The moments when our titular character, Sunshine, was hopeless and lost, the first thought that came to mind was: Thank God Iâ€™m not a woman. And as soon as I thought it, I recognized how privileged it was to even have such a thought. How easy it is to be a cis man. And because of that, Iâ€™ll never truly understand how a woman feels.But this is precisely what the film accomplishedâ€”it made me feel.Direk Tonetâ€™s writing and direction are potent and hard-hitting, while Marisâ€™ performance is just as powerful. For a film that exudes a seemingly hopeless atmosphere, with no end in sight to the worldâ€™s harshness, Marisâ€™ Sunshine shone like a light at the end of the tunnel.I hope the future is kinder to women, and I hope I get to contribute to paving the way for that future to become a reality.

I still remember when Direk Tonet shared the concept of Sunshine back in 2021 at a workshop I attended. Everyone knew it was risky, yet the story had to be told. It wasnâ€™t a question of â€œhowâ€ but â€œwhen?â€Fast forward to today, Sunshine finally lives and receives its well-deserved spotlight. Itâ€™s easy for some to dismiss it as â€œjust a film about abortionâ€. When in reality, itâ€™s a gritty portrayal of thousands of Filipinasâ€”all the dreams and lives lost, the could haves and what ifs. The fact that this film exists (in this political and social climate) is already a miracle. It being one of Direk Tonetâ€™s masterpieces is just a bonus.

My experience with this film didnâ€™t end when the credits started rolling. Walking out of the cinema and into the crowded floors of a large mall, I began to watch people with a weighted heart. The children playing. The mothers of different ages. It left me reeling and in silence for quite a bit, to the point I felt a little sorry to the company I watched the film with. That was the moment I knew this film would leave an impact for a lot of people, and could even be divisive among most of its Filipino audiences.Sunshine leaves a mark. A film that paints a very real, raw, uncomfortable, and deeply moving picture on what it is like to be a Filipino woman with a dream, a mistake, and an agency that is being challenged by those around herâ€”even by herself. It does this through depicting scenes all pointing towards the state of reproductive healthcare in the Philippines, and all those who are affected by it.Its characters are what makes the film so moving. Of course, Maris Racal does a stunning job portraying Sunshine and the characterâ€™s emotional complexity. Every character, though, has a purpose and reflects Filipino realities accurately. Perhaps the most special characters are what the film uses as a device to move the story along. At first, I felt unsure of it, but by the end of the film, it was very effective.This is a type of story that I feel, and hope, most Filipinos get to see. It is highly relevant as much as it is good. The narrative, linear structure of the film lends to the experience of the casual spectator; it builds up and comes crashing down. The scene of Sunshine being alone in the gymnasium.. is one that will stick with me for a while.I love this film. Go see it. It is so worth the â‚±270.

For a couple of years, I've lived and roamed in the kind of Manila Tonet has painted for us: busy and dirty streets of Recto and Carriedo overflowing with people trying to make ends meet, the filthy motels of Avenida filled with horny, exploitative men who need them, and the whispering neighborhood all around the tight grid-like system such as Tondo, Blumentritt, San Lazaro, Laon-Laan or Dapitan watching, staring, looking for something to make time pass.Under the watchful eyes of this condemnatory city stands a rather bright-eyed Sunshine, a young female student-gymnast trying to secure her spot in athletic competitions such as the Olympics and SEA Games. Her hard work and dedication have reflected in her routine, and her coach is confident in her skill in making it to the national team. But all of her dreams of soaring global recognition have been put to risk when one day, she discovers she is with child.What's heartbreaking about this piece is that this film is about a young woman working day and night fighting for a country who doesn't fight for her. This is a country where a woman needs to make unnecessarily drastic measures just to live a life she works hard on achieving. This is a country built on guilt and shame, yet a country proudly branded for its resilience. This is a country that veiled its dirt and its scum with the cloak of catholic morals and self-righteousness. This is no place for a sun to shine on.It's easy for me to believe in this film, because it is a true story. This is a biography, not of Sunshine and not of Tonet. This is a biography of Philippines in modern day, and for decades this has been told time and time again from the works of Lino Brocka, Ishmael Bernal, and Brillante Mendoza, to works of Kip Oebanda, Ramona Diaz, and now Antoinette Jadaone. For years filmmakers like them have hoped for a brighter future, hoped for people to open their eyes and unveil what is hidden in plain sight, and Tonet, in this incredible feat, making the movie ticket as cheap and as accessible as it can be, is reaching out to us saying "This is my country. Look and see."

The moment Sunshine opened, I felt like I was already there in her world. Thatâ€™s one of the things Iâ€™ve always admired about Direk Tonet Jadaone: how she builds these quiet, lived-in spaces that donâ€™t just exist for her characters, but completely pull you in. You donâ€™t just watch the story unfold, you feel it with Sunshine.What stuck with me the most is the way the film builds this deeply uncomfortable paradox: a country that loudly declares abortion is murder, yet leaves no room for safe options, quietly allowing dangerous pills to be sold under the table. The contradiction isnâ€™t even subtle, itâ€™s the whole point. Being a Filipino is already hard, but being a woman in the Philippines? It's brutal. The film doesnâ€™t sugarcoat anything, it throws you straight into the brokenness of it all, from healthcare to shame culture to justâ€¦ surviving.As the story unfolds, youâ€™re taken on this intense ride with Sunshine, a girl trying to make sense of what sheâ€™s going through while the world around her offers no real answers. It forces you to confront your own biases. You start to ask yourself: what would I do in her place? Whatâ€™s the â€œrightâ€ choice, really, when youâ€™re trapped in a society that only ever gives you wrong ones?Menggayâ€™s story hit like a gut punch. Itâ€™s the kind of pain thatâ€™s so real, but we never talk about because weâ€™re scared to. Menggay isn't just another casualty, at the end of it all -- she's still a kid.What I love most about the storytelling is that it doesnâ€™t preach. It makes you think, it makes you question -- but in the end, it reminds you that it should all boil down to what Sunshine feels is right. What she knows is best. It gives her that agency, that voice, something this world so often tries to take from girls like her.I've always been a fan of Maris Racal, and I agree that this is her best project yet. She didnâ€™t need to go big; her silence already said everything. And I loved how the film used gymnastics as this quiet metaphor of control, performance, and discipline all while her personal life spirals into uncertainty. Itâ€™s so smart.And I have to say: the cinematography? Stunning. Of course, the gym scenes were beautifully shot, we all expected that - but it was the motel scenes that floored me. There was something about how those moments were framed that just hit harder. Like everything was raw, exposed, still. And what really stayed with me, long after the credits rolled, was this one feeling: at the end of it all, our dreams, theyâ€™re always for the younger versions of ourselves. We fight, we keep going, because we hope theyâ€™d understand. That if we ever had to explain why we chose what we chose, theyâ€™d look at us and say, â€œgets kita.â€But the question that lingers is: are we, is this world ready for a story as brave as Sunshine?

Thereâ€™s no denying Sunshine matters - it speaks to harsh truths and tackles its themes with care and emotional honesty. The film had a timely subject, sincere writing, and phenomenal acting - Maris Racal was stellar, while Jennica Garcia delivered with quiet power. But I struggled with certain elements, particularly its attempt at magical realism. The presence of the imaginary child felt clunky, tonally jarring, and out of sync with the otherwise grounded narrative. Frankly, the character felt unnecessary - the film had already evolved past the need for her. The story had power, and I wish it had trusted its own strength without the added flourish. Ultimately, I admired its purpose more than loving its execution.

Sunshine sheds light on a topic many still avoid, the abortion and women's choices. It's not just a Philippine issue, but a global one. Sensitive as it is, this film proves it's a conversation worth having, especially with the youth. Sex education needs attention, lalo na mula sa mga nasa pwesto. The government should support this by pushing for proper education and open dialogue.Kudos to the whole Sunshine team for bringing a story like this to light, something we should be openly discussing in this day and age.

The premise was simple but the message was hard. It did not just amplify a young girl's struggle with how to handle a life-changing conflict, but it also showed how the external actors play a huge role on how things must go. The film aimed to magnify how conservative the culture of the Philippines is, in which in this modern age, some of it could be considered obsolete.Coming from someone with a short attention span, I found myself staring at the cinema screen for the whole time, even after the film ended. There were no dull parts of the film, all scenes were necessary to how the story flows.Maris Racal's portrayal was exemplary. It was a different flavor from what she was known for, and this might be the turning point to her career. I would also have to give some flowers to Jennica Garcia, even with minimal participation in the scenes, her eyes and her minimal actions spoke volumes.

In a deep personal level, saying that I like this film is an understatement. This is a well crafted story that follows a gymnast enroute of becoming an Olympian. Antoinette Jadaone is really clever in tackling a stigma with boldness and sensitivity at the same time. I really appreciate that the movie also depicts the reality and scenarios of living in Manila on a daily basis. I also appreciate the shots where the busy streets of Manila is in the backdrop. This may be an overstatement but Lino Brocka will be proud. I do not want to compare but when I was watching this movie, I remembered the late Gil Portes' classic High School Scandal starring Gina Alajar and Sandy Andolong. Its a proof that we need movies like this to be informed and educated.Maris Racal, the entire heart of the movie, humbly carried the story in her back - a teenager who got pregnant in a very religious and conservative country. This is her best one yet - humble, raw and precise. The supporting cast are great, too. Jennica Garcia's eyes are really captivating on those crucial moments. And Anika? Bruuuh, we really need to watch for that little one in the years to come.One of the best Filipino films in recent memory, Sunshine is bold, thought-provoking and relevant. Sunshine deserved all the hype and that f*cking Crystal Bear award. I am waiting for the movie's release since last year and finally, Sunshine is home! And hopefully, this will be a strong contender for the Oscars next year!Mabuhay ang pelikulang Pilipino!

Play "Perpektong Tao" by Maris Racal.Oh Diyos ko po, mapapatawad Nâ€™yo pa ba ako!!!I walked into the cinema with so much expectationâ€”and Sunshine delivered more than my expectations. This is a landmark film. A humanizing, soul-stirring, and bold piece of cinema that dares to speak truth in a country that often prefers silence and compliance.In a nation as conservative and deeply religious as the Philippines, Sunshine dives headfirst into the conversations we often whisper about, especially around the elderly and religious individualsâ€”abortion, reproductive health, sexual abuse (WITHIN the family), and the religious hypocrisy that surrounds them. One of the most powerful moments for me was when she prays to God in the middle of an abortion attempt: â€œLord, tanggalin Mo lang â€™to, babawi ako sa lahat-lahat.â€ That line aloneâ€”honest and devastatingâ€”is a statement that cuts deep into the Filipino moral paradox.Napakagaling. Maris Racal carried this film on her own, brilliantly. No awkward or cringey momentsâ€”just pure, intentional acting that hits you right in the gut. This is easily her most brilliant and mature performance to date, and I am hungry for more.Also, just to share my theory: I donâ€™t think the kids she sees represent a â€œmother figureâ€ version of herself. To me, they were the babiesâ€™ little angels, quietly watching over their mothers, protecting them, forgiving them.I laughed, I wept, I cursed out loud inside the cinema. PUTANGINANG PILIPINAS TO. We need to see this. Sunshine deserves every bit of international acclaim itâ€™s been gettingâ€”and more. And most of all: the Philippines is ready. Filipinos are ready for this conversation, for this kind of truth-telling, for this kind of art. More than a film, itâ€™s also a wake-up call. Never doubted you, Maris Racal.

Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s Sunshine is a powerful and unflinching examination of the ongoing issue of teenage pregnancy in the Philippines, anchored by a stunning breakout performance from Maris Racal. The film transcends a simple narrative, offering a poignant and necessary critique of a society grappling with deeply entrenched religious and political views that often leave young women isolated and without agency. Through its raw and unapologetic storytelling, Sunshine doesnâ€™t just present a problem. It takes a stand and demands that we, the viewers, confront it alongside its protagonist.Where the film truly excels is in its unflinching depiction of the societal and systemic failures that trap young women like Sunshine. The Philippines has the second-highest rate of teenage pregnancy in Southeast Asia, and a 2023 survey by Save the Children Philippines revealed that more than 500 adolescents become mothers each day, some as young as ten years old. Sunshine masterfully illustrates the intense personal isolation behind these numbers by using the accessible medium of sports. Read my full review here.

I have a love-hate relationship with the Philippines.My country has it all, a strong historical background and culture, beautiful agricultural sights. The Philippines shines in so many ways. This country is easy to love, but itâ€™s also easy to hate. On the other side of the spectrum, the Philippines is plagued with corruption, deeply oppressive religious standards, and many more hateful traditions and mindsets that continue to affect the Filipino people. The bare minimum is oftentimes glorified as the best that society could do for itself in the Philippines, but is to settle for less to settle for enough? This is the question that Sunshine raises. In a country that struggles to stand for its women, Sunshine did what many movies could not, it fearlessly depicted what was real and happening in our country. It showed the pure, unfiltered realities of a young, adolescent woman facing an unwanted pregnancy. The film doesnâ€™t hold back. From the infamous â€˜motel sceneâ€™ to the different women we follow in the film, direk Antoinette Jadaone fearlessly portrays the dangers a woman has to go through just to gain autonomy over their body, hopes, and dreams.Upon a second watch (this time with my mom and my cousin), I noticed something about the way Sunshine (Maris Racal) progresses in the film. She starts off as quiet. When she finds out she is pregnant, she only tells her boyfriend and her best friend. When sheâ€™s worried or angry, she conceals her emotions. She is held back. She is chained. As the film progresses, she slowly finds her footing, first through the infamous â€˜basag windshieldâ€™ scene, and then through the numerous situations she finds herself stuck in. There is a scene near the end of the film. Sunshine is practicing her routine. She is emotional, and sheâ€™s made up her mind. As she ends her routine, the ribbon falls around her body, chaining her. She has a heartfelt conversation with â€˜bataâ€™ and she breaks free from her chains, which directly leads to the ending. Nothing is holding her back, she wonâ€™t settle for less, she has had enough.There is a scene in the film between Thea (Xyriel Manabat) and Sunshine. They are at a school canteen, eating separately from each other, but through their eyes, through the way they are looking at each other, you know that they are in support of one another. In a country that fails its women, they are forced to support each other in silence.Listening to my momâ€™s thoughts and reaction to Sunshine was the best part of my experience with this film. A woman who is somewhat religious, understanding why someone would want an abortion. An emphatic moment between my mom, me, and all the Sunshines in our country. The irony of watching a film entitled Sunshine during tag-ulan season is an irony thatâ€™s hard to look past, but I think this film couldnâ€™t have come at a better time. We are settling for less. The streets are flooding, and the women in our country struggle to find the healthcare they deserve. We are chained and we are held back. When will we break free? When will we have enough? For all the Sunshines out theregets kita Sunshine, kakampi mo ako palagi.

The film exposes the moral violence meted out to women who dare to choose not to become mothers at all, in addition to theâ€¦

Why does every opinion of theirs have to be based on religion? Why do women get harshly punished for the actions of men, while they can just go on with their lives like it's nothing? "Sunshine" is one of the most important Filipino films of all time as it sheds light on the struggles of women in a conservative country that shames them for not embracing motherhood in any circumstance. It's a powerful story that teaches viewers about empathy, bravely tackling a sensitive topic about women's rights and the dangers women like Sunshine face when a country punishes them for making choices about their future instead of giving them the proper care and support they need.Director Antoinette Jadaone is a creative genius. She masterfully tells the story of "Sunshine" in a manner that opens hearts and minds. Hopefully, this movie achieves its dual purpose: To spark healthy conversations about women's health & rights and to encourage people to show kindness and understanding to the "Sunshines" of the world. Sana pagkatapos ng pelikula, mas marami ang magsasabi ng mga salitang: "gets ko na."Meanwhile, this outstanding story comes alive beautifully on screen also because of Maris Racal's strong performance. Maris slays as Sunshine especially in the quiet times she tries to mask her anxiety and appear calm when her reality is chaotic.Manifesting that this movie becomes the Philippines' entry to the 2026 Oscars.

Sunshine overflows with strong political commentary, dissecting how a society steeped in flawed systems, conservatism, and the double standards of religion and morality profoundly impacts our personal and rational choices.While some abrupt jumps between sequences occasionally pulled me out of the experience, the film was largely immersive. The casting is perfect, from Maris Racal as the titular lead, up to the pastor, whose towering arrogance embodies a patriarchal mindset, believing women are inherently reliant on men.The film allows us to fully realize the power of having a choice and making one in a world we wish were kind and harmonious. Antoinette Jadaone's best film to date, Sunshine is thought-provoking, yearning for a time when we can fully embrace and realize our choices once they're made.

The supporting characters did what they were meant to - help tell her story without stealing the spotlight.What stood out to me visually was how natural everything felt. The cinematography wasnâ€™t overly stylized, but it matched the tone and mood perfectly. Set against the harsh backdrop of Manila, the film captured that mix of grit, morality, and religion in a way that felt all too real. It opens up an important conversation about sex education, teenage pregnancy, and abortion - topics we often shy away from, but ones that need to be talked about.More than anything, Sunshine shows how hard it is to be a woman in a world thatâ€™s stuck and unforgiving. It doesnâ€™t scream its message, but it stays with you. If there really is such a thing as a â€œbest,â€ this might just be one of Jadaoneâ€™s strongest works and definitely Maris Racalâ€™s best performance yet.

We are in a limbo. So much of Philippine cinema, especially that which makes the rounds in local and international film festivals, is stuck churning out â€œgroundbreakingâ€ firsts. Because our cultural discourse is so behind, our filmmakers are tasked not only with telling stories, but also with inventing the stories to be told. Theyâ€™re required to stake out new thematic ground, not in service of aesthetic evolution, but simply to keep up with the global conversation. The cost of this is a cinema that often feels overburdened with didactic intent and undernourished in emotional and formal rigor.In a particularly polarizing gesture, Jadaone introduces a hallucinated child character, a device that indirectly echoes Jojo Rabbit (2019). But this choice results in jarring tonal shifts that muddle the filmâ€™s emotional center. What was perhaps intended as farce to illustrate inner turmoil instead dilutes the stakes, softening the thorniness of the subject matter with a cartoonish detour. Itâ€™s an interesting idea but one that never quite coheres with the rest of the filmâ€™s pro-choice sensibility. In fact, by personifying an unborn child as a character which speaks and thinks, then Sunshine unintentionally reinforces the very moral framing that anti-abortion rhetoric thrives on. It circles back into the age-old â€œwhen does life begin?â€ debateâ€”a question that continues to paralyze policymaking in the country, even when the conversation should be about autonomy, access, and proper healthcare. The film doesnâ€™t just inherit this moral hang-up; it stages it, literalizes it, and in doing so, muddies the clarity of its own politics. Whatâ€™s more revealing than the film itself is the discourse surrounding it: a ubiquity of gender-essentialist and bioessentialist defenses, as if any critique of any form is automatically a threat to representation. That instinct: to guard a filmâ€™s cause rather than evaluate its craft just proves how far behind we are as a nation in talking about gender politics in filmmaking. The refusal to embrace genuinely revolutionary tactics, whether in politics or art, has kept us coasting on the optics of progress ever since.Full review for the Kinoise Substack published here

Sunshine is the product of the environment that failed her. It's an excellent movie that's blatantly shows how women are being boxed with limited rights and decisions in their lives with her being a young gymnast who is forced to weigh her personal dreams against societal expectations. What makes the film compelling is how honest and raw it is which made it difficult and easy to digest at the same time. It's difficult to digest since the film doesn't sugarcoat nor romanticize, it confronts. It slaps us with the reality that our system is really crooked when it comes to having the options such as abortion which draws you into Sunshineâ€™s emotional turmoil. It's also easy to sort out as well as the film itself utilized a lot of symbolism and metaphor that's very comprehensible to the young audience since it was depicted in way of being simple and straightforward.This is the kind of film that should have been made long ago. Its themes were not only relevant, but urgent not only within the country but the world. Sunshine deserves to be shown in schools, especially for young women who are still learning to navigate their autonomy and choices in a culture that often denies them both.All I can say is that Sunshine is not just a film, it's a conversation starter, a one we desperately need.P. Sunshine isn't afraid to show what it truly means to be a woman in the modern world. In a society where your choices are often shamed, imposed, or forced into the very core of your identity, Sunshine remains steadfast in her decisions. We are too unforgiving towards womenâ€”too critical, too much of everything. And for a 19-year-old girl simply wanted to chase her dream, who are we to shame her for the choices she takes pride in?The film is heavy, filled with thrilling sequences and beautiful picturesque cinema that adds an insightful edge to its narrative. It doesn't shy away from the realities of living in Manila, where everything is muddy, dreary, and dried in irony. It reminded me at different tangents of Black Swan and Manila in the Claws of Lightâ€”a woman haunted by the consequences of her actions while navigating Manila's streets with weary kindness and understanding.All I can say is, "Gets ko na." Sobrang gets ko. Each of our choices is valid and every human experience is nuanced. Puno't dulo ng pelikula ay kababaihan, at sana mas marami pa makapanood nito.
Ang tunay na pelikula ay matapang.

In a country where a uterus can feel like a prison, Sunshine breaks through the silence with a scream.This is not just a filmâ€”itâ€™s a rebellion against a system that punishes Filipinas for daring to survive.What a fearless and necessary filmz Sunshine dares to confront a brutal reality in a country where abortion remains illegal and where womenâ€™s rights are often reduced to whispersâ€”silenced by false morality and systemic neglect.Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s storytelling isnâ€™t just intimate; it is a searing indictment of how the state and even the healthcare system fail Filipinas. This film reminds us that every choice a woman makes is shaped by power structures that shame her, control her body, and turn compassion into judgment. Through Sunshineâ€™s journey, we see how being a woman in the Philippines means living in a constant struggle for autonomyâ€”ang hirap maging babae, pero mas triple ang hirap ng mga babae dito sa Pilipinas.Sunshine is not just a movie; it is a mirror held up to a society that polices womenâ€™s bodies while abandoning them in their most vulnerable moments. Itâ€™s a rallying cry for the Sunshines, Theas, Helenas, Geleens, and Edens of this countryâ€”voices we must hear, stories we must protect.May this film be the turning point for our generation: progressive, pro-women, and unapologetically pro-choice.Thank you to the entire Sunshine team and SM Cinemas for making this powerful narrative accessible by lowering ticket prices. This is cinema with a purpose.

Maris Racal is astonishing as she gives a star-making performance in Antoinette Jadaone's finest film yet. Sunshine takes us by the hand in a bustling Quiapo that's full of hypocrisy, contradiction, and a brutal system on women and their bodies. It's a random odyssey of a woman trying to take back what is her's in an unforgiving conservative society. In the film's opening moments, we see an ambitious athlete confused and paralyzed with the news of her untimely pregnancy. She's scared and she's prolonging the agony of confronting the inevitable. One thing that some people may ask is, why doesn't she immediately ask anyone for help? Doesn't she have a family? Why is she trying to deal with such a serious problem on her own? Is this the society that we've grown into? Where a young woman is so afraid and paralyzed to get any help that she risks her life trying to deal with it on her own? The answer is a resounding YES. We are living in a country where dominant beliefs and religion are shoved down in women's throats even if it means giving up their dreams. Where young women are scorned and defined by their mistakes instead of being educated and getting a strong support system. Most egregiously, we live in a society that stigmatizes and punishes women but tolerates the very system, and actions that led to their unwanted pregnancies. That is the society that Jadaone perfectly paints in this harrowing film. Jadaone uses Quiapo as the backdrop to tell this story as she blends elements of neorealism and magic realism. This film has a great sense of place as Sunshine roams around a Quiapo that hides hypocrisy underneath its Catholic cathedral. Jadaone goes full Brocka mode through these scenes as she showcases different communities and people through a neorealist lens. That's why I found the film's surrealist tendencies to be a little bit jarring. Sunshine encounters a kid that appears only through her consciousness and it really makes you wonder if this type of storytelling fits the themes that Jadaone is exploring. It just runs the risk of making it too melodramatic and undercutting its authenticity. But what keeps it from going off the rails is her unwavering compassion and understanding of Sunshine's plight. Direk Tonet did mention in the Q&A session after that she swore that she was gonna hold Sunshine's hands and be by her side through every turbulence she'll face while writing this movie. In the film's third act, the neorealist and magic realist narratives just blend into a powerful, poignant, and profound moment while Sunshine practices her routine one last time. I think this is a film that our country desperately needs right now. It's bound to spark debates and fruitful discussions about abortion, reproductive health, and women's right. Some may disagree with what Sunshine ended up doing, but at least this is a film that ignites a discussion for these taboo topics. I will never know how it feels to be a woman in an unfairly conservative country. But this film rings with so much vitality, bravery, and honesty that I just cried by the end of it. This is so damn close to being a masterpiece. Gets ko na!

Maybe most ingenious about Sunshine is its willingness to accept the decision to abort likely also involves a negotiation with the unborn child, maybe even a plea for forgivenessâ€”less from God, because getting that would be easy, and in fact Sunshine gets it out of the way early on, but more from who the child would have been. For the film indeed that is the longer battle, and it affords Sunshine a long array of events that could make the explaining easier. She sees her dilemma reflected in the city's decay, her choiceâ€”which she readily makesâ€”put into perspective, rounded out, by another girl's inaccess to that choice. Very carefully, and backed by research, Jadaone dissects what that choice may mean for women like Sunshine in a developing city like Manila, where dreams are scarce and their fulfillment even rarer. Sunshine's choice is an act of self-determination, in a world where that's seen as vulgar, irreverent: that is clear. But to what should reverence be owed, in any case? Sunshine argues it's simply a matter of priority. When Sunshine chooses her dreamâ€”which she's been carrying in her womb longer than she's known her unborn child's ghostâ€”we empathize with her, as does the ghost. That shows the filmâ€™s executed its heavy work.

If thereâ€™s anything that is uniquely Filipino in terms of interior design, itâ€™s the green walls. It generally evokes feelings of tranquility and harmony, but Jadaoneâ€™s latest film flips it around to signify chaos and dysfunction. The color is almost everywhere, itâ€™s inescapable: the walls of the protagonistâ€™s home, the sterile and hostile clinic spaces, even the motel where the filmâ€™s lead almost died, comparable to the grip Catholicism has on the Philippines. While they say thereâ€™s a separation between the church and the state, itâ€™s barely upheld in practice, as they hinder human rights that could save thousands of lives. And yes, I am talking about abortion laws, or the lack thereof here in my country. Jadaoneâ€™s Sunshine addresses the huge elephant in the senate, as it depicts the life of its titular lead (Maris Racal), whose life is turned upside down due to a sudden news of her own pregnancy. Itâ€™s easy to blame women like Sunshine for getting pregnant. After all, sheâ€™s presented as a domineering figure in her sport, even bound to compete in the Olympics, and she technically practiced unsafe sex, but not every case of unwanted pregnancy is like that.There are multiple shots where Sunshine is physically separated by a fence-like barrier: be it the metal gates in the church, the ever-stretching horizontal jeepney rails, or the cold and black window frames, that subtly signal how Filipinas are imprisoned by their surroundings. Almost every gratingly infuriating, thought-provoking, and ludicrous dialogue circles back to one simple question: why is it that women are the ones penalized and restricted on matters that could jeopardize their own health and safety, especially in pregnancies caused by rape and incest?While watching, I was constantly reminded of a film with similar thematic points, that of Hittmanâ€™s Never Rarely Sometimes Always, and how women need to be discreet, travel thousands of miles, and suffer in silence over matters that should be openly discussed and not considered taboo or immoral. If anything, I think this film is being highly censored in the Philippines, as the movie review board slapped an R-16 rating on a film that should be watched by teenagers. How can we avoid teenage pregnancies when our government avoids talking about practicing safe sex to the right demographic? Not everyone gets a happy conclusion like Sunshine did, so I hope that this film sparks a necessary conversation about womenâ€™s rights outside of the walls of movie theaters. Jadaoneâ€™s Sunshine is truly one of the Philippinesâ€™ best releases of the year so far, in both its themes and execution, and a must-watch for all types, especially men and the religious-alike. We watched Sunshine yesterday, July 24, during the block screening at SM Megamall. I had seen the trailer beforehand, so I knew we were in for something bold, something necessary. But I wasnâ€™t prepared for how deeply it would sit with me long after the credits rolled.I didnâ€™t cry while watching the film, but once it ended, I found myself overwhelmed. The weight of Sunshine doesnâ€™t hit all at once â€” it lingers, it settles. And it stays.At its core, Sunshine is the story of a woman taking control of her body in a society that keeps telling her she isnâ€™t allowed to. Itâ€™s not simply about one choice, one moment, or one woman. Itâ€™s about the collective experience of many Filipinas who navigate a system that consistently fails to hear them.Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s direction doesnâ€™t shy away from discomfort. She faces it head-on, inviting the audience to confront the silences weâ€™ve learned to live with - about abortion, reproductive rights, the stigma around sexuality, and the lack of access to informed sex education in the Philippines.Sunshine is timely, urgent, and painfully real. It gives voice to the cry of our generation, echoing the need for progressive reforms that protect women and children. The film challenges its viewers not just to empathize, but to act.As a viewer, I left the cinema not only moved, but also awakened. Sunshine isnâ€™t here to entertain. Itâ€™s here to disturb, to provoke, and to push us into uncomfortable yet necessary conversations.To my fellow Filipinos: letâ€™s not turn away. Letâ€™s create spaces where women can speak freely, where choices about their bodies are met with compassion, not judgment. Letâ€™s demand that our lawmakers stop treating reproductive health as taboo.To filmmakers and storytellers: keep telling these stories. We need more films like Sunshineâ€”bold, unapologetic, and grounded in truth. The personal is political, and cinema has the power to move both heart and policy.Let Sunshine be a beginning. Let it be a spark. And letâ€™s keep the conversation going.

Walang Sunshine sa mundong patas.Hindi ko mapigilang ihalintulad ang Maynilang ipinapakita ng Sunshine sa Maynila na kung saan nakilala si Lino Brocka. Amoy mo ang malamayang usok ng mga sasakyan at hindi mo na ito kailanman malabas sa iyong sistema. Mahapdi ang tirik ng araw sa balat. Ramdam mo ang pawis sa balikat ng bawat kasalubong na para bang ramdam mo na rin ang bitbit nilang bigat. Rinig mo ang ingay ng mga umiiyak na sanggol sa kapitbahay at pati ang nakabibinging busina ng tren na dumadaan sa Avenida. In a Quiapo churchyard, abortion pills are sold right across the â€œabortion is a sinâ€ signages. In a cramped hospital, the doctor who preaches their kind and merciful God is the same one who will shame you until you are forced to say Iâ€™m sorry, God, repenting a thousand times not to a benevolent being, but to a woman in a coat. Four women, round bellies squeezing against each other, share only two small hospital beds. Hundreds more in that one tiny room, some whose dreams never saw the light of day. Iâ€™ve had two girls already. Youâ€™re so lucky that your child is a boy. The horrifying realization that 13 isnâ€™t even the youngest of them.Hindi mabait ang mundo, at mas lalong hindi sayo mabait ang mundo kung babae ka. But sometimes, it takes just a sliver of warmth to remind you that you are not alone. The kind that comes from the ate sa botika who hands you a pregnancy test without judgement. The kind that comes from your best friend texting they love you right when you donâ€™t know if youâ€™re making the right choice. Or the kind that comes from the gentle caress of a young girl bleeding out, telling you she does not want to die in the back of a police car. How you can sense that the fear in her voice is also the one that crept up on you days before, as the motel lady put you in tricycle telling the driver to hurry to the hospital. Iâ€™ve always found the word â€œateâ€ to be a strong signifier of the tight the bonds between Filipina women. We may not know each other, but we know that we carry similar burdens. Call a woman ate and their heads turn with instinct. The film does not only show you the grim, unrelenting, cruel Manila that takes (and claws) more than it gives. Nor does it exclusively show you the girlhood that was stolen from you by the capitalistic and patriarchal structures so deeply embedded in society.Yes, it shows you that. It does not hold back from showing you how tiresome it is to clean the poo of a newborn or how much more easy it is to find empathy in illegal markets than it is in public institutions. Yet, what it also shows you is that whenever you feel like a lone speck of light in the dark, just call an ate. Ask them for help. Rest on their shoulders. You are all each of you has. The film itself does its job of telling an important story beautifully. One of the key narrative devices may be a bit too on the nose for some viewers, but I find that it adds a sort of tangibility and gravity to the story that otherwise would have been missing some heart and soul without it. Tonetâ€™s directing is sharp and focused on such visceral and visual contradictions. Racal is bursting with passion and rageâ€¦vulnerableâ€¦and stellar. Everyone from her coach and older sister down to the younger kids our titular character meets held so much weight in their portrayals. Noong pinapanood ko, ang nasa isip ko, tunay na tao â€˜tong mga pinapanood ko. Walang Sunshine sa mundong patas. Ngunit, hindi patas ang mundo natin. Kaya mabuti nalang at may pelikulang ganito (in a country where abortion is illegal, at that). Mabuti nalang na sa bawat lalaking kagaya ni Miggy at Bobot na nagdidesisyon para sa buhay ng kababaihan, may mga katulad ni Sunshine na hindi takot i-reclaim ang kababaihan niya. Walang sino man ang makakapagdikta kung ano ang pagiging babae para sa atin. Higit tayo sa mga desisyong pinili para sa atin.Pangarap ko rin ang mga pangarap mo, Sunshine.

Maris Racal turns in an inspired peformance as a gymnast with dreams of competing in the Olympics. In the end, the film makes a strong statement that this could be the new breed of Filipinas, hardworking and capable of greatness. If the problem can fixed, then the country should be better off. Recommended viewing.
