Bakit? Nanay ba kita? Gut-wrenching and brave, Sunshine speaks truth with honesty and feminine rage in a heartbreaking story of womanhood, a character study that puts a young woman, an aspiring Olympian in the most harrowing ordeal â€” pursue her dreams or let go of it, continue her pregnancy or terminate it. In a country where traditions and conservatism plague our sociopolitical landscape, and at a time where the world at large is being corrupted by right-wing fundamentalists, Sunshine stands with a strong pro-choice message; that women should have the rights to bodily autonomy despite the patriarchal structures that harp on religious preachings in which our women have to pay social costs or worse, their own lives and safety. At the center of it is Sunshine, played by the brilliant Maris Racal whose tenacious yet delicate character work put so much layers to a heartfelt protagonist. In the first 10 minutes alone, Racal delivered a string of unbridled emotions, from being flushed with regret, anger and desperation, she grew with intensity, defiance and vulnerability. Her resolve is one of strength and a moving emotional core thatâ€™s unshakeable while being present in every turn in Sunshineâ€™s dilemma in which we met the most colorful and textured cast of unusual characters. Even with Racalâ€™s stellar lead performance, every supporting actor also put on a remarkable stamp that not only served their scenes but also the entire story. From Jennica Garcia to Annika Co to Elijah Canlas to Meryl Soriano to Xyriel Manabat to Angeli Bayani to Rhed Bustamante to Piolo Pascual, itâ€™s perfectly casted and Jadaone made sure that they deliver a well-calibrated turn for Sunshineâ€™s story. A chilling and entrancing dissection of womanhood, the film shifts gears as a sports movie to a melodrama injected with some satire, absurdity, and a mystical element, itâ€™s full of inspired creative choices that are in full concerto. With its spectacular cinematography and production design from drab and somber interiors with a hint of natural light or sometimes depressing fluorescent light, to neon-tinged urban areas where chaos lingers just around the corner while also capturing Sunshineâ€™s extraordinary close-ups behind window railings that cage her or framed by her vibrant pink ribbon; its outstanding sound design that puts Sunshineâ€™s inner turmoil at the center of a noisy Manila and blends a surrealist element to its heart; and a formidable original music that juxtaposes Sunshineâ€™s personality from her life as an gymnast to her personal life. Sunshine is an urgent film that needs to be seen and heard, thereâ€™s power in its universality and Tonet Jadaoneâ€™s feminist voice soars with an elevated storytelling. Beaming with Filipino sensibilities and humour, its melodrama is used with beautiful intent while being grounded and playing with raw emotional reactions from the cast, and levity and grit in its screenplay. And as cliche as it sounds, itâ€™s a totally different Jadaone that made this movie. Thereâ€™s maturity that put her titular character at the center of a well-crafted film but thereâ€™s this restraint we havenâ€™t seen before that refined the storyâ€™s message without ever being didactic. Undoubtedly, her best film yet, an opus that cements her place as an important voice in Philippine cinema but also a landmark film that tackles subject matters that only a handful of Filipino filmmakers have touched on. An absolute achievement in todayâ€™s climate of Filipino cinema, thereâ€™s power in its tone and its themes â€” a protest that exposes controlling hypocritical men and medical professionals, and an interrogation of a systemic inequality full of governmentâ€™s shortcomings in giving proper care and support for unwanted pregnancies, in a place where poverty and overpopulation have been a decade-long problem. But also in Sunshine, we found hope and her light in confronting her reality while finding women who helped and listened to her, a kind of feminism that celebrates sisterhood even in the most horrifying circumstance in a womanâ€™s life. With high hopes, this should spark a conversation about womenâ€™s struggles and rights. In light of the overturning of Roe v Wade in the US, akin to Never Rarely Sometimes Always, Sunshineâ€™s story is real and rampant in the PH, and as disturbing as it sounds, unsafe abortion have been killing 1 in 3 Filipinas each day. â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”This reminded me of a podcast conversation I once listened to about a woman talking to her mother at a time sheâ€™s getting to know her more as an adult. Sheâ€™s learning about her momâ€™s history and asked her if her mother ever wondered about living that life instead of having her. Of course the mother responded that sheâ€™s happy that sheâ€™s born and sheâ€™s her child. To which she replied with, â€œif I didnâ€™t happen, YOU would have been born.â€I think motherhood is beautiful but do you ever wonder what kind of woman your mother would have been if society gave them the rights to choose or their religion didnâ€™t make them to aspire to fit into a mold of a woman? Maybe she could have been a president or she could have invented the cure to HIV/AIDS? Who knows?

Too often, films about abortion fall into the trap of emotional manipulation, when they push a specific agenda, reducing a complex issue to a simplistic, black-and-white narrative. But Sunshine rises above that pattern.Instead, the film offers a nuanced portrayal of the struggles (and even rage) experienced by women who are denied access to reproductive healthcare - told with such compassion and delicacy that you cannot help but empathize with and root for Sunshine because the conservative society has failed her. I hope many people get to watch the film because it is both a deeply personal and universal story that casts a light on one of the most pressing crises in the country: teenage pregnancy. And I also hope Sunshine ushers in a healthy and open conversation because women deserve the right to make decisions for themselves. This is the kind of film Iâ€™ll be thinking for days kasi ang bigat pero napaka-cathartic panoorin. And it features a talented (and reliable) ensemble of actors - napakahuhusay ng lahat, lalo na ng mga kababaihan.

I knew this would be important, but I did not think writer/director Antoinette Jadaone would go this hard! I truly, truly appreciate the commitment.This is a perspective that has long since needed to be shared. These are the stories that need to be told! It sent out a message, not by preaching, but by showing different realities faced by many, and trusted the audience to come to their own conclusions.If the reactions in the cinema were any indication, this has already started a conversation. I'm seeing posts on Reddit from people who have been through some of the same or similar situations. I hope it keeps people talking until the things that need changing finally change for the better.Beautiful work. Powerful message.Thank you for telling these stories.

Direk Tonet Jadaone holds a mirror up in the middle of Quiapo and asks the question: what is the proper protocol to take control of your life? Does the prayer come before or after the abortifacient? Does the boyfriend have to take it too? Sunshine, as a film and as a character, is bold and unwavering. She doesn't preach or ask for pity. She doesn't beg for the forgiveness of her boyfriend or the religious. The story is clear all through out -- Sunshine has made her decision, and while she seeks understanding, she seeks it only from those who matter, not from the audience and definitely not from the holier-than-thou.While Sunshine embarks on her journey to find answers, we never forget what she is -- a young girl in the Philippines, left to deal with the consequences of an unplanned pregnancy alone. It is so easy to put the blame on women or on impulsive, lustful teenagers, but the film reminds us that in a country where religious biases trump teenage pregnancy and maternal mortality rates, pointing fingers helps no one. The film reminds us that for women and other marginalized sectors, the first line of defense against systemic neglect is community.Brave and unfiltered, I can easily see Sunshine becoming a Filipino classic. What a beautifully written, directed, and acted film. This is Direk Tonet's best so far, and definitely a career-defining performance for Maris Racal. Gets ko na. Gets na gets.

Heavy raindrops were like meteorites landing on the pockmarked pavements of Manila when we braved two storms to catch the screening of Sunshine. Our tuktuk carried only three passengers: me, my partner, and another manâ€”seven people short of the usual full ride as it had been a week of rain with flooding which meant classes and government work were cancelled. When it rained harder, our driver couldnâ€™t help but mutter Tama na. Gutom na kami.Itâ€™s hunger borne out of poverty that limits, if not entirely removes, the access of ordinary Filipinos to watch important films such as Sunshine. Like any other works of art attempting to feature parts and parcels of Philippine society, etched on its tapestry is the signature Manila mayhem: masikip, mabaho, maingay and magulo.But the structure of the film is far from chaotic despite the complicated and challenging subject Direk Antoinette Jadaone took upon herself to flesh out. The stakes were high and indeed pushed the protagonist to do what she thought needs to be done. Her point was clear and warranted no further elaboration. Maris Racal was stellar in her portrayal of an aspiring Olympian who got pregnant at the blossoming of her career as a young athlete. The same can be said about the equally astounding young actress Annika Co who was a perfect foil to Racalâ€™s character.The film, with its shorter than usual run time of barely an hour and a half minutes, didnâ€™t hold back in driving its message, leaving nothing open for interpretation. Towards the end where Sunshine was performing her routine, I thought for a moment that her beaming towards the camera with her majestic ribbon would be the final shot of the film. But when the young Annika was shown watching Sunshine finish gracefully finishing her performance and embracing her when it ended, that was when I realized, gets ko na, that in this narrative, she would have a choice, one that's entirely her own.Direk Tonet has managed to make such a compact film about choice. While choice for women is such a privilege in a conservative country like ours, thereâ€™s something powerful in showing that Sunshine made a choice, one that goes against the conventional. While other films of the same topic would leave it to the audience to ponder whether or not the protagonist would choose the controversial choice, Sunshine showed us that yes, she did that!After the end credits have rolled, we were left staring at the black screen, perhaps, feeling fulfilled, weighed upon, or hungrier than ever for films of the same caliber. Sunshine is so monumental for Philippine cinema that it reaffirms one of my aspirations, that one day, Filipinos can have the choice about what films to watch in the cinema every weekend, not choose just either oneâ€”satisfying their physiological hunger or fulfilling the hunger of the soul.

â€œGETS KO NA.â€First things first, thank you Direk Antoinette Jadaone for being so brave. Our country badly needs films that dare to confront the cries and injustices our society (esp women) continue to face. Sunshine is a soft, aching plea for change. Itâ€™s a quiet but urgent cry for body autonomy, for choice, for justice. And itâ€™s not just about one womanâ€™s pain â€” itâ€™s rooted in something deeper: a system that has long failed us, most esp women, in this country.

Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s Sunshine begins with control. With poise, with the perfect arabesque, and with the precision of a gymnast that is ready for the next move. But as the film moves along, the tension in the stillness builds up and begins to show. Behind the clean flow and rhythm of theribbon, the rehearsed elegance of the body is still pushed to their limit. Sunshine feels like a cruel misdirection, but the contrast is exactly the point that womanhood needs.In a country where abortion is still illegal without exceptions, Sunshine doesnâ€™t just tell the story of a young womanâ€™s crisis. It captures a quiet violence of expectation, the pressure to remain graceful even when they are under a system that does not allow women to fail, to choose, or even to speak freely. In the Philippines, the Revised Penal Code punishes abortion with imprisonment, while access to safe and legal procedures remains out of reach for most women, especially those who are young and unfortunate. Punishment because of abortion with imprisonment, and this legal stance is reinforced by deeply rooted religious conservatism. It is not just illegalâ€”it is unthinkable. The stigma runs deep, and the silence surrounding it is even deeper.According to the Center for Reproductive Rights (2023), thousands of women are forced into this silence every year. Estimated around 1.1 million Filipino women induce abortion annually. About 1,000 of Filipinas die each year from abortion-related complications, and over 100,000are hospitalized due to unsafe procedures. These numbers are not just statistics, they are lives of the young, scared, and the unheard. Sunshine puts that reality front and center, but does so without shouting. It doesnâ€™t force emotion, it lets it build naturally. This film follows Sunshine as she navigates through the aftermath of a missed period, a distracted boyfriend, and a society that offers no legal, safe, or accessible options. Sheâ€™s left to carry the weight of a decision she didnâ€™t choose, in a system that treats her body like public property.Sunshine (played by Maris Racal) is a kind character with stillness that feels like a resistance. Her performance is tight, contained, and filled with the kind of fear that is quiet and does not seek and beg for sympathy. A character with a facade that represents many generations of women where they mask all of their feelings and hold on to the thought that â€œthis too shall passâ€.She is not trying to explain herself, she is simply trying to breathe and move in a world that keeps on closing in. Racal does not rely on big breakdowns or dramatic lines. She holds her ground even when that ground is crumbling beneath her. Every look, every breath, feels calibrated. Like someone preparing for a landing they know they might not even survive. What makes the performance even more powerful is how familiar Sunshine feels. She is notwritten as an extraordinary character. She is a regular young woman, navigating school, relationships, and the uncertainty of early adulthood. She could be any girl from any province, any city, any university. That ordinariness is important. Because it reminds us that this story isnot rare. It is not fiction. It is the quiet, constant reality of so many young women in this country who are forced to navigate the consequences of a decision they didnâ€™t even get to make.Jadaone doesnâ€™t push for spectacle. The film sits with silence and discomfort. No overdramatization and overexplanation. Her braveness has a place in Philippine Cinema as this take and storytelling of hers about abortion in a world where systems and institutions are fallingshort, the quiet resistance of Sunshine speaks volume. Instead of turning the film into a message movie, Jadaone chooses to linger. She doesnâ€™t try to solve anything. She doesnâ€™t pretend that resolution is possible. And thatâ€™s what makes Sunshine hit even harder. The film doesnâ€™t just show the problem, it lets us sit in it. It allows discomfort to stretch across the screen without rushing to ease it. That discomfort mirrors what many women feel in real life. The shame. The fear. The confusion. The silence that comes not from peace, but from pressure.It also explores the feelings through visuals. Pao Orendain, the Cinematographer of the film captures the feel of the City of Manila. How it is familiar inside the streets, but also how suffocating it is. The noise pollution that is made by the vehicles, the streets filled with conversations, and the trains rattling as it passes by. The way they captured it, Manila is just another place where it forces the characters to move carefully, just like any other people who lives, visits, and goes to Manila to reclaim life. The streets hum with life, but not always with warmth. The camera observes from a distance, never forcing perspective but always aware of the space Sunshine must navigate.What makes Sunshine stand out is that it never asks permission to tell this story. It does not frame abortion as a debate, or as an issue that needs to be justified. It centers the experience without apology. In doing so, it offers a kind of cinematic resistance that feels rare in Philippine cinema. Jadaoneâ€™s choice to tell this story without moralizing, without preaching, without forcing catharsis, gives it more weight than any dramatic scene ever could.And in a country that still debates whether women should have that right, Sunshine lands, not perfectly, but with all the force of someone who has had enough. Someone who knows she deserves more. And that is enough to shake the ground beneath her, even if no one else is watching. Like a gymnast mid-tumble, it shows how much strength it takes just to survive a fall.And sometimes, survival is the bravest routine of all.Gets na gets kita, Sunshine.

This review features some spoilers.In local cinema, as with mainstream media, thereâ€™s a dearth of films tackling abortion. 12 Weeks, Anna Isabelle Matutinaâ€™s Cinemalaya feature debut, was the latest attempt I could recall, or at least one that had something useful to say. At the same time, a comprehensive sexuality education integrated at all education levels (separate from the education departmentâ€™s sex ed order), as proposed in the anti-teenage pregnancy bill, has been under fire from the countryâ€™s conservative population.Into this frantic context emerges Sunshine, the latest indie darling from writer-director Antoinette Jadaone. The sole Philippine entry in the Centrepiece section of the 2024 Toronto International Film Festival, the film finally comes home. Itâ€™s making its local premiere exclusively at SM cinemas, after touring the international film fest circuit to critical renown, including the Crystal Bear for Best Film at this yearâ€™s Berlin International Film Festival.But make no mistake, as the picture refuses to be singled out as an â€œabortion film,â€ a descriptor so sweeping and limiting that it is seen only vis-Ã -vis morality. Jadaone finds new ammo with which to make sense of the polarizing topic: gymnastics. (The filmâ€™s TIFF world premiere, in fact, came at the heels of gymnast Carlos Yuloâ€™s double Olympic gold in Paris.)The sports drama unfolds through the title character, played by Maris Racal, a young gymnast whose preparation for national tryouts is upended after discovering sheâ€™s pregnant. Refusing to compromise her shot at Olympic glory, with her useless boyfriend (Elijah Canlas) almost instantly ditching her, Sunshine resorts to illegal abortifacients offered by Manilaâ€™s underbelly, where she runs into an enigmatic young girl (Annika Go) bent on tracking her every move and policing her every decision. Soon, she internalizes biblical shame.Sunshine follows Jadaoneâ€™s feminist inclinations. Her directorial debut Six Degrees of Separation from Lilia Cuntapay (2011), is a raw mockumentary that doubles as a compelling paean to the titular screen bit actress, whose name is nearly synonymous with Philippine horror but has largely remained underappreciated. In Never Not Love You (2018), Nadine Lustreâ€™s Joanne is a breadwinner who trades a long-awaited job promotion in Manila for a fraught chance to begin anew and dream together with her privileged boyfriend in London, only to wrestle with the punishing economics of romance. Fan Girl (2020) explores the dark side of being a superfan through a female character whoâ€™s a proxy for the filmâ€™s articulation about the psychology of idle worship in a nation forever beholden to it.Shortcomings of these movies aside, Jadaone insists on narratives that do not treat and present the female gaze as though itâ€™s self-explanatory. The director often edges toward gray areas and destabilizing standpoints, whether or not they wind up humorous, fascinating, schmaltzy, or troubling.Whereas Jadaoneâ€™s previous movies are attuned to the conventions of their respective genres, Sunshine offers something new to the directorâ€™s dramaturgical defaults. The film is an intersection of neorealism and magical realism. It trains the camera on Manilaâ€™s grime, decay, and nonstop noise, embracing its outcasts and harsh truths (the Lino Brocka comparisons are inevitable), just as it punctuates the gritty reality with a magical invocation via the imaginary friend that trails Sunshine.â€œMedia literacyâ€ would tell you that the spectral presence is a representation of the internal-external friction the heroine deals with; fetus in the flesh and the body that refuses to carry it; the back-and-forth between morality and pragmatism. (Jadaone, in an interview with Filmmaker Magazine, revealed she was inspired by the imaginary character in Taika Waititiâ€™s 2019 satirical drama Jojo Rabbit.) But beyond this, the make-believe figure is a surrogate for the conservative, pro-life fraction of the audience, with the director opting to engage in the subject matterâ€™s complexity instead of comfortably locating the film in an echo chamber. While the narrative device could prove as an apparent play at sympathy, indulging in a â€œwill she, wonâ€™t sheâ€ kind of thinking (surface-level reading could also suggest that women seeking abortion are deluded, ridiculous as that implication might sound), it also offers access to the broader violence disguised as â€œconscienceâ€ that puts women, regardless of gender identities, at a disadvantage.If anything, Sunshine is less about the act of abortion itself than about the systems that encourage women to settle for dehumanizing rights already decided for them by a patriarchal few, systems that prohibit them from dreaming, and tell them that to dream only means more labor, nothing more.Sunshine, like Petersen Vargasâ€™ Some Nights I Feel Like Walking (which made its Philippine premiere in June), harnesses the metropolis as a character of its own, instead of reducing it to a mere symbolic backdrop. Whereas Some Nights steeps its urban tale in neon erotica, completely absent of daylight, Sunshine shifts between the cityâ€™s diurnal and nocturnal environments.Pao Orendainâ€™s camerawork here chiefly reaps magic from close-ups and interior shots, often framed from the window and dotted by a shaft of light (hence the Brocka sentiments), locating the viewer into the heroineâ€™s intimate yet anxious state. The self-induced abortion scene in the sketchy motel, a sight casually interrupted by frantic railway noise, is particularly visceral that you can almost feel the texture of the image.The camera also draws focus to the irony that permeates Manilaâ€™s streets, particularly around the vicinity of Quiapo Church, where makeshift stalls selling figurines, scapulars, and all sorts of religious paraphernalia also offer abortion drugs and quack treatments, just as banners declaring â€œabortion is murderâ€ remain a typical sighting. In other scenes where Sunshine traverses the cityscape, the visuals are more straightforward. Accompanying the images is a soundscape that immersively mirrors the congestion, exhaustion, and urban din that form part of the DNA of the countryâ€™s capital.Jadaoneâ€™s script nearly leans on the miserablist. When Sunshine finds an opportunity to pull herself out of the vexing situation, poverty immediately gets in the way, leaving her with no choice but to ask her boyfriend for a meager P5,000 to secure the abortion drug and a cheap motel room to perform the deed herself. Yet even in Manilaâ€™s hospitals, the conditions are dire; patients are forced to share beds, and hallways are turned into makeshift wards, crowded by people in need of attention beyond the medical. Rape and casual prostitution also get in the way, as in the case of Menggay (Rhed Bustamante), the pregnant 13-year-old Sunshine comes across in Quiapo.In a highlight moment, Sunshine, livid upon meeting her friendâ€™s abuser, suddenly picks up a beer bottle and whacks it over the manâ€™s head, before sprinting to escape the scene. (Curiously, Jadaone plumbs the politics of self-determination by contrasting Sunshineâ€™s ability to decide for herself with Menggayâ€™s distance from that very sense of agency.) Even the Quiapo vendors selling abortifacients, who some might think merely exploit the desperation of their customers, are also victims who simply donâ€™t earn enough.Unflattering as these depictions are, itâ€™s hard to deny that these arenâ€™t routine realities in the social inferno that is the Philippines. Still, there is humor, whether in a scene that involves a knife interrupting a silly argument, or in another that sees a self-righteous doctor preaching the goodness of the divine.As Sunshine, Racal delivers a performance that would be a disservice to reduce to neat superlatives. Itâ€™s a physical portrayal that required the actor to undergo training with national gymnastics coaches for nearly a year. Itâ€™s a role that might put her in the center of another controversy after barely surviving the previous one. But just as Sunshine is asked to â€œdrown out the noiseâ€ whenever she steps on the mat, Racal distills every layer and emotion into a character thatâ€™s simply life-like, almost free from the veil of performance-making. Jadaone once told me that her ideal lead performance is one that â€œis part of something bigger than herself.â€ There has not been a more worthy portrayal in local cinema this year.At the same time, the movie functions as a reintroduction to the boundless talent of Jennica Garcia, who plays Sunshineâ€™s elder sister, a single mother trying to keep everything intact. Her portrayal expertly captures what a supporting performance should beâ€”one that has enough screentime to be an emotional anchor for the lead but also generates her own moment. Thereâ€™s a kind of invisible labor informing the character that Garcia encapsulates with an onscreen presence that always feels grounded and never incidental.Sunshine is hardly a social exposÃ©. What ripples throughout this partly winding urban tale is a ready, fatal fact about the place of women in this eternally eroded nation that weâ€™d rather dismiss as â€œcontroversialâ€ or â€œdivisiveâ€ because we refuse to listen. The filmâ€™s visuals might be artful, but they donâ€™t always convey a pretty picture. Itâ€™s no coincidence that the movieâ€™s narrative throughline is the community that Sunshine finds in the women around her: her elder sister, her best friend (Xyriel Manabat), despite her initial inhibitions, her coach (Meryll Soriano), the young Menggay, the compassionate doctor (Angeli Bayani), and even the imaginary friend. Though this sense of solidarity comes at varying degrees, it keeps Sunshine afloat and does not let her think of herself as a monster for terminating an unwanted pregnancy.Once Sunshine nears its final shot, I keep thinking of Fan Girlâ€™s insular ending that succeeds its heroineâ€™s already exhausting journey. Iâ€™m glad to learn that our heroine this time does not succumb to sheer epiphany. Here, hope actually feels like a tangible possibility instead of an unwarranted emotional wallop.Sunshine is perhaps not Jadaoneâ€™s most definitive work; That Thing Called Tadhana (2014) or Never Not Love You might claim that distinction. But it is her sharpest creation yet. It took a whole lot of research and lived experiences to put this story on the screen. It took a bit of time for the film to make its way back to where it started. Itâ€™s a miracle that it even got the go signal to be screened publicly. I can already sense all the hot takes and thinkpieces it will generate. And I can only hope that it will be as meaningful as this.This review appears on PhilSTAR Life in a slightly different version.

Last year, I saw High School Scandal. Both films share the same throughline that Philippine health care sucks when it comes to pregnancy and sex education. High School Scandal was made in the 80s. The difference being is that Sunshine made me feel hopeful, while High School Scandal made me feel depressed.Here's the thing. Sunshine is a very heavy film, but what makes Sunshine such a heartlifting film to watch is that she had the proper support system whether she decides to keep the child or not. She gets to choose if she wants to carry the baby or not. She has a sister that cares about her well being, a best friend who will do everything for her, and strangely enough, a manifestation of what her child will be. The film shows that women should at the end of the day, have the final choice in matters related to childbirth.Oh and with heavy topic such as this, let women be the major voice in the storytelling. Maris Racal is a powerhouse actress. Antoinette Jadoane is a great writer and director and deserves all the praise in handling such a tough topic.

very tearjerker sya ma!!!ANYWAY ang galing ni maris huhu commendable acting also from rhed bustamante sobrang cry talaga ako sa scenes nya ğŸ˜­ i love how direk tonet emphasized na not all teenage pregnancies ay dahil sa raging hormones at lack of education nila, but that they also exist because they were raped, no less than by their relatives!!! kaya sobrang importante ang pelikulang to para isulong na madecriminalize ang abortion ğŸ˜­also!!! loveee ung scene nung kinakausap si sunshine ng doktor after unang attempt niya, hindi natin maikakaila talaga na no matter how educated a person is, minsan talaga hindi umuusad ung mga belief nila sa mga comtroversial na bagay. kaya shoutout kay jennica garcia nung binara nya si doc ang galing nya don maaa

â€œGets ko na.â€In this film, we follow Sunshine, a rhythmic gymnast and an Olympic hopeful, as she travels through Manilaâ€™s dark, narrow, grimy, and crowded streets and alleys in search of a way to terminate her pregnancy in a country where abortion is illegal. There are few parts of this film that really stood out to me because they made elevated the movie and made it more compelling.The first part that I really liked is how the city became a living representation of this countryâ€™s oppressive stance against anything pro-abortion. The city allowed us to have something tangible, to be able to relate to Sunshineâ€™s struggles even more. Second, the magical realism aspect is also a highlight for me. Once it finally clicked what Ariana and Annika Coâ€™s characters represented, I was blown away. One common argument of those against abortion is that you are going to kill someone whoâ€™s probably gonna be a very important person. And yet, we get Annika Coâ€™s character. Through a very powerful performance we end up caring for this kid. But once you start to realize who she us and who she represents, you start to realize that sheâ€™s not just an extension of Sunshine but a representative of all babies born to mothers forced to carry a child. She and these babies are vessels forced to carry the unfulfilled dreams of their mothers. She said something like, â€œAng pangarap niya ay ang pangarap ko.â€ And that line broke me. The argument is always, â€œWe are not fulfilling someoneâ€™s potential if we abort them.â€ but thereâ€™s always a failure to acknowledge that forcing someone to bear a child is also not allowing them to fulfill their potential.The last part that stood out to me is Maris Racalâ€™s great performance. She is the movie. Without that performance, this film will fall apart and she delivers. What this film did is humanize a debate thatâ€™s usually so contentious it ends up being too one dimensional. It made the debate more accessible to every one. The movie is unflinching and raw. A harsh criticism of a society and culture who despite being always proud of their women, continues to fail them by continuing to enabling oppressive systems that mostly targets women. A big middle finger to a society that still strongly reeks of misogyny. It also an exploration of the countryâ€™s broken healthcare system. This film is a celebration of female friendships and sisterhood. The people who helped Sunshine in her journey are women. It forces you to be uncomfortable. It forces you to think and have empathy. This film is highly relevant and should be a required watching for everyone. Probably one of the most important Filipino films ever made. Hope it gets an even wider release.

we meet sunshine through her battle of being an olympian. armored by her well-worn asian games shirt and her head held high, she shines the brightest among her peers who also look up to her and what more she can become. her coach knows this too, along with her family and lifelong friend, who would all do everything to make sure she achieves them.perhaps its in the nuance of a story that is deeply feminist and human, but antoinette's jadaone's sunshine is the strongest in its ability to capture the realities of adolescent pregnancy with both gentleness and fierce. portraying (albeit sometimes preaching about, but deservingly so) the world of a filipina girl navigating the weight of expectations and the silence surrounding sexual and reproductive health, the story unfolds as a reflection of what we lack and suffer from. this flaw persists in the lesson of consent that was never taught, contraception never offered, the judgment of clinical service providers, the terrifying possibility of dying alone, and the unbearable strength it takes to push forward anyway, not because youâ€™re fearless, but because you must. as a youth. as a woman. as a human with dreams and rights.the reality today is rough: the philippine government failed to pass its version of the adolescent pregnancy prevention bill in the recent senate, the current curriculum and implementation of the comprehensive sexuality education is in question, and more and more right-wing (ish) groups are mobilizing their funds to hinder the fight even more. but hopefully, with these kind of films made accessible to the public, we will be reminded that abortion happens not just because teenagers are risky or that they have been abuse hence it's justified, but because they have the right to decide for themselves.after all, sunshine's every step and every twirl, carries not just her own hope, but the collective dreams of those who raised her, and fought for her to have this. and in watching her take the mat, we are reminded of every girl who dreams of olympic gold, of becoming president, of curing AIDS, and how urgent it is that we believe in them first before some blob of blood. that we talk to them about things that matter. that we care.because when we do, they shine.

A film full of images of ironies: The jeepney with Godâ€™s Gift sign, the abortifacients sold next to religious figures, sunshine being named one when her life seemed to be dark, and words of encouragement that made the burden heavier. In a country that is driven by morals, Sunshine begs to question and reassess our morales. What is moral? What is acceptable? Are we accountable? Aside from ourselves, who are accountable?Strong performances and storytelling, Jadaone and Racal hits a homerun.

In a country where abortion remains criminalized, Sunshine is both a risk and a revelation. It speaks directly to the young women whose stories are erased, stigmatized, or left in the shadows. It exposes the hypocrisy of a system that forces women to choose between their futures and their autonomy, between silence and survival.This film does not simply ask whether abortion is right or wrong, it asks us why weâ€™ve made it so dangerous to even ask the question.Decriminalize abortion now!!!!!!!

Time and time again watching films and sharing my appreciation for the art form always felt one-dimensional. But there was a gut feeling that Sunshine was gonna be different.Watching this with my religious mom, laughing through the hypocrisies of it all and finally tearing up toward its third act felt intriguing. As we walked down to a nearby coffee shop, she shared her miscarriage story; she was just as scared as Sunshine, a story on what-ifs and what couldâ€™ve been, a thought they both pondered on.This time my mom didnâ€™t.She went for her thirdAnd gave birth to whomsheâ€™s sharing the story to.The comparisons with Brocka arenâ€™t an exaggeration. Sunshine is arguably direk Tonetâ€™s best and most important piece, bar none.Watch in theaters while itâ€™s out.

sobrang totoo at #danas yung pagganap ng mga aktor at lente ni jadaone rito. lapat sa reyalidad ng pagiging babaeng pilipinong maralita yung pelikula at pinaka nagustuhan ko na hindi lang ito nagmitsa ng simula ng diskurso tungkol sa reproductive health ng kababaihan at usapin ng legalidad at moralidad ng aborsyon sa bansa, tumindig itoâ€” sa katauhan ng bata, ni menggay, ni dra. helen, ni geleen, at ni sunshine.para sa'kin, doon mo lang makikita yung pananda na nagtagumpay yung layunin ng ganitong uri ng pelukula e. hindi sapat na ibato mo lang yung tanong o ilatag sa mga manonood yung hamon na bumoses sa isyung tikom ang karamihan. gustong gusto ko na sa huli, pinili ni sunshine yung pangarap niya at nang maabot niya yung buo at perpektong routine para sa qualifiers, tahimik at walang script yung eksena pero doon ko pinaka rinig na rinig yung puso ni niya. takot, ngunit buo ang loob, at napaka tapang ni sunshine hanggang sa huling segundo ng pelikula. para sa'kin, sobrang halaga na ipakita kung gaano kalaking bahagi ng buhay ng kababaihan yung nakasugal sa tuwing nalalagay sa panganib ng unwanted pregnancy. at yung suporta mula, unang una, sa pamilya, at higit, mula sa gobyernoâ€” upang matamasa ng mga menggay at sunshine ng bansa yung kaligtasan at pagkakataon na mabuhay nang para sa sarili at pangarapâ€”ay hindi dapat ipanawagan kundi ipagkaloob nang kusa at maging mandato.kitang kita ko yung paglago ni maris racal bilang aktor dito. iba rin ang kinang ni jennica garcia at annica co, sobrang deserve na makita pa sa mas maraming proyekto.

â€œdrown out the noiseâ€and yet, no matter how hard Sunshine tries to ignore these noises, what she endures is a different kind of restraint, pain, and messâ€”the kind she canâ€™t forcibly silence, even if she tries.hindi ako babae, pero gets ko si Sunshine. itâ€™s been so long since a film has impacted and triggered something in me. to a point where a line gets stuck in your head. kumbaga sa kanta, na-lss ako sa linyang â€˜to ni Coach Eden.without a doubt, Sunshine holds a special place in my heart. maybe itâ€™s because of how timely and relevant its message is, or because of Maris Racalâ€™s powerful performance, or how it portrays the real noise and mess of Manila. i donâ€™t know. but, what i do know is that i am deeply in love with this film, and iâ€™ll never get tired of talking about it. imagine, from the moment i first saw the trailer last year, to the moment iâ€™m writing this review, iâ€™ve loved sunshine. iâ€™ve loved all the people in charge of making it. and iâ€™ve loved Direk Tonet even more.Ang Husay Husay Husay.

Sunshine is a victim of her poor choice. She is a victim to the patriarchal system of the country. It perfectly encapsulates the intersectionality of being impoverished and a woman in the predominantly catholic setting. It is a bold statement to the cruel realities women face, especially the ones at the bottom. She is caged by the system. Jadaone has given justice in telling the plight women face.Sunshineâ€™s character is imperfect and flawed, but real which makes you root for her character. This was emphasized by the camerawork which maintains a certain intimacy with the character that makes you see Sunshineâ€™s vulnerability. Racal portrayal of Sunshine makes you want to empathize with the character because amidst of all the imperfections, there is this young dreamer. Her poor decisions are the consequence of the society she exists in, wherein there is no other choiceâ€” leaving her to opt for desperate methods.This film is so personal bilang isang babae.

Wow. Galing. Pinagisipan. It reminds me, yet again, of the society we live in. In this film, just like any other woman, Sunshine is a sunshine of her ownâ€”a woman with dreams, goals and stories to tell. A story that is too scary to talk, yet need to be heard and seen. I hope this film will not just become a story of its own, but a way for us to be strong enough to discuss these kinds of issues.

Sunshine Is Every Woman Who Dreams Beyond Her CircumstancesSunshine was not created for the sake of making a statement, nor just triggering a conversation; it was meant to make people feel and understand why abortion happens and how our current system makes them dangerous for women. Sunshine did not need to be pitied or root for, she needed to be understood.The film opens and immediately solidifies Sunshineâ€™s ambition. It is anchored on Sunshineâ€™s eagerness to excel, to achieve, to succeed, to be the best, to be an Olympian. And this ambition is not going anywhere. With every tiptoe that Sunshine stands onâ€”as she throws her pink ribbons and gives in to impulseâ€”she stands tall again, catching the ribbons as if they were always meant to fall in the right placesâ€¦ until they don't. Sunshineâ€™s perfect harmony gets disturbed by her sudden realization that she is pregnant. Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s intentional direction on making some scenes too loud, too chaotic, and far too overwhelming added to the personification of Sunshineâ€™s mind; scrambling, panicking, terrored. It was not just Quiapoâ€™s busy streets, it was also Sunshineâ€™s trembling heart. But in between the anxiety and fear, Sunshine gathers the courage to try making a choiceâ€”even amidst the confusion. Sunshine finds out in the harshest way possible that a choice is not an option. She is put in a situation where the only way out is to give in to â€˜sinfulâ€™ acts, dangerous pills, and death-defying abortion attempts. For a young teenager whose dreams seem too far from where she is, this is the only way. While many expect this decision to become the climax of the movie, Sunshineâ€™s story is far from over. In my understanding, the film explored her conscience through Annika Coâ€™s beautifully done character. It reminded the audience that while women consent to abortion, they are still carrying its moral burden. Annikaâ€™s character became an instrument to make women who seek abortion feel human, with human conscience and sensibilities. But it was done with such care, careful enough not to make it counterproductive but rather stuck in the ideology of the system that she grew up in.However, Annikaâ€™s character is only a personification of Sunshineâ€™s chaotic mind, making Sunshine her own companion to her dawning journey. This character becomes Sunshineâ€™s comfort in the dangers of her abortion attempts, showing the deeply awful and tragic realities many women face; alone in rotting walls of the city, drowning out the noise, and daring to dream bigger than the spaces they are subjected in.But what makes this movie even more special is that it did not let Sunshine go through it alone. While the movie was an avenue for telling the reality, it also became a source of hope for many women, especially for young ones who will watch it. There will be other women supporting them in their decision, other women who will not judge them for their choices, and other women who will create a safe space for themâ€”at least in ways that they can, in the rotting system we have. Finally, Sunshine does not just urge the system to give women the rights to their own body; it explicitly explains what women go through in the struggles that we speak of. It does not undermine the calls for a systemic change, but it brings you the stories behind why a choice is necessary. It opens you to a narrative that does not just agree to progressive actions, but puts the heart in it. And in between those narratives, the movie reminds us that women are more, that they deserve to take up more space. Women are dreamers, they have ambition, they are complex, cohesive, and compassionate. Women are more than their mistakes, their stories go beyond. And that is the essence of a choice; to let them dream. To free them from the shackles of an already oppressing society. To not dim their light and let them shine, like Sunshine herself.To all the Sunshines out there, you are not alone. Be steadfast on your ambition and dare to dream big. And you take up space even bigger.

Sunshine is a brave and powerful filmâ€”one that confronts a deeply taboo subject with grace, nuance, and emotional weight, especially within the context of the Philippinesâ€™ heavily religious culture. Tonet Jadaone doesnâ€™t pull punches, but she doesnâ€™t sensationalize either. Itâ€™s an honest, grounded portrayal of something often swept under the rug.Maris Racal shines in a career-defining performanceâ€”raw, vulnerable, and fully committed. This isnâ€™t an easy watch, but itâ€™s a necessary one. And for those who stay with it, itâ€™s deeply rewarding.Easily one of the best local films Iâ€™ve seen this year.

In many known movies, abortion is commonly narrated as a quest with so much comedic acts, plus some forced shallow arguments to inject drama.But for Sunshine â€” How the movie depicted purchasing a pregnancy test kit in the Philippines = an act to get humiliated. Sunshine, a teenage Filipina athlete forged to be an Olympian who had an unwanted pregnancy, was the sacrificial being for a story to be told.Sunshine happened in the Philippines, where access to reproductive health services is way harder to have compared to other countries, like in the US and Europe. The country has been enclosed with regressive conservatism, causing talks about sex to still be taboos. Abortion is still illegal as well. The movie happened right smack in the heart of Manila City â€” Quiapo. It is an area known for a well-known Catholic Church and the surrounding kubols or booths of herbal medicines and potions for all uses â€” from seducing someone, cursing someone, to inducing abortion (or in Filipino, â€œpampawala ng kapit ng bata.â€) The story, its darkness, and some womenâ€™s resort to the said harmful options would not have happened if only proper education and healthcare are available, to be honest.Sunshine was very telling of the struggles of Filipinas. But I think itâ€™s globally reflective as well because it told the following things:1.) Unfair treatment on female athletes: Remember Venus Williamsâ€™ pregnancy? She almost died after giving birth, and she was kicked out of the top ranks because she cannot play during recovery. The WNBA players? They just wore shirts last All-Star weekend saying â€œPay Us What You Owe Us.â€ And here, Sunshine, an aspiring Olympian, unintentionally risking her passion and potential bread and butter just because proper help is nowhere in sight.2.) Violence against women and children: Catcalling, predatory stares, and rape were parts of this movie. The movie did as much as it could to raise awareness that these actions are still apparent and are unfortunate enablers of all things that went downhill for the female characters. Sunshine mirrored reality, especially for us, Filipinas. I hate writing that sentence, but, itâ€™s the truth. â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”Technical items I liked:â€¢ Rico Blancoâ€™s Challengers-esque film score! The music was so immersive. â€¢ Rhetorical characters (which are pretty difficult to execute and usually come out as trying-hard, but they werenâ€™t)â€¢ Piolo Pascual and his presence. The audience just gasped as soon as he entered the frame!â€¢ Most of all â€” Maris Racal. Her future is so bright. Pain, so much pain, was expressed by her character. And she did more than enough that the audience would want to stop whateverâ€™s causing her agony.â€¢ Gusto Ko Sakin Ka Lang is a banger in a tugstugs jeep ğŸ™‚â€â†•ï¸If youâ€™re in the Philippines, watch this in any SM Cinema. If youâ€™re outside the Philippines, watch out for more future film festivals. Sunshine has been shown in the Toronto International Film Festival, Berlin International Film Festival, Palm Springs International Film Festival, and many more.

Sunshine is more than a film about a teenage gymnast reaching for her olympic dreams. it reflects the struggles, hopes, and quiet battles of countless young girls trying to find light in a world that often dims their shine. Sunshine isnâ€™t just an athlete wearing an asian games shirt holding a pink craneâ€”she is a woman, a sister, a student, a friend, and someone younger girls look up to. set in the noisy, smoggy, and congested streets of Manila, the film doesnâ€™t shy away from the uncomfortable realities many Filipino girls face: teenage pregnancy, poverty, lack of access to healthcare and education, judgment from professionals, and the systemic neglect of womenâ€™s rights. it's not just Sunshine's storyâ€”itâ€™s the story of so many young women who are silenced, dismissed, and left to figure things out on their own. Antoinette Jadaone once again directed a story that is not meant to be questioned, but understood. it's in movies like this that we uncomfortably see how and why women resort to abortion-simply because they are forced by circumstances. pregnant teens do not need to be told how reckless they were; they already know it, and they're already bearing the consequences of their actions. what they actually need is someone they can seek help from, someone who can give them the support they need.lest we forget it's the government that continuously denies women their right to a safe society free from the shackles of abuse and neglect.Maris Racal, you are one hell of an artistâ€”and seeing you and Jennica Garcia in an Antoinette Jadaone film was something i didn't know i needed.

another breathtaking film from direk tonet... the love and care put into the creation of this film truly pours out of the screen with every sequence.i enjoyed the way it lulls you into a false sense of security with how it makes you think that you know where this is goingâ€“before it completely flips your world upside down by the end of the second act. such clever and gripping storytelling and honestly, i expected nothing less from its director :')it's the subtle illustration of solidarity between women that really brought it home for me. it's what made my heart ache the most too. so glad i got to catch this in the cinema, it's definitely one for the books

SUNSHINE: THE REVOLUTION!Lost for words after watching tbh, like fr!!Usa sa ni tatak jud nako ani na film kay ang thought na I HAVE NEVER, AS IN NEVER SEEN MS. MERYLL SORIANO THIS RAW, LOUD AND CLEAR EVEN WITH NO-ACTING ACTING STYLE WITH POIGNANT ROLE AS SEEN IN THIS MOVIE. Grabeee, kuhang kuha kaayo niya ang no-acting acting na pinakagusto nako with independent films. If wala lang jud ko kaila niya, i could say na siya gyud ang trainer ni Sunshine like ana siya kamaayo na wala nako nakita iyaang pagka Mama Meme or any other characters she portrayed but THE COACH OF SUNSHINE. Hands up Ms. Meryll! Inay Maria must be proud of you! I hope you'll bag an acting award on this film, you deserve it!Second, gets man na nakafocus pud ang ending sa role ni Ms. Jennica Garcia cause siya nga lang naman nagtiwala at nakakaintindi kay Sunshine, but I would have love to see the change of tone on Ms. Meryll Soriano's character (kulang po yung exposure emz) â€” she has been one of the dynamic characters in this film and I want to see her sa ending more, now that Sunshine has done what she really loves to do, and parte rin naman siya ng success ni Sunshine. She, in the first place, confronted Sunshine about the "rumors" but in the end, in her quiet strength, sinuportahan man pud niya.Third, TAYO ANG CHARACTER NI ANNIKA CO. Ang character ni Annika Co reminds me of the character ni Joven sa Goyo: Batang Heneral. Annika Co doesn't just represent "Sunshine's child", she represents how Pinoy see and interpret in their own narratives ang mga personal decisions ni Sunshine. Kumbaga ing-ana ang most judgments sa mga tawo sa mga personal decisions ni Sunshine. She was taken lightly kay ang character naglalaro thru a child actor pero katong part sa falling action na ni ana si Annika ug "ngayon gets ko na..." with full of love and a hint of conviction. That's the cue, mao na ang gusto ni Sunshine mahitabo sa nation na magets siya na women should always have the right with their bodies, and what to do with their bodies. I was ugly crying sa whole falling action-resolution because of that freaking satisfaction makita sa nawong ni Sunshine while gracefully performing sa iyaang practice. Ing-ana ang gusto nato makita sa mga babaye if they choose themselves and could become as selfish as these men or even more. Basta gahilak rako ani na part kay heartfelt kaayo ang whole scene with Annika plus giatay dalang dala kaayo ko sa musical scoring ani na scene even without dialogues, just pure execution.Andami ko pang gustong sabihin, but mao ra sa ni ang nitatak sa ako while watching.This is not just a reflection of what's happening sa mga kababaihan, cause this is also a call for action na kailangan na mulihok ang mga lawmakers na ma-Decriminalize ang Abortion sa Pinas to give chance to all women who are not ready to become mothers kasi may mga pangarap pa na mas dapat unahin. Let women be selfish for once. Hindi lahat pwede maging ina; hindi lahat gustong maging isang ina.

In a deeply religious country, I understand why Director Jadaone found it necessary to use symbolism through the characters of the child and Ariana in order to present the film Sunshine in a way that would allow it to be shown and appreciated by a wider Filipino audience.

Gets ko na.A brave yet genuine film that tackles a lot of social issues in the Philippines. The depiction of the Manila slums and the protagonistâ€™s struggles make this movie impactful. Being a woman in this country is another level of challenge that this movie accurately showed.I love you so much direk Tonet and Maris!

The film conveys a strong message and opens discussion on a pressing (yet not widely discussed) issue in the Philippines: teenage pregnancy.There were scenes that made me cry, but thatâ€™s because itâ€™s where it really makes me empathize with Sunshine. I felt so many emotions while watching. I felt anger, felt the unfairness of society to women, felt the remaining hope and rooted for Sunshine. I loved the cinematography and the score, especially when Sunshine locks in for performance. Maris Racal and Jennica Garcia were powerful on screen together and individually. Maris does not just play Sunshine. Maris is Sunshine. I love that for her.

Jennica Garcia, best supporting actress! Grabe. Iyaq na naman si ako, naalala ko na naman iyong â€œSunshiiineâ€ nya. Grabe. Andame kong thoughts sa movie! I canâ€™t! Direk Tonet, kung nababasa mo to, yis galeng tai nah!!!! Woooooooh!!!!!!ADDENDUM CHAR (i just canâ€™t stop thinking about this movie after like a week) Sunshine is a story of hope entangled in realityâ€™s shadow.Iâ€™ve seen this film beforeâ€”many times. As a student, learning the theoretical aspects of medicine. As an intern, having actual encounters through interviews with women like Sunshine. And as a practicing physician, who trained to become an OB-GYN, completing many incomplete miscarriagesâ€”induced or notâ€”removing whatâ€™s left of what we call products of conception. Sometimes people call it products of misconception when theyâ€™re trying to be funny.This movie didnâ€™t just slap us with the sensitive issue of abortion. It dissected so many layers of issues we need to talk about more oftenâ€”and pondering them in reality is a mental and moral gymnastics at play.I would love to discuss all of them one by one, but this is a movie review after all, not an essay on the dangers of lacking a solid law to protect our young women from the societal pressures of patriarchy and religionâ€”pressures that push them into life-threatening situations, only to be blamed for doing something they had no real choice about. In short, fuck the system.Itâ€™s always been a mental gymnastics for me to decide how to approach situations like this. And this movie is telling me exactly how. Jennica Garciaâ€™s character deeply resonated with meâ€”from the way she calls Sunshineâ€™s name so tenderly, to the way she assures her that sheâ€™ll be there no matter what. She reminds us that we all need at least one ate around us who looks after us despite everything. (She literally said, shouted even, BE KIND!)Another character who lingered in my mind was the 14-year-old teenage mother. Shoutout to the team for dressing her in something colorfulâ€”a subtle clue to her identity, only revealed later. She was one small character representing thousands of teenage mothers, who are becoming younger as the years go by. She also represented the vulnerable group prone to sexual abuseâ€”the group we have somehow failed to protect.Iâ€™d love to dissect each of the characters, but Iâ€™ll leave that to you. Instead, Iâ€™ll talk about Sunshine (last na, promise). Maris Racalâ€™s portrayal was a masterclass in character acting. Sunshine is a fearless dreamer, full of dedication and passion to make that dream come true. She perseveres despite her familyâ€™s circumstances. Sheâ€™s also a believer, kind, and someone who truly cares. You see it in the small thingsâ€”like the way she makes the sign of the cross before her performance, or when she prays fervently in Quiapo Church to ask for guidance or forgiveness on the thing sheâ€™s about to do or not to do. And thatâ€™s the beauty of this filmâ€”it tells you so many things without saying so much. It urges its viewers to talk about them because these are urgent matters. Maybe weâ€™re still far from legalizing abortion, but this movie isnâ€™t just about that. Itâ€™s telling us we have so many other issues to tackle.In short, we need to protect the Sunshinesâ€”or this world will become darker than it already is.

Iâ€™m fairly easy to please when it comes to films. Give me a solid plot, a bit of laughter, a love story I can root for, and a strong ensemble, and Iâ€™m happy. Sunshine delivers all of these, but more importantly, it delivers a quiet, aching kind of truth. The trailer already sets up the premise: an aspiring Olympic gymnast finds herself two months away from the qualifiers, and pregnant. What unfolds is not a cautionary tale, but a necessary, grounded story about the private cost of dreams and the impossible decisions women are often forced to make.This is not a conventional film. At several moments, I found myself crying with Sunshineâ€”because I know there are many women like her. Women who have been in the same position, or still are. In a country where laws continue to deny women the right to make choices about their own bodies, Sunshine handles its subject matter with a kind of restraint and realism that does not demand pity, but insists on empathy. Even if you havenâ€™t experienced what she has, you feel itâ€”because you are human, and perhaps more deeply, because you are a woman. When the credits rolled, it took a while before anyone in the cinema, including myself to get up and leave. There was a heaviness in the room. Everyone sat in silence, letting the weight of the film settle in.Some have described the film as Brocka-esque, and I find that comparison apt. This is Tonette Jadaoneâ€™s most powerful work to date. A film that is necessary, timely, and deserving of all our support. I hope more people watch Sunshine and understand this side of womanhood, one that is constantly sidelined in the name of morality and ethics. There is truth, and power, in giving women the right to choose. In letting them take ownership of their own bodies. Always.

As a Filipino woman, this movie hits so close to home. So many moments in this movie that made me realize that I might have been too jaded to comprehend just how common unwanted and taboo pregnancies are. I feel a sense of pride over the protagonistâ€™s choices, for being â€œkontra-agosâ€ in a society and industry that perpetuates ownership over a womanâ€™s body and future. Maris shined, but Jennica Garciaâ€™s performance as the firm yet nurturing older sister really stuck with me. Lastly, this movie brought to light just how much we need progressive reproductive health policies in the country, and just how much we have to fight for it. I would have wished for the movie to be straightforward about what happened after Marisâ€™ decision, but thereâ€™s a certain charm about it being sort of open-ended.

Thereâ€™s a quiet power in Sunshine, one that doesnâ€™t shout its message but lets it settle in your bones. This film is many things: a coming-of-age story, a critique of a broken system, a glimpse into the intimate pain of being a girl in a country where your choices are limited before youâ€™re even allowed to make them.It focuses on the deeply human moments of fear, frustration, and quiet strength as Sunshine navigates an impossible decision in a society that offers her no safe options. Maris Racal delivers her best performance yet, as thereâ€™s a stillness to it that makes it all the more heartbreaking.What I really loved is how it doesnâ€™t feel like itâ€™s trying to explain itself and it just presents the reality where religion, poverty, and patriarchy intersect in deeply personal ways. Itâ€™s a whole world closing in on a girl whoâ€™s just trying to breathe, fighting for her freedom to choose and a right to dream.Seen at SM City DasmariÃ±as

Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s Sunshine listens. It listens to the silence of shame, the dissonance of faith, and the quiet, aching resolve of a girl who simply wants to choose. Itâ€™s the kind of film that our deeply Catholic country isnâ€™t ready for, but desperately needs. That itâ€™s showing in nationwide cinemasâ€”not just tucked in the corners of a progressive film festivalâ€”feels like a small act of rebellion in itself.Like Eliza Hittmanâ€™s Never Rarely Sometimes Always, a film I often return to when thinking about stories of quiet resistance, Sunshine unfolds with restraint and tenderness, never sensationalizing what is already unbearable. But where Hittmanâ€™s film relies on cold urban detachment, Jadaoneâ€™s world breathes with a Filipino kind of chaos: loud horns, dim chapels, vendors selling herbal â€œsolutionsâ€ beside icons of the Virgin Mary. Itâ€™s all there. The hypocrisy, the hush-hush remedies, the weight of sin pressed upon young womenâ€™s shoulders before they even understand the language of their own bodies.Maris Racal is astonishing. She carries the film with a performance so grounded, so lived-in, that she often feels less like a character and more like someone we know. A friend. A cousin. A girl on the jeep beside us, clutching a bag, hiding her fear behind a tight grip and a brave face. Her Sunshine is not loud, but she is brave. And perhaps bravery today looks exactly like this: choosing to take control of your life, even when the world tries to stop you.Jadaoneâ€™s direction is both intimate and distant, borrowing from the gaze of Brocka but infused with a distinctly feminine grief. We see Sunshine from behind glass, from across alleys, as if we too are complicit in watching but not speaking up. Yet the film never loses its tenderness, even in its political anger.Sunshine is not an easy watch. But it is essential. In a country where reproductive rights are still cloaked in rosaries and stigma, this film asks us not just to look, but to sit, to stay, to listen. It doesnâ€™t beg for permission. It asserts presence. And sometimes, in a nation deafened by doctrine, thatâ€™s more than enough.

iâ€™ve already seen so many pro-choice films that greatly explore the difficulties of going through an abortion (never rarely something always, happening, etc) but i must say that it feels really different to watch a film like it made in your country.. because in the pro-choice films iâ€™ve watched before, theyâ€™re usually either set in the old times where abortion was still illegal in their countries or set in a modern setting whereas the female lead needs to travel in other places/states to undergo abortion legallyâ€¦ but in sunshine, itâ€™s set in the modern times or the living conditions of filipino people right now yet thereâ€™s still no place to go where abortion is acceptedâ€¦ which speaks a lot about the real life situation for women in our country. women anywhere have to go through a lot to apply *the choice* that theyâ€™ve decided on.. however, it is much much worse in the philippines as itâ€™s a complete taboo and sometimes it feels like weâ€™ll never see in our lifetime where abortion will finally be legal in the countryâ€¦â€¦ so, it truly is a remarkable feat that we got a pro-choice filipino film now. not only that because itâ€™s directed by one of the most well-known directors, released nationwide, and promoted in mainstream shows and platforms. this film shedded some light to everyone and it was very much needed for every filipino woman out there.thank you direk antoinette, maris racal, and all the amazing women here for sharing the story of sunshine. â˜€ï¸â¤ï¸â€ğŸ©¹

"Sunshine" is Direk Tonet's best film to date, especially with how raw and brave this is. She captured the societyâ€™s biggest aches perfectly. Gets ko na kung bakit deserving itong manalo ng awards at ipakita internationally.Maris Racal brings sunshine with her strong and raw performance as the titular character, probably her most defining role yet. Kitang-kita at damang-dama dito ang kanyang saya, galit, at hirap na kanyang pinagdadaanan.

This film is, at its core, a well-intentioned and emotionally resonant film. It tackles difficult subject matter with sincerity, and for the most part, it does so with grace. However, I found that the inclusion of fantastical or imaginary elements occasionally detracted from the weight of its core issues. While I understand the metaphorical ambition behind these stylistic choices as well as their function in softening the emotional blows with humor or levity, I believe the film is at its most powerful when it forgoes embellishment and leans fully into the raw intensity of its subject matter. In those moments, when it embraces the chaos, the pain, and the emotional urgency it really becomes something far more affecting and memorable, allowing the simplicity it strives for to emerge, though itâ€™s often overshadowed. At times, the dialogue veers into overtly inspirational or didactic terrain, feeling more like affirmations meant to uplift than naturalistic exchanges between characters. Itâ€™s clear that the film doesnâ€™t only aim to tell a story, it wants to educate, to empower, to stir social consciousness. Yet in doing so, it sometimes edges closer to the tone of an educational TV movie than a fully realized work of cinema. Thatâ€™s not a critique of its moral imperative, itâ€™s a film that should be shown in schools but rather an observation about its limitations as a piece of narrative storytelling. The emotional and ideological weight it seeks to carry isnâ€™t always supported by the nuance or complexity that cinematic storytelling demands.What grounds the film and gives it its most enduring power is its emotional core. Maris Racal delivers a performance of quiet strength and vulnerability, anchoring the film with remarkable consistency. Especially compelling is the subplot involving Rhed Bustamanteâ€™s character. Without revealing too much, her arc resonated with me more deeply than the central storyline. It was heartbreakingly authentic, subtle, restrained, and profoundly human. In that thread, the film touches something honest and unflinching.I also admired Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s formal restraint in certain key scenes, particularly her choice to mute the sound. In a film so concerned with voice and expression, those pockets of silence carried tremendous weight. They allowed the viewer a moment of stillness, a space for reflection and imbued the film with a haunting quietude that deepened the emotional stakes.That said, the filmâ€™s message doesnâ€™t always land with clarity. After a pivotal hospital scene, I overheard two audience members blame the protagonist for her choices, siding with the doctor who confronts her. That reaction, while anecdotal, reveals a significant shortcoming: the narrative may not have sufficiently challenged ingrained prejudices or prompted the kind of empathy it aspired to cultivate. It bravely addresses urgent topics- reproductive rights, bodily autonomy, the realities of being a young woman navigating unjust systems but the film doesnâ€™t always sharpen these into a coherent or persuasive argument. In trying to reach everyone, it occasionally loses the sharpness needed to truly confront.Still, â€œSunshineâ€ is a valuable film, one with earnestness, compassion, and purpose. Its flaws are born of ambition: the desire to inspire, to uplift, and to inform all at once. But perhaps empowerment doesnâ€™t always need to be accompanied by joy. Sometimes, it is in the unvarnished confrontation of pain without fantasy, without consolation that we discover our deepest strength. I donâ€™t mean to suggest the film ought to have ended in despair, but rather that its final act, which shifts into metaphor and closes with a success story, might have benefitted from something more grounded, more unresolved or ambiguous . Real life rarely provides a clean arc, and in a film so rooted in truth, the ending felt almost too easy, too neat.

A random review ***it may contain spoilers*** I was in awe after seeing the first 10mins or more of this film. I like the raw and realistic on the situation where she had an idea if she might be pregnant, from the varsity clinic, how she react, getting a pregnancy kit to a local pharmacy, how she search online on how to get rid or literally â€œmawala sa sariliâ€ in the moment she found out, i may say if i were in that age I probably be acting the same thing Sunshine did.It very direct, light and eye opening to different perspectives in abortion, from the pro life views, to views of men who is not ready fathered or accept responsibilities, to the views of her friends and colleagues/societal norms, in the perspectives of her coach and to her lifelong dream, to the views of some unwanted pregnant women who dealt from complicated situations, to view of her own family, for Sunshine and to her unborn child. We all have out own biases when it comes to this topic; abortion but at the end it still in the capacity of the woman, the beholder to take choice on what choices she want to takeâ€¦ I was too happy how her family especially her eldest sister Geleen support Sunshine in what decision she may lead to. Its a gemIn silver screen seeing that moment, that scene that is so comforting, q moment that most of us longing in a situation like this. Itâ€™s not about taking responsibilities but owning and accepting mistakes and making peace to yourself. We know what is good and what's right but in the end of the day we are the not the right one to decide for someone else fate and choices especially we are not in that situation, where they are coming from.I want to commend Maris Racal for casting as Sunshine. After Mary Grace rushed to the hospital and Dr. Helena offer her service after a male doctor rejected Mary grace and Sunshine, only women understands womenâ€¦ period say it all. God, itâ€™s life and death situation, would you still judge a person of her crime that saving her life?*the Tito Bobot scene- Sunshine gives Justice, p*tang-ina nya. Hayop!

Sunshine is a film that proves time and time again that art matters. This is unrelated to the film but Ethan Hawke best explains it when he said that human art is a sustenance that lets us make sense of the things that we have no understanding of. And Sunshine exceeds in that very criteria because of how delicate the plot is yet it puts so much faith on its viewers by challenging them into understanding the struggles explored in the film, and it cleverly succeeds in such a way that does not make it intrusive. The viewer is allowed to draw their own opinions without the film ever forcing them to side with it. Sunshine is Antoinette Jadaone's magnum opus, and the film further shines as Maris Racal delivers a performance of a lifetime. I cannot stress enough how important this film is to the Philippines, and how it is a step forward to everything it stands for. Manila is unforgiving, relentless, and dark, but even the streets can feel like home with even just a little light.

Gets na gets ko na.To be honest, Sunshine may follow the story of a gymnast, but it's really about the quiet, impossible contortions many women are forced to make just to keep goingâ€”physically, emotionally, morally. Itâ€™s about the weight of carrying something you didnâ€™t choose, in a world that offers you no real way out.It asks the kind of questions that linger long after the credits roll: How do you hold on to your dreams when your body no longer feels like your own? How do you choose anything at all when every choice comes with shame, fear, or punishment?In a country where abortion is completely outlawedâ€”even in cases of rape or danger to the motherâ€”and where women are taught to suffer silently for the sake of appearances or faith, Sunshine hits differently. It doesn't shout. It doesn't try to shock. It simply tells the truth as it is lived: with quiet pain, with small acts of defiance, and with the kind of strength that often goes unnoticed.This film doesnâ€™t just resistâ€”it listens, it aches, and above all, it stays with you.July 26, 2025SM Mall of Asia

in a country where abortion is still criminalized & still buried deeply beneath shame and fear, im glad that this film dares to say what so many are too afraid to: that we simply need to talk about this and that this silence is not a safety but just a mere violence in a very very slow motion.upon watching, i just noticed such apparent layers: desperation, love, pain, and so frustratingly impossible choices. and such never fit neatly into laws written without compassion. im really just so glad that they made a film about care, about womens autonomy, and about the dignity of choosing what to do with ones body, especially in a country like ours, where so many are denied that choice, where morality is frustratingly weaponized and healthcare is gatekept. im really hoping this sparks more than the praise. rage, conversation, and ofc solidarity. and im sure this is already starting to become one of those local films that are not afraid at all to confront our truths no matter how this disturbs the comfortable. we need to legalize abortion. not only simply bc of efficiency, but bc of necessity. bc everyone deserves the right to choose, to be safe, and to be seen.

To hell with these topics being taboo in the Philippines - Jadaone says LETâ€™S TALK ABOUT IT and this film did that. Definitely a film that will start conversations and something that will linger in thought even hours after watching it.This film - for starters, was really well-shot and well-edited. That was my first takeaway. Second, well-scored. And when that credits rolled and I saw that Rico Blanco did it? The dots were connecting and with Maris Racal as the protagonist? Wow that was definitely personal maybe thatâ€™s why it was done so good.As a man, who actually didnâ€™t know anything about this topic - THIS WAS EYE-OPENING EDUCATIONAL FOR ME. I didnâ€™t know how self-abortion works, I didnâ€™t know how much it cost, I didnâ€™t know what it looks like, I didnâ€™t know how treatment is done after, I didnâ€™t even know that doctors refused service for this! Imagine my fuming anger when that scene happened. For me, this was information overload.I appreciate how this was not Maris Racal anymore. This was Sunshine. Sunshine was a real person. It borderline made me forget that this was a film, it felt like reenactment of something, or maybe unintentionally, it was.Also, scriptwriting and editing masterclass - How you make people laugh with subtle punchlines with great timing, but not cutting off the momentum and emotion you feel for the scene, and also not lightening off the topic at hand. The way that that were balanced? Hats off to Jadaone and the editor, Ben Tolentino (THE GOAT)Performances were topnotch as well! I love that you feel the cast, from lead to support, not one-upping each other. You felt them read the script and read the room and operate on that energy. They were supporting each othersâ€™ performances and maybe thatâ€™s why it became more effective as a script. The execution was phenomenal.Personally, I would have loved some bit more fleshing out by the third act, because I feel like the un-accustomed or laymen movie audience may not get it immediately with the execution of it and it wouldâ€™ve been better with the topic at hand to be spoonfed a bit more (but not too much). But yeah this is more of a personal nitpick at this point.Either way - BEAUTIFUL FILM! Is this my favorite Jadaone? Iâ€™m not sure yet. But is this objectively the best Maris Racal? TO DATE YES!

So so so much empathy in Jadaoneâ€™s lens and Racalâ€™s performance â€” in many scenes I found myself sharing Sunshineâ€™s pain, so when she finds peace in her decision, I couldnâ€™t help but beam with pride too.

Sunshine isnâ€™t just a filmâ€”itâ€™s a quiet cry from someone who feels stuck, trying to move forward in a world that keeps pulling her back. Tonet Jadaone tells the story with gentle honesty, never shouting, but always making you feel.Maris Racal plays a young gymnast chasing her dream. But life throws her a twist: an unexpected pregnancy. Suddenly, her bodyâ€”once her source of powerâ€”feels like it no longer belongs to her. Sheâ€™s scared, tired, and unsure what choice feels right.The setting isnâ€™t just Manilaâ€”itâ€™s its soul. Busy, sacred, messy. In one scene, sheâ€™s buying abortion pills from a street stall, while church bells ring nearby. The contrast is sharp, but real. Sunshine doesnâ€™t tell you whatâ€™s right or wrong. It just shows you whatâ€™s true.What stayed with me most is how the film feels personal. Like every time Iâ€™ve had to choose myself, even when others didnâ€™t understand. It reminded me that courage isnâ€™t loudâ€”itâ€™s the quiet strength to keep going.If youâ€™ve ever felt like you were drowning in expectations, Sunshine reminds you that even in the darkest alleys, thereâ€™s a sliver of light. Not because the world is kindâ€”but because you choose to keep walking.
