Yesterday, I stumbled upon a Twitter post pointing out parallelisms between Jadaone's Sunshine and Brocka's Insiang with how both films' main characters, in at least one scene, were framed behind bars, mirroring their metaphorical imprisonment within gendered norms of their respective social milieus. Indeed, although almost 50 years have passed between the two films, it's an unfortunate reality that women's rights in the Philippines still have a long way to go, with conservative Catholic values hindering its advancement. Both Jadaone and Brocka present us with their titular characters' fractured psyches, trying everything within their limited power to achieve some kind of self-emancipation. Another Twitter post, however, posits that while Jadaone echoes Brocka in some ways, she ultimately diverges from him by virtue of her "woman's instinct" that also augments her narratives with an "added layer." Obvious gender essentialism and identity politics aside, this is a sentiment that I'm keen on interrogating: what does it actually mean to have a female directorial sensibility, particularly in the vein of Antoinette Jadaone?An easy answer would be to look at the central conflict of Sunshine, that is, unwanted pregnancy, and that Jadaone opts for a female teenager as its main focalizer. I'm pointing this out because trans men and intersex people can also get pregnant hence a pregnancy plot point would not inherently be women-specific (although there would surely be many overlaps), so it's Jadaone's directorial decision to create a female protagonist that imbues the film with intricacies of the female experience---how proceeding with motherhood would be career suicide for an athlete aiming for the Olympics, how Sunshine is constantly berated by self-righteous people she encounters, how society itself was built against female self-determination, and despite all these, how Sunshine finds small pockets of refuge in other women---a friend, a mentor, an inn receptionist, a doctor, an abused prepubescent, a sister---who are empathetic enough to understand her pain and conviction, and to whom she's equally compelled to reciprocate kindness whenever the situation permits.Further, Jadaone digs deeper and finds the Catholic religious institution, itself a remnant of feudalism, as an underlying hegemonic force against women empowerment, so culturally embedded in Philippine society that Sunshine finds it wherever she goes, be it in the drugstore, in the hospital, in the university, in the sport that she loves, even in the man who got her pregnant. Unfortunately, here is also where Jadaone's supposed female sensibility loses steam: religious guilt is so ubiquitous that even she is not aware that it limits her perspective, that instead of finding multiple angles of inquiry she instead chooses to hammer in the same anti-religious (therefore anti-patriarchal) talking point over and over and over again, even to the point of physicalizing the unborn children, a weirdly pro-life creative decision in a film that self-categorizes as pro-choice. Heck, the film just assumes that the audience already knows about the economic facets of being a Filipino athlete so it makes no effort in examining it, nor is it concerned with how Sunshine and her family earn their money (nobody seems to be working!). No, those aren't important; just focus on the fact that Sunshine is a woman and that she's oppressed because of it. "Drown out the noise," her coach tells her, but is it really necessary to drown it out if the noise is as repetitively monotonous (albeit still imminently threatening) as Jadaone presented it?My argument is that uncritical admiration for "female sensibility" is as dangerous as the patriarchy it contends with, and that it's the same liberal narrow-sightedness that applauds Jadaone's bravery for tackling taboo gender topics and turns a blind eye to her cowardice in heeding the pro-Palestine boycott of the Berlinale film festival in the same breath; what's the point of female sensibility if it is devoid of anti-fascist solidarity? Perhaps Sunshine is actually a self-surrogate for the lengths Jadaone is willing to go through in pursuit of her career, and we're all just supposed to root for her because it's great that Philippine cinema is acknowledged and praised internationally, everything else be damned.And maybe I'm expecting too much from Jadaone, that I should just accept that her films are self-contained texts that will never reach the same kind of radicalism and depth as Brocka's (which is admittedly a high standard to reach), but deep inside I want to believe that she's capable of bolder, stronger filmic statements.

Ganito pala sa Maynilaâ€”maingay, mausok, at puno ng pangarap. Sunshine holds up a mirror to Manila's contradictions. There is a sketchy motel that asks for your ID before handing over the keys, as if the system needs to know if you are old enough to make your own decisions. A crowded hospital where pregnant women share beds in the maternity ward, almost as if they are only given a small space in a world they live in. A religious landmark for those seeking miracles, but just outside are street markets selling religious paraphernalia and illegal abortion pills.Maris Racal gives an outstanding performance as Sunshine, a young rhythmic gymnast whose Olympic aspirations are upended by unexpected pregnancy during tryouts. One of the film's striking choices is the inclusion of this magical presence played by Annika Co. To me this character felt like a reflection of the conservative audience inserted into the narrative, a constant presence, watching, whispering, and trying to make sense of Sunshine's decisions.The film closes with the hope that Sunshine, and others like her, might still get the chance to finish their routine and maybe, even become champions of their own lives.

Set against the relentless rhythm of Manila, the film captures how the world keeps movingâ€”often without mercyâ€”especially for those society has pushed to the margins. Yet, in the middle of all the noise and indifference, it reminds us that even the smallest act of empathy can mean everything to someone, not only for Sunshines out there but also to Mary Graces alike. There should be a choice. Always.

"Naiintindihan mo ba 'ko?""Gets ko na."Aside from the usapan between Jennica and Maris, dito talaga ako naiyak. Naisip ko tuloy bigla 'yung lyrics sa Indak na "makikinig nga ba sa isipan na alam ang wasto, ngunit pipigilan ang pag-ibig niya na totoo." Kudos to Sunshine for choosing what she feels right for her. Kung sa kwento at paraan ng pagkwento nitong pelikula, sa totoo lang. Kung ano talaga nangyayari sa lipunan. Walang labis, hindi nagkulang, kaya malakas ang impact. For me, iba talaga ang gawa ng direktor na nagmula sa Indie then pinapasok ang mundo ng mainstream. May pag-asa ang Pelikulang Pilipino.

Sunshine is a charming film. Beautifully directed, well-acted, and elevated by a great score and gorgeous cinematography (ang ganda ng Maynila kahit gritty). The pacing is tight and purposeful (walang fillers, or at least I didn't feel it), and honestly, I loved every minute of it. Itâ€™s the best Filipino film Iâ€™ve seen this year.What stood out most was how it tackled the lack of body autonomy that women face in this country. We reaaaalllyyy need a legal avenue for abortion, and I hope this film helps spark that conversation. Ang hirap maging babae sa Pilipinas!I also liked that it showcased the real Manila without falling into poverty porn (great shots of Quiapo). It celebrated female friendships and relationships without centering men, and it showed the complexities of family without resorting to toxic tropes(supportive ate yes! Jennica Garcia was amaaaazing). I loved the inclusion of sports too; we definitely need more athlete-centered films.Pero, at the heart of it all is a strong, well-developed main character â€” flawed, impulsive, but deeply likeable and easy to root for (even during her chaotic, violent outbursts!!! I loved those moments, geh girl go lang!!!).Maris Racal was phenomenal. She captured Sunshineâ€™s stress and anxiety with so much nuance â€” it never felt overacted. Grabe, I really felt her frustration, and by the end, I felt her relief too.I donâ€™t usually write movie reviews, but this film was so phenomenaaaaal I couldnâ€™t help but put my thoughts into words. Ayan tuloy, nakapagsulat ako ng ilang paragraphs! I really hope it gets the support it deserves and that more people catch it in cinemas before Tuesday so that it gets extended and marinig ni Direk yung now on it's 3rd week â€” ganern!Thank you, Papa God para sa movie na to!!!

Ang tapang!Not only is this Jadaone's bravest and best film yet, it's also arguably the most important local film in recent years. And the fact that it got past the Movie and Television Review and Christians Board and is now showing in the most mainstream cinemas in the country, is already a big win in itself.Sunshine joins Joanne and Jane as Jadaone's women trapped but still dreaming, living, and surviving in a world by and of weak men.And much like what she was able to get out of then-up-and-comers Nadine Lustre and Charlie Dizon, Jadaone gives birth to another star in Maris Racal. And like her big sisters, she SHINES.Jennica Garcia MOTHERED;Maris Racal MURDERED! (oops!)[SM Marikina] < Ang Ranking: Antoinette Jadaone >

Seconds after the credits started rolling, I blankly stared at the ceiling, pondering a lot of questions. Ganitong-ganito yung mga film na gustong-gusto ko may talkback not because I want to know the process but rather I want to learn more about the topic. As they say, â€œArt should comfort the disturbed and disturb the comfortableâ€ at sa tingin ko matagumpay na nagawa yun ng Sunshine. And that â€œGets kitaâ€ scene crumpled my heart so bad (kahit hindi ako babae).From Maris to the supporting actors, everyone truly gave their all. They genuinely breathed life into their characters. My Direk Tonetâ€™s fave alongside with That Thing Called Tadhana and Never Not Love You. Sana marami pa ang makapanood nito at maging paraan upang mas magkaroon pa ng nga diskusyon patungkol dito.

So moved by this film not just by the story itself but also by how it was told---so much so that it snapped me out of a personal slump. It depicted the most raw parts of Manila life without making it feel like poverty porn, tackled sensitive issues without just adding it for shock value, and ultimately gave more depth to the main character's dilemma---plights that women (especially in the third world) struggle with daily. Needless to say, the performances and soundtrack really brought the story to life in a way that will leave you thinking about the film for a while. Beautiful, beautiful.

Usually, when a film claims to challenge a societal norm, it ends up being either too preachy or barely scratching the surface. But sometimes, a film like Sunshine comes along and delivers on its promiseâ€”clear, direct, and most importantly, brave.Not only is this Jadaoneâ€™s best film to date, but itâ€™s also her most important. Itâ€™s a feminist masterclass in storytelling, evident in how every significant character in the film that supports Sunshine is a woman. And to top it all off, the ending was written to give the character what she truly deservesâ€”even if the harsh realities of our country don't always allow a woman to have that.Even the casting was perfect and clearly intentionalâ€”from Marisâ€™s embodiment of Sunshine to Elijahâ€™s portrayal of the privileged Miggy (perfect choice of name, by the way). Setting the story against the raw backdrop of Manila adds just the right weight to the filmâ€™s intention.Minsan lang dumating ang isang pelikulang pwedeng magbukas ng mata ng mas marami pang tao. Sana dumating ang araw na hindi na mahirap maging babae sa Pilipinas. Sana maintindihan ng kung sino man ang nasa taas. Sana masabi nilang, â€œGets ko na."

[SPOILERS!]Ang pinakapaborito kong detalye sa movie nato ay ang fact na â€œwala lang ang pera sa buhay ni Miggyâ€.Binasag ni Sunshine ang windshield ng kotse nya? No problem, sa sunod na shot with the car, intentionally mag-ga-glide ang shot sa harap at makikitang napalitan na ang windshield at wala nang confrontation about it. It is just fixed.Kailangan ni Sunshine ng pera para magpalaglag ng bata? Walang intro-intro, dumukot sa bulsa si Miggy, binigyan nya si Sunshine ng 5k. 5000 pesos!Nalaman ng tatay ni Miggy na nakabuntis sya? Edi sige, sasagutin nila lahat ng hospital bills nya. Susustentuhan nila ang magiging bata until mag-18 ito. Pag-aaralin nila sa Ateneo, La Salle, you name it.Money is not an issue for them.The runners up are:2. Gift of God ang pangalan ng jeep na sinakyan ni Sunshine papunta sa Quiapo for the first time.3. I think (and maybe this is a reach), deliberate ang decision na pink and yellow ang official colors ng movie nato.I am a mark for this film. I have no distance from it. It is a match between Jun Robles Lana and Direk Tonet as my favorite active Filipino filmmaker right now tapos crush ko na si Maris PBB days nya pa lang. Of course Iâ€™m gonna love it.

Sunshine (Maris Racal) is a record-breaking national athlete, but the film fails to show the weight of that achievement.She wears a tank top marked â€œAsian Games 2018,â€ and her coach (Meryll Soriano) warns her against complacency: â€œBalewala lahat ng gold mo sa Asian Games.â€Since the Asian Games are held every four years, and Sunshine is about 19 or 20, this suggests she won multiple golds in 2018 â€” a rare feat. She would be gymnastics royalty, a media darling, likely the most successful Filipina rhythmic gymnast in history.Yet the film doesnâ€™t show her as a public figure. No news clippings, no media buzz, no crowdsâ€”just a few kids asking for a selfie. It also focuses mostly on her ribbon routine, barely showing the hoop, ball, or clubsâ€”all key to establishing her as Olympic-level.Sunshineâ€™s decision to abort is quick, and her fears and ambitions are underexplored. The Olympics, in fact, feel more like her coachâ€™s dreamâ€”the film tells us this but doesnâ€™t show it.Thereâ€™s no pressure from a country rooting for her, nor from sponsors who presumably funded her expensive training (which weâ€™re left to assume, since rhythmic gymnastics is an elite sport). No rival gymnast, no sense of competition, no major stakes, and no real glimpse into the demanding world of elite sport.All this undercuts the tension around her unwanted pregnancy.Jadaone instead spends a chunk of screen time on soapy magical realism. An imaginary, foul-mouthed child follows Sunshine around, mocking her decisions. But instead of adding insight, this character becomes repetitive and irritating.Rhed Bustamante plays another pregnant teen, awkwardly inserted into the plot in an effort to cover too many sides of the abortion debate. But Rhedâ€™s more serious situation makes Sunshineâ€™s dilemma feel shallowâ€”like a story about a girl careless with sex and unwilling to face the consequences.Some visuals in Sunshine hit hard: abortifacients sold beside religious icons outside Quiapo Churchâ€”a jab at how the Catholic Church, in practice, is more ritual than moral compass. Thereâ€™s also a grim motel scene. But these moments canâ€™t save the film.Set in the predominantly Catholic Philippines, where abortion is illegal, Sunshine tries to raise issues around teen pregnancy and reproductive rights, like overcrowded maternity wards. True enough, the Philippines has one of the highest teenage pregnancy rates in Southeast Asia, especially among the poor.But if a film brings this up, it must give some context. The Reproductive Health Law, passed only in 2012, was meant to helpâ€”but the Catholic Bishopsâ€™ Conference of the Philippines (CBCP) continues to fight tooth and nail against sex education and birth control.The film ignores all this. Instead, it gives us a cartoonish, Bible-thumping doctor and a patriarchal pastorâ€”villains standing in for real problems. We donâ€™t expect to be spoon-fed, but when a film enters controversial ground and hints at bigger issues, it has a duty to avoid shallow symbols.In the end, Sunshine parrots Western slogans like â€œMy body, my choiceâ€ without anchoring its stance in the Philippine context. The message feels imported and emotionally flat.ğŸ”´READ FULL REVIEW (DAILY TRIBUNE): https://tribune.net.ph/2025/07/26/sunshine-review-abortion-tale-misses-the-mark

In a world full of questions like â€œNaiintindihan mo ba ako?â€, dare to be the one who says, â€œGets ko na.â€The social relevance of this film lies in its powerful commentary on how women should be given the right to own their bodies. Iâ€™m in awe of how socially conscious the film is, and how realistically it depicts the struggles of women living in a conservative and non-progressive world.I truly hope people will be moved by this film and realize that itâ€™s not just about faith and beliefsâ€”itâ€™s about giving women an equal chance at life by listening to them, understanding where they come from, and supporting where they want to go.This film should be seen, heard, and felt.At dahil diyan, oo sunshineâ€”naiintindihan na kita.P.S. This film is not just about abortion. Itâ€™s deeper than that. Itâ€™s also about our healthcare system, and so much more. I wonâ€™t spoil anything elseâ€”just go watch it.

Ang lungkot.The credits started rolling and I sat there, dazed and tear-stained. I wanted to sing my praises to the movie (and I do!) pero mas nangibabaw sa akin ang sakit.Marami akong gustong punahin. Mga detalyeng mas lalong binigyan ng laman ang buhay ni Sunshine. Like how she was always framed between rails. Clearly an artistic choice, but to me, she was caged throughout the film. By judgment. By society's cruelty. By this country's refusal to grant women autonomy over their own bodies.Wherever she goes, the spaces are as narrow as her choices. Masikip sa bahay kung saan nakikita mo kung paano natapos ang pangarap ng ate niya. Masikip sa paaralan kung saan mag-isa niyang nilalabanan ang mga mapangmatang titig at pandidiri. Masikip sa Quiapo kung saan siya laging tumatakbo at naghahanap ng paraan para makalaya.Masikip sa ospitalâ€”ospital kung saan nilalarawan ang kakulangan sa magandang serbisyo. Ospital kung saan nahuhusgahan ang maraming kababaihan.The only time Sunshine's world seems to widen and glow is when she's inside the training center. Doon lang siya malaya. Doon lang may ngiti sa kanyang mga labi. At sana doon din natin maintindihan kung anong pinaglalaban ng pelikula. Sana gets mo na.Masaya akong may pelikulang ganito. Pero nangingibabaw ang lungkot. What if this is another film on the big screen that will be forgotten soon? I remember watching Brocka's Manila sa Kuko nang Liwanag and saw how many of its harsh truths are still prevalent today. Walang pagbabago. Walang usad. Mahirap pa rin.The real pain of the movie is when we watch it years later and the truth remains: women still have to bleed to fight for their rights.Sana hindi.

Sunshine is another powerful film from Antoinette Jadaone. Beautifully written and brought to life by a powerful cast. Itâ€™s a riveting story that, hopefully, sparks important conversations about womanâ€™s right to choose for herself.

"Gets ko na"Lots of ways to interpret a simple line. Kung kakampi ka man ni Sunshine simula o hindi, you will leave the cinema with the same echoing thought. Gets mo na. Absolutely enjoyed the solidarity between women in this film, but appreciated that it doesn't let you forget that other women can be a complicit to women's oppression too.Outstanding performance from the whole cast. Salamat sa husay at tapang Direk Tonet.

Layunin ng Comprehensive Sexuality Education (CSE) na magkaroon ng kamalayan ang kabataan sa mga isyu ng seksuwalidad lalo pa na nasa yugto sila na tinutuklas ito. Sa kabilang banda, kontrobersiyal ito sa ating bansang Katolisismo ang pinakalaganap na relihiyon. Gayundin ang usapin ng aborsiyon. Sa panulat at direksiyon ni Antoinette Jadaone, isa itong pelikulang sports drama na umiikot kay Sunshine (Maris Racal) na kailangan magpasiya kung ipagpapatuloy o hindi ang pagbubuntis habang papalapit ang kaniyang paglahok sa pambansang paligsahan sa rhythmic gymnastics. Walang tapon sa bawat kuha ng mga eksena, kahit na sa mga background audio nito, sapagkat sumisimbolo ito sa kalagayan ng Pilipina sa ating patriyarkal na lipunan. Nagustuhan ko ang panulat at direksiyon nito dahil sang-ayon sa sinabi ng aking kaibigan, naiparanas nito ang pakiramdam na may isa kang kakilala na kahalintulad ni Sunshine. Bukod dito, naiparamdam nito na kasama ka sa pelikula. Iyong tipong sinubaybayan mo rin ang paglalakbay ni Sunshine sa saanmang sulok ng Maynila. Kaya, makakaugnay at mailalagay mo ang sarili sa kalagayan ng pangunahing tauhan o sa sinuman. Malinis din ang pagkaka-edit ng pelikula sapagkat malinaw sa direktor kung ano ang nais niyang mangyari kay Sunshine. Piling-pili ang mga eksena kaya ang hirap pumili ng pinakamaganda o pinakanagustuhan. Hangang-hanga rin ako disenyong pamproduksyon nito dahil bukod sa ginalugad talaga ang madidilim na espasyo ng Maynila, iniisip ko kung paano sila nakapag-shooting sa ganoong karaming tao. Grabeng blockings niyon. Karapat-dapat talaga na papurihan si Racal sa kaniyang pagganap dito. Tama lamang ang timpla ng iba't ibang emosyon ang ipinamalas niya rito. Ngunit ang pinakanakabibilib sa lahat, magaling din ang mga pantulong na tauhan kaya napalitaw nito ang husay ng pangunahing artista. Ang tinginan nila ni Thea (Xyriel Manabat). Ang coach na tila pangalawang nanay na si Eden (Meryll Soriano). Ang misterysong batang babae (Annika Co). Ang kakampi na si Geleen (Jennica Garcia). Kahit na ang lokong si Miguel (Elijah Canlas). May ambag silang lahat upang mapagtibay ang karakterisasyon ni Sunshine at ang husay ni Racal. Ang ganitong pelikula ang nagbibigay ng dahilan kung bakit mahalaga na mayroong CSE at kung bakit kailangan mapag-usapan at mapag-isipan muli ang legal at siyentipikong pagpapalaglag. Babae man o lalaki, kahit na ang LGBTQIA+, binibigyan tayo nito ng awtoridad sa ating katawan. Sa kabuuan, nagustuhan ko ang "Fangirl" (2020) ni Direk Tonet na naglarawan ng estado ng babae sa rehimeng Duterte. Higit pa sa debate ng aborsiyon, napaibig ako sa "Sunshine" dahil sa pagpapakita nito ng tunay na ideya ng feminismo - ang pagkakaroon ng kalayaang pumili at ng kakampi.

i rarely rave about indie films that tackle societal issues because the ones i've watched either sound too preachy or abstract that it's difficult to grasp. but sunshine proved to be different and that's why i loved it so much. it never tells you whether abortion is right or wrong. instead, it shows you a genuine depiction of the lived realities of girls like sunshine and mary grace and gets you thinking about the many other girls/women like them long after you leave the theater. ang hirap maging babae sa mundo, lalo na rito sa pilipinas pero pinaalala sa akin ni sunshine na kailangan kong tapangan at lumaban di lang para sa akin kundi para sa iba pang kababaihang kasama ko sa araw-araw na laban.

Sunshine presents a two-pronged takeoff on putting forth a controversial subject it aims to transfigure into a discourse. Itâ€™s gritty yet poignant, a dichotomy facilitated by careful restraint in its direction, intricate cinematography, and Maris Racalâ€™s stellar performance.The film deflects clichÃ©s observed in Filipino melodramas that often rely on overly oppressive emotional tropes and techniques. Most notably, it veers away from positioning religion or the Church as a central source of female agency. Instead, it presents it as an androcentric institution where permission for a womanâ€™s reproductive health decisions must be sought, implying a strong assertion of control and dominance over womenâ€™s bodies.Set against the backdrop of bustling, grunge-textured Manila, the camera takes a remarkable grasp on the parallelisms and minutiae of everyday life in the cruel city: a crowded train moving across the metro juxtaposed against a dreary room in Avenida; an abortifacient vendor sitting by a display of Mary Magdalene busts she sells in Quiapo; a tight-knit community devoid of love and empathy for a child.The film refuses to paint the gaps and seams of a faulty society in broad strokes. Sunshine is delicately crafted and measured. It deeply delves into the nuances and detailed complexities of living in a Christian society that has, ironically and deliberately, chosen to position womenâ€™s rights on the periphery.It taps into female solidarity as a form of agency and collective resistance, offering both an idealistic and pragmatic antithesis to the marginalization they have long been experiencing.Reminiscent of Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s pre-studio works such as Plano (2004) and Saling Pusa (2006), Sunshine feels like a beautiful work of personal musings. It is honest, outrageous, yet tenderâ€”marking one of her greatest directorial masterpieces.
a narrative film that tackles relevant issues in the philippines: reproductive health, abortion, poverty, misogyny, etc.

I think it's safe to say by now that Antoinette Jadaone is one of the greats of Philippine Cinema. And not just of now, but of all time. The still-young filmmaker, who cut her teeth on quirky indie comedies ( Six Degrees of Lilya Cuntapay, Beauty in a Bottle) soon became the new queen of Pinoy Romantic Comedies, resulting in an 8-films-in-5-years streak that included classics like That Thing Called Tadhana, Never Not Love You and Alone/Together. Then in 2020, something changed. At the height of the pandemic, Tonet released Fan Girl -- an unflinching, searing commentary on celebrity worship, toxic masculinity and patriarchal oppression in the Philippines. It not only won all the major awards during that year's MMFF, but was also the highest-grossing film for that year. This makes Tonet somewhat of a unicorn: a writer/director who can make socially relevant, intelligent cinema but at the same time kill it at the box office. This feat is especially astounding in a year when zero films have actually made money. And so that six-year streak turned into a five-year absence, and wisely so. Tonet channeled her creative juices towards other roles and mediums: television, streaming, producing. I'm a big believer in taking care of one's filmography, and she's doing just that. And as fans we have finally been rewarded. Hello, Sunshine. Sunshine follows a slew of, and there's no non-blunt way to put it, abortion movies that have come to the fore in the 2020s. You have the US's Never Rarely Sometimes Always and France's L'Ã‰vÃ©nement. All films follow the internal struggle and loneliness that women face when going through the abortion process. Of the three, Sunshine is the most powerful for one simple reason: it's set in the Philippines. And while it hits home because it is home, the oppression, hypocrisy and outright strangeness of the system makes this abortion story unique. It's a country where you can find ads for abortives just buy typing in "abortion" in your instagram search terms, where a vendor of Catholic paraphernalia situated outside a church will also peddle Cytotec, where a doctor who saves your life will also give you a 5-minute telling-to once you're well enough to listen. It's a country where self-righteous sanctimonium has endangered millions of young women's lives. Sunshine is pro-choice, but it's also pro-life. It never tries to turn away from the consequences and the trauma women go through when making this decision. And it shows us what could have been, never cheapening the lives that were lost. These layers, the emotional depth with which Tonet imbues Sunshine, are what sets it apart. It's a very thought provoking film, but it aims straight for the heart. I've spent all this time singing Tonet's praises, but of course Sunshine wouldn't be Sunshine without the brilliant Maris Racal. I meant it when I said that Maris is a generational talent: a true actress with genuine love for the craft who just also happens to be incredibly popular. She breathes so much life and attitude into Sunshine that she really feels like a friend. Someone you're rooting for, someone whose pain you understand.It's a very important film, but don't let its importance weigh you down. End of the day, like all of Tonet's films, it's a story well told with characters you genuinely care about. Sunshine is now showing in all SM Malls. Please do go out and catch it right away.

WOMEN INDEED HAVE THE MOST AUTONOMY OVER THEIR BODIES! PERIOD! Malinaw ang mensahe ng pelikula at napakaganda ng pagkakahabi ng istorya at kung paano ang repleksyon nito sa lipunan. Worth it ang paghihintay. Para kay Maris ang film na â€˜to. Walang ibang artista na dapat gumanap kundi si Maris lang, she perfectly owned this film. Grabe braincells ni Direk Tonet, napakahusay! Technicality speaking, grabe iba ang Pao Orendain walang tapon na cinematography shots grabe ang pulido. Screenplay, grabe sobrang husay ni Direk Tonet nangungusap ang bawat salita sa masa â€” malinaw ang mensahe at may pinaglalaban.Isa lamang to sad and painful reality ng mga kababaihan. Yung film na â€˜to hindi lang siya kwento ng aborsyon, kwento rin ito ng mga taong handang sumuporta sa desisyon ng mga kababaihan â€” ate, kaibagan, coach etc. Grabe yung scene ni Jennica and Maris sa kama, it hit me so bad! Ultimately, these stories are real. These realities exist. Kaya ang isyu ng aborsyon ay importanteng pag-usapan, unawain, at huwag ipagsawalang bahala lamang. Totoo ang dinaranas ng napakaraming Sunshines sa Pilipinas. Salamat sa buhay at istorya mo, Sunshine! Gets ko na! Kuhang-kuha mo ang respeto at pagmamahal ko sa mga kababaihan, Sunshine! Sunshine explores the balance beam of morality, tipping between the push to reclaim bodily autonomy and the pull of Catholic guilt. Itâ€™s interesting how the filmâ€™s key scenes are set in the dark, sketchy streets of Quiapo â€” a reflection of how young Filipinas navigate the lifelong, generational burden of taking control of our own bodies, while still trying to stay in line with the same dark and sketchy standards set by the very society that claims to protect us from it.

This is the sunshine the country needs in todayâ€™s climate.It was Jadaoneâ€™s courage that popped in my head when the title card flashed, a very Filipina name that connotes brightness and warmth â€” two things the film was not intended for, two things the titular character was deprived of. Sunshine is a story of every Sunshine, a Filipino woman vulnerable to systemic injustice and oppression; a story no one could have been told better than a Filipino woman herself â€” and a fearless and intelligent one at that. From reproductive health and general health care system to conservatism, Jadaoneâ€™s care and spirit championed. Her personification of oneâ€™s conscience was beautifully done. I sobbed through the last 15 minutes.True-to-life darkness in the country executed from the literal streets to the contexts of quality of life through Orendainâ€™s realism. Thereâ€™s a harrowing frame in the movie that ticked all my boxes as a fan of dark cinematography. I bled in the dark with Sunshine right there.This film boasts a talented bundle of actresses: Meryll Soriano, Annika Co, Xyriel Manabat, Jennica Garcia, with Maris Racal tying the ribbon, flexing her acting muscles across different tones and needs. Well-written and well-directed performances with standouts coming from Garcia, Co, and Racal. Ah, women.Malalim. Matapang. Mahalaga. Hindi ako babae pero gets na gets kita, Sunshine.

This movie encourages the discussion about reproductive health and how it harms more than it protects those who are directly involved the longer this societal taboo regarding topics like abortion and sex education gets ignored.Sobrang gets ko si Sunshine, magmula doon sa guilt, sa despair, hanggang sa acceptance niya na may karapatan siyang pumili ng nararapat para sa sarili niya. She did it not for anyone else but for herself. Sana mas dumami pa ang makaintindi hindi lang sa naging sitwasyon niya, sa sitwasyon ni Menggay, pero maging sa marami pang kwento ng bawat babae sa mundo.Movie wise, para sa akin, maganda ang pacing. Maayos na naihayag ang kwento ni Sunshine na hindi minadali. Sakto lang para maintindihan pero bibigyan ka pa rin ng karapatan bilang manonood na mag isip. Patawa-tawa lang madalas si Direk Tonet sa AWKP pero ang bawat kwento na inihahayag niya sa mga pelikula niya ay may kirot, may substance, may relevance. Talk about versatility, eme!

There is much to commend about the film and it could have been even more impactful had it fully leaned into its intention of confronting the realities surrounding abortion and calling out institutions to respond with compassion and accountability. While it could have been stronger had it fully explored the idea of safe abortion and pushed institutions to respond, the filmâ€™s restraint is understandable given the legal and cultural context. It opens the door for more Filipino films that reflect the lived experiences of many, especially women whose struggles have long been sidelined. Sunshine is deeply human, and in that honesty lies its strength.
Gets kita, Sunshine.

Within the streets live the busiest minds of pain and anguish that are continuously being punished by a conservative system. Totoong tapang, totoong kuwento, totoong bigat, at totoong pagpapakasakit na sana ay tumawid sa lakas na bumago sa kakulangan. This film vividly speaks that Sunshine's story of courage should not be romanticized or praised, but her womanhood and choice must be liberated.

â€œBakit ka ba takbo nang takbo? Mahirap yan. Tumatakbo tapos di alam kung saan pupunta.â€i faintly remember this video explaining the absence of young prodigies in the film industry. because unlike athletes, the field doesnâ€™t merely rely on oneâ€™s prime to succeed. instead, it honors the individualâ€™s maturity, discernment, and time spent in understanding life. this is what i felt in Direk Tonetâ€™s recent slew of films. since Fan Girl (2020), it feels like sheâ€™s found her voiceÂ¹. informed, empowered, and deeply understanding. with her latest offering, Sunshine, i have to applaud her for having the guts to tell such a delicate story, a sensitive subject matterâ€”in a predominantly Catholic country where abortion is illegal, no less.Sunshineâ€™s charm lies in showing the grim reality of the city, the sheer obliviousness of the night, the secret alliance of the system and culture continually perpetuating harsh conditions for women and their bodies. itâ€™s an incisive picture for us to empathize with the Sunshines of this world, with their dreams at the palm of their hands but their backs against the wallâ€”deprived of freedom, options, and utmost support. and donâ€™t you find it endearing that the ensemble that helped Sunshineâ€™s reckoning are all women? from her gymnastics coach, the motel receptionist, her estranged bestfriend, the healthcare professional, and, of course, her loving sisterÂ².watching Sunshine is important to open the discussion and continue the conversation on womenâ€™s bodily autonomy. and maybe it all starts with an understanding, a mutual agreement, and someone who will say â€œGets kita.â€ like a heartfelt acknowledgment.___Â¹ one could argue itâ€™s already burgeoning since Never Not Love You (2018)Â² Jennica Garcia the artist that you are

"Sunshine" is not just the greatest Filipino movie I've seen but one of the most important Filipino films of all-time! This film deals with controversial topics in our society, abortion and teen pregnancy. A week of national tryout for the gymnast, Sunshine (Maris Racal) finds out that she's pregnant. Conflicts arise as she has to decide what to do next. In between life and dreams, what's the most significant between the two?The film is unconventional at best. This is not your usual and average Filipino drama you'll see. It's a character study about a teenager who is on the down side of her life. We follow her journey through this life and see a glimpse of her life dealing with her problem. Maris Racal defines this film as Sunshine. Her acting here is brilliant. She's perfect for this role. Jennica Garcia surprised me. Her character as Sunshine 's sister marks! What she said to Sunshine near the ending, though it's common, is like a punch to tears! I ended up loving her character. Jennica Garcia deserves an award for being the best supporting actress for this role. Another cast that standout is Rhed Bustamante and Xyriel Manabat both deserve a recognition for their role.Blurring between reality and fantasy, mostly this film is realistic in portraying the whole theme thanks to Direk Antoinette Jadaone directions. Also, the cinematography is the best! Overall, "Sunshine" is a women's movie. It's timely, affecting and brave to its theme. It doesn't spoon feed. It will make you immersed and think. It's worth an experience. This is a rare Filipino movie I've seen! I'm glad and proud watching this in cinema. After watching "Sunshine", it leaves me with a question, "Is abortion a choice if your greatest dream will compromise?"

Antoinette Jadaone's most polished work yet since NEVER NOT LOVE YOU. With a very strong social commentary on unwanted pregnancy and abortion, Jadaone navigates the pain and heartbreak of a woman in the person of Maris Racal as SUNSHINE. A gymnast aiming for Olympics but the conflict arise when she got pregnant. With her electrifying performance a shoo-in already for the next award derby Maris is deserving of all the future trophies that will be bestowed to her.Maris Racal and Annika Co are both fantastic!SUNSHINE is what we need during bad times.

i mean before anything else: maris racal is RIDICULOUSLY good in this. like, she's really one of the greats we got in the philippines right now. i seriously need to tap into her other work.but wow. what a film. it never really tries to pull back with handling the topic of abortion and how taboo it is here. and it doesn't make it some overdramatic thing at points too because... it's all real, once we pull back one surreal element the film has. the way the people treat it, talk down on it, that near total disregard for the pregnant person. it's heartbreaking. watching this just made me think of how much people act like men and women are wholly equal under the eyes of the law in the philippines. but with incidents like what's seen in the film still happening, is that really the case?a real shame that this will be in like three theaters by the time wednesday rolls around. even then, i'm glad a film that handles a difficult topic was able to screen nationwide. i seriously hope this film resonates with people this opens up more minds.

MARIS RACAL IS JUST THE DAMN QUEEN!!! â¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸ thats my pbb bias right there bro ğŸ¥¹ğŸ¥¹ğŸ¥¹ğŸ¥¹ iyak ako hard cheee idk if what i'll say will do any justice to how i feel pero 1st things 1st..... that scene sa umpisa nung nalaman ni maris na buntis siya tas sumakay siyang jeep na nakapinturang "GIFT OF GOD" sa harap GODDAMN!!!! tas bumaba siya nun sa quiapo church para magsorry kay Hesus fak!!! that was so simple yet so poignant to me. that & the rest of the catholic imagery throughout!! how we view mga anak sa sapupunan as biyaya ng Diyos na di dapat tanggihan... so much deliberateness & intention... tas ang ganda nung dalawang frame na nasa kwarto si maris (nag-eensayo sa kwarto niya/nagttake nung gamot sa inn) tas kita yung kalye/kalsada. yung busina ng tren habang sinusubukan ni sunshine na magpalaglag, etc etc. tatak talaga siya sakin. the film never fails to let us know na tagarito si marisâ€”ito ang syudad, ito ang sistema na bumibigo sa kanya at sa mga babaeng tulad niya. love how the message is clear without being too on the nose about it, the ugly state of the maternity ward, the doctors that serve the system vs those that TRULY serve the people, the kids that that teeter on magical realism and shatter the illusion of a fetus' seeming otherworldly potential once let out and born.

The film successfully captured the nuances of a teenage girl in a college setting. Interesting na rhythmic gymnastics ang sports ni Sunshine (Maris Racal). Hindi ito kilala sa ating bansa pero kitang-kita sa sports na ito na kailangan ng marinading determinasyon at disiplina hindi lamang sa larangan ng sports dito sa Pilipinas pati na rin sa paghahanda sa paglaban sa Olympics. Kaya naman ng mabuntis si Sunshine ay naharap siya sa isang desisyong babago sa kanyang buhay at sa mga tao sa paligid niya. Ilan sa mga isyu na nilatag ng pelikula ay ang kakulangan ng sex education at accessibility ng legal abortion sa Pilipinas dahil na rin sa konserbatibong paniniwala. Idagdag pa ang kulang na suporta ng gobyerno pagdating sa ating atleta tulad na lamang sa eksenang sila pa mismo ng pamilya niya ang naghanda ng kanyang isusuot sa Olympics. Religious hypocrisy din ang kinokompronta ng pelikula tulad sa eksenang giniguilt trip ng isang sarado Katoliko na OB GYNE at muli ring pang-guilt trip sa kanya ng pastor na ama ni Miggy kay Sunshine. Si Miggy ay pastor kid na nakabuntis sa dalaga. Hindi na rin naman bago ang pagtalakay ng abortion sa Pilipinas sa pelikulang Pilipino dahil nariyan ang "High School Scandal" (1982) sa direksyon ni Gil Portes at "Hinugot sa Langit" (1985) na pinagbidahan ni Maricel Soriano at dinirek ni Ishmael Bernal. Ang kagandahan ng pelikula ay babaeng filmmaker ang lumikha at alam niya ang nadarama at pinagdadaanan mapa-pisikal, emosyonal at sikolohikal ng kapwa babae. Napakahusay ni Maris Racal sa pelikulang ito. Ang laking tulong ng cinematog kasi 'yun ang nag-set ng tone at mood ng pelikula over-all. Somewhat reminded of "Gusto kita with all my hypothalamus" pagdating sa cinematog. Regarding sa discussion of abortion, medyo closer sa controversial indie film na "Call Jane".

sunshine enlightened me on so many aspects of my womanhood that i feel like i haven't been able to sit down and reflect on yet. sunshine and i are different but i felt her struggle with not knowing what to do with what was going on in her body, and not wanting to disappoint the women and family who have built her up to reach her dream that is now at risk. i knew how it felt to have female friendships i turned to for support and strength, and how heartbreaking it is to lose them. so many scenes made me tear up because of how much it felt like it could really happen and how much it does happen. there are relatives that talk like that and there are doctors that have to risk their license to do exactly what a doctor should do. each theme and character was so intentionally and realistically portrayed that it all made sense, even to the part of my mind that plays devil's advocate when it comes to films like this.sunshine really is a must-watch for everyone para ma-gets mo na.ang galing tlga ng cast bruh

SUNSHINE (2024)3.8/5 SAME, ARIANAâ€¦ Sheâ€™s a main biÃ tch!! HAHAHAHA GETS KO NA!! Isa sa mga pinakapulidong gawa ni Direk Tonet. Ka-EME represent, alongside â€œNever Not Love Youâ€ & the iconic â€œBeauty In A Bottleâ€ and â€œThat Thing Called Tadhana.â€ Maris Racal literally emanated Sunshine!! Sheâ€™s a ray of sunshine. This film is really for her. I didnâ€™t know who else can bring Sunshine to life than her. & ANNIKA CO & JENNICA GARCIAâ€¦. ACTING MASTERCLASS!! MY FAVES IN ONE FRAME!! THE Xyriel Manabat couldâ€™ve been maximized more kasi halimaw sa actingan masterclass, but I think she had a proper exit. It is a delight to see Ms. Angeli Bayaniâ€™s presence contrary to her former portrayals. Her character only appeared for how many seconds, BUT THE IMPACT OF HER EXPOSURE IS OVER THE TOP!! Ang nagpalaylay sa storyline is not the open ending, but a rushed conclusion of the problem. Nasagot nga ba ang problema? Anong nangyari kina Miggy at Sunshine? Is â€˜Ari-yun-uhâ€™ also a personification that Sunshine only imagine, like Annikaâ€™s character? Hindi ko maramdaman ang father and son dynamic nina Elijah Canlas and Mr. Piolo Pascual. However, Pioloâ€™s character, as Pastor Jaime couldâ€™ve been explained and discovered more, and not pressed in a few minute exposure. What stood out in the film were Maris, Jennica, Annika, and â€œArianaâ€â€˜s portrayal. Also, Sunshine, due to her juvenile age, can be prone to misconception and misinformation. In a predominantly Catholic country wherein proper sex education and proper healthcare system are nowhere to be found, and practices are dictated by religion and morality, relying on social media platforms as search engines would mean that sheâ€™s susceptible to wrong notions of her reality, which may lead her to resort to the sudden decisions that she make. The debate between religion and choice is long-going in the Philippine context. If the international audiences accepted this film with open arms, itâ€™s about time that the Philippines does the same, and the filmâ€™s message would transgress to those without an open mind and for those who are unawakened with the harsh realities that most â€œSunshineâ€ faces.

Manila in its rawest form. I was teary eyed through the whole movie but something in the scenes always felt lacking. And then I remembered some actual close friends who were once in the same situation, who once asked for my help and company. That what they actually needed was people who would understand and hear them and not who would feel bad for them. This did not intend to resolve anything, cos we have been seeing this in real life and in the news. But this was a good reminder that after all these headlines, after all the movies that tackled the same story, and after all the social media awareness, IS ITâ€™S STILL A PERSISTING PROBLEM FOR MANY FILIPINO CHILDREN AND WOMEN. That we have still yet to save these women, that our authorities still donâ€™t care, and these women are still in danger. MALALA ANG HEALTHCARE, MALALA RIN ANG JUDGMENT! Iâ€™m pro-choice because I advocate for a world where children could be children and play freely and grow old and love the life thatâ€™s ahead of them. I LOVE YOU SUNSHINE FRIENDS! Your reasons will die with me <3

Ito ang ibig kong sabihin kapag sinasabi kong may problematic pattern sa ilang pelikula. Layunin nito ay marahil ipakita ang pinakamasalimuot na kalagayan ng ating lipunan, subalit nauuwi lagi sa paggamit ng trauma at karahasan bilang device lamang. Sa paraang ito, yumuyugto ang kawalan ng respeto sa lived experiences ng mga biktima. Sunshine, however, is not that kind of film.Sa halip na pagsamantalahan ang lunan ng karanasan ng mga kababaihan, pinili ng pelikula na maging mapanagot. It is a story about women, in a world that constantly tries to pin them and to deny them full autonomy and diginity for themselves. Naging maingat at makatao si Direk Tonet sa treatment niya rito sa Sunshine. Hindi niya sinensationalize ang karahasan, bagkus ginawa ito nang may paggalang. Inilantad ang katotohanan pero hindi iniwan sa dulo ang mga biktima at maging ang mga manonood. In this film, we see a woman who is brave. A woman who insists on choosing for herself. A woman who, despite everything, claims her shine. To Sunshine, and to many sunshines out there: ang sinag ninyo ay magmumula sa inyo lamang. Hindi ito hinihiram, hindi ito ibinibigay, sa inyo ito at sa inyo lamang. Kasi gaano man kadilim ang lipunan sa atin, women will always be the brightest. ğŸŒŸ

â€œAng pangarap niya ay pangarap ko rinâ€Habang pinapanuod ko â€˜to di ko maiwasan maalala yung mga students ko babae na maaga nabuntis. Magkakaiba ng kwento pero pinagkapareho nila ay babae ang laging talo sa kwento. Higit sa pasanin nila sa buhay dahil sa pagbubuntis. Dala rin nila yung panghuhusga ng mga tao. Lalabas na malaki ang tyan e, masasabihan ng malandi, mapusok o disgrayada. Dala rin ng babae yung hirap na pisikal, mental at pinansyal ng pagbubuntis. Habang ang nakabuntis sa kanila - madalas buhay binata na. Walang dalang kahit anong bakas ng kahihiyan. Isa rin sa pinaka nalulungkot ako, ay pansamatalang hihinto ang buhay ng mga pangarap ng batang ito para magbigay daan sa dinadala niya. Hindi lahat ng babae ay may privilege na makapag aral muli o mapursige ang pangarap nila pagkatapos magkaanak.Hirap maging babae sa Pilipinas. Hirap maging babae.Laging talo sa mundo di tayo kinakampihan.Sana mapanuod pa ng mas madami. Safe and accessible option for abortion sa Pinas isulong na.

one thing i loved with sunshine is that it really makes you feel her struggle and her dilemma.i'm a guy, i could never really personally go through what sunshine experienced in the movie, but i could still feel what she felt. the struggle between putting your dreams to a halt because of one setback and pushing through despite it all.i was a bit worried that the movie would somehow swerve in the middle with its message, and i'm glad it didn't. it really committed the whole time and it tackled such a sensitive topic with seriousness and grace.the movie showed us how difficult simply living as a woman in the philippines could be, so much so that the only characters seen helping sunshine are women for the most part.maris racal is a generational talent, and sunshine is proof that she is and always will last in this industry if she is just given scripts where she can shine.(p.s. piolo pascual is just the spitting image of my dad at this point that it took me out of the movie for a while)(p.p.s. who decided to hire rico blanco for the score and what was their thought process behind the whole thing)

Nauso na sa mga Pinoy viewers na hihintayin na lang nila sa Netflix yung mga pelikulang Pilipino. Para raw makatipid. Pero karamihan sa kanila, willing gumastos kapag Western superhero movie ang papanoorin. Gets naman din kasi nga may escapism kapag sinasalba ni Superman o ng Fantastic Four ang New York City kumpara sa mga realist stories sa Pilipinas. Bat nga naman kailangan ng malaking screen para lang makitang nag-aaway si Dingdong Dantes at Charo Santos?Pero please, panoorin niyo ang mga pelikulang Pilipino sa big screen, lalo na yung may magandang istorya na maaaring magbigay-linaw pa sa mga isyu. Tulad na lang ng Sunshine ni Antoinette Jadaone. Tungkol ito kay Sunshine (Maris Racal) na naghahanap ng paaran na magpa-abort dahil sa napakaraming rason: hindi planado ang kanyang pagbubuntis, ayaw siyang panagutan ng nakabuntis sa kanya, ayaw na siyang samahan ng kanyang kaibigan, pagtsi-tsismisan siya, at mauudlot ang kanyang pangarap na maging Olympian. Sa dami ng kanyang rason, simple lang naman ang kanyang dahilan: ayaw pa niya maging nanay.Ito ang unang Pinoy film na napanood ko na talagang sinusulong ang karapatan ng babae para sa kanyang katawan. At sa dami ng pinagdaanan ni Sunshine, kahit na may reservations ka sa isyu ng abortion, gugustuhin mong matupad ang gusto ng ating bida. Ramdam na ramdam ko kay Maris ang mga dinadalang problema ni Sunshine hindi lamang bilang isang aspiring Olympian kundi ang isang pagiging babae sa Pilipinas kung saan malakas ang impluwensya ng Catholic values sa ating mga batas.Intersectional din ang pagtalakay ni Jadaone sa isyu ng abortion sa Sunshine. Hindi ito basta-bastang women's rights na nakita natin sa Western media tulad ng Barbie (2024) at Sex Education (2019-2023). Hindi itinanggi o dinemonize ng pelikula ang Catholic guilt pero hinimay ito sa pamamagitan ng pag-humanize nito sa anyo ng batang babae na sumusunod kay Sunshine (Annika Co). Ang ganda ng chemistry nina Maris at Annika at ramdam mong iisa lang talaga sila.So, bakit nga ba dapat panoorin ang Sunshine sa sinehan imbes na hintayin sa Netflix o ano mang streaming service? Napakalalim ng isyu ng aborsyon at women's rights na dapat bigyan ito ng full attention. Pag naman nanonood tayo sa streaming service, may tendency tayong mag-check ng phone. Pero hindi dapat tayo ma-distract habang pinapanood natin si Sunshine. Pag naman sobrang intimidating yung scene, pwede nating i-pause. Pero sa mga ganitong storya, dapat hindi ito pina-pause. Ma-disturb dapat tayo sa ganitong kwento.

iba ka talaga, maris! sobrang hanga ako sa buong screenplay, walang unnecessary details. i am so so sooo delighted with the execution until the end. naramdaman ko ang hagupit ng pagiging babae. at mas nag-alab pa ang apoy sa aking puso upang ipaglaban ang ating karapatan nang aking lubusang masaksihan na ang mga pangyayari sa pelikula ay nangyayari sa totoong buhay at mas malala pa sa iba na walang akses sa sex education.tayong mga babae ay may pangarap, ngunit ang pag-asam nito ay may kaakibat na balakid na hindi madarama ng mga lalake. this is such an important film in our culture. ilang beses ako napa-â€œtanginaâ€ sa mga diyalogo ng mga relihiyosong tao at ng mga putanging mga lalaking walang bayag at konsensiya pero putok nang putok. kababaihan na nga ang nagdadala ng buhay, tapos sila pa lagi ang nakukutya. nasaan ang hustisya?reproductive rights are human rights and decriminalizing abortion will save a lot of women, lalo na ang mga batang babaeng walang kamuwang-muwang. hindi natatapos ang pakikibaka sa pelikula lamang kundi sa paghingi ng accountability sa gobyerno at pagbago sa kaisipan ng mga patriyarkal at konserbatibong tao. i hope many people would watch this and say, â€œgets ko na.â€ kasi gets na gets ko. sobra.

Antoinette Jadaone, gets ko na. Took me a minute to pause, reflect, and absorb the film with all of it. The power of the film is the way it presents and tackles about womanhood and abortion. How Jadaone, shows, and you get it without needing the tell part.Every woman in the film is amazingly presented. From the coach, doctor, sister, and teenager. Iâ€™m giving injustice and lackluster narrative of how powerful, impactful, and lustrous the film is. Each frame is enthralling, given Marisâ€™ powerful performance and how raw Manila is portrayed. You take it as it is. The mess, powering through the noise, and living it all every single day.The film also presents a huge middle finger to the hypocrisy of abortion and religion and how the only time Sunshine (Maris) felt free from her prison, which I must say is visually and creatively presented in the film is through her passion as a gymnast. Will try and revise this to write a cohesive review, but definitely glad I got the opportunity to watch this at the cinema.

either may kakilala kang parang si sunshine, or muntik nang maging si sunshine, or baka muntik ka nang maging si sunshine, or ikaw mismo si sunshine. or, you know, nanood ka lang at may naramdaman. at okay lang rin yun.yung gusto ko na ginawa ng pelikula ay na-explore niya yung delusyon ng unborn child ng isang babae. para sa akin ay innate feminine thing ito-- nagpapakita sila minsan sa panaginip. nagpakita yung akin sa isang panaginip. natakot ako. to have that fear manifest itself as this metaphysical, illusionary child that follows you around when faced with an unwanted pregnancy is so poignant and sickening. pasan talaga ng babae ang mundo dahil ang sarili niyang pag-iisip ay kinakalaban ng katawan niya. ng utak niya. and maybe that's why na-appreciate ko yung approach ng pelikula at ng writer-director na gamitin yung speaking-unborn-child motif na favorite ng mga pro-lyfers because to make someone see or understand something, you have to speak their language. may constant negotiation ang pelikula with its audience. take me seriously, pls, hear me out. wag mong tatanggalin ang mata mo sa screen. umiyak ka. sabing umiyak ka! and you know what, it closed the deal come the final show. i just wish it didn't end with that "gets ko na" line. nitpicky lang ako pero feel ko talaga mas maganda kung sa isang tanong siya nag end tapos final bow niya. wala naman kasi talagang makakaintindi sa buong sitwasyon mo, sunshine. matapang ka. nahihirapan ka. nararamdaman namin yun. but no one will ever understand how it feels until you are in that position.

for once there's no film that quite match what Sunshine did to me, emotionally. an absolute knockout in terms of its concept of bringing controversial topics about abortion and the struggle women face in search for accessible healthcare in the philippines on screen. it's rare to find films that touch most of the pressing issues in our culture, society, politics, and even in reproductive health. this was by far the most distressing and deeply harrowing depiction of teenage pregnancy i've watched since never rarely sometimes always. i'm on the edge of my seat the whole time. sobrang ganda na halos ako nakilabutan at napaiyak sa sudden escalation of events. must watch huhu.Ang tunay na sining ay nagsasalamin sa totoong pangyayari sa buhay, at ang pelikulang ito, ang pelikulang Sunshine, ay nagsisilbing patunay na buhay na buhay ang sining nating mga Pilipino.
A HORROR FILM FOR FILIPINAS AS WE WATCH THE PORTRAYAL OF OUR HELPLESSNESS AND LACK OF CHOICES REGARDING OUR BODIES, OUR LIVES!!!

Women are frequently placed in situations where they feel they have no choices due to the regressive and harsh judgment of society regarding our rights, particularly our right to safe healthcare. Sunshine, as a whole, has stood firm in its mission, showing why such story is important, as women continue to endure the repercussions of societal choices that place us in jeopardy. This film is undoubtedly one of those that was treated with so much care, showing little to no romanticization of the anger and struggles the characters faced, and most importantly, it did not conform to conservative ideologies.Maris Racal is definitely an actress to keep an eye on; her artistry and commitment to her craft shine through in this film. She certainly delivered one of the most valiant depictions of women in cinema, and it felt just right for her to bring the character of Sunshine to life.And of course, Antoinette Jadaone, who consistently brings depth and authenticity to her female characters, has done it again. As many have said, while anyone can create sociopolitical films, having women write and direct them adds a special touch that connects us to our shared struggles. Jadaone knows exactly how to write her female characters, and thereâ€™s nothing more beautiful than a woman who values the lives, journeys, successes, and struggles of her fellow women. Ultimately, as the film shows, itâ€™s women who always end up caring for one another. May we live in a lifetime where abortion is decriminalized and seen as a fundamental aspect of healthcare for every woman, ensuring that no woman ever has to confront death or risk her life due to circumstances that leave her with no choice.
ABANTE BABAE!

it feels like watching social media debates on abortion come to life. it covers familiar arguments, from â€œwhat if the baby could be a future presidentâ€ to real situations like abuse, unplanned pregnancies, and women not ready for motherhood. seeing it unfold makes the issue hit harder than words alone.it also calls out how both religion and close minded people can push views that ignore lived experiences. i loved how the possible future children were portrayed, like the little girl who acts just like sunshine, or the â€œtomboyâ€™sâ€ child being gay. the scenes felt real yet creative, and marisâ€™s acting was excellent.

took me some time to process that a filipino movie about a stigmatized issue was watched by a full theater (that included gen x/boomers!) even when 2 big hollywood films were screening too. this almost never happens to our indie films. props to the team for carefully crafting this. it wonâ€™t easily change peopleâ€™s minds, sure, but it opens up conversations about long-hidden stories of struggle. thatâ€™s better than nothing.

Wala akong sapat na karanasan para makipagdiskusyon ukol sa screenplay, sa directing, sa musical scoring, o sa writing ng pelikulang 'to. Pero dahil matapang na inilahad ni Direk Tonet ang kwento ng sangkababaihan, naiparamdam niya sa akin na sapat ang kaalaman ko para maintindihan ang gusto niyang iparating. Nasaksihan ko ang pelikulang isinulat hindi para mamilit, ngunit para magkwento.Para ito sa lahat ng naging ate, coach, menggay, doc helen, at iba pang kababaihan sa pelikula na nagpapatatag ng isang pagkatao sa mapanghusgang mundo. Mga babaeng nagpapadali sa mga karanasan ng kapwa kababaihan. Higit sa lahat, para ito sa iba pang mga Sunshine na piniling makawala sa pinaghalo-halong boses ng prinsipyo, moralidad, paniniwala, at kristiyanismo, para piliin ang pangarap niya.Kung iisipin, iisang Maynila ang nilalakaran, nasasaksihan, dinarasalan, at pinupuntahan natin. Pero ibaâ€™t-ibang buhay at konsepto ang pinaniniwalaan ng bawat kaluluwang minsan nang nanatili dito.Sa pagkilala ng mga babaeng piniling ialis ang kapit niya sa limitado at panandaliang kalayaan na ibinibigay ng sistemang ito, at sa panonood ng pelikula kahit hindi ikaw si Sunshine, sana maintindihan mo.

Dreams carry a powerful forceâ€”one that can drive people beyond the bounds of their morals. In the film Sunshine, this force is embodied by a young gymnast, whose ambition, fueled by societyâ€™s expectations of fame, pushes her to the edgeâ€”physically, psychologically, and morallyâ€”as she struggles with the weight of success and an unplanned pregnancy. Surrounding her are characters who reflect and intensify this tension: a doctor torn between personal ethics and the responsibility of helping an abortion patient; a street vendor selling both faith and death, caught in her own contradictions; a friend navigating the rift between her parentsâ€™ choices and her own agency; and a coach who, in relentlessly pushing her to break physical limits, unknowingly drives her toward moral collapse. The film offers a counterpoint through the voice of a childâ€”a quiet yet powerful presence that serves as both an echo of the gymnastâ€™s inner conscience and a projection of the expectations society imposes on her. This voice becomes a haunting reminder of who she is and who she is expected to be, grounding her in an innate moral compass even as sheâ€™s pulled deeper into chaos, anxiety, and confusion.Sunshine presents a world where the pursuit of dreams comes at a cost, and where ambition blurs the lines between resilience and ruin.

Mga kabataan ngayon di makapagpigil.Sabi ng bantay sa botika na buntis.I like any movie that utilizes metaphors to emphasize the severity of a situation. I think Annika's character was such an important part of the movieâ€”despite others saying it downplayed the severity of the situation since it was a whimsical conceptâ€”since it brought contrast as well as a different but important point of view in such a controversial topic.

4.5/5I think this is one of those films that I will not just 100% getâ€”not because it was badly written or executedâ€”rather, it is such a lived experience (even phenomenological) that is scathing, intense, and too real.But Jadaone & Maris Racal (and the whole ensemble!) made this film so empathetic, bold, and brave to actually tackle and make you realize what the social reality is. The collective Filipino religious trauma, poverty, crime, the lack of accessible healthcareâ€”it's all encompassing with Sunshine's experience (and to all Filipinas as well).Gets kita, Sunshine. Ang pangarap mo ay pangarap ko rin.

i find it hard to explain the experience of watching Sunshine it left me with a heavy heart, a quiet kind of ache, and a deep reflection. pero isang bagay ang malinaw, mahirap maging babae lalo na sa mundong paulit-ulit kinukuwestyon ang iyong mga desisyon, ang iyong halaga, at ang iyong tinig.kaya i have so much admiration for Direk Tonet and the entire team behind Sunshine for their boldness and honesty. it takes real courage to create a film that confronts the silences, the shame, and the societal fears around topics we often push aside especially in a country like ours where conservatism still tries to drown out stories like these. despite the progress weâ€™ve made as a society, there are still so many walls around conversations that women desperately need to have.as a woman, i felt seen. i felt understood. and more importantly, i felt less alone. Sunshine gives voice to the quiet suffering that many Filipinas carry stories of pain, confusion, guilt, and survival. it doesnâ€™t offer simple answers, but it offers empathy. and thatâ€™s powerful.i hope more Filipinos get to watch this film, not just to be entertained, but to really listen. to open their hearts and minds to the struggles of women they may not fully understand. i hope it challenges them to reflect, to unlearn, and to care more deeply about the rights and realities of women.sana magets niyo rin

How does a young woman endure a life filled with â€œfaithfulsâ€ who feel morally superior to judge and ridicule her choices in a society riddled with antiquated beliefs, further magnified by patriarchal politics where men can walk away without responsibilities and consequences? How do you thrive when institutions that are supposed to protect you are trying to pin you down? Maris Racal shines as the titular character Sunshine, hindi sumosobra o kinukulang, raw, honest, perfectly capturing a young woman in turmoil while trying to show a facade that everything is okay. She is supported by an amazing cast: Annika Co, Elijah Canlas, Xyrel Manabat, Piolo Pascual, Rhed Bustamante, and the most affecting performance of Jennica Garcia.This film captures the gritty essence of Manila without being patronizing or didactic. Each frame is filled with ironies: abortion drugs sold beside a church, a repeated shot of split windows showing dreams, chaos, judgement, and slivers of kindness. One shot in particular shows Sunshine rehearsing at home, on the split side are young people probably coming home from a fun night, kasi bata lang naman si Sunshine and she is willing to sacrifice everything for her dreams, at napakarami pang tulad niya, lahat sila hindi napapakinggan. Listen, read, learn, resist until every woman has autonomy over her body.Drown out the noises, lift your head, close your eyes, and let your light pull you through.

â€œgets mo na â€˜ko?â€ id like to believe that the kid was a depiction of sunshineâ€™s conscience and its such a powerful statement to put out there â€” that sunshine didnt have anyone to convince but herself. that its okay as long as the choice was hers and not anyone elseâ€™s, especially in a society that often robs women the decision to make a choice in the first place.and despite the loud and often guilt-ridden noises that paralleled the packed and polluted streets of manila, it contested the catholic and cis-heteropatriarchal belief that the sole purpose of womanhood is motherhood and to choose to become someone else is to sin. but sunshine wouldnâ€™t have come through all odds if it werenâ€™t also for the women in her life that chose to show up for her. the only thing more powerful than the dangers that women are constantly subjected to, are the embrace of fellow women who just understand it. sunshine didnâ€™t even have to utter a single word, her silence, both in her vulnerable and fearless moments, was heard. the quiet glances between her and thea, reassuring her that she is seen. her sisterâ€™s arms reaching out to her in bed, making her presence known and reminding sunshine that sheâ€™d never be alone, the gentle squeeze of menggayâ€™s hands to let her know sheâ€™s safe. they all heard and seen each other, and having someone whoâ€™s willing to carry and share your burden with is enough for everything else to be bearable. gets na gets kita Sunshine, at sana mas marami pang mga pilipino ang makarinig at makaintindi saâ€™yo at sa kuwento mo.

Sunshine tells the story of a 19-year-old gymnast pursuing her dream of making it to the national team to compete in the SEA Games and eventually, the Olympics until a life-altering event changes everything.Ito marahil ang isa sa pinakamahalagang pelikulang Pilipino ngayong taon, o baka pati na rin sa buong dekada. Hindi ito nagpaligoy-ligoy sa layunin nitong maglahad ng katotohanan masakit man ito o hindi.Unang tumatak sa akin ang pangalang Antonette Jadaone noong napanood ko ang That Thing Called Tadhana. Mula noon, sinusubaybayan ko na ang kanyang mga pelikula maging ito man ay romcom, crime, psychological, o political. Siya at si Direk Dan Villegas ay palaging may tatak: may kirot, may kurot, at higit sa lahat, may lalim.Ang Sunshine ay isang napapanahong pelikula na nagsisilbing mitsa para sa mahahalagang diskusyon: ang kalagayan ng mga atleta sa bansa, ang sistemang pangkalusugan at pang-edukasyon, pananampalataya, gender roles, at higit sa lahat, ang karapatan ng kababaihan sa sariling katawan.Madalas nating marinig: â€œAng anak ay biyaya.â€ Pero kailan nga ba ito nagiging biyaya? Kailan naman ito nagiging pasanin? Ang isang pagbubuntis ba sa murang edad ay dapat tawaging biyaya, lalo na kung ito ay dumating sa panahong hindi pa handa ang isang babae? O isa itong uri ng sumpa, bunga ng sistemang mapanghusga?Hindi laging pisikal ang pang-aabuso sa kababaihan. Minsan, ito ay nasa anyo ng mga ideolohiyang pinipilit ipalunok sa kanila. Kapag inagaw mo ang kakayahan nilang magdesisyon para sa sarili nilang katawan, para sa kinabukasan nila, para sa mga pangarap nila, iyon ay anyo ng pang-aabuso.Wala nang mas akmang gumanap bilang Sunshine kundi si Maris Racal. Ang kanyang pagganap ay puno ng pusoâ€™t tapang mula sa kanyang mga sulyap, bawat paghinga, hanggang sa mga katahimikan niya sa ilang eksena. Nararamdaman mo ang kanyang sakit, pangarap, at takot. Isa ito sa mga pinakamahusay na performance ng isang aktres sa kasalukuyang panahon.Ang buong ensemble cast ay maingat na pinili mula kina Elijah Canlas, Meryll Soriano, Jennica Garcia, Annika Co, Rhed Bustamante, Xyriel Manabat hanggang sa mga may limitadong eksena ngunit tumatak: Juan Miguel Garcia, Madeleine Nicolas, Angeli Bayani, at Piolo Pascual. Bawat karakter ay may silbi sa masalimuot ngunit malinaw na salaysay ni Sunshine.Ang pelikulang ito ay malakas, matapang, at mapanghamon. Hindi ito madaling kalimutan. Hindi kami agad nakatayo matapos ang closing credits hindi dahil baka may post-credit scene kundi dahil ninanamnam pa namin ang bigat ng mensahe nito.Sa huli, isang malaking saludo kay Direk Tonet Jadaone. Maraming salamat sa liwanag at lakas ng Sunshine. Sa panahong maraming gustong manahimik, pinili mong magsalita. Mabuhay ka, Direk!Rating: â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸ (5/5 - unanimous)

God forbid a woman chooses herself.Sunshine is a film I recommend every woman in my life to seeâ€”yes, also those who belong to the earlier generations. How I wish a film like this existed when I was around Sunshine's age. This film isn't just about teenage pregnancy and women's reproductive rights. It's also about courage and knowing oneself better than anyone can. I wish any girl who's forced to choose between herself and other people's plans for herâ€”no matter how more reasonable they areâ€”gets to realize it's not a sin to pick the former, especially if it leads to a more purposeful life for her. And with this, I also hope that the girls who do so, gets to have the same support system Sunshine has. I am a woman.I get to choose the life I want for me.I am not a baby-making machine.I am more than my womanly traits.Mahal kita, Sunshine, at gets kita.

Sunshine (2025, Project 8 Projects)I acknowledge that there are a lot of things in life I take for granted as a cisgender man. In Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s new film, Sunshine, she presents a flawed yet heartbreaking tale on the female cost of pregnancy.In the film, we follow nineteen-year-old Sunshine, who has dedicated most of her life, along with the support of her sister who was also a former gymnast, in rhythmic gymnastics and her pursuit to enter the Philippine team for the Olympics. However, several weeks before the National tryouts, Sunshine discovers that she got pregnant after a recent sexual encounter with her boyfriend.Stepping out of the theater, I realized how itâ€™s so hard to be a woman, not just in the Philippines but in general. And pregnancy, one of the human experiences that only a cisgender woman can experience, and how much it impacts on their health, emotions, and even their dreams or aspirations - especially when it happens completely unplanned. All of these are further amplified in the situation here in the Philippines where sexual education is still not a priority, access to quality maternal care is expensive, and role of religion to beset unfair expectations towards women.Despite having a strong message, there are things in Sunshine that I wish had been improved on. I must admit I felt a bit cheated out because the movie was initially hyped as a sports movie focusing on gymnastics - the same way Rookie did for volleyball, but in the end was more of a character drama that whose lead character is a gymnast. I wish that Jadaone delved deeper on Sunshineâ€™s motivations on why gymnastics is important to her because at how the story was written, Sunshine couldâ€™ve played any sport and the story would remain the same. Before I get called out, I know the movieâ€™s true intention is a commentary on the state of female reproductive health in the Philippines, but I felt like it was just a missed opportunity to highlight the state of female sports in the Philippines, particularly gymnastics because Filipino sports movies are so rare. I also felt like that the script couldâ€™ve been tightened up a bit as the elements of magical realism introduced in the story (without going too much in spoiler territory) didnâ€™t land as much in terms of story logic.As a follow-up to her lead starring role in 2023 movie Marupok AF, Maris Racal continues to be one of the promising actresses of her generation. And in Sunshine, she delivers one of her career best performances so far, especially at lengths her character goes through and in the dedication to train of the gymnastics segments of the story.Overall, Sunshine is not an easy watch because it doesnâ€™t mince the hard truths of how it is living as a woman in the Philippines. And now with with the ongoing female reproductive health and sexual education discussion in the Philippines, Antoinette Jadaone offers a strong message on why it is imperative that protections for womenâ€™s health should be passed, and why the movie Sunshine deserves your time and your attention.However, irony that this movie can only be seen by a limited number of people because of its R16 rating as well as the unfair cinema practices in the Philippines, makes this even more frustrating.

first, iâ€™m so happy of the featured sport. since the achievements of carlos yulo, gymnastics has been rising in the country. i think we need explorations of the fields in which we actually excel, even much more from the perspective of a woman.second, this film has a scent of lino brockaâ€™sâ€”the journey, the road, the streets, the jeep, the buildings, the motel, the church, the stalls and stores, the hospital, the government, the peopleâ€”the social realism of it all. but different to his, sunshine has its own rhythmâ€”a never-ending going back and forth, a push and pull, a dilemma that only athletes know, only pregnants know, only women knowâ€”a jadaone rhythm.third, everything about this film is brave. sunshine is brave. women in this film are brave. the writer is brave. the director is brave. it carefully touches a taboo topic that a lot of filipinos tend to talk about in shallow means, or even a lot also do avoidance of it. but this film just keeps on going and itâ€™s not even apologizing for it. unapologetic but with care. and that is why THIS FILM IS IMPORTANT.maris, you are indeed a sunshine.

This film was grounded and felt real with every relatable action and reaction. I felt the pain and the fear, the uncertainty and the anxiety, the fervor and doubt. At no point did I feel the scene overstayed its welcome, it lasted just right amount of time to cause discomfort for the comfortable and comfort the uncomfortable. Sunshine stands to be a symbol for what is wrong with Philippine society (healthcare, religion, etc.) and what is right (truly loving and caring family) and could be a source of courage for the many who undergo similar situations but whose voices are drowned out and left unheard. Personally, I was moved to guilt for the parts I played in perpetuating the same problems the film emphasized.

ANIMA ceased to exist last July 31, 2024, and this film is the last project that was ever produced by the company to be released.Iâ€™ve spent the past year trying to find meaning in such a swift demise â€” after all, most people prefer to go out with a bang; and I felt like we went out with the most sad, unceremonious accordion noise. But Iâ€™m glad that, a year later, Sunshine came out, a film that all things considered, is so bold and so loud and so strong in what it wants to say. Leave it to Antoinette Jadaone and Maris Racal not only to craft such a severe, yet truthful and empathetic tale, but also to rally a community to see this film. It makes me feel like we went out with a bellow, and all of our pains, struggles, and heartache with our sudden departure was heard somewhere, somehow.ANIMA was where I really grew into my own as a marketer, a coworker, and as a person. Iâ€™ll miss it dearly, but will cherish the memories forever. Iâ€™m happy Sunshine is shining brightly for us.

Katahimikan at pagkatulala. Napakaingay ng utak ko kanina, pero walang namutawi sa aking bibig pagkatapos kong masaksihan ang pelikulang â€˜to. Kulang ang isang oras para magbalik-tanaw sa kwento mo, Sunshine.Isa lamang ang tiyak kong masasabi: Ang hirap maging babae. Ang hirap galawan ng isang lipunang ikinukulong ka sa ideya na ang puwang mo sa mundo ay nakabase sa iyong sinapupunanâ€”sa pagluluwal mo ng bata.Kapag babae ka, hindi ka pwede mangarap nang mataas. Hindi ka pwede maghangad ng magandang career. Kapag babae ka, hindi mo pwedeng piliin ang sarili mo. Kailangan ang timeline ng buhay mo ay nakaangkla sa pagbubuo ng pamilya.Hindi lahat handang maging nanay. Hindi lahat kayang maging nanay. Hindi lahat ng babae ay pipiliin maging nanay.Balang araw, nawaâ€™y makita ng lipunang ito ang kababaihan bilang isang pwersa, bilang isang lakas. Bigyan sana ng lipunang ito ang mga kababaihan ng kalayaang lumipad at kumawala sa mga rehas na pumipigil sa pamumukadkad ng kanyang pakpak.Maraming salamat, Sunshine, sa matapang at mahusay na pagbabahagi ng iyong danas. Isa ka mang kathang-isip, ang buhay mo ay hindi nalalayo sa kasalukuyang tinatahak ng isang babae sa bansang ito.Hindi rito nagtatapos ang kwento mo. Magpapatuloy tayo, at bitbit ka ng bawat kababaihang kagaya koâ€”saksi sa paraan mo ng pakikibaka sa mapang-aping lipunan.Papaburan din tayo ng mundo.

The fact this got to even show in SM nationwide makes me amazed and is a testament to what this film symbolizes and argues for in our society. Even if I didnâ€™t really care for a certain plot device used in the movie and in fact took my enjoyment at certain points from a very grounded and compelling story, the highs of this film is extraordinary and something I will always praise. The way the camera and direction paints the complex feelings of Sunshine, the usage of Manila as both familiar yet alienating in its loudness and chaos, the rage and social commentary that is extremely brave in our current societyGiving tons of flowers for this film, I would even say that taking away the campier/comedic aspects of the film would have made this a masterpiece in my eyes!
