Really nice. Brava ğŸ‘ğŸ½ Nakakatunaw ng puso. Also shot in Manila, My Manila. So you know how I feel about it haha. What can I say man. Tonette Jadaone. Napakalinis magkwento. Really nice placemaking; finally for a long time, an honest-feeling Manila. A motel in Avenida you could hear the banging of rail tracks? Gusto ko rin yan mapuntuhan! Haha. Favorite ko rito yung little transgressions. Madalas ang pekilula tungkol sa shame, kumporme sa shame. That is to say parang laging uphill battle. Pero dito ni minsan hindi ako kinabahan para kay Sunshine. Panatag na panatag ako, nakakatuwang panoorin ang deliryo ng biyahe niya mula Quiapo-Avenida-Paco. Wala akong awa, naluluha lang ako sa lungkot. Bitin na bitin lang ako sa last sequence which looking back looked like an Aronofsky reference but contrivedHere is Maris Racal, who Iâ€™ve told my friends has a Mona Lisa face. Minsan 'di ko mawari kung anong nararamdaman niya, but with her command on-screen you could tell what she wants. Desperado. That is an actor you want to play Sunshine.Because Sunshine only has her mistakes to prop her up to dreams, which is a tricky proposition in the city, but nonetheless possible. And is often the case. Kailangang gustong-gustong-gustuhin mo lang talaga. Some kneel for a quarter-mile in Quiapo. Ang iba, pumapatay. Nevermind if your conscience is (literally) following you, you just have to make it work. Ito ang ibig sabihin kung mabingit ka sa mga kuko ng liwanag. To be a womanâ€¦. to be a mother. Gets mo na?

ang tagal ko bago isulat yung review ko sa SUNSHINE. sa pangkalahatan, walang dudaâ€”maganda at matapang ang pelikula. hindi lang maganda sa produksyon, kundi nakakanginig din ng laman. ang galing ng mga aktor, mula sa mga beteranong sina meryll soriano, xyriel manabat, elijah canlas, hanggang sa mga mas batang bituin na sina annika at julius. at higit sa lahat, si maris, na may malalim at matalim na hugot. simple pero malinaw ang paraan niya ng paghahatid ng mensahe: ang mga babae ang gulugod ng lipunan. nag-iiwan â€˜to ng tanong na bakit sa kabila ng bigat ng responsibilidad na iyon, mailap pa rin ang mundo sa kanila? representasyon ang pelikulang ito na kulang pa ang mga diskusyon patungkol sa mga karapatan ng mga babae sa pilipinas. sa pelikulang ito, hindi ko kayang maging kritikal dahil alam kong hindi ko hawak ang karapatang humusga sa kwento ni sunshine. HINDI KO ITO KWENTO, at siguro iyon ang pinakamahalagang bagay na kailangang kong maunawaan. ako ay taganood lamang, at bilang manonood, ang tanging sigurado ako ay kung paano pinaigting ng pelikulang ito ang pagmamahal ko para sa kababaihan.habang pinapanood ko, parang unti-unting lumalalim ang pagkakaunawa ko na hindi pa rin patas ang batas sa mga kababaihan. mas nagkaroon ako ng lakas na sumandig sa tabi nila, sa pakikibaka para sa maayos, pantay, at respetadong pagtrato. hindi ko kailanman lubos mauunawaan ang bawat sakit, takot, at pag-aalinlangan na kaakibat ng pagiging babae pero dahil sa pelikulang ito, mas malinaw na sa akin: sila ang sentro ng komunidad. at kung may dapat magbago, hindi sila iyon ngunit ang sistema, paniniwala, at pagtingin ng komunidad sa kanila.

Philippine cinema is very much alive, and a woman is our flag-bearer. As a cisgender male who calls himself a feminist, I'll never fully understand what it's like to be a woman in this country. This film, however, gave me the feeling of walking in their shoes. Every step was a courageous move toward something that could later become a matter of life and death. The story was written in a very deliberate manner, with the cinematography strengthening the narrativeâ€¦

an underrated beauty of cinema is how it can invite one into a suspended state of reality. for a brief and borrowed hour or two, our story pauses to make space for someone elseâ€™s. sunshine (2024) is one of those rare films that honors the lending of time not with surprise and spectacle, but with empathy as its goal and medium for exploration.and the language of empathy in sunshine settles in slowly, almost bodily. aptly named, the movie seeps through the senses like the quiet force of nature: it casts a harsh light on the grayed and shadowed alleys of manila, where sins and prayers blur into one cruel cacophony. it burns with familiarity when we recognize sunshine, the girl, in our own world.she sits beside us in overcrowded jeepneys, gets scolded like us in hospital beds, walks among us on streets of quiapo that shame and steal a strip of dignity. with the same light, the film reaches for the sunshine within us - the ones who dream and persist, who dare hold our potential as promises. there are sunshines among us held tightly by sisters, while some sunshines are held up only as stubborns who flicker through the dark. yet herein lands the most transcendent part of the film: it peddles no moral lesson or pedantic sermon. all that it offers is an invitation to bear witness to sunshine, as she moves to the rhythm of a music only she can hear and pushes against the gravity of choices forced upon her. the film doesnâ€™t seek answers; it simply asks for understanding. in its own sober way, it holds out hope that when the borrowed time is up, may we not only remember every sunshine who flies and rises, but also the ones who fall and return, until we see how every ground that meets her, holds her, or traps her, as she labors to birth her becoming, is also the same one we own.

Si Sunshine ay ako.Hindi man ako rhythmic gymnast, pero may pangarap din ako. Gaya ng maraming babae at dalaga na dumaan sa unwanted pregnancy o pregnancy scare, ramdam ko ang takot ni Sunshine. Yung pagkabalisa at pag-ukit ng konsensya kapag nakahiga sa kama. Yung konsensyang lalong lumalalim kapag may mahinang katok sa pinto. Ito na siguro ang pelikula na kung ang younger self ko ang makakapanood, hindi niya magugustuhan na nakakarelate ako kay Sunshine. Pero ganito talaga, personal na ito sa akin. Naiintindihan ko si Sunshine. Damang dama ko yung galit. Yung takot. Yung tapang, na bahala na nga basta wag lang mapurnada ang mga plano. Ramdam ko at alam ko kung saan hinugot ni Sunshine yung tapang na 'yon. Ang karakter ni Sunshine ay nakaangkla sa batang pasulpot-sulpot. Para sa akin, inner child niya â€˜yon. Pero may kasama akong nanood na nagsabing baka konsensya niya raw 'yon. Pwede rin.Tingin ko inner child niya 'yon, dahil sa tricycle scene, duguan rin ang hita ng bata. Na para bang sinasabi na kung iniinda ni Sunshine ang sakit at pilipit ng puson, dama rin yon ng inner child niya. Nasasaktan. Naaawa. Maliban doon, gusto ko rin i-emphasize kung gaano ka poetic ng eksena. Naka higa sa hita ng bata si Sunshine na nag-aagaw-buhay. Hinihinging lumaban siya. Hindi ba't magandang pagnilayan na sa lowest points ng buhay, ang boses na naririnig mo ay ang boses ng munting ikaw? Maliit, oo, pero may bigat, may bagahe.Ang rason naman kung bakit daw konsensya ni Sunshine ang bata, ay dahil sa eksena sa ospital. Galit na galit ang bata kay Sunshine at hinahanap niya si Ariana, isa ring batang pasulpot-sulpot. Ineexplain ni Sunshine na okay na si Mary Grace pero ang importante para sa kanya ay si Ariana, na nawawala. Nawala na ba si Ariana dahil nawala na rin ang dinadala ni Mary Grace?Pero sa kabila ng lahat, matapang si Sunshine. Doon sa unang hospital scene, kita mong may hiyang nararamdaman si Sunshine. Pero dahil sa trauma at pagkalito, sunod lang siya sa pinagsasabi ng overly righteous na doktora. Hanggang sa napuno si Sunshine. Isa sa pinaka-paborito kong linya niya ay nang tanungin niya ang doktora: "Para saan?" Na para bang may panghuhusga rin si Sunshine sa kanya. Ang daming layers ng pelikulang â€˜to. Hindi lang siya tungkol sa isang babae. Kwento ito ng pinagdadaanan ng isang babae sa isang bansa na binigo at binibigo ang mga kababaihan na magkaroon ng karapatan na magdesisyon para sa katawan nila. Nagbabago na ang panahon. Hindi na dapat taboo ang usapin ng sex at sex education. Higit sa lahat, ang mga batang gaya ni Mary Grace ang pinaka bulnerable sa lahat. Ramdam ko rin si Mary Grace. Ano ang laban ng isang 13-year-old sa isang Uncle Bobot? Alam nating maraming Uncle Bobot. At dapat lang na basagan ng bote sa ulo ang mga kagaya nila. Maraming kagaya ni Mary Grace, nananahimik lang, natatakot. Kaya nga ang pelikula at kwentong ito ay magandang halimbawa ng quote na:â€œArt should comfort the disturbed and disturb the comfortable.â€ Mahusay. Napakahusay. Truly a landmark film.

We are introduced to Sunshine through her warming up with other student-athletes and performing her routine for the upcoming Olympic team tryouts. Viewers can tell that her prowess and national team member status is a mix of talent and hard work, that even when she messes up halfway through, it doesn't make her any less of a great gymnast.When she first finds out that she is pregnant, the camera focuses on her hands tremble. But she immediately acts on it â€“ searching for suspicious dealers for pills, telling the boy that knocked her up, and going to church to pray that the Lord takes away the being forming in her womb â€“ even when we see glimpses of her trying not to lose her composure in the humid streets of Manila.The film shows and justifies Sunshine's reasons for wanting an abortion, even if the means available in the Philippines will harm her. She has dreams that can't be put on hold, and she clearly is a young girl with mannerisms and tendencies deemed "immature" â€“ factors that do not make her fit to be a mother.But in a scene wherein she talks to a pastor (played by Piolo Pascual, who made everyone in my cinema gasp) that promises financial support throughout her pregnancy and motherhood, she rejects it. "Ayoko maging nanay," she says, plain and simple.That was my favorite part of the film, because it felt cathartic to hear it. Although Sunshine had good reasons for the choices she makes, we must not need to have justified, valid, and layered reasons for wanting an abortion. Some of us do not want to be mothers and undergo the medical complications that come with carrying a child, just because.I hope that it has more time to stay in cinemas. I hope that more people see it, and by the time the credits roll, sana ma-gets niyo na kami.

The body of the story may be about Sunshine, but its soul revolves around Menggay.From the moment the official trailer dropped, Sunshine instantly captured my interest. Iâ€™ve been waiting ever since for the chance to see it and after months of anticipation, I finally did. And now, I can say this without hesitation: I have nothing but praises for the film.More than just well-made, Sunshine is a brave and necessary work. Itâ€™s a film that demands to be seen â€” not only because of Maris Racalâ€™s powerful performance, but because of how urgent and relevant its message is in todayâ€™s world.Unlike other films that leave you in feel-good state when the credits roll, Sunshine leaves you with questions â€” difficult, uncomfortable questions that deserve to be brought into the open.What if women had better options?What if men received the same public scrutiny when it comes to unwanted pregnancies?What if we had a healthcare and justice system that actually protects girls like Menggay?What if we dared to talk about abortion in a way that invites honest, compassionate, and informed discussion?This is where the film finds its power. When Menggayâ€™s story arc unfolds, thatâ€™s when Sunshine cements its message, it stops being just a film and starts becoming a mirror to reality.Because this is for the countless Menggays out there â€” young girls with no real choices. Mga batang gaya niya. Isang 13-anyos na tinanggalan ng karapatan ng mismong sariling pamilya.And the painful truth is: there are far too many Menggays in our country. Uneducated. Deprived of opportunities. Denied the chance to choose a safer path forward.Watching this film taught me to become more open-minded. It urged me to weigh both the pros and cons of abortion more critically, and to consider how we can use art as a tool for education and awareness.In the end, Sunshine is not just a film â€” itâ€™s a challenge. A challenge to our government to craft better, more inclusive campaigns. Ones that donâ€™t just resonate with the intellectuals but reach the grassroots, where change is most needed. #Sunshine

After two decades in the industry, Antoinette Jadaone has cemented her capacity to bend, direct, and write with different genres â€” the deconstruction of ekstras with Lilia Cuntapay, the ironic and hilarious takedown of cosmetic surgery industry with Belo-approved meta-comedy â€œBeauty in a Bottle,â€ and the dialogue-driven romantic hugot dramas with â€˜Tadhana.â€ Without a doubt, Jadaone stands as one of the most vital voices in Philippine filmmaking today, consistently challenging conventions and pushing Filipino Cinema forward. In all her films, one thing thatâ€™s notable she's put women's voices at the forefront. She has since taken a pandemic pause after Fan Girl, but this has also led to her researching and diving deep into her most recent film, Sunshine. The film follows a student gymnast, Sunshine (Maris Racal), who discovers sheâ€™s pregnant just as sheâ€™s about to compete for the SEA Games. The film takes a surreal turn when she encounters a kid/ alter ego appears in crisis moments, reflecting her inner turmoil as she faces societal judgment.Throughout the film, Sunshineâ€™s emotional arcâ€”marked by anguish, desperation, and vulnerabilityâ€”lays bare the reality where womenâ€™s access to safe choices is morally questioned and legally denied. This taboo isolates her: abandoned by friends and her partner, judged by doctors, and pressured by her coach to give up her dreams. Social stigma is one, but the films also highlights how poverty and consequently, sexual miseducation put into question the dignity of women. To be able to choose freely, is too high of a cost for Sunshine who has to deal with its social, financial, and legal repercussions. The film understands how for women in the fringes thereâ€™s little to no choice.The film is not without hope. Her sister, whoâ€™s a single mother, grounds Sunshine. Her alter ego serves as emotional salve during her many crises. And she also chances upon an underaged girl months into her pregnancy who reflects and echoes her experiences. In each of them, Jadaone realizes Sunshineâ€™s future: to be a single mother, carry her pregnancy to term, and have a daughter. The film effectively wrestles with the nuances of her situation: to choose her dreams or be with a child. Ironically, Sunshine occasionally stumbles under the weight of its many themes: its surreal elements and side characters threaten to overshadow Sunshineâ€™s emotional arc. It makes one wonder how better the film would have been had it just been, as the film title suggested, about Sunshine. Nevertheless, the film is a showcase of Jadaoneâ€™s confident vision.Thereâ€™s this wonderful scene in the film of a maternity ward that just for brief moment became a community for pregnant women and mothers helping and supporting one another. It epitomizes the warmth that carries Sunshine forward: from isolation to solidarity, and from uncertainty to self-understanding. Parting with her past, she talks to her alter ego hoping sheâ€™d understand. They hug. To be understood thatâ€™s just what Sunshine needed.

Alam kong napakahalaga ng pelikulang ito sa kababaihan pero ang hiling ko ay sana mas maraming kalalakihan ang makapanood nito.Ang misogyny at patriyarka ay mga problemang dulot naming mga lalaki. Matibay ang paniniwala kong kami ang dapat may pinakamalaking ambag sa pagbubuwag ng mga ito. Dapat kami ang nagpepenitensya. Pero hindi ganito ang realidad. Mga babae tulad ni Sunshine, Menggay, at ang maraming babae sa pelikulang ito ang bumabaka at nagdurusa sa ilalim ng huwad na sistema. Tila habambuhay silang nagpepenitensya para sa isang kasalanang hindi matubos-tubos kahit pa anong gawin nilaâ€”ang kasalanan ng pagiging babae.Mahusay ang pagpapakita ng Sunshine sa iba't ibang impyernong dinaranas ng kababaihan: personal, panlipunan, pisikal, mental, pinansyal, sekswal, at, higit sa lahat, pulitikal. Ramdam ito sa bawat eksena kung saan galit, pag-aalala, at pagod ang namamayagpag sa mga linya, ekspresyon, imahe, at tunog. Pati nga mismo ang kalagayan nito bilang pelikula ay isang impyerno rin: ang masalimuot na danas nina Direk Tonet sa paghahanap ng distributor, ang katotohanang madalang abutin ng mga ganitong pelikula ang mainstream consciousness ng mga Pilipno, ang mabilis na pagliit ng bilang ng mga sinehan na nagpapalabas nito, at ang nagbabadyang diskurso na tiyak na magiging mapaghati. Samakatuwid, ang pelikula mismo ay dumaan at patuloy na dadaan sa impyernong ginawa ng patriyarka.Ipinapakita ng Sunshine na mula noon hanggang ngayon, kababaihan ang umaako sa responsibilidad na hamunin at buwagin ang patriyarka. Kaya sana mapanood ito ng mas marami pang lalaki, lalo na kung hindi pa sila mulat sa realidad ng kababaihan, mga batang ina, at mga biktima ng sekswal na karahasan. Tayong mga lalaki ang nag-imbento at nakikinabang sa patriyarka. Tayo ang may kasalanan, tayo ang dapat magpenitensya.

i knew i had to watch this before this film disappears off the face of the earth like gitling did. no regrets because this might be antoinette jadaoneâ€™s magnum opus yet. sunshine (2025) had no metaphors and subtle parallelisms: it screams that a womanâ€™s autonomy is her own. a very straight-forward, well-thought of, and a passionate piece about how a woman was made to struggle the moment she was born by the system and how itâ€™s designed to take away her ownnes. this is true for everywhere else in the world; but much more significant in the context of a third world country such as the philippines. abortion is a controversial topic in the country, to say the least. it is seen as a violation to the sanctity of lifeâ€”a sin to remove a clump of cell in a human body. swayed by the biblical texts and the catholic church, abortion is illegal in the country. but for women like sunshine and mary grace, the law does little to stop the reality: it only pushes them to do the act in shadows, where the only option is unsafe and risky. the religious references throughout the film were palpable: from the jeepney that sunshine rode to quiapo bearing the sign that says â€œgift of Godâ€ to sunshineâ€™s physical manifestation of her conscience in the form of her would-be childâ€”which shows an inner conflict between her faith and survival. these references do not seem disrespectful but rather an emphasis on how deeply stitched sunshineâ€™s struggle to catholicism is. itâ€™s a critique on how the bible is weaponized to police a womanâ€™s choices and her bodily autonomy. i want to make a point on the healthcare system too which the film really did a good job criticizing: with all its faults, the healthcare system is biased against women. the lack of access to safe procedures, institutional neglect, and moral policing (made by professionals, mind you) leave women like sunshine and mary grace with nowhere to turn. the lack of quality healthcare in the country is so normalized that it leaves everyone no dignified options to address even their basic needs. a perfect film that paints intersectionality so well: women from different sectors, despite having the same oppressor, face different realities. it did not sensationalize abortion but it gave the audience another angle to look at it from; in a perspective thatâ€™s raw and honest. i was crying at the end (#that scene) because in spite all this, she prevailed. a woman, in a system that set her up to fail, survived and lived to achieve her dreams.overall, sunshine (2025) was hopeful, important, and full of courage. an important film that must be seen by everyone (and more importantly, by women). maris racal, you are a generational talent, you deserve all the flowers AND jennica garcia, this pieceâ€™s hidden gem, you have mothered on a scale no one has ever had before.
it is easy to get drowned in the noise. thank you, sunshine, for believing in your dreams and being loud about them.

Few films manage to hold intensity, tenderness, and truth all at once-but Sunshine does.It was a brave story of strength, love, and kindness. Yet it was also sharp, honest in its portrayal of the harsh realities young Filipina women often endure: the limits imposed on their bodies, their choices, their futures.And still, it was warm. It never allowed you to drown in despair. Instead, it held you with care, gently reminding you that even in the most shadowed and uncertain places, light still finds its way in.Just like its title, Sunshine felt like light breaking through, like a quiet kind of hope that chooses to stay.

Sunshineâ€™s strength lies on its strong messaging. It confronts the audienceâ€” yes, what you heard was right. Maternity wards are in terrible conditions. A lot of R*pe and incest victims are of that age. Bigotry and victim-blaming play a huge part in our society. Antoinette Jadaone doesnâ€™t tiptoe or walk around with her message: she is loud, angry, and knows where she stands. Her direction is both observational and sympathetic, allowing the audience to feel for Sunshine and feel helpless in situations out of our control. Despite all of these, itâ€™s an incredibly hopeful movie about choice. Maris Racal is radiant and fantastic, and Jennica Garcia is the heart of the film.

Sabi nila, kapag ang isang pelikula ay tumatak sa damdamin at isipan ng manonood, naiparating nito ang mensahe nais ipaabot. Kapag dala mo pa rin ito hanggang sa pagtulog mo, ibig sabihin ay maganda ang pagkakagawa. At kung pagising mo'y ito pa rin ang laman ng isip mo, isa itong tunay na obra maestra.Naalala ko pa noong una kong mapanood ang That Thing Called Tadhana. Alam kong iba si Direk Tonet. Para niyang binago ang pormula ng mga pelikulang Pilipino. Simula noon, naging tagahanga na ako ng kaniyang mga gawa. Walang tapon sa kaniyang filmography. May lalim ang bawat karakter na nililikha niya. Naiipakita niya ang mga struggle at kahinaan naming mga babae, pero kasabay nito, naipapakita rin niya kung paanong buong tapang naming niyayakap ang aming pagkababae.At sa pelikulang ito, mas lalo niyang pinatunayan kung gaano siya kagaling bilang direktor. Alam ko nang magiging maganda ito, mula pa lang sa premise at trailer, kuhang-kuha na niya ako. Pero nang mapanood ko na ito nang buo, mas lalo akong humanga. Panahon na, sa tingin ko, para kilalanin si Direk Tonet bilang isa sa mga haligi ng pelikulang Pilipino. Ang pelikulang ito ang magbubukas ng daan para mas mapansin siya hindi lang bilang direktor ng rom-com, kundi bilang isang seryoso at malalim na haligi ng sining at dakilang manunulat.Bawat shot, pinag-isipan. Hindi lang basta kinuha para lang sa aesthetic. Bawat karakter, may saysay at mahalagang ambag sa buhay ni Sunshine, hindi lang basta comic relief o pandagdag lang sa cast. Mahusay ang bawat isa, lalong-lalo na si Jennica Garcia, kada eksena niya, tagos sa puso. Napakahusay rin ng batang si Annika Co, kaya niyang makipagsabayan sa mga beterano. Siya ang nagmistulang liwanag, ang "sunshine" sa kabuuan ng pelikula.At si Maris Racalâ€”kung hindi siya mananalo ng mga acting awards, ewan ko na lang. Para siyang isinilang para sa papel na ito. Bitbit niya ako sa bawat eksena. Bawat ngiti, bawat pikit ng mata, bawat hinga, ramdam na ramdam ko si Sunshine. Ang lalim ng koneksiyon ko sa kaniya. Wala akong ibang hiniling kundi matapos na ang paghihirap niya. Dahil 'yon sa galing ng pag-arte ni Maris. Nagawa niyang kumonekta sa kaluluwa ng mga manonood hanggang magroll ang credits.Hindi na kinailangang i-detalye pa ang mahabang backstory para makilala si Sunshine. Ang galing ng pagkakasulat. Walang patay na eksena, lahat mahalaga, lahat may emosyon. Mararamdaman mo ang lahat: awa, inis, galit, tawa, lungkot, takot, pag-asa, at saya.Ito ay nagsilbing tinig ng mga kababaihan. GETS NA GETS tayo ng pelikulang ito. Hindi lang nito binunyag ang mapait na realidad ng mga kababaihan, pero ipinakita rin nito kung paanong ang mga babae ay kayang maging unapologetically passionate sa mga gusto namin sa buhay, sa mga pangarap namin. Dagdag na rin ang pasilip kung gaano kahirap na itinatawid ng mga atletang Pilipino ang buhay sa loob at labas ng pagsasanay.Hindi perpekto si Sunshine, pero kahanga-hanga ang pagkakabuo ng kaniyang pagkatao. Ang ganda ng paghubog sa kaniyang karakter. Lagi na lang nagtatanong ang kalalakihan: â€œBakit ang mga babae na lang ang laging maingay? Bakit sila ang laging humihingi ng karapatan?â€ Para bang pakiramdam nilaâ€™y binabalewala na sila sa modernong panahon. Sana mapanood nila ito. Sana makita nila kung gaano unfair ang mundo para sa kababaihan. Sa aspetong pisikal pa lang, talo na kami. Kaya kung maaari, bigyan man lang sana ng puwang ang aming mga karapatan na matagal na namin hinihiling na pagbigyan. Ang dali-daling talikuran ng lalaki ang responsibilidad, pero sa babae? Kami ang nagdadala ng lahat ng iniwan na pinsala mapa-mental, pinansyal, emosyonal, sosyal, at lalong lalo na sa pisikal.Ang pelikulang ito ay isang mahigpit na yakap para sa kababaihan, at isang mata na bumubulaga sa mga nananatiling bulag sa mga hinaing at karapatang matagal na naming ipinaglalaban. Ito ang klase ng mga pelikulang minsan lang dumating sa ating buhay at siguradong mananatiling relevant sa mga susunod pang taon.

Alam kong kasabay nito ang Fantastic Four at iba pang malalaking pelikula â€” at okay lang naman â€™yon. Pero sana, bigyan mo ng pagkakataon si Sunshine. Pramis, walang sisihan.

Maris Racal turned into a drama actress in this movie. She played the role so well, from the gymnast to an early teen, pregnant, soon-to-be mother, not ready yet for the responsibility. She gave it all for this. The movie is full of different emotions. You will laugh, become angry, and be inspired. It is a story of a struggling athlete and the reality of different social issues in the country. The cinematography was superb, showing the different scenes in a way that made you get hooked and feel the emotion. The dialogue was natural and sublime and not filtered to show the actuality of what would happen. WHAT I LOVE THE MOST IS THE TWIST ABOUT THE CHARACTER OF ANNIKA AS â€œBATAâ€. It sealed the deal. The last scene with her and Maris made me cry. This is a movie that you should watch.

A film about abortion that is so beautiful that it makes me proud to recommend this film to anyone regardless of their stance in abortion, most especially in a very catholic-dominated society. It spoke so loudly to me of how a woman's life could change from bearing a child in your womb. it could shatter your dreams, make your life critical, or give you a life you have always wanted- to become a mother. Annika, the bata, as a narrative device to signify conscience of Sunshine was Jadaone's wonderful choice to gently discuss a sensitive topic such as abortion without deafening the fetus inside of a pregnant woman. Sunshine was a cinematic storytelling of coming to a decision, with never-ending to contradictions with your conscience and peeking through jalousies of other people's similar but different narratives, to come to a choice for yourself, as a woman.

a film about special people who live a rather normal life, amidst the chaotic yet beautiful, neon-lit street life of manila, filled with a heartwarming sense of humanity. having only seen 'six degrees of separation from lilia cuntapay', i think i can say that direk tonet gets it, she treats her characters in a way that makes us care and relate with them in one way or another; i may not be pregnant like sunshine, but i very much live in the same society as her. the director doesn't glorify or romanticize the world in which sunshine, and we, live inâ€”it is depicted in an achingly honest way, and therefore brutal. and maris racal is able to assimilate (?) in this world built around her character, she was phenomenal in portraying this character in such a manner that is raw and tender; most notable in scenes depending on non-verbal dialogue. although, said scenes are probably my favorite among the entire film, most of them fall short on an emotional levelâ€”just as the emotions are about to hit a gut punch, the scene is cut off. by all means, this is not a perfect film. still, it doesn't take away from the very real and grounded moving story that is sunshine.

watched this through the lens of the gay friend who's walked beside many sunshines in his life. it breaks my heart how familiar everything feels. how hard it is for sunshines to go through something like this in a country where it's still illegal, unsafe, and almost impossible to talk about.this is a movie for the masses. for the women who are left with no choice but to carry the burden quietly. for the world that needs to stop looking away.(fuck men)i hope one day we wake up in a philippines where no one has to suffer just to survive. where people are given real choices, not pushed to desperate corners.the film makes you feel it; how sunshine's world gets smaller the longer she hides her truth. you see it in the tight streets of manila, where every corner feels like it's closing in on her. her fear and panic so loud even when she says nothing. then you see her walk through the chaotic streets of quiapo, where she disappears into the crowd, holding onto the little control she has left. she's not sure if what she's doing is right, but she does it anyway, because no one's there to guide her. she does it alone, hoping that somehow it works. that somehow it saves her.this is a film that deserves to be seen for generations. and i hope that when they do, they can say, "ay, ganito pala noon" because by then, weâ€™ve already made things better.to all the sunshines: you are not alone. ps: this is now my top fave antoinete jadaone film!!! also, they can never make me hate you maris racal!

The chaotic rhythm of life.Spoilers ahead.Bold and controversial, writer-director Antoinette Jadaone continues her non-romantic-comedy streak with another compelling and dark subject matter through "SUNSHINE". Gracing the screen is the titular character, played by Maris Racal in her career-best performance, who finds out she's pregnant while she prepares for her Olympic-qualifying event. Trouble ensues, dream and ambition crash.Teenage pregnancy and women conditions take front and center as the film gives voice to the usual silenced of the society. Jadaone may have placed rhythmic gymnastics in the background but it excellently serves as a metaphorical tool to describe the ebb and flow of Sunshine's life. We see her struggles pitted against conservativism and arguable morality in a country where religion and patriarchy rule and shackle. Through magic realism where we are introduced to two young players who abruptly show up mid-scenes, the film gets a rich layer on how our lead navigates her perilous journey. They channel the moral compass though at times their appearances and comedic flair tend to be uneven and out of timing. Racal, with her sharp strength and vulnerability, is utterly commendable but so is her supporting cast - Jennica Garcia and Meryl Soriano as her strong-willed yet nurturing older sister and coach respectively, Annika Co as her unborn child manifestation (an unpredictable plot twist that eventually made sense), and even the cameos from Madeleine Nicolas, Angeli Bayani, Angie Castrence, Elijah Canlas, and Piolo Pascual fulfill their impressive character actor repertoire. Some arcs and scenes could have been fleshed out because it's got a premise worth exploring but the Philippine censorship may have played its upper hand to prevent the film's full bloom. In the same vein of "4 Months, 3 Weeks, 2 Days", "Never Rarely Sometimes Always", and "Happening", it may not be everyone's cup of tea due to its hefty topic and open-endedness but it's a delight to see an important Filipino film that fearlessly opens the conversation to empower women more on making their own reproductive choices, even with the deafening noise and outdated discourse.Quiapo. Geleen. Ribbon. 4.5/5, folks!Winner of The Crystal Bear Award in the Generation 14plus category at the 75th Berlinale - Berlin International Film Festival, "SUNSHINE" is now exclusively playing in SM Cinemas, rated R-16 without cuts.Tangkilikin natin ang makabuluhang Pelikulang Pilipino!#MovieMadness #PinoyIndieSpirit#TheRoadToTheOscars2026 ğŸ‘Š

Been eyeing this film since last year. Fortunately enough, I was able to watch this yesterday with my Mom. In the midst of darkness and rain, we looked for Sunshine.It adds surrealism without sacrificing its groundedness. Remember crying in a few scenes just because of how real it felt and then that sudden realization hits me, and I remember â€” nangyayari talaga siya sa totoong buhay yet it's inadequately addressed. Alienated, discriminated, and hidden behind idols and symbols stained with shame like the Sunshines and Menggays who are forced to comply with the rules set by a patriarchal, hypocritical, conservative society. I think this film won't force you to agree with its message but it challenges our morals and belief system. Above all, it only asks to be understood. There's multiple shades of womanhood that's not confined within a black and white backdrop. And it's good that we start and continue to talk about it. Overall, this film isn't just about abortion â€” it's a critique on society, politics, and feminism. As well as a call for women's accessible reproductive healthcare.Ps. Dahil sobrang lakas ng ulan pagpunta namin ng nanay ko sa sinehan, halos basa na likod namin, especially likod niya. I had to buy her a blanket (which she had in her back while watching the film). She chose this pinkish? Almost corally one. Overall, napaka-unforgettable experience 'tong pinagdaanan namin just to watch the film that she named her blanket 'Sunshine'.

Grabe gets ko na bat sya award winning.Before I even entered the cinema, prepared na aq mag cry cry. I saw the trailer, the interviews, and the podcasts so I was bracing myself for emotional confrontations and intense family drama pero wala so what really made me cry was how real everything felt. The way Sunshine just tried to carry on, the way Jennica quietly supported her, and the way the story showed how painfully human this situation is. There was so much honesty in how it was told. Pogi din ni Papa P.As a woman who has experienced a teen pregnancy scare before, I saw parts of myself in Sunshine. That helpless feeling, the fear of not knowing what to do, the shame, and the silence around itâ€¦ It was all too familiar. I also have friends whoâ€™ve gone through it for real. They shared their stories, and as I watched the film, I could see their experiences mirrored by Sunshine.Maris Racal is amazing as Sunshine. Everything about her performance was convincing, from the way she moved to the way she spoke (pero direk kita yung face ng double ni Sunshine ha ğŸ˜­ğŸ˜‚). She really looked like a young athlete from a struggling family, someone whose life revolved around discipline and dreams until it all came crashing down. Iâ€™ve seen Maris in different roles before, like in Incognito, where she played this aircon ex-military girly na mukhang ginagawang pangbahay ang gucci, itâ€™s rlly impressive how she completely transforms into Kanal Sunshine bc she doesnâ€™t just act the part, she becomes it.Jennica also stood out for me. As Sunshineâ€™s Ate, her presence was comforting throughout the film. She had this motherly vibe that felt very natural. I liked how the film gave her character depth without spelling everything out. You could tell that her love for Sunshine came from a place of experience, like she had her own quiet struggles too. Galing din ni Annika.Even the supporting casts delivered. The manghihilot, the abortion pill seller, the doctors and the people Sunshine met along the way werenâ€™t just fillers. Their performances felt soooooo real, and they matched the tone of the film so well. I didnâ€™t feel like I was watching actors, I felt like I was watching people actually living through these moments.Sa ibang indie films, I cringe when I hear characters cursing because it feels like the writers are just slapping random tangina words trying too hard to sound edgy or cool. But here, everything made sense. The dialogue flowed naturally. The curse words werenâ€™t just for shock, they felt earned u know. One of the scenes that stayed with me was in the motel. It was quiet, then the sound of a train passing by filled the background. That sound stuck with me. It gave the scene so much weight. It felt like the world outside was moving forward, while Sunshine was stuck in a moment where everything felt uncertain. That kind of sound detail is the kind of thing I really appreciate.As someone na working din sa field, I couldnâ€™t help but notice the small design details. Sunshineâ€™s costumes were on point, from her jerseys na may ibat ibang year (aminin, pambahay natin mga intrams shirt ğŸ˜‚) to the athletic tapes on her body, to her bag full of pins and cute hair clips. Those little choices made feel convincing talaga. She looked like an actual teen athlete, not just someone pretending to be one.The scene in the church was another standout. She didnâ€™t even go inside. She stayed outside and prayed, and that choice said so much. It was symbolic. It showed how distant she probably felt from her faith or how unworthy she thought she was in that moment. That kind of framing really hit me.I also appreciated the sound design. Instead of dramatic bg music, they focused ambient sounds. It gave everything a grounded feeling. It was like I was right there with her, experiencing everything in real time.The pacing was perfect. There were no awkward pauses, no scenes that felt unnecessary. Sa ibang movies, may moments na napapa-phone lang ako hahahah Every second mattered. Every moment added layers to the story. Even the locations were smartly chosen. They werenâ€™t overly stylized. They felt like real places people actually live in and go through things in.Award ka talaga Sunshine. â˜€ï¸

Sunshine is probably one of the most important film philippine cinema has to offer. beautifully poignant, heart-warming, tragic, and is just fully human. simplicity is it's beauty. if you think that this film is just about abortion, then you're wrong. it highlights how messed up the philippine society is when dealing with such. abortion is never a black and white morally right or wrong thing. there is a whole gray area that you need to understand about it and this film perfectly showcases that.plus a piolo pascual jumpscare.plus plus, despite me wanting to watch movies alone, i was happy to see a packed cinema today.

Sobrang fitting na sunshine ang title ng pelikulang ito dahil katulad ni sunshine, may tapang, puso, at pagkakakilanlan ang pelikula. Matapang dahil bilang predominantly catholic country na sobrang na ka-angkla ang paniniwala, mga desisyon, at disposisyon sa buhay sa kung ano ang tama at mali sa bibliya, isang malaking hakbang ang ipakitang tumaliwas sa nakaugalian at kinalakihang ideya ng kung ano ang â€œtamaâ€. Matapang dahil sa mundo at sa bansang sobrang patriyarkal na nag c-cater lamang sa kalalakihan, walang pag-uubling pinakita na wala dapat may ibang may karapatan sa katawan at kapakanan ng isang babae kung hindi sila lamang. Matapang kasi ilegal ang aborsyon sa pilipinas at imoral ang tingin sa mga taong gustong gawin â€˜to pero walang takoâ€™t na ipinakita na katulad ni sunshine, may mga babeng hindi ginusto at gustong maging ina at dapat ay may karapatan silang mamili. May puso kasi naguumapaw sa pagmamahal ang pelikula. Pagmamahal ng kapatid, kaibigan, mentor. At higit sa lahat ang pagmamahal sa kapwa babae. Ang pagmamahal na ipinakita ni sunshine kay menggay, ang pagmamahal na pinakita ni doctora helena sa kanilang dalawa. Masakit in a way pero sobrang gandang isipin na women will always have each otherâ€™s back at the end of the day. Walang titindig para sa isang babae nang lubos kung hindi babae lamang rin. Ngunit ang nangibabaw rito ay ang pagmamahal ni sunshine sa sarili niya at sa kanyang mga pangarap. May doubts si sunshine bilang isang babae, bilang isang katoliko. Kaya nga ilang beses natin siya nakitang nagdasal eh at kaya na rin nag e-exist ang karakter ni annika co. Siya yung nagsilbing physical form ng nagsalong upbringing at inhibitions ni sunshine pero at the end of the day, nanaig pa rin ang pagmamahal niya sa pangarap niya. Ang ganda, sobrang ganda. May pagkakakilanlan kasi sobrang pinoy na pinoy â€˜tong pelikulang ito. Mula sa kung paano pinakita yung ingay at gulo ng maynila, hanggang sa dynamics ng magkakapatid sa pamilyang pilipino. Pati kung paano nabubuhay ang mga babae sa bansang bulok ang reproductive health system at hindi tanggap ang pagiging sexual nila. Sunshine is now my favorite maris racal performance which was previously held by peachy of Pamilya Ko. I know itâ€™s the bare minimum and literally the point of acting but you can really tell sheâ€™s a good actress kasi walang bahid ng kung sino si maris racal sa totoong buhay sa mga karakter na ginagampanan niya. Sobrang believable niya as an actress. In my opinion, this is direk tonetâ€™s best work to date. Her magnum opus so far. Also, jennica garcia is truly a fucking star. She owned every scene she had. P.S. tangina mo miggs at bobot i hope you both rot in hell!!!

hindi lahat handa, hindi lahat may gusto at ayos lang 'yon. walang mali sa ginawa ni sunshine dahil sa buong pelikula, ngumiti lang siya nang totoo noong natapos niya nang maayos ang routine niya.

sa mga pelikulang lokal, mga kwento tungkol sa urban poor ang pinaka-dama ko dahil buhay ko ito at buhay ito ng mga mahal at kilala ko. naiintindihan ko ang paghahalintulad nito sa Maynila sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag, not only because of its messaging but in the way it presents itself â€” with so much bitterness yet so much heart. napakaimportanteng pelikula ni Sunshine. napaka-espesyal at sobrang lapit sa puso ko. and, unsurprisingly, this is direk jadaone best work yet, as well as maris racal.

sobrang raw ng pagkagawa ng pelikula. walang background music para lang mas may "impact" yung isang senaryo. mararamdaman mo na lang yung bigat na nararamdaman ni sunshine: sa bigat ng pressure na maabot yung pangarap (considering it's for the whole country), pressure na pag nag-decide siya for herself and for her loved ones dream for her, eh labag naman sa norms and belief ng mga nasa paligid, dito papasok yung bata na feeling ko "konsensya" nya. nung naintindihan na ng "konsensya" yung "logic" bakit dapat gawin yung isang bagay, naabot ni sunshine pangarap nya. sarap din makita na hindi pamilya nya yung nagco-command ng dapat paniwalaan, hinayaan nilang si sunshine yung pumili. basta andami ko pang gustong sabihin, sobrang galing mo direk at maris.

Mula sa isang kulturang lubhang konserbatibo na pinanday ng mga relihiyosong paniniwala hanggang sa mga magulang na nagpabaya sa tungkulin nilang protektahan ang kanilang mga anak. Dagdag pa rito ang mga kalalakihang hindi kayang akuin ang responsibilidad ng kanilang mabibigat na kasalanan-- gaya ni Miggs, na nagsabing natatakot siya sa sitwasyon nila sa harap ng kanyang paring ama, pagkatapos niyang murahin si Sunshine dahil hindi niya naayos ang kanilang problema. Sa kanila, napakabilis tumalikod, na para bang ang lahat ng bigat ay kayang dalhin ng nag-iisang tao.sa ilalim ng ingay ng Maynila, ipinapakita ng pelikulang ito ang katahimikan-- isang uri ng pananahimik na nagtatago ng isang mabigat na katotohanan mula sa lahat. THISSS IS CINEMAAAA U GUYS ğŸ˜­(YAS, edited w/ a short commentary)what i love about sunshine is it never tries to sell the idea that motherhood is innate, pure, or noble. instead, it asks the real question paano kung ayaw talaga? and itâ€™s so bold to center that lalo na sa context ng pilipinas where everything about being a woman is reduced to sacrifice.weâ€™re raised to believe na ang katawan natin ay para sa pamilya, para sa pananampalataya, para sa kinabukasan ng iba. never para sa sarili. kaya sobrang rare and sobrang radical makakita ng pelikula na nagsasabing "hindi mo kailangang gustuhin. hindi mo kailangang magpaka-martir.â€sunshine understands na abortion is not some abstract â€œdebateâ€ about morality. itâ€™s lived. itâ€™s embodied. itâ€™s desperate. and it doesnâ€™t look away from that. it shows us what women are actually left with when theyâ€™re denied safe and legal options. instructions sa papel, gamot na walang label, pangambang baka mamatay ka sa proseso. it doesnâ€™t sensationalize it, but it doesnâ€™t sanitize it either. and thatâ€™s where the power lies.the film knows the violence doesnâ€™t start when a woman decides to abort. it starts when the state tells her she canâ€™t. when even in the face of trauma, poverty, or kahit simpleng â€œhindi ko kaya" o "ayoko," the answer is always â€œwala tayong magagawa." sunshine sits with that anger. nire-recognize niya na ang lack of choice ay isa lang sa napakaraming anyo o mukha ng systemic violence. patunay ito of how the law protects an imagined morality while punishing the actual living woman.and yes, this film is very aware that class makes all the difference. hindi lahat may access to private clinics or doctors willing to take the risk. karamihan, kung hindi lahat, gaya sa pelikula ay sa quiapo ang bagsak. o kaya naman hilot. 'yung iba wala talagang means & are forced to be victims of the way laws, culture, and religion collude to trap women into roles they never asked for. and that matters. because the way we talk about abortion in this country is always so detached from those realities. laging hypothetical. laging abstract. laging nakadikit sa spiritual na paniniwala. but sunshine shows that for many women, hindi lang siya tungkol sa pagkakaroon ng choice o sa moralidad kundi buhay at kaligtasan din nila mismo. literal na tinatanggalan sila ng basic human rights. ang sarap himayin ng pelikulaaa especially 'yung subplot tungkol doon sa 13-yr old girl tapos isampal 'yun sa mukha ng mga taong hindi magawang ilabas ang sarili nila sa personal nilang mga baluktot na paninindigan.ig the best part for me is how sunshine never tries to justify. likeee it doesnâ€™t go â€œlook, she had no choice,â€ or â€œsheâ€™s a victim, kaya understandable.â€ no. it says na kahit may support ka, kahit privilege ka, kahit hindi ka biktima, may karapatan kang pumili. and that, for me, is what makes it a GREAT feminist film. hindi siya nakikiusap sa audience na intindihin si sunshine. it tells you, plainly, na she owes you nothing.and maybe the most haunting part of this film is how it visualizes the weight of that decision. hindi bilang guilt or punishment but as memory. the film doesnâ€™t erase the what-if. it shows you that even when a choice is right, it doesnâ€™t come clean or easy. and that doesnâ€™t make it wrong.FKK SOBRANG GALING LANG !!

A sunshine of hope in the dark, conservative alleys of Manila.This is a film that tackles what we Filipinos mostly shame women for: abortion. In this film, we see how the patriarchal society has a chokehold on our women. Men continue to crush the dreams of women, whether through abandoning them (ehem Miggy), ruining them (ehem Bobot), and deciding for their future (ehem Pastor Jaime).But not Sunshine.Despite everything, she persisted. She never gave up. Her trials and eventual triumphs gave a nice contrast to the setting: the dark alleyways of Quiapo. In the desolate streets, there she is continuing to shine. And can I just say, sobrang galing ni Maris! She really did justice in portraying the character. Additionally, Iâ€™d also like to commend Annika Co in her portrayal of the bata. Superb, she has potential! Her character is like an annoying voice of reason for Sunshine. Pero grabe, naluha ako in the end sa scene nilang dalawa.And Rhed Bustamante too as Mary Grace. Despite a short screen time, I felt that she was the soul of the movie. Through her, we saw how Sunshine comes to realize her fight for her dreams. Mary Grace was the bridge that Sunshine crossed to eventually come to her decision of persisting with her goals. I also liked how the women in the film supported each other. Thea, despite her mother not allowing her to hang out with Sunshine, showed up in the end. Coach Eden, who helped Sunshine realize her dreams. Her sister Geleen, who strongly supported her in every way. This film is an ode to women, and tackles an issue that should really be talked about more.

PEAK PHILIPPINE CINEMA! peak storytelling. peak everything. sunshine is loud and clear. this film talks deeply about women and womenâ€™s rights, especially in reproductive healthcare. in this country, there are countless individuals like sunshine, someone who will do everything for her dreams at all costs.
Alam mo yung nakaka-putangina? Miggy walks away with his future intact. Sunshine, meanwhile, has to carry the grief, the fear, the consequences, and still be expected to rise from it â€œwith grace.â€
That's my girl!

Sunshine tried to open a discussion about a topic rarely talked about in the Philippines -- and in that aspect, I think it was already a success.For it to be played in Philippine cinemas is already a win for the film, on top of the other awards it has received abroad. In terms of the technical aspects, I liked how the film showed the beauty of Manila despite its flaws, how graceful rhythmic gymnastics look like despite being a tough sport, and how the venues mostly used in the film had enough space needed despite being cramped.Story-wise, I like how it tackled the problems of the Philippines in terms of reproductive health, but also showed the pro of being a mother -- or at least having a mother figure by your side. However, while I understand why Sunshine made that decision, I think it somehow lacked that oomph on why she was eventually convinced to do IT. What happened after THE TALK? Still, I believe Sunshine should be watched by many. Sunshine shows that one may be in a dark situation, but if you stand your ground and believe in what's best for you, then you know how or where to find the light.

major major edit kasi walang laman yung una kong review ditoSunshine is such a progressive film in my opinion, which is crazy kasi bare minimum palang 'to ng dapat na malaman ng mga tao, na pinagdadaanan ng mga babae on a daily basis. sobrang natakot ako dito to be honest, sa reaction ng mga manonood; especially men. it's heavily emphasized sa pelikula kung ano yung gusto nitong iparating, sobraaaang laking factor nito na kung isa lang liberal na close-minded at misogynist paâ€”baka nagwala ka na kung nagbayad ka ng 350 para mapanood 'to sa sine ganon mwahahahaang hirap mamili ng favorite kong scene rito, siguro kasi nga bihira ako makanood ng ganito na local film with this kind of concept. so beautiful, so feminine, and so brave. pero siguro, yung papel ni Anika dito yung isa sa pinaka importante. siya yung what if ni Sunshine, "what if nanganak ako?" siya 'yon, and nakakapanibago na hindi makain ng guilt sa ganitong istorya, insteadâ€”i was uplifted. naintindihan niya si Sunshine. walang tapon sa cast din; si Xy, si Rhed Bustamante na favorite ko rin yung papel, kahit si Elijah.tip of the iceberg palang ito, and hopefully next time wala nang holding back kasi women deserve to be heard even in the most gruesome circumstances.

A lot has already been said about this filmâ€”timely, important, brave. Sunshine is not great just because it tackles abortion, it welcomely invites us to be with its titular character. Every scene we are with her, and no scene is wasted. We know she got big dreams, and it's all she's ever known. We feel her despair, anger, and the facade through her smile. We see her make bad choices, but we understand why.I've seen a similar film in 2020, US's Never Rarely Sometimes Always. What sets Sunshine apart is it is set in the Philippines, a predominantly Catholic country. From the moment Sunshines wants to know about her status, judgment has already been cast upon her. People around her treat her as if she's some sort of contagious disease. Institutions, who are supposed to provide help, condemns her and gives a long-ass speech as if they're god. Yet, she finds a glimpse of hope in the most unlikely of places.Direk Tonet has proven to be one of the most versatile and essential modern directors in the Philippines. From her indie roots to her modern take of romcoms, she consistently has made semi-blockbuster memorable Filipino films. In her shift to sociopolitical drama, which already started in Fan Girl (2020), her voice as a female writer-director is clearer than ever. Hearing the germ of idea for this film got me intrigued, inspired from Jojo Rabbit (2019). At first, I was skeptical of this borrowed plot device, but it completely won me over and elevated the film in the end. Manila is captured as pure as it is. The score is played at the right moments, and so did pure silence.And of course, Maris Racal, the heart of this film. A year of training and research for the character paid off. She is Sunshine through and through! Her in that motel scene is raw and chilling to say the least. All the supporting actors and bit roles are just as great and gives life to Sunshine's world. Jennica Garcia may have a few lines, but her performance especially in that scene with Maris is one to be remembered for, especially for teenage mothers. A surprising yet worthy appearance comes from Rhed Bustamante, whose minor role made a huge impact on meâ€”I cried!Sunshine is such a lightning in a bottle kind of Filipino film. Who would have thought that a great indie pinoy film about abortion is getting this high amount of traction and success? One's hope is for this to create discussion among us and to move the needle systemically for girls like Sunshine. (And as a cinephile, I hope more films like this get produced and be seen by Filipinos, because Philippine Cinema has always been alive!)

Courageous. This is how I would describe the film. The way it speaks to and for society, portrays women's experiences, and challenges the pre-existing notionsâ€” the societal pressures, religious guilt, patriarchal normsâ€”all were executed perfectly.One thing that I can't seem to stop thinking about is the personification of Sunshine's troubles. Some said it could be her conscience, maybe her guilt, maybe it's also the pressures society had brought upon women experiencing the same struggle, but I personally saw it as the personification of the child inside her. Kasi as a pregnant woman, one of the top things that she's probably considering the most would be the child (since it has been embeded into us that the child has a life as soon as it's formed). Ang galing lang kasi talaga ng portrayal na 'to and it keeps my mind gears churning. And that 'gets ko na'â€¦ I BAWLED.Sunshine is also one of the movies na mayroong ibang level of understanding yung mga babae, e no? A man could watch this and empathize, pero iba yung dating ng pelikulang ito lalo na sa mga babae sa Pilipinas. I would really only trust movies about women to women. Props to DIrek Tonet for this, really.Listing the things I love abt the movie here too!- Sunshine and the women she encounteredâ€¦- Ang galing nung mga bata at ni Rhed tangina!!!???? - basagin ang ulo ng mga rapist >>>> magbasag ng bote sa ulo ng rapist- I have a lot more kaso my short term memory can't write it now because I'm logging this days late UGH.But It feels really freeing to see this kind of story sa theater, with a broader audience. Salamat sa matapang na pagbitaw ng mga salitang "Ayaw kong maging nanay" at "Hindi pa ako handang maging nanay" sa harap ng bansang ang tingin ay ito lang dapat ang kahihinatnan ng kababaihan. Oo, motherhood is great, but it's not for all of usâ€” especially for ones who are forced into it.Para sa pangarap, buhay, at kaligtasanâ€” Isulong natin ang karapatan ng kabataan at kababaihan! No to Abuse, Harassment, and Teenage Pregnancy!Yes to Reproductive Health Awareness! Decriminalize abortion!Hayaan nating magdesisyon ang bawat babae para sa kanilang katawan dahil ito ay kanila, at kanila lamang. #ProChoice :)

It is refreshing to see such a brave filmmaker like Antoinette Jadaone take on such a taboo topic as this, and despite its obvious flaws, there is so much to be celebrated about "Sunshine". Her depiction of realist Manila within a predominantly Catholic albeit judgmental Philippines is strikingly affecting, and the first half of this in particular is a worthy showcase of great filmmaking. The plot device did take me out of the film from time to time, and I do not think it was necessary nor was it effective. Yet, what more can you ask for when you have such a riveting turn from Maris Racal, who puts forward a performance for the ages. Those around her are also excellent, particularly Jennica Garcia, who embodies so much heart and emotion in the little scenes that she is in. Could this have been a better film? Yes. But is it one that is worth seeing? Absolutely.[Watched at SM Mall of Asia cinemas]

â€œdrown out the noise.â€easier said than done when the noise is everything.the streets of Maynila. the train. the coach. the prayers. the stares. the guilt.Sunshine isnâ€™t just a film about a girl with Olympic dreams and an unplanned pregnancy. itâ€™s about how loud the world gets when youâ€™re no longer allowed to dream. the kind of noise that follows you into cramped maternity wards, judgmental glances, and conversations that arenâ€™t even about you, but your body.itâ€™s claustrophobic â€” not just visually, but emotionally. the tight shots mimic how it feels to be backed into a corner: by family, religion, institutions, and the echo of â€œwhat will people say?â€ that never stops ringing. thereâ€™s no space to move. no time to think. just pressure.this is a strong film. one that dares to confront the Philippinesâ€™ obsession with purity, shame, and control. it pulls back the curtain on a country where reproductive health is taboo. it also shows the quiet fear around abortion â€” how itâ€™s never really said out loud, but always there, hiding under the surface. a real choice that girls are never allowed to make. where the system will preach â€œlife is sacred,â€ but give you a plastic chair in an overcrowded ward and leave you to figure it out alone.sure, it plays it safe sometimes â€” there are parts where you wish it pushed a little more. but it still says a lot, even in quiet moments.Sunshine doesnâ€™t claim to have all the answers. but it knows the questions that need to be asked.about bodily autonomy. about access to care. about what it really means to grow up in a place that punishes girls for being girls.APAKAHUSAY NYO MS TONET AT MARIS!

the world is unforgiving to womenlike the corners of manila that bore witness to sunshine and her quiet struggle, like the santo niÃ±os in quiapo that hide fatality, a risk to escape a life that was never theirs to carry. like the church that stands in the midst of relentless shame.the world is unforgiving to women, where desire is almost always consequence for who were born to bear its fruit yet never a sliver of guilt from those who took part in it.the world is unforgiving to women yet it expects so much. so much burden to carry. so much life to spend carrying. with only sisters, other women, to carry it with, to lighten the load.rarely has a film induced so much crying from me. itâ€™s not perfect, but it hit a part of me that mourns for our women, for the lives that have forever been altered by the lack of knowledge and autonomy and conversation. and still, everywhere there are quiet ways that we hold each other through it all.

Watching Sunshine wasnâ€™t just watching a movie. Parang I was sitting beside a woman, listening to her story ng tahimik lang, pero sobrang bigat. Itâ€™s not easy to watch, but thatâ€™s exactly why it felt so real. What hit me the most was how the film didnâ€™t try to be loud or preachy. The film doesnâ€™t try to romanticize or a free promotion for abortion. It just let the silence do the work. Minsan iyak lang, minsan wala talagang salita. That makes it more powerful. Hindi ito simpleng kwento. Itâ€™s about pain, dreams, and mga choices na hindi talaga madaling pagpilian.Pero I have to say, may parts na medyo kulang for me. Sana mas dark yung cinematography, like Khalel 15 â€” gritty and raw. Lastly, hindi ito movie para sa lahat. But still, Sunshine gives us something real. And if youâ€™re willing to sit with it and really listen, then youâ€™ll see a side of womanhood na madalas tinatago.
A woman who refuses to ruled by their own body, choices and dreams is something powerful and bravery. !!!! ğŸ™‡â¤ï¸âœ¨

Mula pa lang sa trailer, alam ko naâ€”hindi ko puwedeng palampasin ang pelikulang ito. Direk Tonet â€˜yan, eh. May tiwala ako sa kakayahan niyang gawing matula ang trahedya, at gawing tahimik pero mabigat ang mga sigaw ng kababaihan sa lipunang laging inuuna ang hiya kaysa sa hustisya.Isa sa mga personal na dahilan kung bakit ako nanood ay dahil gusto kong unawainâ€”hindi man buo, pero kahit kontiâ€”kung ano ang dinadala ng isang babaeng katulad ni Sunshine. Bilang isang assigned male at birth, pero hindi ganap na komportable sa label na iyon, alam kong may distansya sa pagitan namin ni Sunshine. Pero iyon mismo ang dahilan kung bakit ako nanahimik sa sinehan. Tumigil akong mag-analisa, at hayaan ang pelikula na magsalita para sa sarili nito. Hindi ko kailangang maging babae para makiramay. Pero gusto kong makiramdam. At dito, sa pelikulang ito, nagtagumpay akong maramdaman si Sunshineâ€”ang kanyang pagkalito, galit, at takotâ€”na para bang sarili kong laman-loob ang kinikiskis ng eksena.At sa prosesong iyon, nadama ko si Sunshineâ€”ang pagkalito niya na hindi simpleng pagkaligaw, kundi paglalakad sa isang landas na sinabihan siyang bawal. Ang galit niyang hindi mapagsigawan, at ang takot niyang hindi inamin, pero nandoon sa bawat kumpas ng katawan niya. Maris Racal didnâ€™t just play Sunshineâ€”she inhabited her. She carried her, as if every scene weighed heavily on her spine, even when she stood upright. May mga eksena na walang dialogue pero mas mabigat pa sa sigawan. At doon ko nakita ang mastery ni Maris bilang aktres: ang kakayahang magsalita gamit ang pananahimik.Nakakatawang may nagsabi raw sa likod ng kamera na â€œhaggardâ€ siya habang nagsu-shoot. I laughedâ€”not because itâ€™s funny, but because itâ€™s too real. Ganito talaga ang hitsura ng kabataang babae na araw-araw tinatanggihan ang mundo, pero hindi puwedeng mapagod. May mga Sunshine sa Quiapo, sa mga post sa Reddit, sa mga comments na deleted, sa mga babae sa jeep na tahimik lang pero may bitbit na kwento. And it takes a film like Sunshine to remind us: they are not voiceless. We just havenâ€™t been listening.Unang tingin kay Annika, iisipin mong comic relief siya. Isang batang gumugulo sa eksena, parang pang-balanse sa bigat ng naratibo. Pero habang tumatagal, na-realize kong siya pala ang pinakamatining sa lahat. Hindi siya ordinaryong karakterâ€”siya ang konsensya ni Sunshine. Hindi ang moralistic kind, but the invasive kind. Yung konsensyang hindi laging tama o mali, kundi nagtatanong: â€œNasaan ka na?â€ â€œHanda ka ba?â€ â€œIto ba ang gusto mong piliin?â€ At dahil hindi laging consistent ang paglitaw niyaâ€”minsan parang guni-guni, minsan parang totooâ€”mas naging epektibo siya. Kasi hindi ba ganoon din ang konsensya? It creeps in when you're alone. It arrives uninvited. In a country where abortion is taboo, Annika becomes more than a personâ€”sheâ€™s a presence. A question. A symbol of possibility and loss, but not in a way that condemns. Sheâ€™s not there to judge Sunshine, but to make us feel what it means to carry a choice you canâ€™t share with anyone. Sa isang bansang ang moralidad ay naka-template mula sa pulpito, ang pagkakaroon ng karakter tulad ni Annika is radical. Hindi siya plot device. Isa siyang reimaginasyon ng konsensyaâ€”hindi para ipahiya ang babae, kundi ipaalala kung gaano kabigat ang dalahin sa lipunang pilit silang pinatatahimik..Ang Sunshine ay hindi pelikulang pro-choice dahil gusto nitong makipagtalo. Hindi rin ito pelikula tungkol sa abortion dahil gusto nitong mag-skandalo. Ito ay pelikula tungkol sa karapatan. Sa kakayahang pumili, kahit pa masakit ang pagpiling iyon. Sunshine doesnâ€™t celebrate abortionâ€”it honors the courage to face it. Sa lipunang ang kababaihan ay kailangang laging malinis, laging mabait, laging matino, heto ang isang pelikulang nagsasabing: ang katawan mo ay hindi kasalanan. Ang pagpili mo ay hindi dapat katumbas ng pagkapako.Maraming salamat, Direk Tonet. Salamat sa hindi pag-ikot sa ligtas na naratibo. Salamat sa pagbibigay ng boses sa katahimikan. Salamat sa paghubog ng pelikulang hindi lang para sa kababaihan, kundi para sa lahat ng gustong matutong makinig.Bilang isang lalaki na walang MATRES, pero may malasakit sa mga may isa, ramdam ko ang urgency ng kwento. Sunshine is not a perfect filmâ€”but it is a vital one. And in a country that rarely gives women room to speak, a film like this doesnâ€™t just feel brave. It feels necessary.

" Drown out the noise."This line in the Sunshine struck me after watching the film. Noise is considered as a plot device in the film literally and figuratively. I like how the background music or the noise from the background is used to set the tone and mood of the film especially in scenes where Sunshine is walking or riding a jeep home. Noise in the film can also represent the doubts that fill her while practicing and self-righteous religious people who judge her actions throughout the film.The film is about a gymnast who plans to join the tryouts for the Olympics. However, she receives a result that is unexpectedly pregnant which can hinder her chances in getting in. Maris Racal is great in her role as Sunshine and I think that she embodies the role of a gymnast especially since she tried gymnastics to prepare for her role. There were scenes that were remarkable for me such as when she tries to hit a the mirror of a car after her boyfriend (played by Elijah Canlas) doesn't take responsibility for her pregnancy. I also loved the supporting characters as well. Despite their small roles, they made a mark for me. For instance, Jennica Garcia was impressive in her scenes with Maris Racal as her older sister. You can feel that she defends and protects her sister and stay by her side especially during her revelation that she is pregnant. Xyriel Manabat is no surprise for me since I admire her acting skills since she was a child actress. She is great as Sunshine's best friend. Annika Co, an upcoming child actress, is a scene stealer where she acts as a conscience to Sunshine. She is charming and witty in her role and I think the twist made sense to me in one scene.In addition to it being a sports drama, this film also tackled the themes of women's choice and abortion. These topics are considered sensitive and taboo in a dominant Catholic and conservative society. As a man, this film moved me and realize how hard it is to be a woman in a society wherethey are judged for having an autonomy in their body. In a third world country, healthcare is considered a privilege especially for the poor. Because of abortion being considered illegal and immoral, women are forced to resort to unsafe practices which can endanger them. It is shown in the film and I think it's interesting that it depicted two doctors: one which discriminates women because of her religious bias and one which tried to understand and helped another character in the film who turned to abortion. It's a sad reality, but I'm glad that this film will open conversations about themes like these.Overall, I find Sunshine an impressive film. I think this is Antonette Jadaone's best film so far. It's my second film that I've seen in cinemas and I'm grateful to witness it in the big screen because it is worth the watch there with its immersive experience. I was definitely looking forward to it since it's rare to watch a sports film which centers around gymnastics and it has been shown in film festivals abroad. I was worried that it won't be shown here because of how controversial it would be because of the stand of the Catholic Church and other religious sectors regarding abortion. I guess more people are more open-minded towards the topics unlike before. Aside from the acting, what I found compelling in the film is the cinematography and scoring which adds tension and mood to the it. Despite its limited release and pitted against two superhero films during its premiere, I really hope more people will get a chance to watch this movie. Even if it shows the harsh realities of life and in sports, I agree with other film critics that it also shows hope. There is Sunshine after the rain.

No doubt my favorite Jadaone film, Sunshine is not only an important work of art in a cultural context, but an objectively beautiful, clean and concise narrative work. What I mean is not a single frame is wasted, or given up for style points - every decision of performance, framing and pace is made to serve the story, to make us empathize with Sunshine, to feel what she feels.Woman vs the institution - the clarity of this theme is just so powerful, yet weâ€™re brought into Sunshineâ€™s world through masterful camerawork that just feels honest. Thereâ€™s a shot I love, where Sunshine is framed inside a window (in her room then in a motel), and the chaos of the city goes on about her, uncaring and apathetic to her situation. Thatâ€™s the whole movie - the slow-burning horror that she is being shunned by society, cramped into tiny spaces trying to survive. It made me cringe to hear the chants of â€œPilipinasâ€ by the crowd in her performance at the end (the sad reality of Filipino athletes, unsupported in training yet celebrated in victory)Maris Racalâ€™s best performance. The care and dedication she brought to the role should be applauded. Everyone else in the movie is so dialed in too, a subtle superpower of Direk Tonetâ€™s ear for relatable acting and dialogue. Also love the Pastor P appearance, who brings such an important discussion into the public consciousness. The ultimate boss level: God & practicality vs the womanâ€™s decision.Instant classic!

â€œSunshineâ€ gripped my soul and left me hollow with unease. the first ten minutes we follow Sunshine as she drifts aimlessly through the restless streets of Manila, and thatâ€™s how the entire film feels. yes, itâ€™s sending a message, but watching her spiral felt almost voyeuristic, as if we were witnessing something intimate and illegal. no propaganda, just raw, heartbreaking truth.and as much as i hate comparing directors, the rawness of each frame felt deeply â€œBrockaâ€ but captured through the tenderness and gaze of a woman. at the filmâ€™s core is Maris Racal, exceptional in her quiet nuance, supported beautifully by Jennica Garcia.this film will linger with me for days. itâ€™s about the cruelty of the world, the ache of aspirations, the fragile hope for a better life, and, ultimately, a womanâ€™s choice.And at the center of it all, I love when a woman chooses herself.

sobrang halaga sa akin ng sunshine dahil hindi lang karapatan ng kababaihan ang buhat nitong adbokasiya, kung hindi pati na rin ang karapatan ng kabataan na madalas isinasantabi lang sa usapin ng reproductive health. kung ang tema ay tungkol sa pagiging pro-choice lang, magwowork pa rin naman yung kwento kung young adult o di kayaâ€™y isang full grown woman si sunshine. pero siya ay isang teenagerâ€”bata sa mata ng batas at babae sa mata ng lipunan. eventually, titignan na rin siya bilang isang babae na lang dulot ng kanyang pagkabuntis, na para bang nawawala agad ang pagkabata porket may dinadalang bata.doble ang pasan ng teenage pregnancy, dahil bilang bata o babae man, wala silang say sa sarili nilang katawan. kulang pa ang impormasyon at rekurso kapag kailangan na nila, making them even more vulnerable sa panganib. tulad ni sunshine, marami ang natutukso sa mga ilegal at nakamamatay na paraan para lang ipaglaban ang karapatan nila sa sariling katawan, dahil wala silang natatanggap na anumang uri ng suporta. mas pinahahalagahan ng lipunan ang buhay na namumuo pa lang sa sinapupunan kesa ang buhay na nariyan na. kaya bukod sa panawagan para sa legal na proteksyon sa autonomy ng kababaihan at dekalidad na healthcare system, lumilitaw rin sa pelikula ang agarang pangangailangan natin para sa comprehensive sex education na siyang magpoprovide ng necessary and appropriate resources sa mga bata tungkol sa sex, contraception, consent, at iba pang mga kaugnay na bagay na gagabay sa kanila para tahakin ito nang ligtas at malay.sana ipalabas pa ito sa mas malawak na audience huhu kelangan to ipakilala at idiin sa consciousness ng mga pilipino ngayon din!!!

"gets ko na"a moment in this film that really struck me was the last scene with sunshine and her almost child â€” that could've been me to my mom. my parents were teenagers when they had me, and my mom told me na she tried buying pamparegla from quiapo before, but her parents stopped her saying it was a horrendous sin kay Lord. if she had chosen to live her life without me existing, i would thank her for it. gets na gets ko siya. i hope this film will successfully convey its message to the viewers, and serve as an eye-opener for those who believe that a woman doesn't have a choice.rhed bustamante's character as a 13-year old who was sa'd by her tito reflects the reality of a lot of women â€” girls even, cause she's not even an adult yet. abortion being illegal in the philippines doesn't stop people from doing it, hence it leads them to doing it in a horrifying and deadly way. pamparegla pills and hilot are ways people resort to because of abortion being inaccessible here in our country. tapos nung na-ospital siya hindi pa ginamot? tangina talaga ng mga lalaki! thank you dra. helena for your life!to all anti-abortion out there, i hope this film reaches you. if it's not convenient for you, then okay, but at least think about those who really need it. overall, this film is such a great commentary on how women aren't always meant to be mothers, and that one failure won't ever stop you from reaching your dreams. to all sunshine's out there, kapit lang :))
salamat sa buhay mo, direk tonet!

â€œSunshineâ€ is more than a film, it is a visceral, unflinching portrait of womanhood in the Philippines. It gives voice not only to the silenced narratives about teenage pregnancy and abortion, but also to the layered realities of how Filipinas live, dream, suffer, and survive amid the relentless chaos of urban life. It dares to confront uncomfortable truths.The cinematography is superb! Every shot is meticulously composed to convey the oppressive density of Manila. The stress is not just seen, it is felt. Salamat, direk Tonet! This is a big contribution to the success of Philippine cinema.

many reasons why i absolutely loved this movie: 1) watched it w someone who is very dear to me (hi angel if youâ€™re seeing this)2) the actors3) the story it tells 4) what this film means for the future of abortion and RH in the PHok now lets go point by point starting at no. 2. hoping the people reading this dont think im intellectualizing my review or whatever bc i just have a lot of thoughts and i couldnt sleep so im writing this nowâ€¦2) actorsits lined up with amazing, talented actors so itâ€™s absolutely a no-brainer that they would all deliver their lines stunningly. however, each character brought out such vivid emotions that i believe only their respective actor/actress could bring out. props to the casting director and direk jadaone for this. i first give my flowers to elijah canlas and piolo pascual. honestly believe that no other pair of actors could portray this father-son, catholic tandem better. elijah weirdly embodies the annoying, conyo, gago actor really well, while piolo is no stranger to playing a overt Catholic. i also am all praise for xyriel, meryll, and jennica. the women in the film who, in a world that is cruel, chose to be kind, especially to Sunshine. i praise jennica especially because with every line recited, you can feel her characterâ€™s exhaustion of having to give up their dreams and forcing themselves to accept their reality in an unforgiving society, as if she had a choice. of course, annika co is also a standout star here. though a rookie in the industry, i loved seeing her on the big screen. lastly, maris. no one can play Sunshine but Maris Racal. i fear i have to make a separate review on her solely. i hope she bags many, many awards because she deserves it. 3) the story it tellsthe story of Sunshine is one that I, as a woman, have encountered many times. while post-debrief, i recounted the amount of times i was told a former schoolmate of mine became a teenage mother, and i thought about all of the dreams they had to give up simply because they had no choice. even in this film, Sunshineâ€™s reality painted her to have little to no choice at all. while itâ€™s not a new narrative, itâ€™s a narrative thatâ€™s stuck in the pastâ€”in traditional, old, conservative Philippine society, which is why movies like Sunshine feel so refreshing. it strives to go beyond what society is now. 4) what this film means for the future of abortion and RH in the PHthe fact that a film like this was produced and is being shown during a time where, globally, conservatism is on the rise and the Philippines is nowhere close to even considering the decriminalization of abortion, is already something revolutionary in itself. hopefully, this movie opens more doors to more discussions on abortion and bodily autonomy. i really have lots of respect for direk tonette and Maris for being at the forefront of what could be the beginning of the creation of a bigger platform for many women across the country to speak about autonomy and choice.
