manila in its barest, philippine societal system in its most oppressive on women, patriarchy in its sharpest teeth clenched tightly on women leaving them bloody (literally and figuratively), long held religious beliefs in its firmest grip leaving many more regressive, and most of all love and support system in its purest and most tender. i keep wondering by the end about the women who werenâ€™t given the privilege to choose, those like mary grace, those who never had the support they needed when faced with the same dilemma, those whoâ€™ve braved the use of unconventional means of abortion and may have almost died or indeed died. i wonder of their dreams, of their autonomy, of the life they have to face. and this is a reality lived by many women in the philippines, that despite the film leaving on a positive note, i just cant help but think: this world isnâ€™t built for women to thrive, instead itâ€™s a world where they have to fight tooth and nail just to survive, and in the film, to just get the basic need of a choice over their body. a world crafted where menâ€™s needs and wants are at the forefront, and where women would have to beg to even be considered.

first ever review!! new lang sa letterboxd xDD i enjoy being here! AND it really calls me to put some review sa film:_)truly every movie we watched leaves a mark but this cut deeper. mahirap maging babae sa sistemang dini-dismiss ka. hirap. sobrang ganda ng lahat, pati personality ng quiapo, na kahit gabi sa maynila, maingay pa rin. sa public hospital na halos tabi-tabi at yung mga pasyente na lang din nag tutulungan. ito kasi yung realidad na hindi alam ng karamihan, na hindi maintindihan ng ilan na walang ginawa kundi magsimba at maging komportable sa buhay.and i was wishing that it reaches those people, i hope they sit with the same uncomfortable feeling that the characters had. i hope it twisted their minds, to make them think. i hope it bleeds them just as how their "beliefs" put women in danger by denying abortion.lahat ng bida sa pelikula ay babae :'DD i have no intention to romanticize their circumstances, and it aches and comfort that there is warmth against all of it, na assurance na kasama pa rin ng mga kababaihan, natin, yung isa't isa.

the very experience of breaking down on public transportation while hev abi blasts through the speakers lol. kidding asideâ€”hay, grabe. this film feels like being punched in the gut, only to be offered a warm hug right after.growing up as a woman means being taught to feel shame about everything. liking sex. not liking sex.getting pregnant too early. getting pregnant too late.being too submissive to men. not being submissive enough.getting married. not getting married.prioritizing your career. choosing to be a stay-at-home mom.and the list goes on. just full of contradictions.that's why i cannot emphasize enough how much i love the film's concept: a woman saving a woman saving another woman. sunshineâ€™s sister standing up for her. her saving mary grace. her friend. her coach. the doctor. even the pregnant women na nagpapaypay sa kanya while sheâ€™s unconscious. just women looking out for each other.i watched this in the cinema, and when i went to the ladies' comfort room after the credits rolled, lahat kami mugto ang mata. i think we had all seen parts of ourselves reflected back at us. and it hurt. but it also healed.i hope more stories like this are told. i hope more women continue to take up space, hold each other close, and do whatever the hell they want. without apology, without SHAME.p.s. it couldn't have been anyone else but maris <33

beautifully acted and well written. thereâ€™s a sharp, dark humor threaded in its dialogues on sex, childbirth, & dreams, an unflinching tone that never really leaves u, and a quiet reality of sunshine that mirrors so much of what we rarely say out loud. a combination that truly amplifies the much needed conversation that this film advocatesâ€”one that gently but firmly questions our sense of life, morality, and the cost of it all. also, iâ€™m a big fan of the jadaone-racal duo like shet ang galing potaena sana gets niyo! #marisracalapologist

a powerful statement regarding womens body autonomy, â€œshow, dont tellâ€ tasteful undertones of the controlling patriarch as shown by Pastor Jaime (Piolo Pascual) assumed on Sunshines unborn child, the girl following Sunshine around condemning her every decision is the perfect representation of catholic guilt, and how limiting/dangerous abortion laws in the philippines are for the impoverished that result in life-threatening â€œend of the roadâ€ solutions. not a stretch to say that this is one of the best filipino movies iâ€¦

â€œdrown out the noise.â€sunshine tramples on both internal and external noisesâ€”judgment, fear, catholic guilt, and desperate prayers; the chaos that quietly unfolds in the dark streets of manila, and the ironies existing at the heart of folk-catholicism as underground, unsafe abortion exists steps away from a sacred ground. itâ€™s impossible for sunshineâ€”for womenâ€”to drown out the noise. My favorite detail in this movie is the portrayal of different women, each with her own turmoil, resources, and stage in life, struggling in a deeply patriarchal and faith-bound society, while still finding the strength to stand for each other. wala nang ibang makakaunawa at dadamay sa paghihirap ng pagiging babae kundi kapwa mga babae.this film is dark, heavy, and uncomfortable to watch (as it should) but necessary. it shatters your core and makes you question how far can religious ideas go in a hostile and punishing society. we need to open up a conversation. stat.about manila. about how quiapo has its own pulse.about commuting. about the air in your ponytail in the jeepney.about motel rooms. about pleasure in the darkness, for cheap, coerced, manipulative f*cks.about the repercussions of said f*cks. about how shameful it is to live with it in a place with ever-pointing fingers and watchful eyes.about motherhood. about how it isn't as glam when you're not as ready for it.about sports. about how athletes stand on their own two feet, sans government support.about the sunshines in our own circle. about the decisions you never really made but lived with anyway. about the dreams you chased with a sprained ankle.the ribbons you twirled and ripped.the jerseys you wore until they were worn out.the maternity clothes in your shopping cart.but what choice do you have?the answer is none.because how do you live in a country that is against you?in a system that is made for you to break, slowly, agonizingly?in places of pity and shame, how do you rise?in breaking glass windows and cages, who cheers you on?in places where the sun is scarce and the skies are dark, who forges your shine?

I love my mother so much. For me, sheâ€™s the best woman in the world - the only woman I love with all my heart. I enjoy Filipino films because of her influence - she loved classic Filipino films. She loved Sharon Cuneta. She loved Aldub. But I recently learned that she once dreamed of becoming a flight stewardess - a dream I never knew she had.I only learned about this and other stories of the woman I thought I knew when her sister shared them with us during a visit this year. Thatâ€™s when the realization sank in, I knew my mom, but not the little girl she used to be - the one with so many dreams. A probinsyana with this dream of going around the world. But she had me (I'm the eldest) when she was eighteen. Unplanned. She said she never regretted itBut I remember when I was young, she drowned herself with alcohol almost every day. Now, I understand. She never had a choice. I'm happy that she is my mother. But it also hurts me to know that she could be in a better place -pursuing her dreams, seeing the world - if not because of me. This film got me because I hope my mom had a choice at that time. I loved her so much, but I hope in her next life, she chooses her dreams.

SUNSHINE advances itself as a film about bodily autonomy in a nation that denies its very terminology, yet it does so through the insulated idiom of psychological realism rather than the concretised mapping of the material conditions that make autonomy, abortion, and girlhood existentially precarious. We are immersed in affect, but the structure underpinning these sensations is left either ambient or altogether unrendered. Yes, the pharmacy exists as a moral space and the hospital as carceral, but where is the livelihood? Who funds the training? What does it mean, materially, to be a 19-year-old athleteâ€”and an international one, at thatâ€”with no visible labouring parent and no bread line to back it up?Abortion is outlawed in the Philippines because it preserves state-church power and results in the reproductive labour of the poor as exploitable and their agency criminal, but to bracket class from the narrativeâ€”in a context where economic vulnerability is the foremost determinant of reproductive injusticeâ€”is consequential. Instead, the endless deferral into mood, while expressive, is in itself a seductive alibi for political disengagement. I understand that this is a film of interiorityâ€”that the point is to reflect Sunshineâ€™s constrained perceptual fieldâ€”but her interiority is a response to economic realities that the film chooses to elude, and when the audience is asked to interpolate systemic weight from ambience without any clear depiction of how deprivation functions, what we get is an abstraction that parades as empathy, and from that abstraction, other evasions proliferate: the neoliberal myth of the meritocratic athlete, whose suffering must be understood as psychological strain rather than as infrastructural abandonment; the convenient fiction that ambition alone propels a body through state-sponsored regimes without subsidy or the material realities the film forgoes. To abstract oppression into psychic distress then, while refusing its logistical origins, is to risk reproducing the same symbolic economy the Church relies upon: one in which the body is meaningful only as a metaphor and a vessel onto which morality is projected.This aesthetic disposition of interiority is of course obviously a structure inherited from the exportable idiom of European festival realism where the trauma of the Filipina is depicted legibly for the global North. From this perspective, it would make sense that the institutions that manufacture her precarity are rendered as emotional rather than historical, inviting the audience to feel with her but never to accountâ€”but by doing so, what emerges is not so much a Filipino film but a Filipino offering: an artefact of pain rendered in tones familiar to jurors abroad, a choice that aligns seamlessly with both (1) Jadaoneâ€™s career pivot into the international circuit, having premiered the film at Berlinale and TIFF, and (2) the filmâ€™s own final sequence: Sunshine performing her routine at the SEA games before a panel of foreign adjudicators, body taut and calibrated for approval by those who will never understand the weight of what she forfeited to arrive there. By naming these two parallels do we metabolise the rage of a system into something palatable and interpretable, and since both Jadaone and Sunshine must contort to be seen, in being seen, they are asked to become less what they mean. Perhaps the question is not whether SUNSHINE fails as a film or recedes as an offering, but whether it was ever permitted the autonomy to be anything elseâ€”whether within the landscape of Philippine cinema, where funding is precarious, distribution systems anaemic, and state culture support present only for the films that do not threaten it, a film like SUNSHINE must already enter the frame pre-legibilised and pre-digested, its rage ironed out for export. This is, after all, by the admission of its own producer Bianca Balbuena, a film that delayed its domestic release in order â€˜to premiere in top festivals [around] the world to create noise and curiosityâ€™, with the implication that only through international approval could the film attain enough value to justify its own existence at home. Thus, to resist the very circuit that enables its existence is impossible, but recognising this sharpens our understanding of the conditions under which those evasions occur. What we must ask, then, is what kind of complicity we are willing to forgive in a nation that punishes truth so severely that even its cinema must contort just to be heard.

Quiapo has always felt like a contradiction. It's a district that thrives on both holiness and hustle, tradition and survival, all crammed into claustrophobic, identical alleyways. At its heart stands a towering church, surrounded by vendors selling everything: street food, religious images, herbal medicines, fake documents, sex toys, and abortion kits â€“ pamparegla. The irony writes itself. And yet, that's where people are forced to go when they're desperate. Like Sunshine.Sunshine (Maris Racal) is a gymnast on the rise who discovers she's pregnant before a major competition â€“ just as her future starts to tighten around her. The plot is simple, but never small. What unfolds is a slow, steady panic of a young woman trying to figure things out in a country that offers her no real choices. You feel the weight that she's carrying, not just in her silence, but in her body. She's holding so much in, almost willing it all to be a fever dream. But beneath that restraint is a quiet rage â€” in her posture, in her breath, in the way she fights to keep it all together.The movie doesn't try to frame anything as heroic or tragic, and that's what makes it powerful. What stood out most to me was how angry, how fearless, it allows itself to be. It simmers. Controlled, but with crushing intensity. This is Direk Tonet's best work to date. It's her most honest and her most focused. And you can tell she did this with immense care. The love is in the details.

DI AKO NANGHINAYANG SA BINAYAD KO.Sobrang napukaw ng atensyon ko kung gaano ka realistic ang bawat eksena, ang ingay at lagkitan sa maynila, ang mga deboto ng quiapo church, ang mga ale na nagtitinda ng pamparegla at pampalaglag sa harap ng simbahan, ang kahirapan, ang unwanted pregnancy, ang krisis sa healthcare system, ang aborsyon at ang konsensya ni sunshine na hinahabol sya bawat minuto ng kanyang araw. it really captured every struggles ng pagiging babae sa bansang to. Sobrang raw, sobrang totoo at sobrang tapang ni direk tonet sa paggawa ng gantong pelikula na sana marami pa ang makapanood. Also, the performance of THE Maris Racal. Dalang dala nya ang emosyon ng manonood, the rage, pain, and bravery of Sunshine. Isa sa talagang nagpa agos ng luha ko ay ang eksena na sumasayaw sya, nakangiti pero ramdam mo ang bawat emosyon. Grabe ang scene na yun, walang dialogue pero tagos sa puso!! It was really indeed the best performance of her. And that ending, i love how direk tonet didnt show what happens to the unborn child, and pinakita na lang na nakaabot sya sa competition, it just shows na ang pagkakaroon ng choice ay magsasalba sa mga pangarap na minsan ng kinain ng sistema ng bansang ito. Gets na gets kita, Sunshine bago ko pa ito panoorin at sana magets ka na rin nila.Ginawa ang pelikula na to hindi lang para sa mga babae, ginawa ito para ipakita sa mga taong hindi nakakaintindi ang reyalidad ni Sunshine. Mahal kita direk tonet sobra!!!

This film gives you the opportunity to judge Sunshine & her decision-making as she deals with the consequences of an act she did not commit alone yet had to face entirely by herself. Dahil sa sistema at mga paniniwalang hindi pabor sa mga kababaihan.After watching, you might say â€œgets ko naâ€ as you start to understand how they feel & where theyâ€™re coming from. Unfortunately, thatâ€™s only the tip of the iceberg. You must also imagine the lives of all other Sunshines out there whose stories remain unheard and unseen. In the real world setting, you no longer have access to every womanâ€™s story. But through Sunshine, you gain something just as important: empathy and understanding. And maybeâ€” just maybeâ€” hindi naman matatapakan ang pagkatao mo if you simply allow women the freedom to decide for their own lives. Kudos to Maris Racal for beautifully executing the role of Sunshine and to Direk Jadaone for passionately pushing this brave and controversial work of art!

[4:46AM] iba yung alam mo lang, sa naiintindihan mo talaga. staying informed is one thing, but feeling it? letting it crack something open in you? ibang usapan â€˜yon.alam kong masama ang aborsyon sa mata ng simbahan. lumaki akong alam 'yon; itinuro, inulit, pinaniwalaan. alam ko rin kung paano siya tinitignan ng lipunan, ng batas, ng sistemang matagal nang hindi pumapanig sa kababaihan. isang sistemang feudal, patriyarkal, mapanghusga. pinalaki tayo rito, pinalo, pinatahimik.pero alam ko rin ito: may karapatan ang babae. sa sarili niyang katawan. sa sarili niyang desisyon. at sa healthcare na hindi dapat ipinagmamakaawa, kundi kusang ibinibigay. alam ko rin na hindi dapat tinitingnan ang aborsyon sa lente ng kasalanan o krimen, na para bang awtomatikong mali ang pagpili, at masama ang pumipili. pero ang hindi ko alam, ang hindi ko kailanman mararanasan sa ganap na paraan, ay kung ano ang pakiramdam. ang bumangon araw-araw dala ang bigat ng isang desisyong walang tama sa paningin ng lahat. ang labanan hindi lang ang sarili mong konsensya, kundi ang mundong hindi kailanman kinilala ang pinagdadaanan mo, ang takot mo, ang dahilan mo.yun ang hindi ko alam. at yun ang pinaramdam sa akin ng Sunshine.and i think that's where Sunshine really succeeds. it doesnâ€™t glorify. it doesnâ€™t argue. it simply shows. it gives us a glimpse. into a life of a young woman, into her choice, into her pain, and the kind of quiet strength we rarely talk about. gusto lang talaga ng pelikula magkuwento tungkol sa isang babae. ang dami kong gustong himayin. but if thereâ€™s one thing that stayed with me, itâ€™s this: Sunshine gives voice to stories we rarely hear. and maybe we avoid them kasi nga masakit. mabigat. kasi hindi tanggap ng kultura at sistemang kinalakihan natin. uncomfortable. but thatâ€™s exactly why they need to be told.what makes the film powerful is how intentional it is. every frame, every silence, every turn it didnâ€™t take. lahat may dahilan. it couldâ€™ve been more clever. it couldâ€™ve been more dramatic. pero hindi siya nagpakitang gilas. instead, ginamit niya â€˜yung simplicity para tumama. para magpa-reflect. para magpa-isip.what i appreciated most was that it didnâ€™t force me to take a side. it didnâ€™t try to tell me which choice was right, no matter what sunshine ended up deciding. it just asked me to listen. to sit with sunshine. to be there with her. even when things were loud & messy, even when she herself didnâ€™t know what to do. and sometimes, thatâ€™s all people need. not answers. just space. and empathy. maraming empathy. Sunshine moved me to empathize in ways i didnâ€™t expect i could.gusto ko rin pala i-highlight kung paano naging karakter ang maynila rito. magulo ang maynila. marumi. maingay. minsan bitag, pero minsan daan palabas. minsan parang impyerno, pero minsan parang tanging lugar na may pag-asa. sunshine moved through its chaos looking for clarity, and somehow the city mirrored her confusion. klaustro ang mga eskinita pero may mga puwang. noisy yet full of silences. manila is hysterically cruel, yes. brutal sa babae, sa mahirap, sa pagod. pero sa likod ng lahat ng â€˜yon, may mga sulok na mabait. tahimik. marunong makinig. may tenderness na hindi nagpapakita, pero nandiyan; in the people who care quietly, in the moments of stillness in between the noise.and god, maris. maris fucking racal. this is hers. this is every womanâ€™s story. she is a woman in every way that matters. alam kong magaling na siya dati pa. nakita ko na rin naman ang ibang trabaho niya. but this time, iba. masarap sa pakiramdam na makita ang isang magaling na babae na hindi nakakabit sa loveteam, walang lalaking bitbit sa screen para lang matawag na lead. walang kilig, walang branding. sakanya lang talaga ito. and that felt right. that felt important.the way she portrayed sunshineâ€™s pain and stillness and quiet strength, it just hit. hindi siya umaarte. she wasnâ€™t trying to convince anyone. she just was. may mga eksena na wala siyang sinasabi, pero ramdam mo lahat. nakakaiyak siya, pero hindi dahil may music o linyang mabigat. nakakaiyak kasi totoo. kasi hindi mo alam kung saan ka huhugot ng ginhawa sa pinagdadaanan niya.totoong haggard nga siya buong palabas hahaha, and it just made so much sense. ganun talaga ang itsura ng babae na napagod na. sa sarili. sa mundo. sa kakaisip ng tama. sa sistema na walang binibigay na sagot. and yet she kept going. and yet she was still trying. that lookâ€”the mess, the confusion, the exhaustion, thatâ€™s what a woman in the middle of a fight looks like. not dramatic. just human.maris, saâ€™yo talaga ito. no one else couldâ€™ve done it this way. no one can take this away from you. and i hope alam mo kung gaano kahalaga ang binigay mo sa pelikulang â€˜to.and the women around sunshine, sila rin ang puso ng kwento. sa mata pa lang ng bawat isa, kita mo agad. hindi sila filler. hindi sila background. si jennica garcia, si annika co, si xyriel manabat, atbp. pati yung mga sandaling lumitaw lang, ang doktor, ang bantay sa motel, yung pharmacist sa botika, yung babae sa quiapo, maski yung mga babae sa maternity ward. lahat sila may dala. lahat sila may pinanggagalingan. and they all stood with sunshine in one way or another. iba-iba sila, pero iisa ng tinig. kababaihan ang nagdala ng pelikula. kababaihan ang gumising sa kwento.Sunshine isnâ€™t easy to watch, especially if you're a woman in this countryâ€” but maybe itâ€™s not meant to be. kasi tunay na kwento siya. and real stories donâ€™t always comfort. they challenge. they disturb. they demand something from you. and thatâ€™s what this film did. it made me feel. it made me think.sobrang ganda napasulat tlg ako ng review. i had to sit with it for an hour or two. ang husay mo direk tonet!

May nag-uusap kanina sa likod ko habang nanonood ako pero hinayaan ko nalang kasi nasanay na ako, tapos sakto yung scene na sumunod is yung sinabihan si Sunshine na â€œdrown out the noiseâ€. Okay lang sana eh kasi may libreng commentary ako, pero nung nalaman na ni Sunshine na buntis na siya, yung lalaki sa likod ko sinabi na â€œtatanga-tangaâ€ siya. Medyo nawalan ako ng focus sa panonood dahil sa narinig ko kaya lumipat nalang ako ng pwesto maya-maya.Sobrang ganda ng paghandle ng movie na â€˜to sa topic niya, lalo na sa bansang â€˜to na sobrang sensitibo ng mga ganitong usapan kahit na hindi na naman sa ibang bansa, kaya malakas yung respeto ko sa lahat ng involved sa paggawa nito, lalo na si direk Jadaone, kasi kailangan natin ng mga pelikula katulad nito para makasimula ng pag-uusap at pagbabago sa bansang â€˜to. Ang daming taong tumutol at humamon sa konsensya ni Sunshine sa ibaâ€™t ibang paraan, pagkontra sa kanya gamit ang relihiyon, ang batas, ang pera, ang kalalakihan, at iba pa. Kada sulok ng Pilipinas may matatamaan, kasama na yung nakaupo sa likod ko, at dapat lang.

Ang pelikulang ito ay tunay na isang sikat ng araw. Nakakasilaw. Tumatagos ang sinag. Totoo siya sa pakiramdam.Dahil totoo nga siya. Totoo si Sunshine.Matatanaw mo lang siya kapag binigyan mo ng oras ang sarili mong huminto at pansinin ang paligid. Saka mo mapagtatanto: kasama natin siya sa bawat hakbang ng kasalukuyan. Kahit sa gabi. Kahit pa sa gitna ng unos.Isa siyang payak na reyalidadâ€”nararamdaman sa dulo ng mga daliri. Parang singaw sa paligid; halos masamyo mo sa hangin. Ganyan siya kasinsid. Ganyan siya humihingi ng pansin. Patuloy siyang lumulusot kahit sa pinakamasisikip at pinakatahimik na puwang ng kaingayan. Siya ang bumabati sa bawat umaga. At kahit sa gabiâ€™t hapon, may iniwang peklatâ€”mga bakas na, sa paglaon, bumubuo ng mas malaking larawan. Larawang pumupukaw sa atin tungkol sa mga madalas itinatanggi, pinatatahimik, isinasantabi. Mga bagay na totoo, at tunay namang nangyayariâ€”ngunit ikinukubli. Tila bawal. Tila tabu. Ngunit sila pala ang tunay na bumubuo sa bilog, ngunit nananatiling hindi kinikilala sa tatsulok ng lipunan.At ang tanging hangarin ni Sunshine: na maging isa ka sa â€œatin.â€Ako? Gets ko si Sunshine. Gets namin siya.Sana, gets din siya ng iba.

As a pro-choice person in the healthcare field, this is a harsh and brave storytelling of the reality in the PH. Maris is a star and the whole cast carried.

â€œMy body, my choice.â€ But is it really when your options of what you can do with it is stuck in a country overtaken by religion and politics stuck in the medieval times? Sunshine falls under one of my most favorite genres: social commentary by simply showing girls just trying to live. You can see throughout the film that sheâ€™s just a girl. Asking Miggy for money, asking for help when she needs, acts on her impulse, has dreams and goals, using twitter and Reddit for research (#real), etc. She knows she canâ€™t take care of a whole ass child right now, all she can (and she should) do is to chase her dreams and make a career out of it.Though you can also see that Sunshine doesnâ€™t really hate the kid. She takes care of her the way she canâ€“ giving her money to get home, looking for her when sheâ€™s lost, protects her from adult themes (drinking, abortion, etc). So her decision at the end, itâ€™s not because she hates the kid, itâ€™s because she loves herself. With the limited choices she had, she made the most out of her youth And whatâ€™s so wrong with that? With being just a girl?

sunshine tackled various polarizing topics that are still on the table for discussion in a predominantly catholic country like the philippines. the story handled it very delicately without imposing on its audiences, without forcing them to change their opinions. it became an eye-opener instead, starting conversations and making everyone reflect on their own as well.the film rendered everyone speechless. we all clapped after sunshine ended. a must-watch film indeed. maris and jennica were phenomenal actresses. this is direk tonet's magnum opus. gets na gets ko ang pelikulang ito.fuck the patriarchy. decriminalize abortion. abortion is healthcare.sm north edsa, cinema 6

set in the small but chaotic world of what lies below carriedo station, just a girl trying to reach her dreams and do whatever it takes, a pregnancy won't stop her, even if it is illegal in the philippines. a lot of people seemed to leave her behind while she was trying to figure out what to do: the guy who knocked her up just gave money and bailed, the motel staff helped her unto the tricycle but didn't accompanyâ€¦

women carries the weight of the world the moment they were born 'no? a woman that chooses herself has a lot of implications that makes them look selfish.this film is consistently tight, not making moments linger a second longer than it should be. it places urgency to sunshine's situation and i just love how sunshine has full autonomy and gets right to it the moment that she knew. admittedly, a certain plot device employed here might've become a burden in the long run, there's a moment where it felt like the film doesn't know what to do with it, but in the end it still landed pretty well. jadaone throws a lot of anger in this film. an exasperation to the tito bubots of this world, to the judgmental people who's supposed to make you feel safe, to the system that prohibits women to have safer options, but never to sunshine. what might this film's great achievement is that you feel it too, the film carefully takes you on a walk to make you understand and feel its anger, to understand sunshine, just how much important her dreams are and how she doesn't aspire to be a mother in this time of her life. women carries the weight of the world the moment they were born, but people like sunshine makes it feel that choosing themselves is an act to be truly selfless and for once be free

Direk Tonet knows exactly when to let silence speak, when to drown out the noise, and when to let emotions simmer. In Sunshine, she invites us into Sunshineâ€™s mental and bodily struggles, but leaves just enough space for the characterâ€™s autonomy and our own. While some films impose what should or shouldnâ€™t be, Sunshine deliberately resists the impulse to moralizeâ€” and does so with intention. Instead, it evokes. It urges us to feel and think through its subtlety. Jadaoneâ€™s placement of Sunshineâ€™s body within the harshness of Manila is a political act. To know Sunshine, then, is to know the spaces that both suffocate and shelter her.The film doesnâ€™t offer easy answers (or any at all), but thatâ€™s precisely what makes it resonate and linger.

â€œgets mo na?â€â€œgets ko na.â€matagal ko nang gets, pero mas gets ko na. it is such a privilege to witness this film on the big screen, i wouldnâ€™t watch it in any other way. sobrang tapang, apaka tapang ng pelikulang 'to. dahil hanggang ngayon, kontrobersyal pa rin ang usaping reproductive system at abortion sa pilipinas.tangina. ang hirap maging babae. i cried, everyone in the cinema cried. this film is an open letter for everyone, to understand women on a much deeper level, their struggles.higit sa lahat, mahigpit na yakap sa lahat ng babae who had to bleed in silence. at isang palakpak para sa mga babae at sa pelikulang pilipino.narinig ko yung katabi kong matanda kanina, noong scene ni menggay. sabi niya, â€œdapat kasi tinuturuan ang mga babae.â€ sana pagkatapos niya panoorin, gets na rin niya, katulad kung paano nagets ng batang sunshine si sunshine.

A damning portrait of a misogynistic society and how the smallest acts of kindness become beacons of hope. Antoinette Jadaone's empathetic direction and writing is precise, harrowing, and sensitive, capturing its protagonist's defiant spirit against all odds.Maris Racal is flawless as the titular character, portraying Sunshine's turmoil - both internal and external - with stirring rawness. Jennica Garcia is likewise deeply moving as Sunshine's ally and compass, a performance rich with history and life. Shout-out to Paolo Orendain's austere cinematography, Eero Yves Francisco's oppressive production design, Benjamin Tolentino's laser-sharp editing, and Vincent Villa's absorbing sound design. This film is fully realized from top to bottom and you feel it in every moment.P.S. This better be the Philippines' official submission for Best International Feature Film at the #Oscars.

GETS KO NA.sunshine is full of light and resilience, stands against the grim, decaying backdrop of manila drowned in chaos and darkness. as her journey unfolds, it becomes clear how personal this film is, especially for filipino women. sunshine set in a country under a deeply patriarchal system, while she embodies the struggle of being a woman. as we all know, abortion remains taboo in the philippines and can be criminalized under the revised penal code of 1930. yup, laws written nearly a century ago still control our bodies as this outdated system should be reformed, as it reflects on deeply rooted cultural norms that often affect the struggles faced by the majority of women. The film confronts the harsh realities of teenage pregnancy, abortion, and even the challenges faced by athletes in the Philippines. With abortion being illegal here in the Philippines, many women resort to dangerous methods that put their lives at risk. The movie also highlights how men often evade accountability for such situations, leaving women to bear the heavy burden alone. It sheds light on the prevalent issue of unwanted pregnancies, a reality that is sadly common here. The film emphasizes the powerful influence of religion in shaping societal norms. Overall, itâ€™s a bold and honest portrayal of women's struggles, particularly in a country deeply shaped by religion and patriarchal values. Kudos to Maris Racal and Antoinette Jadaone! Truly a well-deserved win. ğŸ‘

Hindi lamang ito pag-uusapan dahil sa kontrobersyal nitong paksaâ€”humihikayat din siyang mapag-usapan. Nasa isang lipunan tayo na sobrang layo pa sa usaping abortion, at ang isang pelikulang katulad ng Sunshine (2025) ay paniguradong magbibigay liwanagâ€”hindi lang sa usaping abortionâ€”kundi sa usapin din kung paano gamitin ng lipunan ang relihiyon at pulitika para diktahan kung ano ang dapat at hindi dapat gawin ng kababaihan sa sari-sarili nilang mga katawan. Baka maging susunod na presidente ng pilipinas o baka makahanap ng gamot sa aids, oo. Pero paano naman si Sunshine, na isinasang tabi ang karapatan, na para bang pinuputulan niyo ng pakpak makalipad. Paano naman si Sunshine, na mas mataas ang potensyalâ€”National teams, SEA Games, kahit maging sa Olympics pa.Lumabas ako sa sinehan at naririnig ko ang kanya-kanyang diskurso ng mga nanood. Positibo at negatibo. Kesyo gino-glorify ang abortion, kesyo sumusuporta sa mga desisyon ni Sunshine. Ano man ang reaksyon at opinyon nila patungkol sa pelikulang ito, malaking hakbang pa rin yung mailagay siya sa lamesa para mapag-usapan. Hindi na dapat natin ito pinag-uusapan ng patago, na para bang malaking kasalanan. Buhay at kinabukasan ng babae ang nakasalalay.Kaunting spoiler: sobrang halaga sa akin nung eksena na dumaan muna si Sunshine sa simbahan para humingi ng tawad sa mga desisyong gagawin niya pa lamang. Pinapahalagahan ng pelikula ang usaping abortion pero hindi nito binubura ang aspetong moral ng ganoong gawain. Saka, mahalagang detalye rin sa akin yung naroon lamang siya sa labas ng simbahan at hindi siya pumasokâ€”dahil sa tingin niya ay hindi siya karapat-dapat, dahil iba ang catholic guilt ng bagay na gagawin niya.

I was lucky enough to be an extra for this film prior to knowing what it was about, upon seeing the trailer, I knew this was going to be special.Maris Racal truly gives one of the best performances Iâ€™ve seen in a long time. She is able to express pain (both physical and internal) in ways that make me writhe with her. I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve wanted to hug a woman through my screen like this in a while.And wow!!! Annika is a star in the making. She impressed me so much in this, especially in the scene where they head to the hospital. Itâ€™s definitely a scene that will stick with me for a long time. Jennicaâ€™s performance also stuck with me (as a panganay~)Manila is presented so cruel, yet so kind in those moments where Sunshine finds help. Iâ€™ve seen a couple of other films talking about abortion in the Philippines (Hinugot sa Langit and 12 Weeks specifically), but I think this one struck me the most. I found this to be extremely nuanced, the presence of the kids and their roles in Sunshineâ€™s life really made me think. Iâ€™m still not a hundred percent sure how I feel about their presence, but I appreciate that it made Sunshineâ€™s plight something to really think about.I also appreciated the ending, I think we often see a remorseful side post-abortion for female characters here. But Iâ€™m glad we get to see someone who gets to move on and continue to dream, to live.I also thought about the other women Iâ€™ve heard about going through similar situations. With how much the world seems to be going backwards, I really hope this piece makes people think about womenâ€™s right more here. No one should have to suffer.

Not gonna lie, when I first saw the trailer I wasn't sure how this would tackle the topic of teenage pregnancy and abortion, knowing how hard it is to talk about the latter outside of hushed circles without getting a stern lecturing or some weird looks. For most of the movie I was thinking about how in the world this got past MTRCB, CBCP, and literally every old-headed person out there; I'm so glad it did, btw, because it's an important story to tell, and so bravely told at that. Im not sure of the other devices used in this movie but I'm glad we have media that bravely shows a side society tries to push aside. Ang hirap maging babae!!!! We should have better legislation that supports women and children's health and welfare. Whether you choose to be a mom or not, you should be able to carry that out freely and safely. You should be able to be a girl freely. (Such a sorry state of public health honestly hay!!!!!!) Also reminds me of Happening by Annie Ernaux, one of my first brushes with this topic.

watched this movie at a new cinema. new environment & new everything. no connection to the movie at all but i really felt the need to watch this masterpiece asap! so i got out, alone & motivated to push through everything i had set out for the day.my expectations were not disappointed as the movie delivers such a strong message towards the harsh audience which is the Filipino society. everything about the Philippines' secular practices to its contradictions that are laid by the patriarchal nature of the countryâ€”it was cruelly portrayed in the movie transparently. that's what i loved about everything that had transpired in the hour and hour-half time i sat in my seat. everything was in color tooâ€”something our country is quite known for; though maris racal had played the role of Sunshine, her character had pretty much went through the storms of what seemed to be an unplanned pregnancy that would become her hindrance in achieving her dreams. dreams. something women would always give up once motherhood would grip them by the toes. sad but true, tragic but a reality. yet this film assures women all around that carrying a childâ€”or not, should not be something that would hinder us from reaching for the stars. every scene reminds us, the audience, how motherhood is a gift (unplanned or not), and its something we should carefully discern of before accepting such a blessing. sunshine knows this, she knows it too well to give her baby the life she does not deserve, if they was born with a mother not mature enough to handle the challenges of maternity. moreover, sunshine knew her dreams. her lifetime dream. God knows how much she desired the big stage. as said by Doc Helena, our God is a forgiving god; the statement echoes towards the ending as sunshine weighed out her choices. it was not a matter of letting something go, it was a matter of reaching for something that was always there. ika nga, talent is equally distributed, but opportunity is not; and for sunshine, she grabbed the chance. gripped it hard. never letting it out of her touch. and ceased it like it was her last chanceâ€”it was. i loved this movie too much. social class, reproductive rights, healthcare, religion, mixed with the right amount of comedy all married into one thought-provoking film. mabuhay ang pelikulang pilipino!

fuck the patriarchy fuck the government and (i would) fuck piolo pascualbut jokes aside, the movie really showed the harsh realities women have to face in this god forsaken country,, with our deeply embedded religious roots to how society is geared towards men, leaving women to fend for themselves. naramdaman ko yung lungkot pero mas lalo na ang galit mula sa pelikulang ito. direk tonet and maris completely deserve their flowers.

mamaya ka sakin may gagawin lang ako saglet Most likely born from Carlos Yulo's gold win in the olympics and the emergence of recent abortion films such as Never Rarely Sometimes Always, Jadaone presents how teenage pregnancies ruins lives and dreams and how the lack of freedom for women in a religion oppressed third world country is a problem as alarming as any other. Although clearly being influenced by recent films tackling similar subject matter 'Sunshine' separates itself from the pack simply because it's set in a country where abortion is illegal. With no abortion clinics and only shady abortion pills how is a teenage woman chasing her dreams let alone a 13 yr old girl raped by her own uncle supposed to reclaim the life that was supposed to be ahead of them. Portraying Manila as a neverending,never resting street filled with people desperate to find whatever they are looking for. How it is a city filled with the kindest people stuck in the most cruel of circumstances. Contradictory to its title the film never shows us a sun that is shining but rather a moon desperate to try and shine on its own despite the world telling her she can never do so alone.

As a man, watching Sunshine felt odd. As much as I wanted to believe that I am a feminist, I cannot fully connect with what Sunshine was going through. My girlfriend on the other hand, had very visceral reactions throughout the movie. Sunshine is a film that fully encapsulates the social subjugation of young women and their rage. Although I might have implied that only women are capable of understanding and appreciating it, there is still much to learn when you watch it.

It's decent to say the least, it's a Jadaone movie for Jadaone fans. But that's the thing, it's myopic that it themes and logic of the narrative presented is as only limited as the filmmaker's worldview to say the least, or rather it is limited to how Jadaone sees the subject matter in regards to abortion and having an agency which is told in such a simplistic way, lacking that empathy and how objective it is. However, I commend the script to call out against the prejudiced perception but that's how it is, it did not hold accountable to it, and while Sunshine had conviction to make her decision in the end, and matters in her own hands, it didn't feel unearned to be honest. Like who is Sunshine to the audience, as a main character? Why do the audience should root for her, I think the screenplay failed to make its audience care and thank god Maris Racal made it somehow work because she did put effort to act in those dramatic scenes and it shows she's into that role, kudos for putting an extra work on gymnastic scenes.But in some light hearted scenes, it felt like she didn't convey those emotions that at times it felt monotone. She could've shown a more human and relatable side of Sunshine.It didn't helped that the runtime could've expanded or improve some things that were lacking, but overall the film did ok. Lastly, I have a message to those who are invoking Brocka's name or likening it to the film or the filmmaker: "keep his name out of your mouth."

I love this film. It delivers a powerful message about why the legalization of abortion is important. People get pregnant due to many reasons; not just because they wanted to have sex.If abortion is illegal, then abandoning women after impregnating them or raping them should carry serious legal consequences as well. (oo may serious consequences ang rape pero hindi naman kasi ito binibigyan pansin masyado kaya nga takot mag sumbong ang mga victims meaning HINDI SIYA ENOUGH to scare the rapists)This is a must-watch. An eye-opener for people who prioritize their beliefs over understanding the bigger picture of why women choose illegal abortion despite the risks.Hindi illegal abortion ang sagot. Tamang sex education at ang karapatan ng babae sa sarili nilang katawan ang dapat unahin.

â€œpasalamat ka kay Papa God.â€ pasalamat ka para sa sining ng pagpepelikula.madali lang naman mahalin ang pelikulang ito. tulad ng pagmamahal sa mga bagay na pinaniniwalaan at pinaninindigan mo: madali, simple, at walang pag-aalinlangan.there is no doubt that i would love this film effortlessly because the direk tonet jadaone formula never fails in empowering women in their strongest moments; and even more so in their struggles in the fucked up reality of living in a third world country where they are robbed of their freedom to choose.i loved all the little details in sunshineâ€™s home; the subtle reference to problematic people supporting fascists and corrupt politicians; and the way the city of manila is captured in all of its colors, filth, and beautyâ€”showing us familiar roads and alleyways, reminding us of the vibrancy and dullness of the thousands of lives that passed us by.but what struck me the most is the irony of abortion pills being illegally sold where you can buy a statue of Sto. NiÃ±o, an image of the Child Jesus who was born from an unplanned pregnancy (albeit God-willed and wholeheartedly accepted by Mary if youâ€™re Catholic). because much like this visual, i do believe that devotion to God and the right to choose for yourself are not mutually exclusive. if youâ€™re using your belief to shun others instead of understanding them, then youâ€™re not living up to your faith.iâ€™ve said it before in past movie reviewsâ€”to me, unsafe abortions are the most horrific thing you can show your audience and iâ€™ve seen two other films before, one more vivid than the other. but this one in sunshine is the most painful and depressing. hihilingin mo talaga na sana walang babae sa mundo ang makaranas nito. how can something regarded as the source of life drain the life out of a woman? ang pinakamahirap lunukin na katotohanan ay mayroon at mayroong mga babaeng makakaranas nito kung hindi magkakaroon ng maayos na sex education sa ating mga paaralan at hanggat walang access ang lahat sa reproductive health at safe abortions sa bansa. saludo ako sa tapang mo, direk tonet, to show something no other director of today is not afraid to do so.naniniwala akong ang kababaihan ang pinagmulan ng mundo. quite literally, babae ang nagdala at nagluwal sa ating lahat. kaya maraming salamat sa pelikulang ito dahil nabigyan ng spotlight hindi lang ang mga babaeng tulad ni sunshine at ni mary grace, pero pati na rin ang mga babaeng tulad ng ate ni sunshine, kaibigan niyang si thea, ang kanyang coach eden, si doctor helena, at pati na rin ang babaeng bantay sa avenida inn na walang pag-aatubiling tumulong sa kanya. this is womanhood, ika nga. marahil para saâ€™yo, ang mga babaeng ito ay iyong ina, ate, kapatid, pinsan, kaibigan o kasintahan. pero isa lang ang sigurado, may mga babae sa buhay nating nagsisilbing kakampi natin sa araw-araw at dapat lang silang bigyang-pugay at pasalamatan.(please stop reading at this point if you donâ€™t want spoilers for the ending!)at first, i thought annikaâ€™s character is sunshineâ€™s manifestation of her younger self or her inner child that serves as her conscience in every decision she makes. but when weâ€™re introduced to ariana, itâ€™s finally clear to me that they were sunshineâ€™s manifestation of the unborn babies from her and mary graceâ€™s unwanted pregnancies. this is why that â€œgets ko naâ€ scene is so powerful! because after relentlessly asking for forgiveness from God for reasons she couldnâ€™t fully understand, she finally forgives herself for choosing herself and her dreams. minsan ay may ni-repost si direk sa twitter and it is all about the paths our mothers did not take when they chose to love us instead. when i read that, i just cried. obviously, i am thankful my mama chose me but honestly, i wouldâ€™ve understood if she didnâ€™t.i am glad i chose to watch this spontaneously on a work night (thank you, biancake, sa biglaang aya!) kahit nakipagsapalaran ako mula makati hanggang sta. mesa, tumakbo sa extension sa pagitan ng estasyon ng doroteo jose at recto para mahabol ang simula, at naglakad sa madilim at mataong lugar sa harap ng isetann para sumakay sa jeep pa-espaÃ±a. dama ko ang maynila sa hangin sa daan at nasisilayan ko ang buhay nito sa mga taong nagsisiuwian. hiling ko lang na sa bawat tahanang nalalagpasan ng aking sinasakyan, may mga babaeng naaabot ang pangarap nang hindi nahihirapan.thank you, Papa God. thank you, para sa Sunshine.

I can already imagine the discourse once marelease to sa VOD. First of all, I think it is so bold of Jadaone to come up with a concept that is so simplistic yet so real and full of grit despite the subjectâ€™s thematic weight. Abortion remains to be a debatable matter in the Philippines and opinions are always highly polarized among liberals and conservatives. Despite the countryâ€™s right-wing political ideologies, there are still calls from progressive groups urging the government to legislate better constitutions on health and reproductive rights for the benefit of those who need it most. Sunshine happens to be one of these people.Sunshine is a dedicated gymnast and an aspiring Olympian. With only a few weeks left to polish and brush up on her routine, she suddenly found herself in a bind that put her faith, morals, and self-worth to the test. The film doesnâ€™t let us stay in a hopeful frame of mind; rather, it propels us to empathize with the character and question whatever is wrong and fucked up with the system. When Sunshine found out she was pregnant, her first instinct was to get rid of it. Pray it away. End it even if it means drowning in a cycle of self-destructive behaviors. It was clear from the very start she didnâ€™t want to push through and she held onto that. I guess thatâ€™s as far as I can go for now so as to not give away too much of the plot.I watched this alone sa sinehan kanina and as soon as the credits rolled, i overheard someone sa likod ko saying na â€˜bitinâ€™ daw, and i totally get the sentiment that maybe for some people medyo half-baked or kulang ang storya. But sometimes, films donâ€™t have to be loud in order to hit the right spots. With its very straightforward premise and message, I think Sunshine deserves the amount of hype itâ€™s getting.The sports industry is already overwhelmingly taxing and having to face added burdens brought about by unwanted pregnancy can be way more damaging than one can fathom. Sunshine is not a film that will convince you to change your moral and political convictions; rather, it clings to the little hope of making the audience understand that the dilemma Sunshine had to face isnâ€™t something that exists only in the reel world, but something that is very much present in the real worldâ€”in a society where bodily autonomy often comes at a social cost.Above all else, one thingâ€™s clear is we really need better and safer reproductive laws in the Philippines so women wouldnâ€™t have to go through under-the-table practices that put their lives on the brink of death. However, with the current political climate, i guess itâ€™s realistic to assume weâ€™re still a little far off. But with films like Sunshine, Iâ€™d like to think thereâ€™s still an ounce of hope for our country to perhaps embrace ideals that give primacy to womenâ€™s autonomy and rights, at the very least.

â€œGets ko na.â€I think Sunshine is Direk Tonetâ€™s best work yet. It is simplistic, raw, and bothering but it is wrapped in a cute pink ribbons that seeks to hide the harsh truths women in our society face. The bits of humor at times give audiences a space to laugh and forget how heavy the message of the film is and then it just hits you with its narrative and the core message behind it. My favorite scene was the conversation between Ariana and Bata, it was both pro life and pro choice which may be a hard thing to pull off but the team did it effortlessly. I loved how raw and unfiltered it is and how it became a eureka moment for the other audiences. I am in no way fit to write a long ass review about the them of the film because stories like these are rooted in everyday struggles of women in such violent and patriarchal society. I loved the film but I would love more hearing how women react and talk about this film, sila ang tanging nararapat na magexpound lalo nito at naka supporta lang ako.

Habang nasa kalagitnaan ng pelikula, nasabi ko na lamang sa sarili ko, â€œPara saan ba talaga â€˜tong pelikula na â€˜to? Ano bang point nito?â€ Yun pala, ako lang ang hindi agad naka-gets.Ang fucked up lang kasi isipin kung yung bata ay literal na physical manifestation ng nasa tiyan ni Sunshine, parang anim na taong gulang na anyo ng dapat sanaâ€™y magiging anak. Mas fucked up pa kasi kinokonsensya niya si Sunshine (tinawag siyang murderer). Pero later on na-realize ko: hindi siya totoong bata, kundi visual representation lang ng internal conflict ni Sunshine. Siya yung konsensya. Siya yung maliit na boses sa loob. Siya rin si Sunshine.Kaya hindi talaga tungkol sa journey ni Sunshine sa pag-abot ng mga pangarap niya ang pelikula. Mas tungkol ito sa batang karakterâ€”na hindi rin pala talaga bataâ€”at sa mas malawak na karanasang pangkababaihan. Kasi sa totoo lang, ang kwento ng abortion ay hindi tungkol sa bata. Ito ay tungkol kay Sunshine. Sa mga babae. Sa mga may katawan. Sa mga may kakayahang magdesisyon para sa sarili nila.Maganda naman ang ending. Medyo parang Modess commercial nga lang (charot). Pero kung tatanungin ako, feeling ko may kulang. Bilang manonood, hindi ko gaanong naramdaman ang bigat ng emosyon. Kulang sa lalim. Kulang sa hugot. Pero nabawi naman sa pagganap ng mga aktorâ€”walang tapon, mahusay ang lahat.Isang halimbawa ng kakulangan sa emotional connection para sa akin ay yung eksenang umiiyak si Sunshine sa loob ng inn habang isinasagawa ang abortion. Malapit na akong bumigay nun, ramdam na ramdam ko na, pero biglang nag-cut to a shot from outside the window of her emoting and yung maingay na traffic. Aesthetic, oo. Maganda, pero di ko gusto. Parang sinampal ako pabalik sa reyalidad na, â€œHoy, hindi ka kasama sa kwento.â€ Saksi ka lang. I donâ€™t know about you guys, but I donâ€™t like that.Favorite scene ko siguro ay yung early scene sa pelikula, yung umiiyak si Sunshine sa jeep. Maingay sa simula, tapos unti-unting tumahimik habang nakatutok lang ang lente sa kanya. Ang galing nun. Ang ganda. In addition, siksik sa intensyon ang mga detalyeâ€”katulad ng painting sa unahan ng jeep na may nakasulat na â€œGift from God.â€ Hala siya, eh di ikaw na ang tumanggap. (charot)Anyways, ang dami kong nasabi. Pero ngayon na lang naman â€˜to. Ang galing ni Maris. At isang malaking middle finger sa mga mahilig makialam sa buhay ng ibaâ€”lalo naâ€™t hindi naman hinihingi ang opinyon nila. Wala rin namang ambag. Oo, may ambagan!+0.5 star kasi super ganda ng official poster!!

Beyond how brilliant Sunshine is, this film reminded me once again why cinema matters in shaping and inspiring a better society. It has the power to connect, to spark meaningful conversations, and to heal.The film doesn't ask you to take a side or change your stance, instead it offers perspective. It doesn't scream any agenda on you, instead it quietly holds your hand and asks you to listen. This film made me realize just how unfair this world can be to women. It is hard enough to be a woman, even more so to be a woman in the Philippines. As a man, it opened my eyes around struggles I'm privileged not to face, but must learn to understand.Sunshine champions women with deep care and honesty, and Tonet Jadaone continues to be one of the most important voices in Philippine cinema today. I can't wait to see what she creates next.Maris Racal portrayed Sunshine with such precision and depth. Her fears and pain simmer just beneath the surface, yet she keeps moving-focused, trying to hold herself together-trying to drown out the noise as she fights to choose what's best for her.Top 3 scenes that stirred the audience at our local theater:1. The preachy doctor scene 2. Rhed Bustamanteâ€™s pregnancy reveal 3. The â€œAteâ€ scene between Jennica and Maris
I love it when directors and writers put certain meanings into their works!!!

A perspective from a young woman's struggle towards her dreams in Urban Manila. Handle delicate and sensitive timely issues-abortion and #ProChoice. The juxtaposition of society and women's struggle. How each scenes will straight out of reality. Your social support will vary and how public space are intermingle of ideas. Each realities matter yet beliefs they hurt-from a Conservative Christian Obgyne female doctor who cannot fathom how a young woman would not want to give birth, to a female Quiapo vendor selling abortifacients in front of a Church, to a dear sister who raised her both siblings who will love her no matter what (Jennica's performance here is so superb, I almost cry), to a 13 year old girl who been raped because by a family member, and finally Maris Racal's Sunshine who undergo making a decision, a choice--that is so hard and required ethics, but understandably absorbed into her role, how every woman in the Philippines simply existing is so exhausting. But also how the patriarchy compels women as their biggest supporter draping the country's public health that hurt and judge women for their choice, to the point of penalizing them as criminals.Sunshine is realism, carefully managed and lay out how women needs always to advocate for their own choice and bodily autonomy.
Maris Racal I never doubted you my cancelled sister! YOU ATE THIS AWP!

after months of waiting, i was finally able to watch sunshine! and the waiting game was worth it :)sunshine delivers a strong message while keeping things concise. with its 92-minute runtime, the film strongly conveyed a clangorous noise which could spark discussions regarding women's reproductive health as well as the overall state of healthcare in the country. the jokes are so subtle it made the whole cinema burst out laughing except the two boomers in our row. sobrang nabadtrip sila dun sa joke ni jennica garcia sa ospital hahahaha. the film connected so well with its audience, and with this i meant CONNECT! ramdam na ramdam ko yung pain ni sunshine sa isang eksena na 'yon, grabe. at bawat eksena ay tear-inducing dahil grabe 'yung pamumuo ng luha sa mata ko sa halos kalahati ng dulong part ng film. the hospital scenes were so painful to watch in a way that it reflects reality so much. nakalulungkot isipin na ganito ang estado ng public hospitals sa bansa, hindi matamasa kung ano ba ang dapat mayroon tayo. more than that, this film also shows how women do not have a safer option to terminate pregnancy when they choose to do so. kailangan bang mag agaw-buhay ang isang babae para lang maalis sa kanya ang 'buhay' na hindi naman niya hiniling?sobrang kirot sa puso panoorin tangina. pero napakaganda rin talaga jusko. but yeahhh! beautiful shots by pau orendain andddd jadaone has outdone herself here after fan girl (2020)! halimaw! gusto ko magtrabaho sa project8 projects pagka-graduate ko. ğŸ“SM City Sta. This kind of film is what the whole Philippines has to watch. It is an eye-opener that sparks significant discussion in terms of how Filipinos perceive situations in a traditional and conservative way.I definitely loved how it tackled this controversy while focusing on Sunshineâ€™s dream, which represents many teenage girls that suffered from unwanted pregnancies. In this hour-and-a-half film, it did highlight the majority belief yet also countered it in different narratives. Despite being so interested in pre-watching the film, I still didnâ€™t expect how the film has featured many symbols and situations that Filipinos have to realize. I get so emotional about how the storyline has approached this issue, and I hope to see more of this in our country.Maris Racal is the right actress for the role. The way she played Sunshine was so natural and raw. Her delivery of lines, the body language, the expressionsâ€”everything was on point. She made Sunshine as the character that many can easily relate to. The casting was amazing, as were the cinematography, color grading, music scoring, and the flow.Definitely Direk Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s best.
when imagining her unborn daughter wasn't enough, sunshine began to imagine another teenager's unborn child. justice for mary grace... she didn't get any...

sobrang aktres mo, Maris, at napakahusay mo, direkTonet!hindi lang basta pelikulang pinangunahan ng mga babae ito; ang tapang. ang tapang ng pelikulang humugot sa mga paksa na matagal nang itinuturing na bawal pag-usapan. lahat ng matagal nang tinitiis at pinapasan ng kababaihan, inilatag sa liwanag para mapag-usapan, maintindihan, at matanggap.grabe.mula sa pagtutok ng lente sa malayo, hanggang sa marahang paglapit ng kamera sa mga mata ni Maris Racalâ€” ramdam mo lahat. hindi pilit, hindi sobra pero tama. parang gusto mo siyang yakapin, buhatin ang bigat nya sabihing hindi siya nag-iisa.lahat ng karakter may kinakatawan. may girls' girl, may tradisyonal, lalong mas may hipokrito. lahat sila, totoo. kilala natin sila sa totoong buhay, pero minsan ay (baka) tayo sila.pinakapaborito kong eksena siguro yong parte na nalaman na ng ate ni Sunshine ang kalagayan niya. walang sigawan, walang sumbat, kundi yakap, pag-unawa, at respeto sa desisyong mahirap man ay personal dahil galing na rin siya mismo doon. proof ito na hindi nagkulang si Jennica Garcia sa pagbibigay-lalim sa karakter niyaâ€” tahimik man ang portrayal, pero talagang mabigat ang tama.gets na gets kita, Sunshine :)

Antoinette Jadaone unleashes a kind of ferocity in this film that's very much needed from a mainstream voice in our sociopolitical age. The choices made throughout the narrative leave a powerful message that stay with you long after you walk out of the theater. It demands your attention, and it demands that you listen. Sunshine feels like a film that will define a new age in Philippine cinema, not for its technical marvel, but for ushering in a bravery in writing that may just be what's missing from our industry's identity. I might even reckon it to the likes of the Brockas, Bernals, de Leons, or the Diaz-Abayas of the world.Please, catch it in cinemas if you can.

i am angry at the church for instilling deep-seated catholic guilt that permeates thru all levels of our society, at the government for blatantly anti-women policies that lead to unsafe abortions, at medical professionals that push shame on patients, and unfortunately at my parents for not teaching me about contraceptives when i was younger. the film rly captures the loneliness and desperation of googling options for sexual health, not knowing who to turn to, calculating probabilities for pregnancy, mitigating risk of judgment and humiliation. hay naq even the experience of getting an iud made me feel some type of way about my womb. when will women be able to feel like their bodies belong to them w/o guilt or shame???

I have faith in this film's capacity for becoming a beloved classic in Filipino cinema given enough time. An unmelodramatic (if you found it melodramatic, I personally feel that may say more about you than the film!) and unflinching portrayal of the Hell that the Philippines is for girls and women. Somehow, even in all its white-hot rage, Sunshine approaches its controversial topic most of all with kindness, empathy, and understanding. I am overcome by an urge to watch every other previous Antoinette Jadaone film ASAP.Maris Racal, with this single performance, cements herself as our most talented actor from her generation. She's seriously in her FAMAS, Cannes Best Actress, Volpi Cup bag here!

if only i was able to document how i looked when i realized what kind of roles annika and ariyuhna were trying to portray. i was.. blown away. conflicted. i felt sorry, but i genuinely understand. i also just want to commend ms jennica garciaâ€™s performance!!!!!!! as an Ate myself, i feel like despite the <intense> reactions that people around me think iâ€™ll be like if in any case i end up being in that same position, i think i would react like sunshineâ€™s Ate. itâ€™s already a cruel reality, people like sunshine just needs a pair of understanding ears, a heart, and a warm embrace. i feel like i really broke down when jennica repeatedly said â€˜i love you.â€™ with the most sincere and most genuine tone. i really really loved how sunshineâ€™s performance for the competition ended with a face shot or whatever you call it. i like how it ended without seeing how the competition she worked and sacrificed so much went. for me, her actual performance was the one with annika watching it. that â€œgets ko naâ€ carried so much SO MUCH emotions in it that you really just have to agree na oo, gets mo rin.it has been a magical experience to be able to watch this film on the big screen. i canâ€™t believe i only paid 230 pesos to feel THAT much. thank you, sunshine. i offer you so much love and respect.

so much has been said about the bravery to tackle an important but still quite taboo issue in the country but it just cannot be overstated!!! i left the cinema today with a lot of heavy thoughts and feelings that i cant perfectly explain but i think a lot of that is rooted in sadness and anger.sadness over the realization that as a woman i see myself in more ways than one in sunshine. i may not have gone through a similarly tumultuous experience but there are bits and pieces of her character that i see myself in. at times it felt jarring to recognize those. as a healthcare worker myself, i can say that a lot of the scenes in this movie arent far from reality. theyâ€™re sometimes even worse. and itâ€™s just. idk. this film heightened the anger i haveâ€¦ directed at.. i dont know. the society? the government? myself?my emotions about this are still all over the place really.what i do know is that this film will stick with me for years.

This movie is brave in tackling a very delicate issue, but at times, it tries too hard to deliver its message. It needed more grit and heart, and less aesthetics and preachiness. The bit with the pregnant teenage girl felt like a random device, which is unfortunate given the weight it carried on the film's plot.Still, I like how it tried to take on subjects like incest, poor maternal health, Catholic guilt. It works well when it shows its heart -- the tender moments between sisters, the heartbreaking text message to a friend before a risky decision. Maris Racal is good, and the supporting cast also deserves a lot of praise (the Quiapo vendor was great).

Ang bigat wow.Paborito kong parte dito si annika. Sabi ng iba konsensya nya si annika, o way to cope, o di kaya ung unborn child nya.Buong buo ung loob ni sunshine na ayaw nya pa maging nanay, hindi nya pa kaya, tuwing hihingi ng pera sakanya si annika, â€œUmalis ka nga wala akong peraâ€. Pero nagaalala pa rin sya, pero binigyan nya ng pang tricyle, 100 para special, para ligtas si annika. Pero hindi sumagi sa isip nya buhayin nalang ung bata. ayaw pa ni sunshine, buhay nya yung gymnastics. Ang gandang representation nito sa bawat babaeng pinili ang abortion. Kahit gaano ka-desidido, kahit piliin mo yung sarili mo, hindj mawawala ung guilt, ung takot, ung sakit. Kasi tao lang si sunshine, napapaligiran ng mapanghusga, ng mga taong tinuturing na krimen ang abortion. Ang gandang representation na bukod sa physical pain na pagdadaanan ng babae sakin unsafe abortion choices, meron pa syang internal battle sa guilt at konsensya nya.. Nung nawala si Annika, takot na takot si sunshine, nakakapagtaka kasi e ayaw nya naman talaga si Annika in the first place. Pero parte parin sya ni annika. Something in me healed sa last part nung sinabi nya na â€œGets ko naâ€. Ang perfect ng scene na to. I interpret is as making peace, and forgiving herself, na she chooses this and this is what she knows is best.
The silence in Sunshine is so loud. Deafening even. A masterful play on choices.

This movie does an excellent job of shedding light on the social issues that our country continues to face and urgently needs to address, especially in a society where ignorance still prevails. The story also bravely tackles the sensitive issue of abortionâ€”something our country is still not ready to openly discuss.To Maris Racal, you truly did an outstanding job with this project. i have so many thoughts and feelings for this film. but itâ€™s just a great film, hands down. throughout, we see sunshine behind and through bars and whenever we see her beyond it, her choices feel cathartic (like dasurv masiraan ng kotse! dasurv mabasagan ng beer sa ulo!) i found the hospital scenes to be the hard-hitting ones since there are so much to unpack. like either way, youâ€™re trappedâ€”trapped alongside the many other women who are forced to share hospital beds in public health centers/clinics/hospitals or either, you end up fighting for your life when the abortifacients donâ€™t work. given the structures around us, the choices we are given do not serve us nor empower us, which then make these other options more enticing. despite this dreary reality, i found myself being emotional during the final sequence. sunshine finds herself free in gymnastics and thatâ€™s what she gets to do and she gets to drown out the noise. and thatâ€™s all what weâ€™re advocating for, for women to have the choice. GOD i love this film sm. i do think itâ€™s a good first step in addressing abortion in contemporary PH cinema. we are doing this film a disservice if we expect it to fully encompass the extent of nuances of this experience. what we can hope for, perhaps, is the exploration of more nuanced stories like sunshineâ€™s to be seen and heard.

The movie that will haunt you after watching. Sunshine isnâ€™t loud, but it leaves a lasting echo. Her silence feel heavier than words. As she searches the streets of Manila for a way out, we feel every step, the desperation, the shame, the unbearable weight of decisions no one should face alone.What haunts you isnâ€™t whatâ€™s said, but what isnâ€™t. The film never preaches, but it unsettles. You donâ€™t just watch it, you carry it with you. Sunshine doesnâ€™t end with answers. It ends with a breath held in your chest.

gets ko na. sunshine sheds light on the complexities yet unity within the different relationships that girls have with other women. sobrang daming expectations na hinihingi sa atin at iba rin ang pagod dahil dito. maris perfectly embodies the character of sunshine, who stayed true to her dreams until the end, despite the multiple challenges she faced to get there. this film was very, very raw and the execution perfectly delivered the message it wanted to reach the audience. it will forever be in my heart!!! i love you sunshine <3

the irony of the super christian ob-gyne treating sunshine like a child (say thank you papa jesus) while also expecting her to carry a child full term.there are lots of ironies in this movie, especially in how sunshineâ€”a girl, barely a woman herselfâ€”is treated. â€œwhat if the child youâ€™re carrying is the next president of the philippines?â€ but what about sunshineâ€™s dreams? must those dreams end when motherhood begins? whose dreams and potential are more important? sunshine the movie doesnâ€™t answer these questions outright, leaving you to chew on them instead and come to your own conclusions. at the start, i found the narrative device of the child as a manifestation of sunshineâ€™s guilt a little too on-the-nose, but the pay-off in the ending made it worth it. as the ending says: gets ko nabut the best parts of sunshine are when it dwells on the almost fantastical ridiculousness of manilaâ€”not just the place, but also the people. details like the abortifacient vendor using the money sunshine gave her to â€œblessâ€ her holy figurines or the santo niÃ±os looming over their whole transaction or dangerous illegal abortions followed by scenes of overflowing maternity wards. the movie passes no judgement on these scenes but merely offers them up for observation: here is manila in all itâ€™s messy glory. itâ€™s the perfect backdrop for sunshineâ€™s series of bad choices. (and also reminiscent of lino brockaâ€™s film style which i absolutely ate up)

ABSOLUTE CINEMAwhat i love abt this movie is its soooo honest. it tackles abortion, a topic thats still seen as taboo in a conservative country. this movie DOESNT glorify abortion. what it does is offer a different perspective into the lives of women who go through this experience.i love how determined and full sunshine is. full of dreams, full of courage. she is the kind of woman who chooses her own path and fights for it, kahit gaano kahirap. her story is not just about abortion, its about freedom, choice, and dignity.women should have the right to decide for their own bodies. after all, kami ang makakaranas ng lahat, physically, emotionally, mentally. mo one else should dictate what we can or cannot do with our own life.i love how the film doesnt try to force an opinion on the viewers. instead, it invites you to listen and understand. it shows us why some women make this choice, not because they want to, but because sometimes, they have to. kudos!!!! sobrang ganda

Siguro nasabi na ang halos lahat ng magagandang aspeto ng pelikulang Sunshine, pero may isang bagay talaga ang tumatak sa akin: ang ilaw.Hindi ko alam kung sinadya man ito, pero napansin ko kung paanong ginagamit ang ilaw upang i-spot si Sunshine. Sa bawat eksenang naggi-gymnastics siya, ramdam mo ang goals at motivation ng karakter niya. Tunay nga na siya si Sunshine, siya ang liwanag. Ang bawat eksena sa loob ng training court ay nagmistulang higaan ng dilaw na liwanag, puno ng pangarap, dedikasyon, at pag-asa.Pero sa tuwing lalabas siya ng gym, sa tuwing aalis siya sa mundo ng gymnastics, unti-unting dumidilim ang paligid. Ang bahay nila, na nasa gitna ng nakakasulasok na usok ng Maynila. Ang pampublikong ospital na kalunos-lunos ang itsura. Ang mga kalsada ay madilim, makulimlim, nakakalunod ang ilaw. Habang bumabalot ang dilim, makikita sa mukha ni Sunshine, lalo na sa kanyang mga mata, ang pagnanais niyang kumawala. Parang sinasabi ng mga mata niya, ayaw ko ng ganito. Ayaw niya ng dilim. Ayaw niyang masakal ng mundong nasa labas ng kanyang pangarap.Siguro ang pelikulang ito ay hindi lang tungkol sa abortion. Isa rin itong kwento ng mga batang babaeng may pangarap. Kung paanong nililimitahan ng lipunan ang kakayahan nilang abutin ang mga pangarap nila. Kung paanong pinangungunahan at dinidiktahan ang mga desisyon nila kung ano ang â€œtamaâ€ o â€œmaliâ€ habang sabay na pinipigilan silang lumipad nang malaya.Ang dami ko nang nasabi, pero grabe, wala talaga akong masabi sa galing mo, Maris. Ang husay mo, sobra. At ikaw naman, Direk Tonet, ang tindi mo. Dati, pinapakinggan ko lang yung opinyion mo tungkol sa abortion sa AWKP, tapos ngayon, pelikula na siya. Kwento na siya. At hindi lang basta kwento, kwentong siguradong magpapasimula ng usapan, diskurso, at ingay.

Sa dami ng opinyon ng mga tao lalo na kapag tungkol sa katawan ng babae, iba ang ginawa ng Sunshine. Hindi ito dumaan sa maingay na diskusyon o pakikipagtalo. Tahimik lang siya, dala dala ang katotohanang hindi kayang ipaliwanag ng statistics, relihiyon o moralidad. Hindi siya ginawa para kumbinsihin ka o pasayahin ka. Ginawa siya para ipakita kung ano talaga ang nangyayari, at maramdaman mo kung gaano ito kabigat.Kwento sya ng libo-libong babae na tahimik lang, pero araw-araw may dalang mabigat na desisyon. Yung tipong kahit gusto mong may makausap, mas nauuna pa rin yung kaba kasi madalas, ang sumasalubong hindi pag-unawa kundi panghuhusga.Ang Sunshine ay paalala na hindi lahat ng sakit ay may eksenang iyakan.. minsan, nasa katahimikan ng paglalakad pauwi, sa paghawak sa tiyan, sa pag-iwas ng tingin, sa pagbitbit ng bigat na hindi mo pwedeng ibahagi kahit kanino.Hindi ito pelikulang dapat lang mapanood, pelikula ito na dapat pakinggan. Dahil sa mundo kung saan ang babaeâ€™y madalas pinagdidiskitahan, ang Sunshine ay isang matapang na bulong: â€˜Pakinggan mo naman kami.'

I LOVE THIS SO MUCH ğŸ¥¹ two things: (1) you already know my gripe with movies nowadays being too self-aware, esp when making commentary on social issues (e.g. through infodump dialogues and/or in-your-face monologues). given the themes of this movie, i was initially scared that this'll end up having the same issueâ€” but THANK GOD that wasn't the case here. this one actually took the effort to situate us in Sunshine's shoes. it knew how to convey Sunshine's story by fleshing out the world that she lives in, by showing how she relates to others, by showing us the things she does not do and does not say. this movie knows how to practice restraint! that's how it managed to really make Sunshine shine :D(2) i love that this movie makes a very decisive stance on abortion, without having uhhhh such a cold attitude towards children. like, never once did Sunshine change her mind about having an abortion, and this movie also made several strong cases about how motherhood disadvantages/endangers womenâ€” but it also makes it clear that the problem is not... the babies/children? in fact the children are also victims here, as shown in Ariana's case. instead of being shown as ~the problem~ pa nga, this movie instead shows us that children may symbolize hope and companionship and possibilities. the unwanted pregnancy made life difficult for both Menggay and Arianaâ€” but wasn't it Ariana, still, who stood up for Menggay? what Sunshine went through throughout the entire film was difficult and isolatingâ€” but she wasn't exactly alone, was she? hindi man niya gusto 'yung bata, there was a part of her that sought comfort from the possibility of the child's companionship. i think it's just human nature, yenno, to seek connections from others when going through a difficult time. and when you live in a society where you can't disclose all these troubles to anyone, not even to those closest to youâ€” whose companionship can you seek, if not your own flesh that's taking shape into another life? sino pa ba ang mas makakaintindi sa 'yo kundi ang sarili mong laman at dugo? yeah in practice that may not be true LOL kaya nga ipinaabort pa rin ni Sunshine eh xD kahit anong "romantic" ng notion na susuportahan ka ng anak mo anuman ang pangarap mo, that's practically impossible when its very existence is what could hinder you from reaching them lol. pero ayun nga, it's the difficulty of the situation and our human vulnerabilities that add nuance to these discussions.â€”some pro-choice people (and i know they mean well naman) like to claim that abortion is ok because it's just getting rid of some soulless clumps of tissue anyway. and i guess that's scientifically true... but if fetuses are rly just soulless clumps of tissue then why are we so afraid of pregnancy at all...? why do we want to do abortions as early as possible...? I MEAN LIKE, it's silly to keep dismissing the possibility of actual growing life when discussing these things. and the fact that Sunshine Did Not Do That makes this movie good and relevant and real and special and a must-must-must-must watch. i love this movie <33 i hope more people get to see it

in a world where girls are called disgrasyada for carrying the consequences of what boys get to laugh of, where religion teaches you guilt before it teaches you choice, Sunshine makes you sit in that reality.this film should hurt and make you uncomfortable because itâ€™s real. this is what is happening to us women and children. imagine ah the first thing she did when she found out na buntis siya is bumisita sa simbahan para mag sorry. we are raised in a country to fear God more than to trust our own body. it just feels like we are destined to bleed. this film didnâ€™t try to redeem anyone. it didnâ€™t even ask for forgiveness. it just told the truth and maybe thatâ€™s the bravest thing it could doSunshine you are so loved by me!!!! best film iâ€™ve watched so far that is just so raw & vulnerable. i teared up watching this, especially the part na tinabihan siya ng ate nya :,)
