â€œDrown out the noise. Youâ€™re Sunshine.â€ i know that everyone already said it, but this is one of the best filipino films this year! sobrang tapang and opens a lot of conversations about abortion, healthcare, sex education, lahat na! sobrang galing ni Maris, di ko siya nakita as Maris Racal in this film ramdam ko na siya talaga si Sunshine. it was a performance of a lifetime and her best film to date. this film depicts kung gaano nagpagiiwanan and close-minded yung mga pinoy with topics about abortion lalo na at taliwas ito sa religion natin, it also shows how unfair our healthcare and justice system is. the fact na halos walang kakampi karamihan nang mga nakaka-experience nang unwanted pregnancy, sobrang nakaka-lungkot na kahit mga hospital hindi ka matutulungan dahil hindi legal ang abortion sa bansa. i hope that more filipinos watch this and be open on why abortion has to be legal in the philippines. sobrang ganda talaga, wala na akong masabi!

mula palang sa pagbili ng pregnancy test, hanggang sa paglalahad ni sunshine na ayaw niyang maging ina, kapansin-pansin ang paulit-ulit na pagsumbat sa kanyang pagiging bata. ipinagdidiinan na hindi pa raw niya kayang mag-isip para sa sarili.habang nanonood, hindi ko maiwasang mapaisip: ano kaya ang gagawin ko kung ang nasa posisyon ni sunshine ay isang babaeng malapit sa akin? at ano naman kaya ang magiging trato ng mga taong malapit sa akin kung ako naman ang nasa posisyon ni sunshine? sa ngayon, siguro hindi ko pa alam ang mga sagot diyan. pero nakakatakot isipin na ang problemang 'to ay napakalapit sa akin, at alam kong kahit minsan sa buong buhay ko, makakakilala ako ng isang babaeng nasa katulad na sitwasyon ni sunshine na magigipit sa isang sistemang lugi na lugi sila.malinaw na ipinakita ng pelikula kung gaano kaatrasado ang usaping reproductive rights sa ating bansa. sa halip na matuunan ang mga kasong ganito at mabigyan ng suporta, kinakailangan pa ng mga babae na maghanap ng mga alternatibong mas delikado para sa kanilang sarili at sa kanilang dinadala.ang ganda ng pelikulang ito dahil wala nang ibang makapag-unawa at makapagkuwento nito nang buong-buo kundi isang babae lang din.hayyyy.., maris racal, i am your #1 defender. direk tonete, i am your #1 truther. at salamat Papa God for Piolo Pascual! #needthat

The first movie for 2025 that i'm giving my precious 5 stars. And although I would never change my stance on abortion, I always believe that my personal beliefs should never discredit or deny an excellent film-the credit where credit is due. Antoinette Jadaone's best film to date since Never Not Love You. The performance by Maris Racal is a career-defining one, she is so damn good, she can even give Natalie Portman a run for her money. Her subtleties in her emotions are so raw, her transformation into a gymnast is so believable and displayed such bravura, for a moment there she became the character, she was Sunshineâ€”a flawed character that warrants empathy and compassion instead of judgment. So deserving of my 230 pesos. If I could watch this again on the big screen I would.

Hindi lang basta coming-of-age film ang Sunshine. Isa itong kwentong maraming pinanghahawakang realidad, at inilalagay ka sa posisyon ng isang babaeng lumalaban para sa katawan niya, kinabukasan niya, at boses niya.Ang husay ng pagkakalahad ng Sunshine sa mabibigat na isyu tulad ng abortion, Catholic guilt, patriyarka, kahirapan, kakulangan sa public healthcare, reproductive health, teenage pregnancy, at kababaihan sa sportsâ€”pero ni minsan, hindi siya naging pilit o nangaral. Ramdam mong may tiwala siya sa manonood. Si Sunshine ang pumili para sa sarili niya, pero ikaw, binibigyan ka ng espasyong pag-isipan 'yon sa sarili mong paraan.Malinaw kung ano ang tinutumbok ng pelikula, at 'yon ang isa sa pinakamalakas nitong punto. Alam niya kung anong gusto niyang sabihin, pero hindi ka niya dinidiktahan kung paano mo ito tatanggapin. Binibigyan ka ng sapat na puwang para makaramdam, magtanong, at magnilay. Sa panahon ngayon na maraming pelikula ang kailangang sumigaw para marinig, ang Sunshine ay bumulong langâ€”pero 'yung bulong, dala-dala mo pa rin hanggang paglabas ng sinehan.

Sunshine offers something refreshing and different in Philippine cinemaâ€”and honestly, we need more stories like this. Itâ€™s bold, necessary, and deserves to be talked about. Kailangan natin ng mga kwentong totooâ€”â€˜yung nagpapakita ng realidad ng pamumuhay sa bansa natin.Under the direction of Antoinette Jadaone, Sunshine goes beyond being just a story about sports or dreams. Itâ€™s a story about womanhood in the Philippinesâ€”isang bansang deeply rooted sa religion, conservatism, at kung saan ang mga usaping tulad ng abortion ay nananatiling taboo. But the filmâ€™s message resonates far beyond our borders. It reflects the reality of so many women around the world. The film speaks so much truth about the lived experiences of countless women, and saludo talaga ako sa tapang ng mga gumawa nito. In these times, it takes guts to tell a story like this.Sunshine, as a character, represents those who dare to dream, and more importantly, those who dare to choose for themselves. The film is a powerful reminder that you have the right to carve your own path. Lalo na sa isang bansa na madalas i-demonize ang mga choices ng kababaihan, ng LGBTQ+ community, o kahit sinong pumipili para sa sarili nila.The entire film is gripping, emotional, and tense in the best way. Sa bawat eksena, may bigat, may puso, may katotohanan. I genuinely believe Sunshine will be remembered as a modern classic in Philippine cinema. Isa itong pelikulang hindi lang dapat panoorin, kundi pag-usapan.Maris Racal gave the performance of a lifetime. And bilib ako sa tapang mo, Direk Tonet. Salamat sa kwento. Gets ko na.

An important story, that highlights a very important reality in the country. I donâ€™t think I completely agree with giving physical form to the child, but I understand the choice. I do think the boyfriend was too much of a caricature, and the narrative would have benefitted from a little nuance, to add more texture and reality. loved the underlying web of support from most of the women on screen, probably the best part of the whole film.

Direk tonet and the rest of the Sunshine crew are so brave for tackling such a sensitive yet prevalent issue in this patriarchal and catholic society. I liked how they showed both sides of the debate, sparking conflict in me as well as a viewer. And even though I am a catholic who grew up in an all-girls school, I found myself saying â€œgets ko si Sunshineâ€, kasi â€˜yun yung realidad. Not everyone has access to the same resources, nor the privilege to live comfortably. Dito ko rin natutunan na wala akong karapatang manghusga.Maris Racal, tangina napakahusay mo!!! She portrayed Sunshineâ€™s desperation, anxiety, and grit in such a raw manner that it was so beautiful. Fan na fan mo rin ako Jennica Garcia! I think everyone should see this film at least once in their lifetime. It shows the reality of Manila and forces you to face the truths of young Filipino women. Dahil din dito ay mas nahikayat akong pag-usapan ang aborsyon, at sana ganun din ang mangyari sa lahat ng manonood nito. Kasi dapat talaga siyang pag-usapan! A very beautiful and thought-provoking film! Salamat sa sining, direk tonet at maris racal! This is what filmmaking is all about!

Ilang minuto pa lang sa panonood, malinaw na agad sa akin ang mensahe ng pelikula. Hindi gusto ni Sunshine na ipagpatuloy ang isang bagay na hindi niya piniling simulan, at nauunawaan ko siya.Nauunawaan kita Sunshine. Gayundin ang ibang kababaihang nasa parehong katayuan mo. Hindi madaling maging babae, lalo na sa Pilipinas kung saan walang batas na magbibigay-karapatan sa ating awtonomiya sa katawan at reproduktibong kalusugan. Sa madaling salita, walang batas para sa ligal at ligtas na aborsyon.Katulad ni Sunshine, may tapang, puso, at paninindigan ang pelikula. At hindi ito magiging posible kung hindi dahil sa maingat na direksiyon ni Direk Tonet at mahusay na pagganap ni Maris Racal. Sa loob ng mahigit isang oras, inilagay ko ang posisyon ko kay Sunshine. Bawat emosyon at sakit na naramdaman ni Sunshine ay tila parang naramdaman ko rin. Totoo nga, na mas iba ang karanasan sa panonood sa sinehan. Dahil doon, makikita mong iisa ang reaksiyon ng bawat tao sa bawat eksena. Mayroong kolektibong karanasan. At para sa akin, isa itong tagumpay na layunin ng pelikula. Maaaring hindi kami pare-pareho ng paninindigan, pero iisa ang aming nararamdaman habang sinusundan ang kuwento ni Sunshine.At sana, marami pa ang maabot ng pelikulang ito. Sana, marami pa ang maging bukas ang kanilang kaisipan sa ganitong kahalagang naratibo. Sana, maging tulay ang pelikulang ito upang magkaroon ng diskurso mula sa mga nakaupo. Dahil ang kuwento ni Sunshine ay tunay na nangyayari, si Sunshine ay isang tunay na tao.

PERIOD (pun intended)

no one tells you how alone it feels. to carry something you didnt ask for. to suffer in silence because your pain is inconvenient, because your choices are not yours. sunshine didnt just show that. it made me remember it. it made me feel it again.i watched it twice. and both times, it hurt in the same places. but it also touched something soft in me.a reminder im not the only one whos ever felt this way. her name was sunshine. but nothing about her story was light. and maybe thats the pointâ€”women are expected to shine, even when everything inside is collapsing. she made bad choices. yes. but what choices do we really have, when the world makes decisions for our bodies before we even know how they work? what choice does a girl have when the world punishes her for not being ready, and punishes her again for trying to survive it? when the system has failed us already when they have decided that bearing a baby is a demand and not a choice?and i felt seen. in all the things i was too scared to say out loud. the hiding. the pain you cant tell your mother about. the googling. the not knowing where to get pills, or how to afford them. the fear of your own body, and the shame of not understanding it. putangina. ang hirap maging babae. lalo na sa bansang pilit kang pinatatahimik.and stillâ€”there was warmth. there was sunshine. because somehow, this film made me feel less alone. because stories like this remind us that we are not alone. that our pain is not isolated. that someone out there is watching too, and feeling seen. that is what sunshine gave me. a relieving and painful kind of light. that not everything has to be healed, sometimes it just has to be shared.

Gutsy. Had a few elements that were pretty clunky but the razor-edge, frayed rawness sold the everyday dream of a coming-of-age Filipina coming of age in a country where the very same notion is downright dangerous. Maris Racal might just be the finest young actress amongst her contemporaries.

Kakampi mo ako.I think what felt most important to me about this film is that the sensitivities considered in writing this story ensured that reality was still being shown. It showed respect for the people direk was able to interview, and it showed disdain for the culture we perpetuate in the guise of religion and culture.It calls for the audience to see the effects of the choices they ask of others. It calls for empathy for the victims and what they have to go through and give up â€” their dreams, their childhood, their life. And it calls for disgust for the old ways of thinking, and possibly our skewed views on morality.And in these hard times, how proper support from the people around you can allow you to make decisions for yourself and not because of what others will think. Something that most people do not readily have in our society.Every moment of this film has emphasized a deep-rooted societal problem that was asking to be seen. And kudos to direk Tonet for doing so beautifully.

Cried four times lol.While I donâ€™t think this movie is going to convert any pinoy pro-lifers, I also donâ€™t think thatâ€™s the movieâ€™s purpose anyway. This movie is so pinoy, or at least in the Manila sense. The city noise, the sweltering heat, all radiating in the background of Sunshineâ€™s journey to get an abortion. I wouldnâ€™t say the movieâ€™s perfectâ€”I have some issues with the use of Sunshineâ€™s motivations as a student athlete being a little flatâ€”but the movie resonates in the parts where it matters.

Although Sunshine (2024) advanced the conversation about abortion and body autonomy, one treatment of the film sets the conversation back.Don't get me wrong tho', it effectively presented difficult conversations within an already difficult subject. It doesn't just talk about abortion in the moral sense, but also its nuancesâ€”such as abuse and inaccessibility of healthcare, including both financial and policymaking aspects that rob women of the right to appropriate medical procedures.It also gave face to the concept of guilt through the personification of the unborn, embodied by the characters of the unnamed child and Ariana.But that very personification is where exactly the issue starts.The argument for the pro-choice position is the fact that life does not start at conception, but upon delivery. To personify unborn fetuses strengthens the narrative that abortion is murder. "Murderer," as the unnamed child called Sunshine the moment abortion crossed her mind upon knowing that she's pregnant.But how much does this set the conversation back? Not a lot, really.The film did not fail in doing its job. By tackling abortion itself, it already succeeded in sparking conversations such as this one. And that's already a huge step in advancing women's right to accessible healthcare.Let's just hope that we'll get to see more "woke indie films" like Sunshine (2024). Art, after all, is not solely for its own sake.

Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s Sunshine doesnâ€™t waste time. Within ten minutes, we already know what the titular character wants: she doesnâ€™t want this pregnancy. What follows isnâ€™t a mystery or a coming-of-age arc- itâ€™s a fight.We meet Sunshine as she trains for the Olympic gymnastics qualifiers. Sheâ€™s 19- focused, disciplined, and carrying a dream sheâ€™s had and has trained for since she was 10. Then she discovers sheâ€™s pregnant. From that moment on, the film never strays from what Sunshine wants: will she be able to get an abortion?Sound design is a big part in every movie and in Sunshine, the sound feels like another character. Before her routines, her coach tells her to â€œdrown out the noise.â€ But what if you canâ€™t? Sunshine lives by a noisy street. She trains in a chaotic gym. Thereâ€™s a baby in the house that cries at all hours. Even in a church- where she prays not for guidance, but for forgiveness before attempting to buy an abortion pill- there is no peace. Sound, in this film, becomes symbolic of the constant interference she endures. The noise of judgment, of religion, of expectations- itâ€™s relentless.That judgment bleeds into nearly every interaction she has. The pharmacist gives unsolicited opinions when she buys a pregnancy test. Her best friendâ€™s mother condemned her. In a country where over 90% of the population identifies as Christian and Catholicism dominates public life, the supposed separation of church and state is functionally meaningless. Religion makes the rules. And when Sunshine is rushed to the hospital after complications from taking an abortion pill purchased from a street vendor, the doctor shames her in front of other patients, calling her actions â€œa sin in the eyes of the Lord.â€Sunshine carries everything alone. Her future, once so certain, is now uncertain. If she continues the pregnancy, the nine years she spent training will be for nothing. Her body is already changing. Her coach notices. She canâ€™t train like she used to. Her dream is slipping.And then we meet Mary Grace, a quiet but devastating side character whose story lingers. Their first encounter happens at the same place where Sunshine tries to buy an abortion pill. The second time they meet, Mary Grace tells her she thought her bloated belly was just worms- a line so innocent it crushes you. In that moment, we are reminded: sheâ€™s a child. A victim of incestuous rape and we later learn sheâ€™s just 13, after she was taken to the hospital for complications when she attempted to get rid of her pregnancy.In a country where sex is taboo and sex education is frowned upon by religious leaders, what hope do girls like Mary Grace-or Sunshine-really have?Maris Racal is outstanding. Her physicality, her posture, her tension even in the quite moments makes her character feel very real. She carries the film with a maturity and vulnerability and itâ€™s undeniably Racalâ€™s best work to date.At just 90 minutes, Sunshine is lean and direct. It doesnâ€™t meander. Just a young girl fighting again and again for her dreams.Sunshine is a masterful depiction of what it means to grow up in a country where women and girls lack the right to choose. Where â€œI donâ€™t want to be a motherâ€ isnâ€™t considered a valid reason. The film drives this home in its final minutes: the guy responsible for Sunshineâ€™s pregnancy shows up at her house with his pastor father. They assure her theyâ€™ll support the baby â€œevery step of the wayâ€ until the child turns 18. Sunshine listens, then finally says what sheâ€™s been saying all along: she doesnâ€™t want to be a mother.We already know this. Weâ€™ve known it since the first ten minutes. But her ex and his father don't, or rather, can't understand it. â€œThatâ€™s not the point!â€ she yells, and sheâ€™s right. The moment others found out she was pregnant, it stopped being about her, but about the baby. They had no regard for her dreams, for her aspirations, and how pregnancy will affect her well-being. It was never about if she'll be supported, it was about whether she's still "allowed" to have what she wants. And in a country that denies girls and women a choice, the cost is often their dreams, their futures, and sometimes, their lives.Sunshine is just one story, but itâ€™s shared by thousands. And unless the law changes, there will always be more Sunshines. Jadaoneâ€™s film dares to say that-loudly-even when the world tells her to drown out the noise.

Sunshine does not go the way of those brutish Brillante Mendoza social commentary flicks where the end goal is to suffer, and suffer, and suffer... instead it opts to project its demons as an internal problem. That, which works quite splendidly if not for the fact that this is a film supported by a very tepid and uncharacteristic score from Maris Racal's own ex-partner.That being said, the best things about Sunshine actually emanate from its night sequences. It captures wholly the distress, illegality, and dismay of everything to do with abortion, the black market, and whatever Sunshine's problems are adjacent to in reality. Those night scenes seemed straight out of Abbas Kiarostamiâ€™s Like Someone in Love.It's actually so apparent by the film's end that everything that does come out of this leads to the most reasonable one: a film that doesn't explicitly preach what to do, save for what its problem is tied to in context.But yeah, that score really does this thing a disservice. Tom Cruise was right.Anyway, WHAT IS MY HIGH SCHOOL PRINCIPAL DOING IN THIS MOVIE? (siya yung binasagan ng bote nga pala)

Kung hindi ngayon, kailan? Kung hindi ako ang magiging boses ng aking mga batang babae, sino? Mahalagang pakinggan, bigyang halaga, pagtuunan ng pansin, at kilalanin ang boses natin, ng mga kababaihan.Ang usapin na ito ay hindi â€œbastosâ€ at â€œnakakahiyaâ€. Ito ay usapin ng karapatan at pagtatanggol sa karapatan ng mga babae. Ang pagiging kaisa sa abortion ay hindi ibigsabihing hinahatak natin ang mga kabataan sa mga gawaing imoral. It is about having choices especially sa mga kababaihanh biktima ng karahasan, kahirapan, at pagsasamtala sa kamusmusan. Not having a choice is actually a choice but sadly, that choice is not what us women need. We want to be heard. We want to have a choice that is pro women. Bilang guro, tungkulin ko ang ituro ang karapatang pantao at kasama sa tubgkulin na yon ang pagbabahagi ng karapatan na dapat ay malayang ibinibigay sakanila.Hindi ako makapikit sa mga isyung direktang nakaaapekto sa kanila. Kung hindi ako magsasalita para sa kanila ngayon, baka wala nang makinig bukas. At kung hindi ko sila tutulungan na magkaroon ng boses, paano nila maririnig ang isaâ€™t isa?Sana ay magkaroon tayo ng kamulatan tungkol rito, hindi batay sa takot o pananakot, kundi batay sa science, kontexto, at malasakit.

"gets ko na." 3 words that shattered me to pieces. while watching her dancing, you just get it and kuhang kuha ng movie yon. for 19 years, she grew up with ribbon dancing and thats her whole life <//3 i teared up ngl! ofc you wouldnt trade it for the world! shes just a girl with dreams as well! the pacing. the cinematography. the plot. the analogy. the parallelism. the characters. it was ALL amazing! the movie was able to capture that women have it rough. this country places high expectations on women as they also bear the burden of others choices. women have the right to say and do with their body. their body, their choice! honestly, my heart aches for stories like sunshine because this isnt just fiction...this ACTUALLY happens in real life! this movie is a wake call to prioritize womens rights and needs. no woman or child deserves to go through this. i know abortion is illegal here but the system failed them :(( all the stigma and shame that surrounds these topics shouldnt be kept away because others should be aware and educated as well.hindi siya madali dali lang or "you know what to do, take care of it." there is a whole process and its so mind boggling and scary to even think about it. there were so many scenes that made me tear up - maybe out of stress, sadness, or happiness? but yes, any of those emotions allowed me to see sunshines perspective and how the movie played it out. i was so genuinely happy for her at the end :( may every girl deserve to reach their dreams! there is a whole life ahead of you :( everyone applauded at the enddd and wow piolo pascual dlsu mention hehehehehehheheheh

direk tonet, i am (and will forever be) in awe of you.i have always been hooked on to this film even before its philippine premiere, due to its striking plot and of course the leading star attached to it, maris racal. watching this film on the big screen, i felt so uneasy knowing that this is pretty much a reality for filipino women and women overall.sunshine is more than just a story of a girl tortured by the thoughts of bearing a child at such a young age; it is a grounded story surrounded by problems caused by societal pressure towards women and questionable christian morals and beliefs, which also opens up the current state of the country in terms of healthcare and its views on abortion. art has always been meant to provoke, and direk tonet did it so gracefullyâ€”like how sunshine performed her routines, but still so raw with scenes depicting medically unsafe abortions during the second half.the cinematography was very pleasing for the eyes. most of the shots used were very effective in laying out the emotional impact of this film, most especially its exterior and tight shots with sunshine being the subject. another directorial choice that caught my attention was its symbolism. notably, the use of bata and ariana as figments of sunshine's imaginations. despite those major choices, i personally liked the subtle and unnoticeable details more because i truly believe that it was those that helped keep the film coherent with its vision. details like added sound bites from the television and radio or the production design of sunshine's house.overall, i love it. yun lang HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA

watching this movie took me back and reminded me that pagbabae ka, magisa ka lang. they were able to encapsulate that with sunshine navigating everything on her own. having to hide because there is no other choice. the moment she tells anyone, she wont get help, it means surrendering her dreams even if she doesnt want to. to have a movie discuss the sensitive topics of this country such as abortion, child pregnancy, premarital pregnancy, and the negative side of religion is so brave. to be able to show it in a story so compelling and very filipino is so important imo. sobrang ganda ng cinematography, using manilaâ€™s lights and noise while also highlighting the darkness within its shadows. everyoneâ€™s performance in this film adds so much to the already great backdrop and dialogues. there was so many scenes that went so hard, too. when sunshine was on the jeep, when she was alone in that motel, when she performed, even when she was just walking. every scene felt so important because maris embodied and delivered sunshine so well. ramdam ko yung galit, yung desperasyon, yung sikip sa dibdib ng walang magawa. especially when she woke up in the hospital, the doctora started making her ask god for forgiveness. my blood boiled and i may have cried angry tears ngl. we are so used to religious guilt tripping in this country, its not even helping anyone. anyway, Sunshine deserves her flowers. Gets na gets ko siya. sheâ€™s the reflection of the filipina of our time. Full of hopes and dreams, yet pulled down by the country that does not care about the health and safety of its people.

â€œkahit anong mangyari, kakampi kita.â€first of all, this movie is so refreshing. it shows the struggles of our main character, sunshine, and goes into depth how unwanted pregnancy can lead to mental and physical problems, the desperation of having limited options and resources, the shame encoded into our heads at birth by religious and societal expectations, and most importantly, it shows the resilience women are forced to do just to simply survive.second of allâ€”i love, love, LOVE how this story is not your typical filipino pro-life propaganda warning. itâ€™s honestly so upsetting how conservative and unprogressive our county is with abortion, but hopefully with this movie, older generations can sympathize with not just sunshine, but also mary graceâ€™s situation.iâ€™m actually so glad sunshine doesnâ€™t force its main character to attach herself to the stigma of â€œabortion is murderâ€ mindset; but rather, being able to be firm and push through with her decisionâ€”knowing that sheâ€™s not ready to be a motherâ€”and doing whatâ€™s right for her (and the baby), without the influence of her boyfriendâ€™s opinion, as well as the boyfriendâ€™s father who offered to take care of financial expenses, which is quite rare.another beautiful moment in this movie that i personally love is the sisterhood between sunshine and geleen. geleenâ€™s understanding nature is powerful in itselfâ€”that having one person who will love you and guide you despite everything youâ€™re facing can make your way in life a little easier. knowing that you have someone to lean on in times like this is so fortunate, cause not many filipinas can have that kind of support system.and dr. helenaâ€™s help? as someone pursuing medicine, i understand the male doctorâ€™s perspective on how he doesnâ€™t want to loose his license, but with just dr. helena stepping in discreetly, she is incredibly brave. sheâ€™s risking her entire life on the line for someone she doesnâ€™t even know, and for me, thatâ€™s such a great example of camaraderie between women.although the first doctor that â€œhelpedâ€ sunshine was unnecessarily rude. iâ€™m glad geleen stepped in and defended her sister. as a doctor, donâ€™t you have to leave religious talk outside work? what an asshole.overall, iâ€™m so glad that philippine cinema is slowly stepping out of its comfort zone to talk about sensitive topics like these despite half (or even the majority) of the country being against abortion. i hope this movie spreads like wildfireâ€”a wake-up call to break free from patriarchal laws, and the belief that womenâ€™s bodies and choices are truly their own.

This. This is the movie I will recommend to international friends if they want to know the Philippines.The characters, the culture, the psyche, how far and behind we are in women's rights and sex education is rolled into this beautiful, heart wrenching movie. We may venerate a baby (Sto. Nino) and the virgin (Mary), but the way women and children are treated is ironically (if not disgustingly) far apart from our devotion to the Catholic faith. And we are reminded of it from the set and location. Even the jeepney's signage. The writing is clever in its use of language. Its use of [insert -ism] was gently introduced and when you realized what it is, it hits hard. I can't describe it any other way how confidently gentle this was tackled.It reminded me of 70's-80's era of Filipino films. This is the highest praise in the canon of Philippine cinema. I can't praise this enough. Watch it, if you have the time and money, in theaters. It is very much worth it.

There are films that entertain, and then there are films that hold up a mirrorâ€”brutal, honest, and impossible to look away from.Sunshine did that to me. It stripped me raw and left me in quiet reflection long after the screen went black. I saw in Sunshineâ€™s story not just a character, but the collective ache of countless women whoâ€™ve had to choose between self-preservation and duty.The central challenge of Sunshineâ€”a young gymnast discovering her pregnancy at the cusp of her Olympic dreamâ€”hit me in a visceral way. Not because Iâ€™ve ever been pregnant, or aspired to the Olympics, but because I know what itâ€™s like to carry something heavy in silence, to want something for yourself while the world insists you exist for others.Sunshineâ€™s fear, defiance, and quiet longing mirrored the emotional territory I navigate daily: trying to live on my terms in a world that insists I donâ€™t get to choose.My full review here: inthewakeofthings.wordpress.com/2025/07/30/sunshine-2024-on-choice-compassion-and-the-weight-of-expectations/

What I like about Sunshine is this film fully embraced Antoinette Jadaone's artistry as a filmmaker, similar to her magnum opus "Fan Girl".The luscious colors and shades at the backdrop of a failing city. The grounded surrealism. And Jadaone's honesty in what she wanted to convey in the film. Much like her previous romance films Alone/Together and Never Not Love You, this film grappled with social and economic uncertainty but this time it highlighted Maris Racal's character's struggle to love her passion in gymnastics. It's no surprise Racal acted the hell out of her role, but my flowers are for Jennica Garcia who encapsulated the ghost of Sunshine's what-could-have-been. Sunshine further proves Jadaone is in her prime, and there's so much more she can make in the next years.

marami akong nakikitang western reviews calling this so-so. if titingnan mo nga from their pov, oo nga? ano bang bago dito, it's literally about a high school student getting an abortion to focus on her olympian gymnast dreams. but this is where context matters. films like sunshine are so important as a conversation-starter in countries like the philippines where abortion and reproductive health is deemed not as important by a male-dominated government and a religious culture. ang dami pa ring pro-life kaya sobrang hirap para sa mga kababaihan tulad ni sunshine at mary grace magkaroon ng access sa safe ways for abortion. sobrang nakakadala makita sila na irisk ang buhay nila para magpatuloy pa mabuhay. mahirap magbuntis pero di hamak na mas mahirap magpa-abort.at lalo itong pinapahirap ng isang patriyarkal na lipunan, katulad ng doktor na unang nilapitan ni sunshine para tulungan si mary grace. tumatak siya sakin kasi siya ang salamin ng mga kalalakihan sa ating legislation chambers na walang pakialam sa karapatan ng mga kababaihan at galit na galit sa mga plataporma na nagsusulong ng kanilang welfare. isa pa yang si miggy at ang tatay niya. mga barumbado. kaya oo, importante ang paggawa at pagpapalabas ng mga pelikula tulad ng sunshine. nagulat nga ako pinondohan to ng fdcp? at pinayagan ilabas sa maraming sinehan. sana marami pang mamulat sa importansya ng pagbibigay ng choice sa mga kababaihan. choice mabuhay, at hindi lang bilang tagadala ng buhay.

Late diary entry. It really is true that employment screws the cinephile in us. This is Jadaone's Never Rarely Sometimes Always (2020) mixed with the magical realism of Jojo Rabbit (2020), and Brocka's depiction of Maynila as a harsh, predatory city that traps and exploits the marginalized. There's a night scene that was basically taken from a Brocka handbook, framing, camera movements, dialogue. I love Jadaone's growth as a filmmaker and this project shows how she matured in multiple filmic aspects, but more so on the commendable screenplay. The conversations felt realisticâ€“ something a Gen-Z would say in the present context. There's a clever and subtle critiquing done by adding the English-speaking scenes as well. As if they poke fun at the other contradictions in our postcolonial, patriarchal society now.Multiple ironies and contradictions lie in this filmâ€”the titular character's name doesn't coincide with her lived experiences, the vendor selling the religious images of Nazareno and Sto NiÃ±o also sells the abortion pills, how the people who claim to care for us are so quick to judge if situations do not align with their perspective or morality. Sunshine to me was a thought-provoking way of presenting a very evident issue in our Philippine society, and Jadaone made it brutally honest without lacking the compassion and clarity to bring about this story.I love how hopeful the ending was tbh. I know that this country has been so steeped in religious conservatism that even acknowledging how hopeful that ending was would raise flakâ€”but this movie has done a great deal to create awareness and productive discussions on unwanted pregnancies. Sunshine was a confrontation of our modern maladies, something that very clearly threatens the health and future of women. That's another contradiction in itself, having a government by the people, for the people and yet it chooses to ignore the evident crises of its people. I digress. Gets kita, Shine. [Watched at SM Seaside with my baby]

throughout the film, the people surrounding sunshine kept telling her what to do with her pregnancy.abort it. keep it. do this and do that. we can have all these conversations about pro-life and pro-choice, of whether we agree with her actions or not and thatâ€™s fine and all. but that is not the point this film makes.regardless of what your thoughts on abortion are, this film forces you to meet sunshine where sheâ€™s at. to feel her pain, her struggle, her desperation, her hopes and dreams. this film tells you to look at her, understand her first. no one in this film except her sister and that kind doctor was able to do that. the people surrounding her were coursing plans of action for the future without actually asking her how sheâ€™s doing. it was painful to watch her go through challenge after challenge and yet no one really saw her. Kaya gets kita sunshine. I see you. I feel you. I hear you. Your actions may not be understood by many, but your story is one of bravery, of kindness, of survival. Gets na gets kita.

My favorite part of the film is how Sunshine simply does not have any maternal figure in her life.Her mother is literally nowhere! Numerous characters try to act in this woman's place, but all fail in being the figure Sunshine needs.I believe this is why the coach remains a flat character for the entire duration of the plot. Even if she refers to Sunshine as "anak," we never get to see her be a mother to her. The coach is at the center of the conflict, the one person who must never know that she's pregnant. Thus, Sunshine refuses to open up to her coach, refusing to be cared for knowing the consequences. When her coach hears rumors of her pregnancy, there is no comfort in her words when she confronts Sunshine. Instead, all the secretly pregnant teenager receives is a reminder of what is at stake, that she won't get to be on the team. This pushes Sunshine to go back for a stronger round 2 of the pamparegla.Not even Thea's mom can give comfort to the friend of her daughter. She literally does the opposite, ordering Thea to stay away from Sunshine. Even when Sunshine asks the motelkeeper for help, and they reluctantly do so. The elder women place her on a tricycle and leave her to bleed out as the tricycle rushes to the hospital.Then there's the doctor. Sunshine's sister perfectly criticizes her demeanor towards Sunshine. Her sister asks the doctor if she's a relative of theirs or possibly their mother because she's acting like one. Though this might seem like a counter, when you take into account how the doctor cares more about Sunshine apologizing to the Lord and thanking Him rather than Sunshine's well-being, the case falters. Also, her character felt more like a voice of how religion greatly affects the medical field and in turn, women's bodies.The same goes even for the case of Mary Grace, who has been impregnated by her own uncle. While her mother is alive, their relationship is complicated to say the least. Her mother enables the abusive relationship between the uncle and child for money, so that someone else can "take care" of Mary Grace, essentially removing herself from the role of being a mom.I think all this is why her sister is highlighted as a light in her life. She is the closest thing to being a mother in Sunshine's life, caring about her health, whether she goes to school or not, and so on. However, they are sisters at heart. They can only hold each other's hands through life. Her sister does not order her what to do with the baby, instead defends her from the doctor, pays for the bill, and gets her home. They are sisters through and through.

Philippines is wayy behind with this kind of conversation, being brushed off easily, especially when it matters the most.Grief here isnâ€™t a dramatic monologue; itâ€™s a quiet dinner, an unanswered message of being alone and suffering. Siguro ngaâ€™t kailangan lang din naman talaga nating ilagay ang ating sarili sa kanilang mga paa sa para maintindihan ang daing ng bawat isa. Si Sunshine ay isang perspektibong pilit paring tinatalikuran ng nakararami. Hindi sa lahat ng bagay kaya ng mga babaeng lunorin ang mga ingay. Maski ang bataâ€™y kayang intindihin na tao lang din si Sunshine, at kahit babae siya; dapat at karapat-dapat siyang magkaroon ng karapatang mamili.
Mahal na mahal kita, Sunshine. Literal na absolute cinema.

Manila is rich with history, and within its walls are cracks that harbors scandalous yet important narrative we are too ashamed to tell. And unfortunately, Sunshine, in essence, represents the face of this cruel fate â€” the very victim of society's refusal to address issues that are relevant yet alarming.And through the film's course, we see Quiapo as this undeniable haven of hypocrisy, a place of contradicting morals, the very product of poverty and its people trying to survive and make ends meet.Jadaone somehow manages to tap into the very surface of these stories rather creatively, without missing a beat and has a stark vision of what the film should be about. At times I feel like the film is a literal outcry for help. Every character here is a representation of that and is the result of what's wrong with the system in general. This paired with Racal's impressive performance strengthens the film's core message. Simply put, Jadaone's work is not a prententious flick that uses sensitive subject matter for mere views but rather an impactful affair that successfully champions itself as a vessel for awareness. Overall, the film is resonating with me, a powerful testament that the film transcends genders and in itself is a beautiful feat because it lets you see and viscerally feel Sunshine, and witness her journey to self-forgiveness and inner peace.

Pangarap.Ang palabas na may nilalamang iba't ibang karanasan patungkol sa usapin na pinalitaw sa kwentoâ€” aborsyon. Marahil hindi ito laging napag-uusapan, dahil bakit? Kasi nakakulong sa isipang mali ang magpalaglag, mali dahil pumapatay ng inosenteng sanggol sa sinapupunan. Hindi naiisip ang sitwasyon ng ina, at ng magiging anak kung sakali mang ipanganak. Sinasawalang kakayahan na magdesisyon ang bawat babae para sakanilang katawan, kung ano ang gusto nila, kung ano ang satinging tama. Ipinakita rito na hindi madali ang desisyon. Ipinakita rin dito ang mga matitibay na rason para hindi ituloy ang panganganakâ€” pangarap.Sana lahat ay ma-gets ang desisyon ni Sunshine, katulad ng pag-intindi ng bata sakanya... "Gets ko na."

The entire time I was watching, I felt like I couldn't breathe. It's claustrophobic and suffocating, just like how Sunshine herself feels. You feel her world slowly closing in on her, invisible walls tightening around her in every frame. The camera doesn't let you breathe, and neither does the sound. Manila's noise is constant, overwhelming, and disorienting, especially for a gymnast who needs focus and silence to thrive. Sunshine is literally and figuratively trapped in tight spaces, cramped jeepneys, crowded streets, the overbearing sound of trains passing by, judgmental stares, and high expectations. Visually and sonically, it captures how isolating and terrifying it is to carry a burden like hers in a society that is less than kind toward women. (Btw, just to put it out there, the cinematography and colors in this film are GORGEOUS.) In almost every film that tackles women's issues in the Philippines, you'll find this line repeated in many reviews here in Letterboxd: "Ang hirap maging babae. At lalong mahirap maging babae sa Pilipinas." It's because it's true. Every day, women here continue to fight for autonomy, for safety, for the right to choose themselves. We live in a deeply patriarchal and religious society that expects women to always put others firstâ€”especially family, be it their parents, siblings, or childrenâ€”and shames them whenever something bad happens to them as if they brought it upon themselves. Society never asks the men who take advantage of women simply existing to change, rather it expects women to quietly endure. Bakit kailangang babae ang palaging mag-adjust? I appreciated how the film showed moments of solidarity between women, but it's sad how that's not always the case in real life.Exceptional performances from the entire cast, especially Maris Racal, who is tremendous in the titular role. From the start, she's completely convincing as an elite athlete and future Olympian: disciplined, focused, and has no room for error, as both her dreams and the dreams of others rest heavily on her shoulders. But it's in moments where Sunshine wrestles with fear, guilt, and inner conflict that Maris truly shines. She captures and presents the character's vulnerability so well. Also, as someone who always adored Jennica Garcia since her GMA days, I absolutely loved watching her quiet and subtle acting as Sunshine's sister.I said in my first review of Fan Girl that I hoped Direk Tonet would make an even braver film, and she did. Sunshine focuses and dives deep into the themes it introduces and stands firm in its critiqueâ€”something that I felt was somehow lacking in Fan Girl. While some moments didn't always work for me and the magical realism elements sometimes took me out, I understand the choice. Part of me wishes it stayed more grounded and direct, but the â€œGets ko naâ€ scene near the end hit so hard that I stopped minding altogether. It's a great, important film and I hope it helps open up more discourse on women's reproductive rights in the country.Go see it in cinemas when you can. ğŸ“½ï¸ SM City North EDSA Cinema 6

After making waves at the Toronto Film Festival last year and winning a Crystal Bear at the Berlin Film Festival early this year, #SunshineMovie finally comes home to the Philippines. Starring Maris Racal in a powerful lead performance, the film follows Sunshine Francisco, a decorated gymnast whose Olympic dreams are threatened when she unexpectedly becomes pregnant. She must choose between her ambitions and the responsibilities suddenly placed on her â€” all while navigating a society that dictates what women should and shouldnâ€™t do with their bodies.Directed by Antoinette Jadaone, the film doesnâ€™t shy away from the hard questions â€” ones that should be answered by the Church, the government, the educational system, and most crucially, parents. Why is premarital sex and reproductive health still taboo in 2025? Why does society police womenâ€™s choices about their bodies? Why canâ€™t we provide options for victims of abuse? These questions linger long after the credits roll.Maris Racal gives a career-defining performance â€” fragile yet defiant â€” as a young woman trying to stay strong while breaking under immense pressure. Aside from her acting, her gymnastics scenes are highly commendable, a testament to her dedication to the role. Jennica Garcia gives a quietly affecting turn as her older sister, shining in key emotional scenes. Child actor Annika Co, making her debut, is a revelation â€” a true scene-stealer with star potential. Former child star Rhed Bustamante will touch your heart & churn your stomach. Piolo Pascual also appears in a poignant special role. Manila, chaotic and contradictory, plays more than just a backdrop â€” it becomes an extension of Sunshineâ€™s journey. From historic churches to narrow alleyways, she searches for clarity, strength, and hope, beautifully captured & lighted by ace cinematographer Pao Orendain.Sunshine is bold, relevant, and deeply moving. Itâ€™s a call to conversation, to empathy, and to change. Super highly recommended!!! Now showing exclusively at SM Cinemas nationwide â€” donâ€™t miss it.

This movie is so satisfying to watch because it empathizes with its main character, sunshine, a young gymnast training for the olympics who happened to have an unwanted pregnancy. Young women like her are figures often shunned in popular philippine media and well, society so itâ€™s refreshing to see someone like her in a sympathetic light. Abortion is such a taboo topic in this country so i very much appreciate the relentless uncovering of the different failures of the government and society with regards to womenâ€™s reproductive health and rights. Props to Maris for fearlessly embodying the role. Abortion is healthcare. It should be a choice accessible to anyone that wants it. It doesnâ€™t have to be earned which is why I do find the imaginary kid representing sunshineâ€™s conscience or the possible â€œkidâ€ she might bear in the future unnecessary and redundant in the face of all the other oppressive opinions surrounding her. If the goal was to voice her inner worries, it wasnâ€™t needed, it was already felt and wouldâ€™ve been better shown some other way. If the goal was to voice the external conservative audienceâ€™s thoughts, then it wasnâ€™t needed as well because theyâ€™re already thinking it, the film shouldâ€™ve been secure with putting its faith on Sunshine alone. Sheâ€™s a woman and she has dreams and having a baby is not part of that. She has value still for just the fact of being a person. I guess it just rubbed me the wrong way. Itâ€™s a very beautiful film nonetheless, shining best in its moments of truth and courage.

this is such an important piece of artâ€”for women, from women, as womenâ€”especially in the context of the reality of being a filipina living in the philippines. the whole runtime genuinely felt like i was watching a piece of philippine cinema history unfold. iâ€™ve never been so emotionally compelled, invested, and moved over a piece of (ph) film (for quite some time now). this is what real cinema should be. the weight and power it bears in emphasizing the ills of society, directing empathy, progressing toward solutions.from the opening sequence of the routine, the editing and cinematography of this movie shines. quickly pacing up to the storyâ€™s compelling conflict, marisâ€™ gripping performance hooks you into a spiraling anxiety. that immediate catholic guilt was just perfect in its timing and execution, you canâ€™t help but greatly appreciate how well thought-out this specifically was. as she walks through the streets of metro manila aimlessly and frantically all throughout in different parts of the story, it mirrors a striking resemblance of a guarded uneasiness that we women all fear that something bad might happen to us in the streets; itâ€™s a fight for our lives everyday. itâ€™s also so bold of a creative decision to figuratively humanize the unborn that at first, suspiciously could have gone wrong in one mishandling of the story but eventually paid Ang iniluha ko naman talaga kasi sobrang bigat sa puso knowing how raw and authentic this has been, especially with the fact that a lot of women, even girls, actually experience this, na this just goes way beyond the screen but is a sad reality of some.Being a woman will always be both a blessing and a curse, most likely when it comes to fertility, because often it will always be tied down to a woman's worth. Being a mom takes a lot of courage, for it requires a lot of sacrifices, dedicating your whole life to a child you've conceived for 9 months. It makes you appreciate motherhood and admire the women who dream to be a mother who is capable of giving unconditional love and a good life in a sense na they are willing to do everything for their child... But the truth is not everyone wants to be a mother, and society must learn to respect this kasi it is genuinely for the betterment of everyone, most likely for the child itself. Kasi being a mom is such a huge responsibility that most aren't even ready for, and a lot of other factors, such as teenage and unwanted pregnancy and being a victim of sexual abuse, contribute to the decision of termination of the child. People often tend to overlook it and deem it as something so negative, but what they fail to see is how this decision will always come from the place of love and care for themselves as well as the baby kasi genuinely I think it is more cruel to continue things you don't even want in the first place 'cause both the child and the parent would only suffer physically, emotionally, and psychologically. Also, I hate how women are expected to sacrifice their own dreams, aspirations, and life itself like it's so unfair how men could easily get away with anything, while the the women will be the ones to suffer, be condemned, and be villainized for things that they both did naman. Kaya sex education shouldn't really be a taboo topic, especially safe sex kasi it would really be a huge help in preventing unwanted pregnancies. Aside from it, grabe ang ganda ng cinematography ng film and sobrang galing ng mga gumanap kasi isinabuhay talaga nila 'yung characters nila to the point na 'you wouldn't even think na this is acting kasi it feels so real. Ewan ko but I really loved the fact na they kept the background noises kasi it makes you feel like you are really there with them at that moment, tapos 'yung overall vibes na sobrang Filipino coded.

As a Jadaone fan who has watched every one of her films since Tadhana, I can definitely say that this is her best work to date. And of course, this is Maris Racalâ€™s magnum opus in terms of acting. Itâ€™s her time to shine.

Antoinette Jadaone <3 the director that you are. Sunshine and her other film Fan Girl proves that she has an eye for slightly underrated yet incredibly powerful actors and it proves that she is able shed light onto themes that are dark, taboo and real. I love seeing Maris Racal in roles like this and this was perfect! Sheâ€™s talented, funny and v pretty ğŸ¥¹The fantastical way the characters were introduced made me cringe a little bit, but it reminded me of college theatre days. Itâ€™s uniquely Filipino in a way that I canâ€™t describe. There were a few rough edges here and there. At one point, I got worried whether or not this film was just overhyped, but the ending powered through to be a film with a lot of heart, yet gripping. Intense! Great work!

Direktang naipahayag ni Direk Tonet sa pelikula ang problema at pangangailangan ng mga kababaihan gaya ni Sunshine. Ang pagbukas ng diskusyong aborsyon sa relihiyosong bansa kagaya natin ay napakatapang. Malinaw na naipakita sa pelikula kung bakit may mga pagkakataong kailangan ito. Hindi lang dahil ayaw ng babae ang magbuntis, kundi dahil unang una sa lahat, hindi niya ito ginusto. Hindi rin niya kaya o hindi siya handa. At malaki ang magiging epekto nito sa buhay at kalusugan ng isang babae.

Sa wakas napanood ko na din ang Sunshine. Ang ganda ng pelikula at ng acting ni Maris dito, sana magkaroon pa ng ibang pelikula na nagttrigger sa topics na kadalasan ay considered as taboo sa bansa dahil taliwas ito sa nakalakihan na paniniwala ng ibang henerasyon. Hindi madali ang usapan na to pero KAILANGAN gawin dahil dumadami ang kabataan na nalalagay sa gantong sitwasyon. Wala man ako sa posisyon na sinapit ni Sunshine at Mary Grace, pero alam ko na sila dapat ay may CHOICE sa kapalaran nila dahil buhay at kinabukasan din nila ang nakataya.

This film left me in awe after watching. A brave and bold take from Direk Antoinette Jadaone, Maris Racal graced us with her best performance yet. This film does not just tackle the taboo, it allows you to think otherwiseâ€” that thereâ€™s a world out there where options and autonomy matter, that speaking up and standing for what you want is ideal.This is a film that shows the world the great craftsmanship of Filipino filmmakers, and hopefully more people gets to see this wonderful work of art.

Accidental pregnancy â€” are women in our country truly given a choice? Fear, dread, societal pressure, and the struggle for autonomy â€” Sunshine tells the story of a young woman full of dreams, now standing at a crossroads because of an unplanned teenage pregnancy.What is the right choice for her?Should she listen to the voices urging her to preserve a life she does not want, even at the cost of her dreams?Or should she listen to herself â€” to her ambitions, her desires, and her right to choose her own future?Motherhood or success?Why must women be forced to choose?PS: Solid ang mga child actors and the lingering scenes that would force you to feel the emotion of the character added so much to the experience.

Sunshine is and will always be an Olympian because only she has the autonomy to choose for herself. ğŸ©· She could choose not to be a mother and no one could take that power away from her or from any woman. In the Philippines, a woman's freedom to choose for herself is criminalized as patriarchal society dictates that a woman shouldâ€¦

This movie might raise a lot of eyebrows here in a predominantly Catholic country like ours, and it might even stir a few uncomfortable conversations. But I think thatâ€™s why it matters. ğŸ™‚What resonates with me most as a woman is how Sunshine powerfully captures a young Filipinaâ€™s agency. Despite growing up in a harsh world, she refuses to let her circumstances define her or dictate her future, thanks to the strength and support of the women around her.It speaks volumes about the kind of society weâ€™ve built, the choices weâ€™re forced to make, and how survival, especially for women like me, is not just a quiet resistance, but a brave act of believing in and shaping the future in our own terms.Still showing in SM cinemas nationwide.#SupportLocalFilms

this film is what a pro-life conservative and misogynistic country needs. i love how the movie was able to make me feel tense and uncomfortable without showing Anything. no sex, no blood and gore, no grotesque scenes that were too in your face para iparating na this is a movie about abortion. a lot of the tension came from harsh realities most filipinos would consider normal. the abortion pills beside a church. the berating ob-gyn at a public hospital. theâ€¦

giving a voice and half the narrative to unborn children rather than keeping the main focus to the women this is happening to barred me from connecting with this film like i wanted to. even the â€œgets ko naâ€ part felt like settling because from the very start her being unprepared or not wanting to be a mother shouldve been enough. i will concede though the justification for the subject treatment is that we live in a very conservative country and this may hopefully sway people to be more considerate but i was hoping for more. i hope for more films to come emboldened by sunshineâ€™s example.

Weâ€™ve always known that the custom of films is that they should be written from the heart,but with â€˜Sunshine,â€™ the beating organ was not a place, it had gained limbs, put on a leotard, then graced the stage itselfâ€”that heart is Maris. The film mirrors how a good-for-nothing man only reaps a fleeting pleasure from an intercourse while pain is all that is left of and might be rooted in a woman forever and how a female that chooses and decides for her own body are condemned by her very own sex. I also appreciate how film celebrates the innate wisdom of children :â€™))Tribulations donâ€™t kindly pick a certain period in our lives, we will be found unarmed in them any time. It is also vague how long its adversities will delay our dreamsâ€”but what is sure is that they can never end them. I encourage everyone to see â€˜Sunshine.â€™ It is undebatable that we expose ourselves to brutally honest discourses about womanhood, safe sex, and reproductive health in the Philippines, dahil sa pagmamalasakit nag-uumpisa ang ating laban na mabuo ang isang mapagpalaya at ligtas na mundo para sa kababaihanâ€”para sa lahat ğŸ’œ

Everything in and about this film is ON POINT. Honestly comes as no surprise given the process and heart poured into this by Direk Antoinette Jadaone and Maris Racal :") Wala na ako nasabi pag labas ng sinehan kundi "on point. sobrang on point ng lahat."pwede magbrain fart na lang??? ang dami ko gusto sabihin, next time na iconstruct nang maayos :)lagi't lagi kong sinasabi na kakaiba talaga ang naratibong taglay at buhat ng isang atleta. at kapag ginagamit ito sa isang pelikula bilang daluyan ng mensahe at aral, mas lalo itong gumaganda at lumalalim. hindi sa inuundermine ko ang storya at halaga ng mga hindi atletang karakter... sadyang mas marami ang at stake para sa mga atleta natin, all the more para kay Sunshine na aspiring Olympian. kaya sa pelikulang ito, hindi ko mapigilang hindi hawakan at damdamin ang puso ko sa sakitâ€”hindi lang dahil sa malupit na sistema o sa kabagsikan ng relihiyon o sa mga storya ng kababaihang binigyang-buhay ng kwento, kundi para sa mga pangarap ni Sunshine na nadedehado. mga pangarap na maski buhay niya, handa siyang ilagay sa panganib. napakahusay ng pelikulang ito. maris racal... grabe ka na. walang ibang makakagawa ng ginawa niya kundi siya lamang. she really drew me in as Sunshine. si annika co ibang klase rin! kuhang-kuha niya yung innocence ng isang bata, kasabay ng subtleties ni Sunshine at ng mundong ginagalawan nila. si direk... syempre magnus opus. all my praises go to the cast and everyone behind this film. mula pagestablish ng setting, pagdepict sa gulo, sulasok, at sikip ng paligid ni Sunshine, yung mga eksena sa kalsada, sa palengke, sa jeep, at ultimately juxtaposition ng Quiapo??? ang lala. on point yet again. not to mention yung pagutilize ng sounds? on point na naman. dialogue? you bet it's perfect. last ko na siguro 'to pero gusto ko pasalamatan 'tong film na 'to. gusto ko pasalamatan si Sunshine. ang tingkad at importante ng diskursong dala ng pelikulang ito. tila isang diskursong matagal ng nilalaban ngunit ipinapasawalang-bahala lamang. isang diskursong pinapatatag ang katayuan ng kababaihan sa sistema at lipunan natin sa Pilipinas. isang diskursong taliwas sa nakasanayang asal at relihiyosong prinsipyo nating mga pilipino. pero again, isang diskursong napakahalaga at kinakailangan. thank you, Sunshine, kasi sobrang tapang mo shet ka. bago ka pa man maintindihan ng nakararami, gets na kita. gets na kita agad. gets ka namin :") <3

Watching it with my brother and my grandmother was really interesting for me because I knew all three of us had different knowledge and takes when it comes to pro-choice and pro-life concepts. We had different perspectives about the topics discussed in Sunshine, which is exactly what makes the movie relevant. And why so many people need to watch it. Every detail and line seemed to be carefully crafted. Every scene had an important message. From men failing to take accountability and leaving all the burden on the woman, the religious and conservative opinions, the reality of the healthcare system, to the harsh truth that criminalizing abortion does more harm than good. Annika Co's role was such an amazing addition to the entire story. Without her, I feel like it would be incomplete. She was a representation of a young girl's heart. I would say I felt like the ending was lacking in impact and power, hence my rating. I feel like there could have been more to show Sunshine's decision and outcome. But regardless, it was a beautifully crafted movie worth the hype and support!

babae at isang agham ang puso ng pelikula. sa maynila: kung saan masikip, mabaho, hindi makakilos ng maayos, at maraming mga tao ang huhusga sa iyo. the movie shows how women even in this modern society, still carry the burden of the spectrum. we, women, are expected to act like it. na laging piliin ang practical at hindi bigyang pansin ang pangarap. â€œmahirap maging babae, mas lalo na sa Pilipinas.â€ Sunshine confronts these social issues. the patriarchal conflicts of societal and religious issues. Maris Racal, carries her character with potential and determination. Ang daloy ng mensahe ng pelikula ay nararapat mapag-usapan. sana sa darating na panahon, people will choose to ignore the religious beliefs of the system- sana makabuo tayo ng empathetic, understanding, and compassionate individuals. kudos!

if you can make time, please, sa sinehan niyo siya panoorin.asa likod mo lang din kami sunshine, ano man ang mangyari. edit (over to sa haba ang tagal kong pinroseso yung film, ily sunshinee!): sun will always shine, gaano man kalugmok ang nangyayari sa atin. yung ganada ng sunshine ay hindi lang sa technical aspects nung film (ang ganda ng cinematography at linya like damn) pero buong-buo yung sunshine kasi kita mong naiintindihan mismo nung mga gumaganap yung character sa mundo ni sunshine.sa ganitong usapin madalas nating maririnig na ang tanga-tanga ng mga bata, ng mag jowa, lalo ng babae pero nakakalimutan natin na BATA sila at sa kung paano itinuturo sa kabataan ang sex ed sa atin, ang hirap nga pag-usapan ng sex sa loob ng bahay tas isisisi sa bata? ayos lang ba kayo. Ang dali kasi natin sisihin yung bata na di ginusto ang naging outcome, madalas, ano mang galing nila sa ibang bagay, kapag nabuntis sila, automatic, ang tanga na nila pero di natin lagi iniisip na ang naging outcome ng problema ay galing sa negligence mismo ng nagpapatakbo ng sistema. this film is important kasi dito pinakita yung rason kung gaano kabigat yung kahalaghan to have access to safe and legal abortion for women and in a developing country. hindi sinubo sayo pelikula, hahayaan ka niyang i-digest yung mga nangyayari on your own pace, hahayaan ka niyang intindihin, magkaroon ng opinyon, sumalungat, mag-agree, at higit sa lahat, after mo panoorin to, baka sakaling alam mo na ang gagawin kung may makikilala kang sunshine sa totoong buhay.kasabay ng ingay at bilis ng buhay sa maynila ay ang maaring bilang ng babaeng nalalagay sa alanganin ang buhay dahil wala pa ring access sa ligtas na abortion.Boses ng babae at kabataan yung asa pelikula, ang tagal na neto, bakit ba ang bagal nating ma-gets? skl,,, favorite scenes ko ay yung motel scene yung may lrt, yung nagppractice si sunshine bago yung competition yung may malalim siyang hinga, at yung dinudugo siya habang asa tuktuk/tric na pati yung batang babae dinudugo.again, watch this film kasi makakahanap ka ng kakampi at mas maiintindihan mo ang mga bakit. ugh thanks direk tonet, maliwanag ang future ng ph cinemaaa!

â€œThe unbornâ€ are a convenient group of people to advocate for. They never make demands of you; they are morally uncomplicated, unlike the incarcerated, addicted, or the chronically poor; they donâ€™t resent your condescension or complain that you are not politically correct; unlike widows, they donâ€™t ask you to question patriarchy; unlike orphans, they donâ€™t need money, education, or childcare; unlike aliens, they donâ€™t bring all that racial, cultural, and religious baggage that you dislike; they allow you to feel good about yourself without any work at creating or maintaining relationships; and when they are born, you can forget about them, because they cease to be unborn. You can love the unborn and advocate for them without substantially challenging your own wealth, power, or privilege, without re-imagining social structures, apologizing, or making reparations to anyone. They are, in short, the perfect people to love if you want to claim you love Jesus, but actually dislike people who breathe. Prisoners? Immigrants? The sick? The poor? Widows? Orphans? napakahusay. sobrang hirap maging babae. yun lang ang natakbo sa isip ko as i watch sunshine (and the other women in this story) face the shame, guilt, and judgement of everyone around her. you are shameful, guilty, but at the same time you think to yourself that you deserve to live the life that you want. and you have to fight for that. as you fight for your own freedom, you can't help but look at those around you trying to do the same. just like sunshine, you look at mary grace with pity and do what you can. bata ka palang. not only were you stolen of your innocence but by your own flesh and blood. sobrang bigat sa pakiramdam kasi tunay to. nangyayari to. her story probably had the biggest impact on me.. this movie gives you the experience of what it feels like to be a woman. more so, a woman in the philippines. na walang maasahan kundi sarili niya. na basta tumutol ka sa sinasabi o paniniwala ng mas nakakatanda sayo, ipapahiya ka. wala kang ibang kakampi kundi kapwa babae mo. the women in this film are flawed but you feel the warmth and support they give each other. because that's all we have. i'm rarely moved by filipino movies but this hit hard... so beautifully written and executed. di ka babae lang, babae ka!!!!!!!!!!

First of all, hands down to Maris Racalâ€™s acting. She absolutely delivered.Sunshine powerfully reflects how difficult it is to be a young woman in the Philippines. The film highlights how this country has continuously failed and disregarded its women, trapped in an unprogressive system blinded by religion and outdated norms. It chooses not to see the real dangers and struggles they face every day.Our government should focus more on this long-standing issue because protecting women is not just necessary, it is crucial. Women are the only ones who hold the right to their own bodies, and we need to give them the full chance to live freely, safely, and with dignity.This film does not just tell a story. It demands awareness. It is a wake-up call.

sunshine is a film by Tonet Jadaone. context is very important because if you have seen jadaoneâ€™s films (That Thing Called Tadhana, Fangirl, Alone Together among others) then you will know this is HER film. you feel it in every frame. the writing. the direction & performances. thereâ€™s no voyeurism here. no moralizing. just truth. honest, specific, sometimes messy truth about what itâ€™s like to be a woman in this country. not in the headlines, not in theory, but in the streets, in health centers, in quiet conversations with friends who are too afraid to say what they really need.maris racal delivers the performance of her life. she holds back when she needs to. she breaks in silence. she carries every scene with restraint, sensitivity & precision. she becomes sunshine. and itâ€™s the kind of performance that demands to be remembered.the ensemble is just as grounded. jennica garcia, thea, the kid: each one brings something real to the table. nothing is forced. they donâ€™t play characters. they play people youâ€™ve probably met. maybe they remind you of someone you know. maybe they remind you of you.what makes sunshine work is not the acting or the direction but the refusal to look away. the film doesnt hide behind a metaphor. it gives us a manila that feels exactly like the one we move through. where pamparegla is sold outside churches. where motels wonâ€™t let you in if youâ€™re alone. where grieving teenagers are all around but they have kept it in because no one has dared say â€œyouâ€™re safe here.â€ from my POV, the film takes a narrative risk. thereâ€™s a device that briefly pulls you out of the realism it builds so well. but it sticks the landing. because what matters is that you never stop feeling for these women. and that you leave the theater asking why stories like theirs still feel unsafe to tell.iâ€™ve had my own sunshines, close friends, a relative, a classmate. women who needed care, not judgment. watching this film felt like watching them again. and all i could think was, â€œplease, let her be safe.â€this film deserves a seat in our national conversations. not just in cinema panels, but in health committees, in policy rooms, in the offices of people who still think there is a valid excuse to deny access to care.one of the most necessary films of the year.

got really emotional composing my thoughts for this so [medj personal na reflection ahead]i was 6 when she broke the news. she was trembling and on the verge of tears. and i couldn't really understand why she suddenly had to move out from our house. and i just remember feeling sad about it, yet confused and unaware of the full weight she was carryingforever proud of her and the life and family she had built, but gets ko na.sunshine made me confront this heavy childhood memory and i wish i was old enough back then to understandâ€”enough to assure her na everything will be fine, or at least sit beside her, hold her hand tightly, and somehow let her feel na hindi siya nag-iisa.

This is a brave and essential film that dives into the tough reality of an unplanned pregnancy in a country where abortion is illegal. Maris Racal gives a raw, powerful performance as Sunshine, a young gymnast whose dreams are at risk, leading her to desperate, illegal options. The movie smartly uses Quiapo's setting, showing its mix of strong religious faith and hidden illicit acts, highlighting the difficult truth about women's reproductive freedom and how religion and judgment impact their lives. It's an honest look at a situation often ignored, pushing viewers to understand the hard choices women face when personal control over their bodies conflicts with strong beliefs

this one hit omg here r my thoughts ğŸ˜„- jadaone just gave us a visual storytelling masterclass brah. The amount of meaning etched into every single frame was so tastefully done and was especially satisfying to watch as a young filipina- they could never make me hate you maris racal omg what a star ğŸ˜­ğŸ˜­ğŸ˜­ sobrang halimaw umarte taena!- i felt like that gif of leonardo dicaprio pointing at the screen whenever i recognized a filming loc LMAOAOOA like omg thats morayta?- i really loved the subliminal messages scattered throughout the film.. all the little moments when you see mothers who clearly did not want to be mothers, the moments when you see children who were born into families unplanned, the moments when the male characters refused to provide assistance when needed.. they made up such little parts of the plot but they added so much volume to the message- i also really liked the choice of making the aborted children their own characters in the story. it may be a double-edged sword kind of thing but i think addressing the "buhay pa rin yan!" argument by giving the kids their own autonomy and still concluding that despite fear, they truly just want the best for their mothers was just spot onnn- lowk felt too short LOL like feel ko there was potential for more.. pero the film is enjoyable as it is- somebody else said this already but this was one of those social commentary films that critique today's society simply by showing a woman living a regular week in her life. Like this is the reality of thousands of filipino women. The reason this hit so hard for me and for my sister and all the young filipino women in the cinema with us was because sunshine could easily be usi'm really glad this received critical acclaim because its narratives like these that filipinos need to hear. surviving in the conservative catholic philippines as a woman is nawt for the weak ğŸ˜­ and its about time that progressive, proudly pro-choice films like sunshine make it big

â€œSorry. Gagawin ko ang lahat. Babawi ako, Lord, basta alisin mo lang â€˜to.â€ not a verbatim quote, but i remember the part where sunshine went outside the church to apologize. oh god, that part really, really struck me. as someone who is religious yet pro-abortion, and open to beliefs and choices that the catholic church doesn't traditionally approve of, i often carry a persistent guilt. but, like sunshine, if something doesn't feel right for me, i won't force it.responsibility is a choice. it has always been a choice.and if i or someone choose not to take on certain burdens, i trust that He is compassionate enough to understand. i will always stand with the pro-choice movement, cause no one should be denied the right to make deeply personal decisions about their own body and future.after watching the movie, yes, MAS na-gets ko na. at mas iintindihin ko pa. :) five stars!

alam niyo yung feeling na pagkatapos manood ng pelikula tungkol sa struggles ng modern women, o ng kababaihan in general, parang may nagaalab na galit sa loob mo? ganon na ganon ako. tipong hindi lang galit na umiiyak sa tahimik, kundi galit na kumakabog, galit na gusto mong isigaw, gusto mong may baguhin.galit ako sa sistema. galit ako sa kung paano itrato ang mga babae â€” na parang katawan lang, na parang obligasyon nilang tiisin, magparaya, manahimik. galit ako sa mga bulok na paniniwala na tinuro sa atin at patuloy pa ring pinaniniwalaan. galit ako sa tradisyon na sinasanto kahit matagal nang nakakasakit. galit ako sa mga mata na mapanghusga, sa mga bibig na laging may masasabi pag babae ang gumagalaw. galit ako sa mundo nyeta!pero itong galit na 'to, hindi to galit na mauupos lang. hindi to galit na lilipas pagkauwi. ito yung klase ng galit na may pinaghuhugutan â€” may direksyon, may laman, may pagmamahal. galit na gustong ipaglaban ang kapwa. galit na may layuning itama ang mali. ganito yung pinaramdam sakin ni direk tonet ngayon. ramdam mo na hindi lang siya nagdidirect eh. nagsisisigaw siya sa pamamagitan ng pelikula. pero sa halip na sumakit ang tenga mo, sa puso siya tumatama.at si maris, grabe. ibang klase, walang duda. sobrang galing niya mag-embody ng role, ang effortless pero ang lalim. habang pinapanood ko siya, hindi ko na siya nakita bilang artista eh. she felt like someone i knew. a friend. a neighbor. a stranger na napadaan pero dala ang bigat ng buong mundo sa katawan niya. dama mo sa kanya yung lapot, yung pagod, yung hagard, pero higit sa lahat â€” yung dignidad. yung tahimik pero matapang na dignidad.at ang mas masakit, 21st century na, pero kailan ba talaga matatapos ang pag-ccrucify sa mga babae? bakit pag babae ang may choice â€” sa katawan niya, sa sex, sa pagiging ina â€” bigla tayong nagiging moral police? gets ko, some people will say, "eh pinili niya makipag-sex." oo, pero bakit sa panahong ito, ang pagbili ng condom, ang pag-access sa contraception, ang simpleng pagtanong tungkol sa pts, ay parang kasalanan? bakit parang kahit anong piliin ng babae, mali pa rin?at sa kaso ni red, bakit parang hindi pa rin siya pinapayagang mamili kung anong gagawin niya sa sarili niyang katawan? bakit parang laging may kapalit, laging may parusa, laging may kapwa babae pa nga na una sa paghusga?ang ironic, diba? ang daming takot sa sex education, sa reproductive rights, pero hindi takot manghusga. the more we condemn, the more we isolate women. at kapag nagiisa na sila, dun nagsisimula ang desperation â€” dun sila mapipilitang hanapin ang mga opsyon na mas delikado, mas tahimik, mas mapanganib.sana makita ng mga tao na hindi lahat ng babae na nabubuntis ay handang maging ina. hindi lahat ng katawan ay handang magdala. hindi lahat ng buhay ay handang isuko ang sariling pangarap para lang maging ina. at hindi ito dahil masama silang tao â€” kundi dahil may sarili silang timeline.sana yung mga taong galit na galit sa konsepto ng "choice" ay matutong makinig. choice is not evil. choice is freedom. and freedom is humanity.sana maging wake-up call itong pelikula na ang kababaihan ay hindi lang tagapagdala ng buhay â€” may mga buhay din silang gustong buuin para sa sarili nila. at kung alam nila sa puso nila na hindi pa sila handa, hindi natin sila dapat pilitin. hindi natin sila dapat husgahan. hindi natin sila dapat ipako sa krus.punyeta talaga ang sistema, pero hindi ibig sabihin wala na tayong magagawa.
GETS KO NA. AAAA putangina ang galing mo Maris fucking Racal bumubula bibig ko!

ngayon mas gets ko na. gustong-gusto ko yung bigat ng pelikula â€” iyak, inis, at pangamba. ayan mga sobrang naramdaman ko sa pelikula. isa si sunshine sa libo-libong kababaihan na mataas ang pangarap pero kulang sa prebilehiyo. dagdag mo pa yung sobrang sulasok na maynila: mabaho, malagkit, madumi, magulo, at maingay. sobrang tapang na pinagusapan yung abortion sa pelikula. ngayon bilang isang lalaki, mas gets ko na ang hirap na pwedeng pagdaanan ng isang babae kung madaming ipinag kakait sa kanya. kahit punong-puno ka ng pangarap, balewala lahat ng yan kung ang kalaban mo mismo ay ang lipunan at ang bansa kung saan ka nakatira. may isang eksena na napapakapit na ako sa upuan ko. sobrang dilim, sobrang ingay ng paligid pero punong-puno din ng katamihikan. ang ganda ganda ng cinematography! madilim at dadalhin ka talaga sa settings ng maynila. ang galing galing ng mga character at simbolismo ng isang character â€” si â€œbataâ€ (anikka). sa dulo ng pelikula, i took her as a symbolism of her â€œconscienceâ€. ayaw niyang gawin yun, kaya nagdasal siya at humingi na ng tawad pero sinusundan siya ng konsensya niya â€” at si annika yun. sobrang ganda! maris, youâ€™re a fcking good as actress. walang pintas sa acting mo dito. mahal na mahal ko si sunshine, at lahat ng sunshine sa mundo.
