parang ang tagal na noong huli akong nanood sa sinehan na maraming tao, puno pa. went to watch this with my friends expecting na kaunti lang kami since nasa outside metro manila kami, pero hindiâ€¦ puno siya. nakita pa namin yung iba naming friends pero â€˜di sila nakaabot at sa next showing time na sila makakanood. medyo tmi siya but i just shared how jampacked the cinemas are for this filmâ€¦ and sobrang worth it niya. best film i have watched this year (minsan lang manood). no but seriously, what this film has ay mahirap pantayan. i love it na kahit na it has an obvious subject na tina-tackle eh hindi niya sinasampal sayo kung anong side yung dapat mong piliin. it even showed both sides of the issue.and the ironyâ€¦ OH MY GOD THE IRONYâ€¦ mapa visual symbolisms o lines, ang daming irony. at sobrang nakakaappreciate yung magsisingit sila ng patama kahit one line lang, ang galing pa rin. from main characters, supporting, to cameos, importante silang lahat. ang ganda ng pasok ng mga subplots at kung paano siya na-connect sa main plot. tapos yung mga nangyayaring sa huli mo lang mage-getsâ€¦ NAKAKA-MINDBLOWN FOR REAL. lalo na yung sa duloâ€¦ yung gotcha moment doon napaluha pa â€˜ko. galing. so angas. amazing. extraordinary. life-changing. siguro kung may masasabi akong negative sa film na â€˜to, siguro yung kapag nagtetext or chat si sunshine tapos di accurate yung tinatype niya doon sa lumalabas sa phone niya, heheâ€¦.

ang sunshine ay kwento ng libo-libong babae na nakikipagsapalaran sa patago at delikadong kalakaran ng quiapo, at ng iba pang lugar sa pilipinas. habang patuloy na tatangkilikin ng mga pilipino ang makitid na ideyang ang moralidad ay nahahati lang sa dalawa â€”mabuti o masama, itim o puti- dadami ng dadami ang mga babaeng ilalagay sa alanganin ang sarili maibalik lang ang kalayaan nilang piliin angsariling buhay.and no, hindi lang ito tungkol sa mental health. tungkol ito sa kawalan ng choices, sa pagiging biktima ng patriarkal na sistema, sa kawalan ng suporta sa mga atleta, sa paulit-ulit na pang-abuso sa kababaihan at pagtingin na sapat na maging nanay ka na lang. hindi dapat tinatapos sa mental health lang ang talakayan sa pelikula na to dahil may higit pa sa usapin na yon ang hain ni antoinette jadaone rito.at bago niyo sabihing isip muna bago buka, paano naman ang mga biktima ng rape? ang mga may problema sa pag-iisip na napagsamantalahan? ang mga batang ni hindi alam ang salitang "puke" o "titi"natutuwa rin ako na bumabalik na ang mga temang ganito sa pelikulang pilipino. mula sa pagpapakita ng epekto ng blind fanaticism (fangirl,2019) hanggang sa kwento ng mga pdl (green bones, 2024) kitang kita na umay na umay na tayo sa kultura ng love teams at comedies na di naman nakakatawa.kung may oras at kakayahan kayo, sana panoorin niyo ang pelikula na to. at sana may maiwang bago paglabas niyo sa mga sinehan.

Hindi tahimik ang Maynila, punong-puno ito ng mga ingay at usok. Dinig ang dumaraang tren, bulungan ng mga tao sa daan, kakaibang tugtugan sa tricycle, nakakasulasok na paligid, at marami pang iba. Mula Avenida hanggang Quiapo, ramdam ko ang nag-aalab na pangarap ni Sunshine. Pursigido. Desidido. Hindi siya nagpatinag sa ingay ng paligid. Mula umpisa hanggang dulo, buo ang kaniyang loob para sa kaniyang sarili at pangarap. Walang halong pag-aalinlangan. Mahusay ang pagkakahabi ng pelikula, mula cinematography hanggang linya ng mga karakter. Mahusay ang pagkakaarte. Madaling maunawaan. Hindi ko naramdaman na halos isang oras na ang nakalipas. Hindi nakababagot. Punong-puno ng pangarap at serye ng kawalan ng akses sa sektor ng pangkalusugan. Dinala tayo ni Sunshine sa kaniyang buhay at pangarap. Isa sa tumatak sa akin na eksena ay ang huling tagpo. Ginawa niya ang kaniyang stunts, nag-gymnastics siya, sumayaw nang walang pag-aalinlangan at pangamba. Sumabay sa indayog ng musika habang dinadama ang bawat hampas ng kaniyang ribbon. Doon pa lang, alam mo na. Tahimik ang eksena matapos ang pagsayaw, ang higpit ng yakap ay ramdam mo. Para bang ikaw ang niyayapos at pinapakalma nito. Salamat sa mahigpit na yakap. Sa malalim na aspekto, nakalulungkot isipin na hanggang ngayon ay hindi pa rin tanggap ang abortion sa ating bansa. Nakalulungkot isipin na nawawalan ng karapatan ang mga kababaihan na mamiliâ€” na piliin ang sarili at pangarap. Mapagmulat at mapagpalaya ang pelikula. Pinamulat sa atin ng bawat eksena ang isang isyung nangyayari sa ating bansa sa kasalukuyan. At pinalaya tayo ng pelikula mula sa tanikala ng tradisyunal na paniniwala at pananaw ng karamihan. Hindi maglalaon, unti-unti na rin matatanggap ng mga tao ang katotohan na bahagi ng ating karapatan ito bilang kababaihan. Sa huli, isa lang ang sigurado, nanaig ang kaniyang pangarap. Pinili niya ang kaniyang sarili ng walang halong pag-aalinlangan. Kaya para sa lahat ng Sunshine, nawa'y lagi ninyong piliin ang sarili at pangarap. Gaya ni Sunshine, ang pangarap niya ay pangarap ko rin. PS. Thanks sa crush ko, pinanood namin 'to together ^__^

Mahal na mahal kita, Sunshine

â€œthe filipino women and the curse of catholic guiltâ€ despite popular western belief where early stages of pregnancy are just lump of cells and does not count as a human being, this is where pro-choice comes in and protest womenâ€™s autonomy through the lens of science. in our nation this is not a strong argument as this doesnâ€™t penetrate the teachings of the catholic/christian church where flesh is flesh and the act of aborting a lump of cells is murder. now this is where sunshine and the jojo rabbitesque kid brave depiction contradicts with the filipino pro-life argument â€œfuture presidentâ€ and the what ifs of the future child, despite some view this representation as counter productive it actually stands for how much catholic guilt and patriarchal values is imbued from the moment we are born, thatâ€™s why no matter how we view ourselves as progressive, modern, and forward, the filipino women still struggle with their autonomy over their body and choices where they face at the mercy of unwanted consequences. thatâ€™s why i admire how brave â€œsunshineâ€ depict the lump of cells as a hallucinatory unborn child where it grounds how filipino culture views it and turns it as a film creative force to show how women no matter the circumstance should have complete autonomy over their body, not in an overly liberal way where everything is muddled in the gray area but as an acceptance that we live in a society where women are still tied to patriarchal reproductive roles and system wherein we disguise feminist liberalism as matriarchal.with abortion still illegal in our country, teenage and unplanned pregnancy a national problem, and contraceptives a taboo subject. this is a film that offers understanding, empathy, and compassion to sunshines out there that are resorting to unsafe, life threatening, and â€œillegalâ€ ways that society calls bad choices but what is â€œbadâ€ when it is the only choice they have. lastly i cannot complete this write up without mentioning the lino brocka, i love how it shows manila as a character with its noise, chaos, and decay through the familiar seams of avenida and quiapo with its religious interplay of choice (accessibility to unsafe preganancy pills) and solace of a religious power it holds.maris racal stellar performance will forever hold her in the filipino cinema history as sunshine, as how nora aunor is bona, and hilda koronel is insiang.i really really hope more people watch this and be a strong catalyst of change for reproductive rights as it is core a healthcare and human rights.

Promise, 'di siya overhype.Weâ€™re halfway through 2025 and far from its denouement but I must say that SUNSHINE, if not the best, is one of the best and one of the most important films of the year. Iâ€™m so sorry, SIX DEGREES OF SEPARATION FROM LILIA CUNTAPAY, but I believe I now have my new favorite Antoinette Jadaoneâ€™s work. They said during the promotion that this is the last day this will be shown here sa provinces and then starting tomorrow, sadly, it will only be shown to 3 cinemas na lang so I felt the substantial need to watch it tonight. Mind you, sobrang bigat pa rin ng pakiramdam ko, tapos na lahat, at ngayon na tina-type ko lahat ng to.Sunshine heavily tackled significantly sensitive issues here in the country - rape, teenage pregnancy, poor healthcare, and machismo. At habang ina-absorb ko lahat kanina inside the movie theatre, I couldnâ€™t help but think about my two sisters who are the same age as the protagonist. Ang bigat. Ang lala. Ang hapdi. Give me a span of time to write an essay about this and I will take that challenge without a doubt. Thatâ€™s how it affected me big time. It hits home.Now letâ€™s talk about the performances. First sequence pa lang, itâ€™s apparent that Maris Racal studied the role. Inakap niya at binigyan niya ng kaluluwa yung karakter. Hindi siya bumitaw hanggang final sequence. She had a lot of silent moments in the film and those were the most powerful. Nakakabingi yung katahimikan na halos hinahabol ko na rin yung hininga ko minsan. Jennica Garciaâ€™s character, on the other hand, though itâ€™s just a supporting role, is one of the main highlights throughout. Yung kahit minimal lang yung dialogues niya, tignan mo lang siya sa mga mata niya, maiintindihan mo sya. I love her here. Sheâ€™s too authentic. May eksena silang dalawa ni Maris dito and that was when I lost it. Iyak ako eh. GRABE YUN. Grabe yun!!!!As for the direction, from the bottom of my heart, thank you, direk Tonet. Iba pa rin talaga kapag ang kwento ng babae ay gawa rin ng babae. Maselan, matapang, at may puso. Salamat sa buhay mo. Nag-uumapaw sa social realism ang pelikula mo. Lino Brocka wouldâ€™ve been so proud!! Sunshine knows Manila and all its aches and decays. May problema ka? Okay, pero hindi titigil ang mundo. Hindi titigil ang buhay ng mga naka-paligid saâ€˜yo. Dagdag mo pa na nasa Maynila ka kung saan life is always on survival mode. The film captured those perfectly.Lastly, Sunshine doesn't preach or impose. She makes her decisions but doesn't force you to change your opinion either. Your role as an audience member is to listen. The rest is for you to reflect upon on your own.Gets ko na.

a beautiful and important film :")i spent most of it crying and whispering curses at the screen. matagal ko nang alam kung gaano kahirap maging babae sa pilipinasâ€”but watching it unfold onscreen hits differently. ang hirap kasi lahat ng sakit, galit, at poot makikita mo. youâ€™re forced to face the things weâ€™ve been taught to bury, forget, or avoid.by the last ten minutes, i was inconsolable.ang hirap harapin ng katotohanan na whatever happened in the filmâ€”our reality is even worse. sunshine may be fictional, but her story is the story of all filipinas. it speaks the raw and painful truth about how limited our choices are.lahat tayo si sunshine.lahat tayo, kailangan pang ipaglaban ang karapatan natin sa sarili nating katawan.lahat tayo, pinalaki ng hiya at takot, forced upon us by societyâ€™s expectations.weâ€™re all just trying to survive the cruelty of our countryâ€™s outdated norms and catholic guilt.as the credits rolled and the lights came on, i looked around at the people seated there with us. there were women my age, some younger, some older. there were men. there were lolos, lolas, nanays, tatays. so many different lives and experiences. and all i could think was: â€œsana lahat ng nandito gets na rin si sunshine.â€and if they donâ€™t yet, i hope they find it in their hearts to have empathyâ€”for her, and for all the sunshines out there.i hope this film reaches more people. but more than that, i hope it urges those in power to finally take a closer look at the very real struggles filipinas face and make the long overdue changes weâ€™ve been fighting for.

â€œgets ko na.â€ â€” tears. almost immediately. a lot of issues were tackled so gracefully and with sensitivity in this film, whilst not necessarily favoring any particular side. the scene where sunshine asks for forgiveness at quiapo church, the same church where she was desperate to find abortion methods, shows how two conflicting views on abortion can be felt at once. also liked how it depicted the pressure of being an athlete, of maintaining your weight, and of the unrelenting need to train despite your life pretty much falling apart. if thereâ€™s anything i want to praise, itâ€™s the way the film portrayed the role of women supporting one another, from the protagonist, her sister, her coach, the doctor, down to the innkeeper that rushed her to the hospital. the worst takes in this film were from men (no surprise there) who didnâ€™t even bother asking sunshine how she felt (because in our incredibly conservative & patriarchal society, women are nothing more than their childbearing abilities lmao). ultimately, the only valid opinions on a womanâ€™s body & whether or not she should undergo abortion should be hers & hers alone ! ! !

â€œNaiintindihan mo na ba â€˜ko?â€â€œGets ko na.â€i grew up in a somehow conservative and very religious household. i was taught by my elders that abortion is murder. period. full stop â€” that no reason could ever justify the taking of a â€œhuman life.â€i never questioned this belief. until i grew up and learned about the social conditions that surround my imperfect â€” almost dysfunctional â€” family. dumating na sa punto na palagi ko nang tinatanong kung bakit nga ba pinili pa akong ipanganak ng nanay ko. tinawag ko ang sarili ko na isang kasalanan. isang aksidente, hindi sinasadya.eventually, i started to question my own views. my mother didnâ€™t have a choice. but what if she did? what if her religion did not instill fear onto her â€” did not make her choose between her dream of living in the US andâ€¦me? what if she was given the right to make autonomous decisions for her own body and for herself?the importance of the sanctity of life has long been asserted in, what seems to be, an unending discussion on the controversial topic of abortion. these endless queries led me to enlightening myself to a greater picture of things. THAT criminalizing abortion is a NEGLECT to womenâ€™s rights. up until this day, womenâ€™s health and bodies have been continuously politicized by society. bago natin ituring na isang krimen ang abortion, we first need to view this on a sociopolitical lens. bakit nga ba maraming mga babae ang nagpapalaglag?what i loved about this film is how it portrayed Sunshineâ€™s story in the most raw and harshest way possible. direk jadaone, a WOMAN director (yes kailangan iempahsize to), saw Sunshine as a human being â€” a young woman who FEELS, who DREAMS big for herself. not as a criminal but as a real woman with real human flesh with the right to her own life. even Manila didnâ€™t feel like a foreign place as a BatangueÃ±a. the entire film was real, we were all living in the same society as Sunshineâ€™s.hindi ito pawang fiction lang. totoo si Sunshine. she is every young woman who had to choose between herself and a life she does not want for herself. she is also every young mom who had to choose between the same things. she is every young woman who is held back by what todayâ€™s society deems as morally upright based on outdated religious doctrines. she is every young woman who was denied proper healthcare, every young woman who was denied their choices and rights.she is every young woman who was neglected by a corrupt system that politicizes on womenâ€™s health and bodies.thank you, direk jadaone for introducing us to Sunshine. and to my mother, i hope you know that i wouldâ€™ve understood you the same way Bata understood Sunshine.

i sat at the best seat in the cinema (in the middle!) and love how tastefully beautiful it is visually and sound wisethe visuals remind me of lino brocka + tsai ming liang meets in quiapo, manila. the place itself becomes a character, those shots of sunshine wandering through the urban chaos tell us so much.. especially that scene in the cheap hotel near morayta, when the train passes by and itâ€™s like the city is holding her pain, witnessing everything, maybe even screaming alongside her. the way they use sound here is incredible, and almost throughout the film too, like the noise (and sunshine trying to â€˜drownâ€™ them out) becomes part of her headspace, you know? the city breathes with her loneliness. the city is even â€˜herâ€™though i find the jojo rabbit inspiration kinda out of place with what the movie already has going for it, maybe itâ€™s just jadaoneâ€™s style of directing, trying to move away from brockaâ€™s straight realism into something more surreal, but it doesnâ€™t really work for me since this story needs that grounded feel. still, i appreciate that they didnâ€™t just simplify everything. i personally think films should capture the messy (nuance!) when dealing with complex topic like thisbut overall i think this is really tight and visually gorgeous. my favorite part is when sunshine just whacks that creep with the suitcase. what an improvement from her previous film where the character just called the police lol. this is how you try to attempt a feminist lens in a movie, especially this one, the character arc trying to â€˜breakâ€™ from the â€˜setupâ€™ of the reality they are set in.. like them trying to pull a fourth wall break, but internally, if that makes sense

Rather, para siyang naging sigh of relief that finally, FINALLY this issue is being talked about and represented on the big screen for the masses. diba? ang pagbubuntis, lalo na ng mga dalaga ay hindi lahat pinlano at ginusto. karamihan, pawang mga biktima lang din ng kakulangan sa edukasyon ukol sa kahalagang ng safe s*x practices. â€˜yung iba, biktima ng kasahulan.although i cannot fully say that this representation of such an issue was able to encompass all its accompanying factors, however, it indeed delved into some of its facets: how abortion is a healthcare and a socioeconomic issue due to it being constitutionally prohibited in the country, and much more. sobrang bigat ng mensahe, ng mga salita, at ng tinatalakay ng palabas. pero kahit ayaw man natin noâ€™n, thatâ€™s really how it is in real life. this movie isnâ€™t fiction; itâ€™s inspired by true events, particularly of the young, pregnant women in the philippines. many do resort in unsafe practices leaving them at more risk, so bakit kailangang mag agaw-buhay muna ang tao para sa desisyong iyon? abortion is a choice, abortion is healthcare.

Aspiring Olympian Sunshine's (Maris Racal) world suddenly turned upside down after she realizes that she is pregnant. This is by far the most beautiful and bravest Filipino film I've watched. There is an important topic that needs to be discussed after watching the film. And we need to sit down and talk about it. Loved the whole technical aspect of the show. Cinematography was on point (go Pao!). The gritty Quiapo was a whole character in itself. The bustling city echoes the fear and confusion in Sunshine's mind, yet amidst all the chaos - she is alone. Rico Blanco's music radiated organically throughout the film. Both silent and scored scenes touched feelings and intensified emotions.Maris Racal cemented her status as one of the great actors of her generation. No need to look pretty as long as she delivers the right emotions that her character calls for. And damn, Jennica Garcia! She fuckin' deserves an award! Take it, take it!!! Especially that last scene (spoiler ahead!) where she's the only one who's crying among the cheering crowd? My heart tore to pieces. Special mention to Annika Co who amused me with her natural acting chops. For a kid to deliver that, she's definitely a hot talent to watch out for! And of course, Direk Tonet. Been a fan of Antoinette Jadaone since That Thing Called Tadhana (and yeah, as a ka-eme, AWKP) and damn she really is one strong voice in this industry. Her writing, strengthened by her directing, sends out a clear message to her audience. Sunshine is an example - subtle yet painfully direct in one.After the 7pm screening in SM North last Monday, she came to answer a few questions and what struck me the most is her sharing about her most favorite part of writing - REVISING. For a professional writer like her, it is very humbling and inspiring to hear that. And her body of work definitely shows how great they are due to the notes, lessons and heart she puts to her stories.Favorite scene in the whole series of course was the last routine of Sunshine where she hugged the little girl. Just found myself crying. I literally wanted to jump to the screen and hug both of them just to say, "it's okay". "Naiintindihan mo na ba ako?" Cast: Maris Racal, Annika Co, Jennica Garcia, Elijah Canlas, Meryll SorianoDirector: Antoinette JadaoneWriter: Antoinette JadaoneProduction Companies: Anima Studios, Project 8 Projects, Cloudy Duck Pictures, Happy Infinite ProductionsDistribution: Project 8 Projects

drown out the noise.sisimulan ko â€™tong review sa paraan kung paano nailantad ang pelikula sa mga manonoodâ€” sa ingay. sa unang parte, maliban sa naging pagsasanay ni sunshine, ay dadalhin ka nito sa marumi at maingay na sulok ng quiapo kung saan nakabudbod ang mga relihiyosong karatula tulad ng â€œgift of god,â€ at â€œin god we trust.â€ hindi ka nito lulubayan subalit halos nakaukit na ito sa bawat ugat natinâ€” para bang isa itong palantandaang isa kang pilipino. sobrang bigat nung isang scene na umiiyak si sunshine sa labas ng simbahan, nagmamakaawa na tanggalin lang ang sanggol sa loob niya at babawi rin siya sa Diyos. dahil iyon naman talaga ang itinuro sa atin tungkol sa relihiyon sa simula palang; ang pagiging kondisiyonal nito. dito rin na-introduce ang batang karakter na hindi natin nalaman kung ano ang pangalan at kung bakit ba siya sunod nang sunod kay sunshine na parang nakatali sila sa isaâ€™t-isa. hindi ko alam if napansin din ng iba na hindi totoo/hindi naman nag-e-exist yung bata at isa siyang talinghaga ng magiging anak ni sunshine. ineencapsulate niya yung pagkakasala, kahihiyan, at trauma sa relihiyon ni sunshine. sinusundan siya nito sa bawat balak niya, sinisigawan siya gilid, at pinagdududa ang sarili. higit pa diyan, suportado rin naman siya nito. ika nga niya, kung ano ang pangarap ni sunshine ay pangarap niya rin. kung ano ang nakabubuti kay sunshine ay makabubuti rin para sa kaniya. sa usapin ng abortion, lingat sa mga tao na bigyan ng kaluluwa ang nagdadala ng bata. na para bang isa lamang itong karwahe at hindi taong may puso at pangarap. na sa sandaling nagkaroon na ng buhay sa tiyan mo ay doon na rin nagsimula ang pagkamatay mo. dagdag ko lang sa parte ng mga bata bilang representasyon/metaporya ng mga anak na hindi pa naisisilang ay si ariana. natuwa ako kasi example nga siya ng mga sinasabi ng tao o di kaya nung doktor kay sunshine na, â€œpaano kung maging presidente siya ng pilipinas? mag-imbento ng gamot sa aids?â€ dahil binahagi niya rin na pangarap niyang mag-artista o di kaya maging unang beking presidente ng pilipinas. at hindi naman din natin isinasantaboy yung mga posibilidad na â€˜yon, pero sa sitwasyon na tulad ng nagdadala sa kanya na si menggay na isang biktima ng incestual at corrective rape bilang isang tomboy, maiintindihan natin kung bakit kinailangan maglaho ni ariana. pinabulaanan din ng pelikula ang mga kuro-kuro na aabusuhin ng mga kababaihan ang legalisasyon ng abortionâ€” na baka maging isang gawi na nilang magpalaglag. naipakita na ang abortion ay hindi madaling piliin. na kahit sigurado ang isang tao na ayaw niya maging ina ay isa pa rin itong mabigat na pagpasya. madugo sa puso, madugo sa katawan. hanggaâ€™t mananatiling walang pagpasya ang mga kababaihan sa kanilang katawan, mananatili rin ang iligal na pagsasagawa nito.walang lugar ang mga kababaihan sa ganitong sistema at bansa. napatunayan ito sa pelikulaâ€” mula sa ospital, sa lansangan, pati sa karapatan mamili. kahit hindi pa nalalaman ang kasarian ng nasa sinapupunan ni sunshine ay hinalaang lalaki na agad ito, isa na namang tanda na hindi kailanman iniisip ang posibilidad ng isang babae. sana sa mga nakapanood nito dahil lang gusto nila si maris, o di kayaâ€™y na-curious sila sa kwento. sa mga hindi sigurado sa kinatatayuan nila sa usaping abortion. sana, tulad nung bata, ay masasabi niyo na ringgets ko na.

Seen @SM North EDSA Cinema 6 w/Post-Show Q&A and Pagpag Session w/Direk Antoinette Jadaone FANTASTIC SUNSHINE 2/2â€œGets ko na.â€ I still recall that time back in high school when we were taught the morality of abortion in Religion class. I was a scholar at a conservative Catholic all-boys school, and although I wasnâ€™t religious (nor did I ever practice Catholicism on paper), its discussions almost shaped my beliefs on the subject matter. What I did not know was that those beliefs were tied with several factors besides religion such as patriarchy and conservatism. That was before the pandemic, and since then, my viewpoints have stirred away from every close-minded and male-led influence those so-called teachings had. Yet, I still find it unfair that I donâ€™t have to go through those experiences that women go through in this patriarchal society, including that of Sunshine. Critics were not kidding about the Lino Brocka comparisons to Sunshine, yet this has that unique female perspective that elevates its authenticity. The film is straight-forward, and in doing so, it is raw, visceral, and brutally honest. It takes its viewers through an experience rather than dictate or spoonfeed, and it rarely shies away from its reality. From the milieu alone â€” from the shitty healthcare system, to the sheer lack of contraceptives (if you could find them, theyâ€™re very expensive), ignorant, privileged boyfriend, and to the conservative religious doctors and rapist relatives â€” we are already shown that this is not a world suitable for Sunshine and for women like her who are struck with unwanted pregnancies. Because thatâ€™s the truth of our nation. Because this is not a country that favors the oppressed. As the famous saying goes, â€œMahirap maging babae, pero mas mahirap maging babae sa Pilipinas,â€ (â€œItâ€™s impossible to be a woman, but itâ€™s more impossible to be a woman living in the Philippines,â€) and that couldnâ€™t be reflected better in this film. Sunshine seeks to reclaim autonomy over her own body, which every woman deserves so but is seldom granted that right. Despite the latter being true, we still see Sunshine do everything she could to get that abortion, even if it means having to spend an unreasonable amount of money just to do so. Some may say that her story is inspiring, but itâ€™s tragic how inspiration is confused with disturbance. This is a story thatâ€™s supposed to shed light on the fact of the matter because this is one of many issues in the country that have to be addressed, especially within our own government. Even its production design and cinematography that go hand-in-hand highlight how constrictive this place is for those who are forced to go through such uncomfortable, unasked experiences. Much of the filmâ€™s raw emotions would not have been as impactful without Maris Racal. Her acting and performance here are simply generational and incomparable. She may be known for her more comedic roles (and pure wit and vibes in interviews), but her role of Sunshine brings out her more vulnerable side that is just as raw as the attitude of the film itself. Among the more underrated performances is Jennica Garcia, who levels up with Maris Racalâ€™s natural performance but brings a distinct, yet supportive dynamic. Child actor Annika is also great and is secretly the one who makes some of the more emotional scenes, especially those towards the end, work so well. In addition, Meryll Soriano stands out, as do Elijah Canlas, Rhed Bustamante, Xyriel Manabat, Piolo Pascual, and Angeli Bayani â€“ even if the latter two only show up in one scene each. Some ongoing debate had sparked since its release here with regards to the weaving of the children subplot into the story, and while it did have its risks, for better or worse, it still cannot be disregarded how brave Antoinette Jadaone and Maris Racal are for telling this kind of story. Perhaps it could have been subtler, but in a country like ours, it was necessary to have been told through a more straightforward direction without being too preachy. There have been a handful of films out there that tackle abortion and unwanted pregnancies, but what makes Sunshine stand out is the mere fact that it is set in the Philippines. We are one of the last few countries to have abortion illegal as we are rooted in traditions influenced by the patriarchy and religion that treat it as an immoral, evil doing and as a taboo simply because, to them, the youth are â€œbeing irresponsible.â€ Sunshine never puts the blame on its titular character for its consequential catalyst, and through its depiction of such a life in this country, instead, asks us to question our reality: Did the youth fail us for exploring a natural part of ourselves, or did the adults fail them by placing and enabling all these barriers as mere punishment substituted by the words of â€œa lessonâ€ or â€œa teachingâ€? Thatâ€™s what makes Sunshine scary: The simple fact that itâ€™s set in the Philippines; that women with unwanted pregnancies have to navigate through these stupid barriers, but it also ends with hope for a better future where women are allowed to make choices for their own body. In fact, we must also be reminded of this saying: â€œNo uterus, no opinion.â€ Such a timely film that is raw and honest with its sensitive topic that must be talked about because so many women have had experiences like that of Sunshine. P.S. Seeing this at one of the many screenings with Q&A and audience sharing truly added to its communal experience. Direk Tonet always mentions how the film is no longer hers but ours now that we have seen it, and you could clearly see and feel it as the credits rolled, with some women opening up about once being a Sunshine or their parents giving birth to them at such an early age. It reminds you that those experiences are real and are still happening to other women underground up to now. Itâ€™s also amazing to see an eye-opening drama such as this fill up the theaters more than it did for Fantastic Four (which made for such a whiplash of a double-feature for me because it tackles the opposite theme to Sunshine).P.P.S. It goes without saying that those who say that Philippine Cinema is nothing compared to Hollywood films should shut up and watch this in cinemas. Cool to see my prof work on this. Ang gwapo rin nina Elijah Canlas at Cris Cao (luh). Oh, and legalize and decriminalize abortion in the Philippines now!Most-Anticipated Films of 20252025 Ranked2025 In Theaters

"gets mo na? gets ko na."This film could've ended there! since it already foreshadows the choice she made. But no, instead it got better and gave the audience a satisfaction of how Sunshine became successful despite her hurdles.I really loved the color grading in this film! at the first scenes it gave me a feeling of uneasiness, and worry for Sunshine â€” maybe that's because of the constant dark grading along with the green or teal background. The film's color grading gradually changed as the story progresses, when Sunshine gained hope, and courage for her decision the film got brighter.Fuck I have a lot to say in this movie. I also loved how they showed a taboo topic in the Philippines as well which is the incest among minors because of the so-called "utang na loob". I really loved how Sunshine stood up to tito bobot â€” that fuckin' asshole. By showing and portraying this taboo topic in this film I hope the viewers gained a light that this is wrong. A minor, pregnant by his tito, is not normal and is wrong. I have always disliked how people compare other Filipino cities to Metro Manila, specifically Cebu City. Because they always go for the most shallow differences and often time the most hypocritical. Every city in the Philippines, and for the most part the world, has traffic, hot weather, trashy streets, muggers, and poor air quality, not just Metro Manila. This frustrates me because there IS a tangible difference between Manila and other cities, it's just that a city's identity is more spiritual in essence. The churches in Cebu City won't have vendors selling abortion pills, nor will doctors in Davao City berate you moments after caring for you after you nearly died from an attempted abortion, but in Manila they do. It's a city of people getting by, it's why you go to Manila, and a deep understanding among everyone that that's what they're all trying to do, just get by.Every year my favorite Filipino movie to come out pass by me until the next year, I think this is the first time that's changed.

the film hits too close to home for me. sunshine is suffocating, and maybe that's a directorial choice. it hits in the most uncomfortable and painful parts of me at times. it resonates with every woman who has to determine a better choice out of two shitty choices: one that might shackle her freedom or one that may free her but haunt her at the same time. it makes you feel rage at systemic failures which birth a backward society that villifies women for their lapses of judgment--damned if they do, damned if they don't. sunshine is linear in its plot. it never really takes you out of sunshine's head, so you see how raw everything is, how immature she is, how she's desperate and breaking apart but trying to keep it together, and how she's just a kid who fucked up. the film works because of this approach, albeit some plot devices are too on the nose--making them iffy and questionable, and may have muddled the film's stance. there are obvious plot holes, little details that could have enriched the world-building were overlooked. some subplots lack depth, but the performances made me look past on these things, in a sense that it was pleasant enough to watch for me. not for everyone, but everyone should be part of the discussion. jadaone's films are usually hits-or-misses for me, but sunshine is one of her better ones. the message may be clear and hopeful, but real life presents a much darker truth: for most women, there are no olympics and dreams to hold on to. in reality, we still have a long way to go in paving for a more humane society for filipino women.here's to working towards a future where women are not shamed for reclaiming their agency, and where their indiscretions are not berated and ridiculed, but treated with proper education and compassion.

"You're Sunshine, Olympian." Sunshine was always meant to compete on the Olympic stage. Her entire life was built around that goal. And yet, life threw her choice no young women should have make under fear and silence. The scene that hit the hardest was when bata (Annika) watched her and said "gets ko na." That moment broke me. It wasn't resentment but rather understanding as she realized that she was never part of the dream and she let Sunshine go.â€¦

"sunshine" delves deeply into prevalent social realities and dares to question long-standing traditional systems. but what struck me most was how it thoughtfully explored womenâ€™s bodily autonomy, weaving it into a narrative that felt both natural and unforced.the lead's inner turmoil exists in the gray areasâ€”a subtle moral dilemma, especially when prioritizing autonomy challenges societal expectations.this raises critical questions: how does sunshineâ€™s obligation to herself impact the broader community? and what roles do the people around her play in shaping or reinforcing these expectations?i honestly wished there was more screen time, yet in the moments it was given, it still managed to leave a profound message about women's reproductive rightsâ€”one that lingers and quietly settles in your mind.

Superb portrayal of religious elements and realism in the Philippines. Kung ipagpalagay mo sarili mo na maagang na buntis at nag gagalugad sa quiapo na tila bawat sulok naka tingin sayo ang panginoon, para ka talagang sinasaksak ng liwanag. E wala kang magagawa, saan ba dapat humihingi ng tulong? Sa doctor na sasabihan kang mag sorry kay lord o kay manang na tiga benta ng abortion pills sa quiapo tas sobrang mahal pa? Ang hirap maging babae dito, yung nakabuntis nakakatakas at yung nabuntis kailangan maging mabuting ina kahit mag-isa na't lahat. Yung scene na nag uusap sila nina Miggy at tatay niya, arghh sorry pastor pero pakyu. Kadalasan sa totoong buhay, o sige nabuntis na nga buti papanagutan EH KASO anong kapalit? Bawal na mag-aral yung babae, yung pangarap na maging propesyonal wala na, dito na lang sa bahay tiga alaga hanggang magkaroon na sapot ng gagamba. Pag babae ang daming kailangang isakripisyo, pangarap ko o yung fetus na to e.Also want to point out how well written lahat ng side characters. Si Dr. Helena!! As someone who belongs sa healthcare forces, ang hirap kung yung sistema natin hindi sinusuportahan yung nga katulad nilang maagang nabuntis, lalo na mga below 13yrs old. Myghod naiyak talaga ako dun sa ateng nabuntis ng tito niya. Marami nakong nabasa na irl stories na kinukutya daw sa hospital mga ganyan. Yung lalaking doctor sa sunshine arghh isa pang pakyu. Bakit tatanggihan ang buhay ng isang biktima dahil lamang sinubukan nilang ipalaglag yung batang nabuo in an illegal way din? Puta doctor ka sa lagay na yan, bakit ko hahayaan mamatay parehas kung kaya ko naman buhayin yung isa? Dahil sa sistema na pumipigil sa atin at sa mga paniniwala na matagal na tayong binabalot. UGHH PAANO MAGIGING PROGRESIBO ANG HEALTHCARE SA PILIPINAS KUNG PURO NA LANG SOCIAL BIASES AT DISKRIMINASYON. Nag breakdown talga aq hays knowing na may mga kabatch din akong sobrang pikit sa problema ng lipunan, paano pa kaya kung nag tatrabaho na sila."Bakit di ka manghingi ng pera sa bf mo""Di ko yun bf, tito ko"Para sa mga biktima ng sexual abuse, isang mahigpit na yakap. With how little budget they had, I just find it astonishing with how much they made the most out of it.â¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸- great sound design! shoutout to the added rain sfx during that Sunshine + Geleen scene and the modified LRT sound during the motel scene- Challengers-esque score during one of the routines- motif of the close-ups on Sunshine's hands- same shot composition on the home and motel window while both showing the exterior and Sunshine inside- simple long static shot during the motel scene- they found a jeepney with a Gift of God signage in its rear- Menggay's pahabol na yakap before Sunshine looks for the bata- Sunshine's face in that Piolo Pascual scene- decision in not showing the real competition routine

â€œSunshineâ€ tackles urgent and relevant issues that are at the core of the current public health system in the Philippines. The film confronts the alarming rise in teenage pregnancies, a problem often worsen by a lack of sex education. It bravely addresses women's rights to choose, challenging the patriarchy that continues to influence societal norms in the country.The film's powerful message is that women have the right to be anything they want to be. They should have the final say over their bodies, their dreams, their choices, and their lives. No one should ever dictate who they are or what they can become. "Sunshine" makes a compelling case that a woman's decisions are her own, and outside opinions, particularly from men, are irrelevant. It is a story that empowers women, giving them a VOICE to be HEARD and a presence to be SEEN."Sunshine" is raw, relevant, and a catalyst for important conversations. It is not just a film; it is a reflection of the struggles faced by countless women. The movie fearlessly asks difficult questions and forces viewers to confront uncomfortable truths. It's a story that deserves to be discussed by everyone, because Sunshine is more than just a characterâ€”she is a symbol of HOPE and COURAGE. Maris Racal's portrayal of Sunshine is the best. She perfectly captures the reality of a woman's struggle and the immense difficulty of navigating life in this world. The supporting cast is equally remarkable. Jennica Garcia and Annika Co deliver powerful performances that are essential to the film's impact. Every cast in this film was remarkable.A big big thank you to Direk Tonet Jadaone for her bravery and boldness in telling this story. Your work is consistently admirable because you don't just make films; you spark meaningful conversations that resonate long after the credits roll.Hindi mahirap maging babae sa mundo kung sa umpisa pa lang ang BABAE ay merong sariling desisyon para sa sarili nila at di dinidiktahan ng kung sino man.

Everything is political when you're a woman! Our healthcare, our lives, our choices... It is all political...These are the reasons why I am a feminist. Filipino women deserve better healthcare!!! Filipino women deserve to have a choice!!! Filipino women are more than being mothersâ€” they are nurses, doctors, teachers, engineers, artists, gymnasts, and so much more. Kaya gustong gusto ko yung confrontation scene na iginiit ni Sunshine kayna Miggy na ayaw niyang maging nanay. WOMEN SHOULD BE ABLE TO MAKE THAT CHOICE FOR THEMSELVES.Living in a really conservative religious country is hell for women nga naman. We are bound to be shamed kahit anong gawin natin. Nakakaiyak na tinitiis na lang naming mga babae ang sistemang hindi naman ginawa para saamin. Kapag nabuntis, sasabihan na malandi. Kapag gustong magpalaglag, immoral. Kapag ayaw maging nanay, makasarili. Saan na lang kami lulugar sa bansang ito???? Kahit ang simpleng karapatan sa quality healthcare ipinagdadamot pa! Maraming salamat direk tonet sa paggawa ng napakagandang pelikula na to. From the cinematoraphy to the sounds to the script! Napakahusay. Yung shots don sa hotel scene and yung ingay ng LRT grabe i think that sums up the whole movie. Kuhang-kuha ang ingay at gulo ng Maynila. Ang Maynila na puno ng gulo at pangarap. I love how depicted sa movie na kahit sa kabila ng kaguluhan meron pa ring nabubuhay para sa kanilang mga pangarap dahil 'yon lamang ang meron sila. Nakakaiyak. Ang ganda talaga. Pangarap ko ang pangarap mo, Sunshine.

hindi ko inakalang may darating na pelikulang hahawak sa isyu ng aborsyon nang ganito kaaga â€” at ganito katapat. walang paligoy, walang takot. hindi lang ito basta kwento. isa itong matapang na salamin ng realidad na matagal nang pinipiling hindi pag-usapan.mula sa bawat linya hanggang sa katahimikan, ramdam ang puso at paninindigan. ang husay mo, direk tonet. malinaw ang direksyon, matalas ang intensyon.at si maris racal, siya ang tamang sunshine. kinarga niya ang bigat ng papel at binuhay ito nang may tapang, lalim, at dignidad.isang pelikulang hindi lang dapat mapanood dahil maganda ito kundi dahil mahalaga ang mensaheng dala nito.sa ibang buhay, ayoko sanang maging babae. pero ngayon, gusto ko nang baguhin 'yon. at sa susunod na habang-buhay, nawaâ€™y maging babae akong may ganap na karapatan sa sarili kong katawan.dahil sa bansang ito, ang hirap mangarap kapag paulit-ulit kang inaalisan ng kapangyarihan sa sarili mong pagkatao.

overheard a girl in the restroom saying â€œat least mabait si [yung character] pioloâ€ and maybe thats what makes this film effective and horrifying. patriarchalism masks itself in kindness, in family values, religious salvation, in medicine, in the thought of care. we are so deeply entangled in its edifice we cannot decipher care from control. against the backdrop of the sticky, restless, and noisy streets of manila, Sunshine becomes a suffocating experience. a formidable display of how patriarchy is insidious. even the reactions of the women around sunshine are outcomes of its thinking, sometimes its intentional, sometimes unaware. the judgement and unsolicited advice are concealed as concern and even sunshine herself isnâ€™t free from it. it is literally manifested as an imaginary child that echoes her guilt, pressure, and the moral burden thats placed upon her. There are moments where its subtexts are parallel to Ernauxâ€™s memoir Happening, which is visceral in its honesty about seeking abortion in 60s France, a time where it was illegal there. But Sunshine is dangerously current. Abortion remains illegal in the country because religion and patriarchy is deeply etched that it is indistinguishable from moral law (yet pamparegla pills in quiapo sit on the same shelves as statues of the infant jesus and still our agency must somehow exist in conflict with holiness.) in the final act, Sunshineâ€™s choice is physically expressed through a routine. her movements make it seem her body is being wrapped in ribbons, constricted and suffocating, but as she continues, the bindings are loosened and ultimately released. the filmâ€™s profundity lies in its portrayal of abortion not as something easy nor devoid of consequences. it is contradicting: physically and emotionally excruciating but undeniably life saving.

I cried three times while watching Sunshine, and I cried the hardest during this particular scene. Itâ€™s when Pastor Jaime and Miggy visit Sunshineâ€™s house to discuss her future. Instead of asking how Sunshine is feeling in that moment, Pastor Jaime immediately begins outlining plans like offering maternal and healthcare coverage for her and the baby, and even proposing an educational fund up to college for the child.This scene highlights another tragedy that women face in a patriarchal society.â€¦

she fought tooth and nail for her dream, yung buong journey nya parang pagpasok sa butas ng karayom â€” gets na gets ko. there's two specific scenes in this that i find so horrifying. is there really no hope for women? etong tanong lang to nasa isip ko in every fucken thing she had to endure. sunshine's own manifestation of her inner child as her conscience was an interesting part of the movie. sobrang devastating nung scene sa simula ng movie na nilalayuan nya yung batang version nya; i think the person i would fear to face now is also the child that i once was. i had a thought before that everyone on earth was once a child, and not many people can afford to continue being one. the scenes with the children in this movie breaks my heart. yung 'fetus' pinangakuan ng magandang kinabukasan pero yung mga ganap na bata na sa movie ay mga biktima. while waiting for our rides home, my friend and i kept thinking how a lot of people are going to misconstrue the point of this movie. im nervous na baka gawin tong movie na to as a cautionary tale about abortion imbis na maging enlightenment on how the system fails us in every fucken way of our being. but i love to think that, like her name, the sun will shine. the light will pass through the darkness. the final scene with her inner child was so important to me. gets ko na. sana magets nyo rin.

Sunshine is an important filmâ€”one that Filipinos shouldnâ€™t miss. Itâ€™s not the strongest film, but itâ€™s certainly worth discussing.In fact, it currently tops my list of Filipino movies this year. And thatâ€™s precisely why I feel a sense of disappointment. At the very least, I wish it had resonated more deeply. It had the potential to delve further into its realism, but instead, it chose to spoon-feed every emotional beat, leaving little room for quiet reflection. While I understand why Jadaone took this direction, I canâ€™t say it worked for me.Personally, I wasnâ€™t fully sold on the use of children as a narrative device. The way the film delivers its message too overtly makes the subplot involving the 13-year-old feel disconnected and distracting. The child character might have been more effective as a symbolic presence, her inner voice, her conscience. Had it stayed that way, rather than taking the more problematic route of literally giving life to unborn children, as in Arianaâ€™s case, the film might have delivered a far more powerful impact.Still, there was a moment near the end, a line that marked a turning point of understanding and acceptance, where freedom was finally felt from guilt. That scene alone earned the film a 9 out of 10 from me.

Sunshine is definitely a must-watch. More than just the brilliant performances, especially by Maris, who portrayed her role with such raw honesty, the film strikes deep because of the story it tells. It dares to talk about what many still shy away from: the state of our healthcare system, the stigma around reproductive rights, and how these deeply affect the lives of women every day. It powerfully shows how abortion is healthcare, and how denying safe, legal options doesnâ€™t stopâ€¦

The OB admitting section was, and still is, one of the busiest parts of the hospital I worked in as an intern. It had been renovated prior to my first duty there, and it would be renovated once again after I'd left. Both of those renovations were done in part to address a persistent issue: that the place never runs out of patients. Every day, and especially on Mondays and Fridays, the admitting section would take in a significant number of expectant mothers with all sorts of conditions. Some would be giving birth for the first time. Some were veterans who were familiar to the staff working there, giving birth like clockwork every year. Some had serious conditions alongside their pregnancies that made giving birth extremely complicated, to the point where their current state posed a significant risk for death while giving birth. Nevertheless, they would slowly fill up the adjacent labor and delivery room, often two to three mothers to a stretcher. On very busy days the stretchers would run out, and the labor room would be filled with mothers settling down wherever they could, mostly on the cold, tiled floor.I remembered those days in the admitting section when I saw Antoinette Jadaone's latest film, Sunshine, about a young gymnast (Maris Racal) who gets pregnant right before a very important event that might lead to the SEA games and eventually the Olympics. Sunshine doesn't have any qualms about making the decision as she immediately gets to work trying to find an abortifacient to terminate the unwanted pregnancy. This process is not made easy. Miggy (Elijah Canlas), the man who impregnated Sunshine, wants nothing to do with her after learning of her pregnancy. He doesn't even tell her to have an abortion directly, only saying that 'she knows what to do.' Getting medical help is equally difficult, and intersects gender with class: medical treatment is expensive (despite the fact that state sponsored healthcare should be financially accessible) and as abortion is still illegal in the Philippines, people resort to black markets to seek the care they need.Once in a while, the OB admitting section will receive a patient who has lost her child. Miscarriages are common, and often they are spontaneous. Once, a mother of a stillborn child asked me if the cries in the next room were her child's, when I knew the infant was lying in a box, ready to be given to back to their parents. Then there are the other kinds of patients, ones who made a choice like Sunshine. They all had their reasons; this was a conscious and informed decision. After a while you know it when they come in. Sometimes the doctor would come in and tell them that what they did was illegal, some would even threaten to call the police. Nothing ever came of it; they were empty threats - often to 'scare' them into not making that decision again. It always made me uncomfortable.To be born a woman is to be born into violence, into a world where the odds are stacked against you. Sunshine is not the first film to depict this violence - films like Rae Red's Babae at Baril (2019) and Jadaone's own Fan Girl (2020) are two examples. They show what a deeply patriarchal society creates: people like Miggy and a certain other character near the end, people who I interpreted as not exactly archetypal or allegorical towards the structures that created them, but as the inevitable products of it. But unlike those two films that I mentioned earlier, Sunshine feels far more indignant, full of anger that Fan Girl lacked, and drawing towards a different conclusion compared to Babae at Baril.Quiapo has been a backdrop for many a Filipino film, and here it is a sanctuary of sorts. It is here where Sunshine goes to find the solution to her problems. Ironically draped in religious imagery, it both embodies the faith it represents (as a source of refuge for those who are in need) and as something that stands against its tenets.Sunshine is a film about choices: the choice to live one's own dream, the choice to live freely as the best person you can be. Sunshine's sister Geleen (Jennica Garcia) coaches Sunshine as she practices in their shared home. Certain background elements (thanks to the film's excellent production design) hint that Geleen, too, was once an aspiring gymnast, whose dreams ended with a baby. If she had the choice, would she have lived a different life? It shows as well in Geleen's character, and Garcia gives a standout performance as her.Finally, that idea of "refuge" may not refer to Quiapo, but something else entirely. Throughout the film there are many people, both seen and unseen, who help Sunshine in her quest. "Ipagdadasal ko kayo," a hilot tells Sunshine after they bring a child to the hospital who made the same choice. "Mag-ingat ka," another one tells Sunshine as she sets off. A sympathetic medical professional gives a knowing look. Every doctor has a story like it: in one of my last rotations at the labor room, a patient walked in nervously in the robe the hospital supplied her. It was a very busy day, and pregnant women overflowed on the stretchers and sat on the floor. She had no business being here: she looked no older than 14, and she should be going to school and playing with friends, not in the last stages of giving birth. Suffice it to say, this pregnancy was not her choice. If she had the choice like Sunshine did, would she be here? On the other hand, the point of the film for me is not whether one makes one choice over the other, but that people like Sunshine and that kid has the ability to choose in the first place.Because the labor and delivery room should be semi-sterile, companions (in this case, the kid's very worried mother) are not allowed in. But the rest of the mothers in that labor room heard us taking the medical history and heard her story. The other expectant mothers gave the kid their blankets, talked to and comforted her, up until she gave birth. Everyone was that kid's mother that day. In a world where you are denied agency, where one is subjected to violence from birth, the least women can do is find refuge in each other.

Maris and the rest of the cast were perfectly chosen for the film, with each character making a meaningful contribution to the plot. Maliban sa acting and galing galing din ni maris sa mismong mga gymnast performances niya!!To be honest, I initially found Sunshine disturbing and lacking in many parts. It felt like the film held back, especially in its screenplay and pacing. But as I reflected more on it, I realized that might have been the pointâ€”although many of the scenes were commendably filmed, the film wasnâ€™t trying to entertain; it was trying to confront. Maliban sa mismong tema ng storya, sobrang daming iba pang paghihirap na danas ng lipunan natin na mismo ako ay hindi aware ang naipakita sa pelikula.The rawness and silence I initially perceived as weaknesses were actually reflections of Sunshine herselfâ€”caught between the pressures of gymnastics and the weight of her misfortunes. In that light, I came to see that her quietness was powerful and already served as the message.The film was created not just to tell Sunshineâ€™s story, but to help us recognize the many "Sunshines" around usâ€”especially in the Philippines, where abortion remains heavily stigmatized due to political control and religious conservatism. Sunshine challenges us to understand their pain and see their urgent need for help.I truly hope that someday, those in power will recognize that safe and legal abortion is not just a debateâ€”itâ€™s a right every Filipina deserves to have.

Sunshine fue una experiencia bastante sorprendente dentro del contexto del cine mainstream filipino moderno. SaliÃ©ndose del margen seguro y cÃ³modo que tiene acostumbradas a las masas a la complacencia social retratada en un romanticismo casi cÃ­nico de la pobreza y la glorificaciÃ³n del poder y la influencia, ademÃ¡s de la necesidad por rectitud religiosa. La cinta, desarrollÃ¡ndose sin teatralidad ni grandes despliegues telenoveleros de drama, entiende perfectamente que la sobriedad y sequedad de la realidad filipina de la clase baja no necesita endulzantes para trabajar de manera efectiva y cortante en pantalla. La cinematografÃ­a es excelente, el ritmo es perfecto y las tomas se toman todo el tiempo necesario para declarar visualmente sus ideas, ademÃ¡s de que la direcciÃ³n si bien denota algunos rastros y pequeÃ±os momentos de la desconexiÃ³n farandulera moderna del voyerismo cÃ­nico que nos fuerza a sentir lastima por la pobreza, no cae totalmente en ello, demostrando mucha fuerza y entendimiento la gran parte del tiempo.

sunshine explored important and sensitive topics that are not only necessary for filipino audience to see but also essential to open dialogues and conversations, to shed light on and ultimately to spark change especially on things that are often labeled as taboo in a conservative and retrogressive country like the philippines.the film does not impose, it only depicts the struggles of the character. it shows her grit, resilience and her power to decide for herself. sunshine is a beautiful portrayal of a womanâ€™s ability to choose and her autonomy to determine her fate. despite the living ironies sheâ€™s confronted with, she remains hopeful, that she could still follow her dreams and that she could rule over her life against all odds. she doesnâ€™t have to conform. no one else could dictate how her story goes but her.sunshine does not necessarily promote pre-marital sex or abortion. it goes beyond issues of healthcare and reproductive health. it advocates empathy and compassion to the sunshines of the world. it allows us to understand the complexities and the silent pains and plights women go through and why thereâ€™s a need for them to have access to safe and equitable options.

sunshine isn't just a film, it's a mirror held up to every system that tells women to endure and accept. from the very first scene, i was already scared for sunshine, i felt her fear, her desperation, her quiet panic, and the film forces u to sit with it.the film hits hard on a truth that shouldn't even be up for debate, sa traditional at conservative country na tulad ng atin, it has always been easier for men. and yet, men should have absolutely no say over women's bodies.sunshine also dismantles the idea that motherhood is the default setting for womanhood. it's not. it has to be a choice, our choice.and sex? it's human and natural. pretending otherwise only creates more situations like sunshine's, where women are forced into situation without access to safe, comprehensive healthcare.this isn't just a movie you watch. it's a movie that makes you remember why we fight, because the sunshines of the world are real, and they deserve better.

set the scene. modern-day manila, a city equally bound by the abundance of opportunity as it is bound by the abundance of consequence. sunshine is a dreamer tied to the goal of becoming an olympian. she is told to drown out the noise while she lives a life enclosed by it. she gets pregnant by a good for nothing conyo elijah canlas and is told that her poverty-stricken ass should carry the burden of aborting the baby. and of all places, she finds herself in quiapo, manilaâ€™s catholic landmark, praying to Jesus as she repeatedly journeys through the downtown in her search for the most effective pills while surrounded by statues of Mary, her conscience carrying the loudest whispers that deem her a murderer, echoed by the church she sought forgiveness inâ€”and the very God she prays to.there exists an assumption about the matriarchal philippines, a country that holds its female sensibilities to the highest regard in the same way it adores Mary. yet as we are exposed to our societyâ€™s deepest cancers, the mask of matriarchy only rings true for as long as it submits to the role of patriarchy and as a result, we are a nation of contradictions because of this reality. only in the philippines you can see a catholic girl pocketing abortion pills in a church. sunshine is no Mary, and manila is no matriarchy. her conscience rides through a push and pull with the conservative ideals she was brought upon. her best friend briefly ditches her out of familial pressure. her exâ€™s family (hi papa p) barges in their house to own up to the mistake. sunshineâ€™s life is filled to the brim with contradiction. in spite of this, even with her lack of maturity and the ever-so demanding backdrop of a patriarchal manila, there remains glimmers of hope, her own thriving matriarchy within the small space she can truly call her own. an environment not bound by fluctuating contradiction, but by the permanence of choice.
Generational performance from Maris Racal, beyond proud to have her and this film representing our country on the world stage!

this movie makes sense. beyond tackling the issues of abortion in the philippines, we see how this lack of choice affects each filipino's morality. we see individuals who are shaped into believing that personal decisions should be rooted from what is lawful and religiously accepted. we never really considered what's best for me beyond laws and beliefs?sunshine is an awakening not just to the affected, but also to those who have power to protect these women and change the narrative towards abortion.we have long been fighting for a safer option, as well as a society that accepts this option.the more we keep safer abortions inaccessible, the more we endanger the lives of those who need it.

recently read the translation of farrokhzadâ€™s review/justification for golestanâ€™s the brick and the mirror where she said the film is a movement in a stagnant environment which should be in motion. i think that also applies to sunshine. philippine cinema (and even jadaone herself) has a tendency of producing movies that expand the capital. after all, you only get to have a second movie if your first one is profitable enough. from a moral perspective, sunshine is a dare to move something in philippine cinema. itâ€™s not the first stroke, of course, and not the boldest either, but this film occupying the same space that other safe bet family dramas and love team romcom is a shift we rarely see these days. itâ€™s a small ripple but it keeps the momentum (or at least rattle the conscience) in an environment that refuses to progress with time. i wish it was bolder, but it is angry, at least.

wait uwi muna q sa bahayedit: pinanood ko yung film nung august 2 ngayon lang ako maglalagay ng review wowang laban ni sunshine ay laban ng mga kababaihan.grabe, it feels surreal na makita yung totoong buhay quiapo sa sinehan lalo na when you also lived that in real life. tuwing nadadaan ako ng quiapo tuwing papauwi galing ng pup, andami kong nadadaanang nagbebenta ng herbal na pamparegla, sa panonood ng sunshine ko na narealize na itong mga tao pala na 'to na nasa bangketa ay iyong nakakasaksi sa pinaka-totoo at pinaka-vulnerable na estado ng iilang babae sa atin â€” kumbaga, ang dami nilang kwento, ang dami nilang danas, at higit sa lahat, sila iyong nakakaintindi sa nararamdaman ng mga babaeng lumalapit sa kanila, sila iyong walang pangmamata.sana katulad ng mga nagbebenta ng mga pamparegla sa quiapo, maintindihan din ng ibang tao na ang abortion ay hindi isang kasalanan, hindi isang taboo topic, at hindi isang desisyon na nakasalalay sa iba ang sagot. siguro kung binubuksan lang yung mga diskusyon na katulad nito sa mainstream media, mas lalawak pa yung kaalaman ng mga tao sa abortion at women's rights, pero dahil nga kristiyano at patriyarkal na bansa ang pilipinas, wala tayong napapala. nanatiling mangmang ang karamihan ng mga pilipino rito dahil hindi binibigyan ng pagkakataon na mapag-aralan at malaman ito.singit ko lang din yung role na ginampanan ni annika rito, SOBRANG GALING???? like how could you expect that performance from a novice child actress who's not even fluent in filipino tapos gaganap sa isang pelikula na sobrang pinoy??? sobrang galing lang ni annika at nag-iisang batang aktres na nakapag-paiyak sa akin dahil lang sa isang linya niya. THE 'GETS KO NA' SCENEEE FUCCCCKKK ANG LUHA KOOOHH :(( and its even more beautiful kasi that also reflects to annika in real life because she fully understood the role she played in the film :( na para bang mas open-minded pa siya sa karamihan ng mga matatanda sa atin. sobrang dami kong luhang binuhos sa sunshine at sobrang dami ko ring natutunan. sobrang raw at sobrang vulnerable â€” kinda ironic pero ayun yung naging strength ng pelikulang ito. mahal na mahal ko mga likha ni direk tonet. grabe. one of the best directors of her time. "Ang pangarap ko ay pangarap niya." This line, spoken by the child, sums up the entire film. Itâ€™s simple, heartfelt, and my favorite line. People may have their own interpretations, but this is how I personally understood it.Sunshine has an older sister, Ate Geleen, played by Jennica Garcia. Ate Geleen was once a gymnast, just like Sunshine. But now, she takes care of her child. The film doesnâ€™t say it outright, but itâ€™s clear that Ate Geleen gave up her dreams and career to raise her baby. Why did she give it all up? We don't know. But maybe itâ€™s because sheâ€™s the eldest daughter â€” the one expected to take care of her siblings, the one who is supposed to work harder, sacrifice more, and carry the heaviest weight.Mahirap maging babae, lalo na kung ikaw ang panganay na anak ng pamilya.Maybe thatâ€™s also the very reason why sheâ€™s so supportive of Sunshineâ€™s decision â€” to have an abortion, to chase her dreams, and to not follow in her footsteps. Ate Geleen knows exactly what itâ€™s like to give up everything, and she doesnâ€™t want her younger sister to carry the same burden she did.The movie ended with Ate Geleen proudly looking at Sunshine while holding her baby. Dahil ang pangarap ni Sunshine ay siya ring pangarap ni Ate Geleen na hindi niya natupad.

Natawa ako sa simula. Like I love how Sunshine visited QUIAPO Church first, then went to Miggy's school ALL THE WAY in DEL MONTE AVE, QUEZON CITY (Sha Tin in the background and I recognize Miggy's school), smashed his car in his school's parking spot, then ran TO RECTO AVE, MANILA to avoid being caught ğŸ˜­ğŸ˜­ğŸ˜­ Never skipped leg day si Sunshine.On a serious note, I love how it is way much more than a pro-choice/pro-abortion movie. It champions compassion and understanding first through the many hardships that pregnancy poses in a country where abortion is very much illegal. It's uncomfortable at times, heartbreaking at others, but in spite of the pain and desperation, it's also empathetic at times too, like with Thea and Sunshine's siblings. Love her sister especially.The only reason why I gave it a 4.5 stars is because there are some... SOME moments where nabitin ako, like I wish the runtime could be a little longer so we could flesh out some aspects of the film, like Doc Helena, Migs and his dad, and the ending, to name some.Overall, I'm SOO GLAD I saw this film. God PH do the smart move and PLEASE submit this for best international feature at the Oscars.

Sunshine was an entity of her own. As consistent as the celestial body her name was derived from, she was stern on her decision up until the end of the film. The rawness of the film venturing into the the "sketchy" streets of Quiapo, digs into shady transactions covered under the mountains of skyways clouded with ignorance over what minorities have to deal with. How does our devotion and concept of purity outweigh the dangers underlying in pregnancy or becoming a mother when one isn't ready to give everything up for a child they bore out of guilt? Or is this just something they choose to turn a blind eye to when the higher-ups knowingly have put women's lives in the gravest situations yet again?Releasing this film in the midst of a conservative country was a bold critique of the proper healthcare we're deprived of, but it was also a cry from all women who deserve better.
This movie is a great critique on the status of abortion in the Philippines. I love it.

let me just say na MARIS RACAL IS SUCH AN AMAZING ACTRESS. totoong haggard nga siya (lol), pero â€˜yung haggardness niya, that actually added to everything. you can see the pain, the exhaustion, and the heaviness in every sceneâ€”it all felt so real.. grabe, nakakamangha talaga siyang panoorin. sobrang husay niya, and because of that, sunshine didnâ€™t feel like a film at allâ€”it felt like someone letting you into her world. it felt like sunshine was sitting beside me, telling her story, and all i could do was listen and feel everything.from the very beginning, klaro na kay sunshine kung ano ang gusto niya. hindi ang maging nanay, kundi ang makasali sa Philippines' national gymnastics team. but the world she lives in kept pushing her into a corner. this film tackled more than just abortionâ€”it exposed how cruel the system is to women, lalo na sa pilipinas. it showed the weight of religious beliefs forced onto our bodies, the cycle of abuse, and the daily injustices women face just for existing. napakahirap maging babae sa pilipinas tangina.lahat ng lalaki sa pelikulaâ€”si miggy, 'yung tito ni menggay, si tatay ni miggy, pati â€˜yung doktorâ€”lahat sila, galit na galit ako. bakit babae lagi ang kailangang mag-sakripisyo? bakit babae ang kailangang mag-adjust, magpatawad, magtiis? putangina talaga. and yet, these characters werenâ€™t exaggerated. they were too real. which makes it even more terrifyingâ€”kasi alam nating totoo â€˜to. it happens. itâ€™s still happening.what haunted me most were menggayâ€™s scenes. dun talaga ako tuluyang naiyak. ang sakit sakit. gusto ko siyang yakapin, gusto ko siyang ipagtanggol. bata pa lang siya pero pasan na niya 'yung bigat ng mundong hindi naman niya kasalanan. sana sa lahat ng menggay, may sunshine sa buhay nila. and then there was anikka. nung una, akala ko multo siya o guni-guni lang. pero habang tumatagal, i realizedâ€”she was sunshineâ€™s imaginary child. or maybe her younger self. or both. she represents so much: a lost dream, a piece of sunshine. kaya â€˜yung eksena sa dulo, when anikka said â€œgets ko na,â€ it wasnâ€™t just her talkingâ€”it was also sunshine finally accepting her own decision. grabe â€˜yung iyak ko dun. that should be enough. a womanâ€™s choice should be enough.the film also showed that women, at our best, are each otherâ€™s safe space. si coach, si doktora, yung kaibigan, most especially â€˜yung ate niyaâ€”lahat sila, may dalang simpatya. yung presence nila nagsasabing â€œnandito ako.â€ yung scene na tumabi yung ate niya sa higaan sobrang nakakalungkot panoorin. it reminded me that the first place we should feel supported is at home. buti na lang at nandiyan ang ate ni sunshine dahil minsan sapat na â€˜yung maramdaman mong hindi ka nag-iisasunshine isnâ€™t just a movie. itâ€™s a wake-up call. it asks us to reflectâ€”bakit tayo mabilis humusga? bakit kulang ang pag-unawa? and most of all, bakit kailangang maging matatag ang babae para lang mabuhay nang payapa? sunshine is a beautiful, heartbreaking, and necessary film. hindi lang siya basta panoorin. kailangan mo siyang damdamin. hindi ka niya pipilitin, pero hahayaan ka niyang mag-reflect, in your own time and your own way.huge congratulations to everyone who worked on this film. sana mas maraming makapanood. sana mas maraming makaintindi

Sunshine, gets ta kaw. Gets ta kaw kun nanga gihimo mo yadto. Dili kay tungod may imo pangarap, pero di pa kaw ready ma nanay. Gets ta kaw nanga imo unahon imo kaugalingon maski an lain tao lain na an panan-aw sa imo. Gets ta kaw na normal da makig iyot, normal da ma curious, tanan sa kita bagan diba? Gets ta kaw kun uno kakusog an mga boses sa imo palibot, di mo na madunggan unoy imo dapat himoon. Di kaw maraot na batasan, Shine, na giuna mo imo kaugalingon. Dapat sa gayud unahon kaw adiser an bata na wa pa gani maanak. Ako sab, Shine. Galibog ako nanga amda gihimo nila na maraot imo batasan, na amda yakasa na kaw sa tanan tao. Kay tungod ba kay yagpabuntis kaw nan sayo? Kay di mo mapanindigan an mga sumusunod na mga consequence? Kay di nimo kaya magbuhi nan bata? Ako sab, Shine. Galibog ako. Di sa nimo sala kun ga try kaw. Sala sa ini nila nanga wa kaw tudlui daan. Nanga ipasa sa an sala sa mga gada nan bata? Kay dili baya kinabuhi isab an mga gada nan bata? Nanga mas concerned pa sila sa bata, na ikaw Shine, gaginhawa na kaw, gapanaw na kaw.Sorry, Shine, kun damo gihapun an dili abri an utok para makipag diskorso sa ini na issue. Sorry, Shine, na amda implikar da nila na an mga babae, tigkarga da nan bata, an mga laki, tig buntis da. Pero Shine, proud ako sa imo. Na imo gipadayun kun unoy imo gusto. Na imo gipanindigan an imo desisyon â€” maski lisod, maski an mga tao dili ganahan sa imo, maski hapit na kaw mabuang. Panduha dakan siguro an gold sa SEA Games, kay an tinuod na kadaogan, nan imo gipakita na an mga babae, dili da sila mga tao-tao sa kalibutan. May ila papel, may ila pangarap, og may ila isip na makadesidar kun unoy ila himuon sa ila mga lawas. Continue to shine, Sunshine.

gets ko naSo many still donâ€™t understand, but itâ€™s enough that some do.This film is braveâ€”fearlessly made, carefully thought out, and clearly crafted from the heart.When I watched it, all I wanted to do was hold Sunshineâ€”hold every Sunshine out there who I know is carrying the weight of this harsh, terrifying society.I still canâ€™t get over the fact that this was shown in Philippine cinemas because, finally, it got the visibility it truly deserves. This is the kind of film the world should see. When I finished watching it, I already knew the state and how our society would portray abortion and how it was always deemed evil and inhumane but after seeing this film, I felt a sense of relief that finally, a film about women, about abortion, about its effects, not just mentally but physically, and how sometimes, we really just have to understand, for who are we to judge someone who really is just fighting to live through and view women in a way that they should be, respected.Even the supporting charactersâ€”especially Jennica Garciaâ€”were brilliant. I felt her love for her sister so deeply. Even when Sunshine thought the world had turned its back on her, her sisterâ€™s presence was a constant reminder that someone was still there, always beside her, fully aware of the struggles she facedâ€”struggles made heavier because sheâ€™s a woman.Also a huge role that was portrayed by Rhed Bustamante. Just, wow. It was a story meant to be told and written. It isn't just fiction it's currently happening today and that's why it should be a story that needed to be shed light on. It was tragic, painful to look at but it was real, all of it, and that's what makes it a story worth telling.And Maris Racalâ€”what a phenomenal actress. Her cries pierce right through you. Her frustration, her courage, her strength as a womanâ€”all of it shines through. In Sunshine, I saw her desperation, her bravery, her womanhood, and her relentless grasp on her dreams, refusing to let them slip away.Maris and Direk Tonet knew exactly what they wanted to tell their audience, and Iâ€™m so glad they did it with such courage. They gave voice to women like Sunshineâ€”women who are still too afraid to scream their truths.I hope this film becomes a beacon for people like Sunshine, the way she brings life to every twirl of her ribbon and every movement of her body to the rhythm. There are so many like her still hidden in the shadows of fear and guilt. And yes, we all know that in the Philippines, some mindsets are hard to changeâ€”but does it have to stop there? Will we allow people like Sunshine to remain caged by a judgmental society?Maybe for now, itâ€™s hard. But because of this film, women like Sunshine can finally catch a glimpse of hope.:â€™)

Honestly, 3.5 stars for the movie overall, but here's extra 0.5 star for the super random cameo that was also somehow super on the nose. It's such a good bit that amuses me to no end. I'd rate the movie higher if not for a plot device that felt completely unnecessary and at times distracting. Take it away, and it won't even change anything about the movie. Every time they employed this plot device, it was just so unnecessary and distracting. The movie also squeezed in too many "unwanted pregnancy" tropes that it risked being too bloated story-wise. Think of an "unwanted pregancy" trope, it's there. They stop short of it being too bloated at the expense of the story (and you have to give it to Antoinette Jadaone for this balancing act), though I still spent a good chunk of the movie wondering how many more tropes were coming. Still the movie is brave, and is made so much better for its bravery. It does not shy away from the realities faced by so many women in this country when it comes to maternal health. It tackled head-on the heavily religious overtones that tends to dominate the conversations around this topic. It shows the ironic juxtaposition of abortion pills being sold next to religious artifacts. But most importantly, it does not get preachy. It does not feel like it is patronizing the audience about what should be in each scene that squeezes your heart, it just shows it. But also Jennica Garcia steals the show in every scene is in. Maris Racal deserves the accolades she's getting for carrying the movie so steadily as its lead and with everything asked of her for the character. But Jennica Garcia just commands every scene even she doesn't say a word. And every scene these two have together was really gold-medal worthy.
